fields.trailText: LAMP'S A £10m GOER
fields.body:
LAMP'S A £10m GOER

David O'Leary has lined-up a £10m summer reunion for Frank Lampard and Rio Ferdinand. West Ham have blown £10m of their Ferdinand money on five new stars - now the board want cash for a new East Stand. Leeds will have a clearout to raise the money.

PURSE: 'NEW ADAMS' Arsenal are lining-up Birmingham's Darren Purse as Tony Adams's successor: Arséne Wenger is ready to spend £4.5m, making Purse his first English signing in his past 16 deals.

Arsenal have sent scouts to check on Blackburn's U21 midfielder David Dunn.  Aston Villa are prepared to sell Richard Walker to Blackpool: 'There's no point in me going back to Villa,' says Walker. 'I'm happy here.'  Bradford are chasing Belgian striker Joris Van Hout: 'Bradford, Derby, Wimbledon and Coventry are watching,' says Mechelen.  Charlton are planning a free transfer deal for Everton flop Stephen Hughes.  Chelsea's Sam Dalla Bona says his dream is to play for Juventus. Claudio Ranieri, meanwhile, wants Barcelona defender Michael Reiziger.  Coventry scouts have been checking on Dutch pair Rafael van der Caart and Arjen Robben - West Ham and Newcastle are also keen.  Jim Smith says he'll stay at Derby next season: 'I've a year left on my contract and I'll fulfil it.'  Everton are open to offers for Francis Jeffers, while AGF Aarhus want right-back Peter Degn.  Ipswich have tied up James Scowcroft on a new three-year deal.  Leeds are eyeing-up 1860 Munich's Austrian starlet Martin Stranzl.  Leicester have handed Simon Royce a new contract.  Liverpool defender Christian Ziege could make a shock return to Middlesbrough - but Bryan Robson says 'it's just speculation'. Gerard Houllier, meanwhile, wants Bari's Daniel Andersson.  Joe Royle says he's 'philosophical' about the chances of losing his Man City job: 'I trust the chairman implicitly.'  Ryan Giggs says Man United should spend big: 'We need a new spark.'  Middlesbrough say Terry Venables won't quit for Valencia.  Newcastle are set to make a big summer bid for Forest starlet David Prutton.  Southampton have denied receiving an £8m bid from Newcastle for Marian Pahars.  Sunderland boss Peter Reid says his three big summer signings will win him the Premiership.  Steffen Iversen says Spurs must qualify for Europe: 'We're good enough.'  West Ham are ready to bid for Valencia's Leon Gerardo - Harry Redknapp also fancies Georgian Alexander Rekhviashvili.

webTitle: Holt puts Hull over the top

fields.headline: Holt puts Hull over the top
fields.trailText: The Humber derby may not have the same resonance as, say, Tottenham versus Arsenal, but with both Hull and Scunthorpe in promotion contention, the capacity crowd here were every bit as passionate as those at Old Trafford will be today.
fields.body:
The Humber derby may not have the same resonance as, say, Tottenham versus Arsenal, but with both Hull and Scunthorpe in promotion contention, the capacity crowd here were every bit as passionate as those at Old Trafford will be today.

Hull's off-the-field prob lems have been well-documented and continue to linger. Plans have advanced for a new stadium but chairman Adam Pearson has threatened that the club will leave their present home early if the ground's owner, the despised David Lloyd, continues to raise rental charges during negotiations.

The crisis has had the effect of turning Boothferry Park into something of a fortress. Before this match Hull had won six consecutive times here, though Scunthorpe had more reason than most teams to feel optimistic about their visit. It was here two years ago this month that they won 3-2 on their way to earning promotion via the play-offs.

But under Brian Little, Hull are a tougher proposition than they were then, when they were fighting against relegation. Nevertheless, it was appropriate that Jon Whitney, one of only two survivors from Hull's side that day, should put them ahead in the 28th minute. He jumped highest in a crowded penalty area to meet Andy Holt's corner and see his header bounce in off the underside of the bar.

Whitney played a part in helping Scunthorpe equalise 13 minutes later when he gave away a free-kick on the edge of the penalty area which Andrew Dawson, another of those who played that day, clipped over the Hull wall and beyond keeper Paul Musselwhite.

That both sides went into the match chasing a play-off spot and separated only by goal difference gave it an added edge and made it one of the most important ever staged between these sides.

Having had to deal with serious disturbances before the match, the police's task was hardly made any easier by the controversial incidents on which the match turned.

Hull were furious to be awarded a free-kick instead of a penalty in the 64th minute, after John Eyre was wrestled to the ground by Mark Jackson, only for Scunthorpe to feel aggrieved when the referee showed their man the red card. Any anger Hull felt then dissipated when Andy Holt powered the free-kick through the wall and into the net.

Scunthorpe were thrown a most unexpected lifeline in the 79th minute when the referee did award a penalty after he spotted Jon Whitney pulling Steve Torpey, only for Lee Hodges to waste the opportunity by striking his effort against the post. It all added to the growing feeling here that promotion is Hull's destiny.

webTitle: Rangers relief as Rovers spare their bottom blushes

fields.headline: Rangers relief as Rovers spare their bottom blushes
fields.trailText: QPR, having gone into administration last week with debts of £11 million, had Grimsby's Luke Cornwall to thank for avoiding the additional blow of landing at the bottom of the First Division yesterday.
fields.body:
QPR, having gone into administration last week with debts of £11 million, had Grimsby's Luke Cornwall to thank for avoiding the additional blow of landing at the bottom of the First Division yesterday.

While they slumped to a 3-1 home defeat against Blackburn, Tranmere's hopes of vacating the bottom spot were destroyed at Blundell Park by two Cornwall goals in the space of six minutes. Tranmere, who had gone ahead through Jason Koumas, their best player, eventually crashed 3-1. Cornwall's goals in the 65th and 70th minutes were followed by one from Steve Livingstone shortly afterwards.

In a match full of bruising physical contact, QPR were also ahead at one stage, through a header by Chris Plummer. But that was the point at which Blackburn found the sharpness which had been lacking in their play. David Dunn brought them level, and he created the chance from which Matt Jansen put them ahead in the last minute of the first half. Any QPR hopes of getting back into the game were destroyed by Eyal Berkovic's goal, his first for the club.

Of the other struggling teams, Huddersfield and Stockport both collected maximum points at the expense of Wolves and Sheffield Wednesday, while Crystal Palace drew 2-2 at Watford.

Watford's manager, Graham Taylor, who recently announced that he will retire at the end of the season, insisted that he will not change his mind. He added: 'When I returned to the club in 1996, I gave myself five years to get us back to the level I felt we should be at and that has been achieved.'

However, on the evidence of their home form, Taylor's dreams of drawing down the curtain on his career with promotion do seem unrealistic.

Palace had gone ahead with a penalty from Dean Austin. Then, after two Watford goals in three minutes from Allan Nielsen and Tommy Mooney, Tommy Black brought them level in injury-time.

In view of his own background as a player, Trevor Francis paid Wimbledon's Jason Euell what could be considered the ultimate compliment last week when suggesting that he might try to sign him if Birmingham are promoted .

Francis, commenting on the match at Wimbledon on the club's official web-site, said: 'Euell is an excellent player and is too good for this league. He is one of the best players in the First Division and can operate in the centre of midfield as well as up front. It would not surprise me if one or two Premiership clubs come knocking on their [Wimbledon's] door if they do not go up this season. He's my type of player - the type of player that I would be looking to bring in if we got into the Premiership.'

No doubt Francis would not mind having a few other Wimbledon players. Euell missed yesterday's match with an ankle injury, but Wimbledon still managed to win 3-1. Still, this cannot have come as too much of a surprise to Francis. As he had said: 'Terry Burton has got them playing some very good football - nothing like the Wimbledon of old.'

The result against Birmingham has brought Wimbledon's run of unbeaten matches in the league to nine.

With Police investigating a suspected arson attack at Oxford's new stadium on Friday - which has caused around £40,000 worth of damage - the club experienced further misery through a home defeat by Oldham which confirmed their relegation from the Second Division.

fields.headline: How did the fans do?
fields.trailText: Arsenal
fields.body:
Arsenal

They call Highbury 'the library'. On Wednesday it might as well have been renamed again: 'the mortuary'. You're supposed to intimidate the opposition in games like this - just look at Galatasaray - but most of the singing was about Tottenham. There was more atmosphere in Arsenal's Champions League games at Wembley. Even the five-minute burst after the second goal was not sustained. What a bunch of prawns.

Leeds United

They've got a bit more European Cup pedigree than Arsenal, and their fans know all about intimidating the visitors. Plenty of noise throughout, plus a great rendering of 'Marching all together' to start with and trademark delirium as the goals went in. You can bet there'll be plenty of noise in the away leg, too - and, if all goes to plan, celebrations to match those in the San Siro in the group stages.

Manchester United

The prawn sandwich factor didn't come into play on Tuesday: there was a good noise level from the home fans. Roy Keane will have been delighted to hear them try to lift the team even when they weren't playing well. But what really made the atmosphere was the away section. Bayern were noisy throughout (as they were at Arsenal) and gave perfectly enunciated versions of 'Football's coming home' and 'Sing when you're winning' after the goal.

fields.headline: Forest deepen Rix's anxiety
fields.trailText: Nottingham Forest revived their promotion challenge with this comprehensive victory, putting behind them a run in which they had gained only one point from four matches and nudging Portsmouth a step nearer the relegation zone.
fields.body:
Nottingham Forest revived their promotion challenge with this comprehensive victory, putting behind them a run in which they had gained only one point from four matches and nudging Portsmouth a step nearer the relegation zone.

The home supporters were not slow to voice their disapproval. Chants of 'what a load of rubbish' assailed the Pompey players after they had been outplayed by a bolder, more methodical Nottingham Forest in the first half.

Chris Bart-Williams took his two goals calmly and there was no denying the visitors' superiority in all departments after a shaky start on the soaked surface.

The match almost did not go ahead and an inspection 90 minutes before the kick-off by referee Roger Furnandiz allowed it to go ahead only on the condition that there was no more rain. Luckily for Forest, the rain stayed away.

Portsmouth went into the match with 10 key players injured and striker Lee Bradbury completing a suspension, while Forest brought back the influential Andy Johnson after their midweek defeat at Watford.

Forest could thank a referee's assistant for their opening goal after 11 minutes, the linesman spotting a handball by Scott Hiley as he slid into a challenge by David Johnson. Bart-Williams converted from the spot.

Portsmouth should have equalised in the 24th minute when Lee Mills was played through, but the onrushing Dave Beasant belied his 42 years by blocking the shot with his legs.

Forest scored again with a goal of great simplicity after 37 minutes. A Portsmouth move broke down inside their own half and with two visiting attackers confronted by only one defender, the Trinidadian striker Stern John struck the post and Bart-Williams had no problem in netting the rebound.

Portsmouth manager Graham Rix made a double change at the interval, sending on Mike Panopoulos and Luke Nightingale, but there was little difference either to the way Portsmouth played or their shape.

Forest allowed Portsmouth plenty of possession but Pompey failed to make much use of it. Mills, still smarting from his miss in the first half, shot against the goalkeeper's feet after 49 minutes and the pace of Lovell twice took him into scoring positions, only to be thwarted by the alert Beasant.

Bart-Williams shot over the bar with seven minutes remaining when a hat-trick beckoned and although Portsmouth forced 12 corners the result was never in doubt.

After the initial euphoria which greeted the appointment of Rix, the reality of an uncomfortable past month now confronts him and the Portsmouth fans were again not slow to voice their anger at the final whistle

fields.headline: Claridge shows class
fields.trailText: Steve Claridge scored his first goals for Millwall as Mark McGhee's side re-established themselves as favourites for the Second Division title with a crushing win over closest rivals Rotherham, who were reduced to 10 men before half-time when striker Alan Lee was sent off.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at the New Den
fields.body:
Steve Claridge scored his first goals for Millwall as Mark McGhee's side re-established themselves as favourites for the Second Division title with a crushing win over closest rivals Rotherham, who were reduced to 10 men before half-time when striker Alan Lee was sent off.

The half-time entertainment was the Grand National commentary, by which stage Millwall were so far ahead it would have taken a stumble of Devon Loch proportions to halt them as they took control of their nearest rivals.

Millwall started this game level on points at the top of the table with Rotherham but ahead on goal difference. But by half-time it was over, with Millwall three goals up and the visitors down to 10 men when striker Lee was sent off for his second bookable offence. It was Lee's third foul in a short time on Millwall winger Steven Reid, who was the target of retribution by some Rotherham players.

There was a flare-up involving Reid and Rotherham defender David Artell when Lee was sent off, and the Millwall youngster was accosted by an opponent as he left the pitch at half-time.

By then there was no doubt who would win after goals from Tim Cahill, Reid and Steve Claridge had put the game out of reach.

Only three minutes had gone when Millwall's Richard Sadlier went close to opening the scoring and then Cahill had a header cleared off the line by Artell. Millwall finally made the breakthrough after 13 minutes when Robbie Ryan's corner was headed down by Stuart Nethercott and Sadlier held up the ball allowing Cahill to shoot home from close range.

Rotherham managed only one serious effort in the first half when Mark Robins's flicked header was brilliantly saved by Tony Warner.

But Millwall increased their lead deservedly when a free-kick from Paul Isill was only half-cleared to the edge of the penalty area and Reid shot home at the second attempt.

A minute later Lee was sent off for a rash challenge on Reid - and with his dismissal, Rotherham's hopes of coming back disappeared.

Claridge scored his first goal for Millwall since joining them from Portsmouth last month when he headed the ball into an empty net from close range after Sadlier's looting header had rebounded off the bar three minutes before the break.

Claridge made it 4-0 six minutes into the second half when he received the ball with his back to goal, turned and chipped a shot over Gray and into the net from 25 yards.

After Claridge scored his second goal, Millwall put on an exhibition of passing football which the 10 men of Rotherham found difficult to break down.

With no great need to score again, Millwall's attacks became less frenetic. But Sadlier was unlucky after running on to a through-ball and shooting into the side- netting, and then had another shot well saved by Gray after bursting through the defence.

Rotherham barely had a sniff of goal. One chance fell when goalkeeper Warner struck his attempted clearance against Paul Warne, the ball rebounding just wide.

Warne then shot over the bar from long range as Rotherham tried to get what would have been no more than a consolation goal.

fields.headline: Leeds play it so Kewell
fields.trailText: With every win it becomes increasingly difficult to believe David O'Leary's in-built caution. Anyone but the man who apologised for sounding like a wet blanket in his match programme would see that potential, for Leeds United, seems limitless at the moment.
fields.body:
With every win it becomes increasingly difficult to believe David O'Leary's in-built caution. Anyone but the man who apologised for sounding like a wet blanket in his match programme would see that potential, for Leeds United, seems limitless at the moment.

After dismantling Deportivo La Coruna 3-0 in such vibrant style three days earlier, Leeds ascended to third place in the Premiership with a performance built on sheer ambition. The virtuoso instincts of Harry Kewell and Robbie Keane, two players who have had restricted opportunities, made the difference. Both have a lot more to offer this season, another bonus for O'Leary, if he dares to admit it.

It seems impossible to imagine Leeds could crown their astonishing Champions League campaign with a place in the final - yet fail to assure their presence in the competition next season. That thought is driving Leeds domestically, and they have built up quite a head of Premiership steam since the new year. Still, David O'Leary feels a top-three finish is a 'massive task' given the gap they had to claw back after a patchy start and barren mid-season spell. Another dose of self-deprecation from the Irishman?

For all their supposed innocence at the top level, Leeds now have the resources to behave like the superpowers they hope to emulate: Alan Smith, such a handful against Deportivo in midweek, was given a rest. Robbie Keane, £12 million-worth of back up, took his place in the starting line-up with relish.

Dealing with a the nitty-gritty after a euphoric European night is the basic requirement for clubs aiming to establish themselves as Champions League regulars and Leeds' commitment was evident from the start. Inside the first two minutes Mark Viduka's desire to win the ball left Claus Lundekvam pole-axed (albeit unintentionally), and David Batty's surge had Leeds appealing for a penalty. Challenged by Dean Richards, he tumbled, but referee Jeff Winter was not impressed.

Their pressure told soon enough, though. Chris Marsden dallied on the ball, enabling Keane to flick a neat square pass to the feet of Harry Kewell. The Australian instinctively reminded us what a remarkable talent has been missing for so much of this season. A good 25 yards out , he teed himself up with a delicate touch, glanced up, and stroked the ball into the bottom corner. Aided by the fact a convenient bobble took his shot over Paul Jones's outstretched hand, he deserved his slice of fortune. Few players would think of passing the ball in from such a distance - fewer still could actually do it. It was his first Premiership goal at Elland Road for more than a year.

Leeds, understandably a little jaded after their effervescent efforts in midweek, still enjoyed the territorial advantage. As for Southampton, it took them 24 minutes to muster their first chance - if you could call it that. Beattie's header looped comfortably into Nigel Martyn's arms. Jason Dodd came slightly closer on the half hour with an ambitious cross-shot that skirted the roof of the net.

You sensed Leeds would need a second goal to finish the South Coast visitors off, and just as Southampton were getting a foothold in the game, they should have done exactly that with a devastating break.

It was an outstanding chance, initiated by Keane's perceptive sliderule pass, which sent Kewell scurrying goalwards and past Jones - the kind of position where inflicting a second blow seemed a foregone conclusion. He almost overdid the tricks in rounding the goalkeeper, allowing Richards to deflect his angled shot with an inspired intervention. But it wasn't over: Kewell retrieved possession and delivered a cut-back to Keane - who also seemed destined to score - Lundekvam, this time, supplied the crucial block.

With Leeds scratching their heads in disbelief you wonder if Glenn Hoddle had been benevolent enough to leave one of Eileen Drewery's prayers with the Saints on his departure.

Incidentally, Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale, in his programme notes, offered a scathing opinion on the new Tottenham manager's conduct: 'Any manager who believes contracts are only to be honoured by one party isn't worth employing in the first place.'

Southampton's players, at least, could not be accused of treating the club's colours lightly. In the second half they continued to withstand Leeds's frequent attempts to pick their way through. They also possessed the spirit to keep Leeds on their toes on the counter. When Jones pumped a free-kick deep into the opposition half, Dan Petrescu stole in to scare Leeds with an audacious volley. It drew a dazzling save from Martyn.

Oh, how Leeds required a cushion and Kewell glimpsed two chances before he was withdrawn; foiled first by the referee, who ignored his strong penalty claim when Dodd handled, then by Jones, who plucked out his curling chip after terrific work by Keane.

So, the young Irishman took matters into his own hands. Having beaten the offside trap to latch onto Harte's punt, he lobbed Jones with cocksure cool. It was a peach, suitable reward for a bold performance.

How important that was, for Richards tapped in Beattie's centre two minutes from time, although the goal was ruled out for offside - a very harsh decision.

fields.headline: Late flourish rewards Chelsea
fields.trailText: Three late goals underlined a performance of stunning superiority by Chelsea. The team who so often this season have struggled on their travels outplayed Derby from start to finish and could easily have won by a bigger margin.
fields.body:
Three late goals underlined a performance of stunning superiority by Chelsea. The team who so often this season have struggled on their travels outplayed Derby from start to finish and could easily have won by a bigger margin.

Derby never got a look-in and while they still have a cushion over the teams below them in the table, this result could have a devastating affect on their morale. As for Chelsea, a European place is not looking quite so distant after all.

The most significant of five changes Derby made after losing to Coventry involved the return after flu of Taribo West, the player who has made the biggest single contribution to their climb from the relegation area.

West, who came to the club on loan from Milan in November at a time when Derby were in dire straits, has been a rock in their defence. But reputations can count for nothing and West was certainly given a good going over in the early stages by Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, Chelsea's leading scorer and one of three men up front in a bold 3-4-3 formation employed by Claudio Ranieri.

Twice Hasselbaink evaded challenges from West. First, he was eventually checked by an outstretched leg of Paul Boertien. Then, after turning away from his marker in the centre circle, Hasselbaink advanced on goal to fire a shot a foot too high.

Chelsea were brimming with confidence and control as Derby struggled to piece anything worthwhile together, although they wasted a good chance on the half-hour. Boertien's diagonal ball in was missed by Malcolm Christie before reaching the far post, where Adam Murray turned it wide.

Chelsea were unlucky two minutes later. Eidur Gudjohnsen measured his centre into space for Gianfranco Zola, who struck the near post with a venomous volley.

Derby finally tested Carlo Cudicini when Murray's cross was knocked back into the path of Darryl Powell. But his drive, though well struck, lacked the necessary direction and was comfortably held by the goalkeeper.

An enforced substitution in which Gus Poyet replaced Gudjohnsen did nothing to alter the balance of the game. Poyet tucked in behind Hasselbaink and Zola, and was soon heavily involved with one shot blocked and the follow-up effort wide.

Poom again came to Derby's rescue with a flying save from Hasselbaink, and really it was no more than Chelsea deserved when they went ahead after 63 minutes. Hasselbaink took on Horacio Carbonari on the outside before pulling the ball back into the path of Zola who found the bottom corner of the net from a dozen yards.

Chelsea underlined their superiority with three goals in the last six minutes. Hasselbaink became the first Chelsea players since Kerry Dixon 11 years ago to score 20 goals in a season in the top flight when he converted from Poyet's pass.

Poyet then drove low into the net from a Dennis Wise corner and in injury time a glancing header by the Uruguayan from Celestine Babayaro's cross made it 4-0.

fields.headline: Return to glory for Ginola
fields.trailText: Aston Villa frustrate you. They are an efficient team, too content to squeeze out results when more taking of risks to win, rather than consolidating to avoid defeat, might lift them up with clubs of comparable size. Having fought back from a goal down to take a lead yesterday, they then allowed West Ham back in to prise a precious point that arrests worrying run of four previous defeats for them.
fields.body:
Aston Villa frustrate you. They are an efficient team, too content to squeeze out results when more taking of risks to win, rather than consolidating to avoid defeat, might lift them up with clubs of comparable size. Having fought back from a goal down to take a lead yesterday, they then allowed West Ham back in to prise a precious point that arrests worrying run of four previous defeats for them.

Two moments of skill by David Ginola, one a goal, the other an assist for Lee Hendrie, overturned Frédéric Kanouté's opening goal, but Frank Lampard pilfered a share of the spoils to stop Villa in their tracks.

It was never going to produce a feast of goals given the teams' goal-scoring records of late, the more so since both only played one striker. The Villa manager, John Gregory, played Paul Merson in behind Julian Joachim, resting Dion Dublin and beginning the match with the £9.5 million signing Juan Pablo Angel as a substitute. West Ham's Harry Redknapp, meanwhile, having decided that Paolo Di Canio and Joe Cole were not a complementary couple, dropped Cole to the bench and deployed Di Canio wide on the left in a five-man midfield behind Kanouté.

Thus the formations - both unusually playing four at the back - allied to the natural caution of the home side and the visitors' lack of confidence, produced a first half of monumental tedium, with no clear-cut chances created and both sides content to prod the ball around in midfield. It rivalled Thursday on BBC1, which featured Barcelona v Liverpool, when the only shot came during EastEnders .

Early on, Mark Delaney blocked a shot by Sebastien Schemmel and Gareth Barry did likewise to Frank Lampard's attempt. That was West Ham's attacking total in the first half. Villa's featured Paul Merson slipping Joachim clear for a low shot that lacked power and Shaka Hislop dived on comfortably.

The rain-soaked surface, watched with concern by FA officials and Villa Park ground staff in advance of today's Cup semi-final, was too slippery for some players, their first touches exposed as inadequate as the ball squirted away. Thankfully the stimulus the game needed came within 30 seconds of the restart. Schemmel sent Lampard into space wide on the right and, looking up having reached the byline, he perceptively picked out the run of Kanouté and delivered a low ball that the Frenchman despatched emphatically past David James from 12 yards.

Relief coursing through them, they began to play some of the football that had thrilled a few months ago. John Moncur almost made it two but Mark Delaney deflected his goalbound shot - and astonishingly Di Canio sidefooted over the bar from seven yards after James had merely pushed out Moncur's low cross to his feet.

Somehow you knew West Ham would rue the miss. They did when, after Stuart Pearce had fouled Joachim on the edge of the penalty area, Ginola stepped up to curl home a free-kick. His talent was on show again in an early left-wing cross that Pearce could only head on to Lee Hendrie, who drove home an instant half-volley to turn the game on its head.

Villa then entrenched themselves and paid the penalty when Pearce's free-kick was headed against a post by Igor Stimac and Lampard slotted home the rebound.

fields.headline: Sky Blues in survival mode
fields.trailText: Leicester's season is collapsing around them in extraordinary fashion while, as is customary at this time of the year, Coventry are just getting into their stride. Goals from Craig Bellamy, Lee Carsley and John Hartson strengthened manager Gordon Strachan's belief that Coventry can contemplate a 35th year in the top flight. Judging from this spirited performance, he may just be right.
fields.body:
Leicester's season is collapsing around them in extraordinary fashion while, as is customary at this time of the year, Coventry are just getting into their stride. Goals from Craig Bellamy, Lee Carsley and John Hartson strengthened manager Gordon Strachan's belief that Coventry can contemplate a 35th year in the top flight. Judging from this spirited performance, he may just be right.

Coventry required just 62 seconds to add some substance to Strachan's belief that last week's victory over Derby was a sign they are capable of escaping relegation yet again. The opportunity was created fortuitously when the ball rebounded off Muzzy Izzet, but Coventry accepted it stylishly as Moustapha Hadji accelerated down the right and crossed low to leave Craig Bellamy with a straightforward task in front of goal.

It was an important contribution by Hadji, undoubtedly raising the morale of a player who had been a moody individual in training during the week following his dismissal for spitting against Derby.

Of equal importance to Coventry was the goal's effect on Craig Bellamy, whose aggressive running from deep was the key feature as Coventry went on to produce one of their most impressive 45 minutes of the season.

The belief that they can stay in the Premiership was evident and even a 10th-minute equaliser from Leicester failed to shake it. Ade Akinbiyi claimed the goal after keeper Chris Kirkland palmed out an awkward, long-range shot from Arnar Gunnlaugsson.

That was the only threat before the break from a Leicester team who, without the underrated midfield influence of Robbie Savage, proved unable to resist Coventry's admirable desire to drive forward at every opportunity.

Strachan's team were rewarded again in the 19th minute when Lee Carsley stunned keeper Simon Royce with a powerful header from 14 yards following Barry Quinn's cross. There could have been more for Coventry before the interval, notably when Royce saved Paul Telfer's 20th-minute shot. John Eustace was inches away with a 36th-minute shot - close, but not close enough to save him from a reprimand from Hadji, who was ideally placed to tuck away a cross from the midfielder.

Then Bellamy started a move that almost ended with John Hartson turning in Marcus Hall's cross, and the midfielder was the provider again in the closing moments of the half when his pass was cut out before it could reach Hartson.

Taylor's response to his team's woeful contribution was to replace Callum Davidson and Matt Elliott with Steve Guppy and Stefan Oakes at the interval.

After about five minutes, the manager must have been pondering whether Elliott's withdrawal was a mistake. The defender would surely have dealt with Telfer's corner; instead, Hartson was given the freedom to head in his third goal since his £15,000-a-game arrival at Coventry. It already looks money well invested by Strachan.

Hartson went close to adding another in the 65th minute when Oakes's misjudged header enabled him to break away an unleash a shot that Royce turned aside at full stretch.

Leicester, meanwhile, were finally making attacking inroads and only an instinctive save by Kirkland from Gerry Taggart's close header kept Coventry in control.

webTitle: Crime tsar Birt leaves to the sound of mockery

fields.headline: Crime tsar Birt leaves to the sound of mockery
fields.standfirst:
Former BBC director-general appointed by Blair 'made no impact at all'
'
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Former BBC director-general appointed by Blair 'made no impact at all'
fields.body:
Lord Birt, the former BBC boss named as Tony Blair's 'crime tsar' in a blaze of publicity, has been quietly pensioned off amid mounting criticism that he failed to deliver.

The peer's work on why criminals reoffend is now officially finished. He will not be publishing a report on his findings, in sharp contrast to other high-profile outsiders hired by Government.

Although Downing Street insists his 'valuable' thoughts were fed into Home Secretary Jack Straw's recent criminal justice plan, his contribution has been mocked within Whitehall. 'It's just been a deathly silence since he was appointed - he's made no impact at all,' said one Whitehall source. 'He was a disaster for the BBC by all accounts and frankly I don't know what he's done here.'

When Birt was appointed last summer to cast a 'fresh eye' over the criminal justice system, Blair insisted that he could bring 'a strategic outlook and an understanding of social trends gained from a long and distinguished career in broadcasting'.

Critics on both sides of the House, however, were sceptical, accusing Blair of simply giving a good friend a job. Privately, there was scorn within the Home Office and even within Downing Street at his appointment.

Ministers have been careful to be courteous to Blair's personal envoy - Birt met Straw for talks shortly before Christmas, and has also had meetings with the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, both Irvine's junior Ministers and drugs tsar Keith Hellawell.

However, insiders say he was in effect limited to poring over the Offenders' Index - records of crime statistics for the past 50 years - in an attempt to discern trends.

The figures, contained in a two-page annexe to the plan, show about half of crime is committed by a hard core of only 10 per cent of known criminals, suggesting these should be the most closely targeted. Birt's critics say this is hardly a surprise to experts in the field.

'All he has come up with is a few daft ideas for Jack Straw's youth justice plan, about building more children's jails when the ones we have don't work and making parents of persistent offenders attend the court hearing to explain what measures they are taking to control their children,' said Harry Fletcher of the National Association of Probation Officers. 'He has not spoken to anyone here and we are not sure who he has spoken to.'

It is understood Birt has not met the Association of Chief Police Officers either, nor organisations working with former convicts such as the National Association for Care and Resettlement of Offenders.

Birt was not paid for his one day a week role. Parliamentary written answers reveal that by November last year he had claimed only £300 in expenses.

The news that his role was over after eight months was slipped out in an answer in the House of Lords under questioning from Tory peer Lord Tebbit.

Asked whether Birt's findings would be reported to Par liament, junior Home Office Minister Lord Bassam said they were 'considered alongside' contributions from other Government departments for the report'Criminal Justice: The Way Ahead', published in February. Birt's role is not mentioned in the document.

Downing Street, however, insisted his contribution had been worthwhile and said he might be invited back for ' ad hoc projects'.

'The bulk of his work is now done and those of his proposals that we were interested in were incorporated into the 'Way Ahead' document,' said a spokesman.

'All he has come up with is a few daft ideas for Jack Straw's youth justice plan, about building more children's jails when the ones we have don't work and making parents of persistent offenders attend the court hearing to explain what measures they are taking to control their children,' said Harry Fletcher of the National Association of Probation Officers. 'He has not spoken to anyone here and we are not sure who he has spoken to.' It is understood Birt has not met the Association of Chief Police Officers either, nor organisations working with former convicts such as the National Association for Care and Resettlement of Offenders. Birt was not paid for his one day a week role. Parliamentary written answers reveal that by November last year he had claimed only £300 in expenses. The news that his role was over after eight months was slipped out in an answer in the House of Lords under questioning from Tory peer Lord Tebbit. Asked whether Birt's findings would be reported to Par liament, junior Home Office Minister Lord Bassam said they were 'considered alongside' contributions from other Government departments for the report'Criminal Justice: The Way Ahead', published in February. Birt's role is not mentioned in the document. Downing Street, however, insisted his contribution had been worthwhile and said he might be invited back for ' ad hoc projects'. 'The bulk of his work is now done and those of his proposals that we were interested in were incorporated into the 'Way Ahead' document,' said a spokesman. gaby.hinsliff@observer.co.uk

webTitle: News: Tempest in a test tube for insurers

fields.headline: Tempest in a test tube for insurers
fields.trailText: Insurers are at loggerheads with an influential committee of MPs over their enthusiasm for genetic testing.
fields.body:
Insurers are at loggerheads with an influential committee of MPs over their enthusiasm for genetic testing. Companies now face a ban on the use of information from genetic tests because of fears they may create a genetic underclass.

The Commons Science and Technology Select Committee has recommended a two-year moratorium on the use of all positive genetic tests. If insurers refuse to stop using test results voluntarily, the Government should introduce legislation to force a moratorium.

The committee has also recommended that the Government insurance industry collaborate to provide an alternative form of insurance for those who would otherwise be denied cover because of their genetic make-up.

In a report published last week, the committee said a decision by the Association of British Insurers that several of the tests it recommended four years ago are no longer valid 'casts the gravest possible doubts' on those still used by the firms.

In a scathing attack on the industry, the committee said: 'Insurers appear to have been far more interested in establishing their future right to use genetic test results in assessing premiums than in whether or not they are reliable or relevant.' The ABI's code of practice bars companies from telling applicants to undergo genetic testing, but permits them to ask for the results of any tests they have already taken.

Insurers claim that if they ignore the results of genetic tests, customers who know they risk developing a hereditary disease will be able to buy large amounts of insurance at the normal price. However, three insurers - Virgin Direct, Standard Life and the Cooperative Insurance Society - do not require applicants to reveal the results of genetic tests, arguing that the numbers involved are so small that their effect is negligible.

In 1998 the ABI named 10 tests for seven conditions for which it believed there were reliable genetic tests, but reduced this to five tests for three conditions last year. Those left are for breast and ovarian cancer, Huntington's and early-onset Alzheimer's.

Only one, for Huntington's disease, has received approval from the parliamentary Genetics and Insurance Committee so far, but most insurers are using the results of all five tests when assessing risk. The Science and Technology Select Committee says this should stop immediately.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Paramount Bank personal loans.
fields.body:
You may think that you have bagged yourself a good deal when you take out a personal loan with Paramount Bank for 8.9 per cent, but be aware that other customers may be getting a lower rate simply because they saw the advert somewhere else.

Paramount, Halifax's new telephone bank, which offers low-cost loans and credit cards, is advertising different rates in different magazines for the same personal loans. While some Paramount ads boast an APR of 7.9 per cent on loans of between £12,501 and £15,000, others advertise a starting rate of 8.9 per cent.

Paramount says: 'This strategy is quite common. We are just testing response to different rates.' It denies it is unfair to customers who do not know that a lower rate is available. Even if they ask if there are lower rates on offer, they will not be allowed to apply for them.

Also be aware that while the 7.9 and 8.9 per cent APRs are displayed prominently in the adverts, they are just starting rates. If you borrow less you will be charged a higher APR. Loans of between £1,000 and £2,999 carry an APR of 15.9 per cent, for example. Paramount insists all its APRs are 'very competitive'.

Last year the Office of Fair Trading published new rules on starting rates after complaints. The rules mean adverts which use a 'from' rate must make this claim less prominent than the typical rate.

Paramount insists that the OFT is happy with the wording it has used in the adverts and that it is issuing more loans at 7.9 per cent than at other rates.

A Paramount loan is not automatically yours for the asking. You will have to go through a credit assessment procedure. The bank may refuse those with county court judgments, bad debts or insufficient income. However, once you have gone through the credit hoop, you are guaranteed the advertised rate, Paramount says.

 Seen an advert or offer which sounds too good? Then write to What's the Catch? The Observer, 119 Farringdon Rd, EC1R 3ER.

fields.headline: Stakeholder 'not for the low paid'
fields.standfirst: Experts fear small savers face benefit trap, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Experts fear small savers face benefit trap, says Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Savers who can put aside only small amounts are being warned this weekend to be wary of taking out the new stakeholder pensions.

Experts fear they could end up in retirement with too little income to live on, but too much to qualify for means-tested state benefits.

The scheme - launched on Friday - is being wel comed for its low costs and flexible terms but concern is growing that it may fail the people it was originally aimed at, the low-to-middle income earners.

The Government's target group was people earning between £10,000 and £20,000 a year. But last week, the head of a government-appointed advisory group on pensions said those earning between £9,000 and £15,000 might be no better off for saving in a stakeholder.

This is because the pension could disqualify them from means-tested state benefit in retirement, taking away their entitlement to the Government's new Minimum Income Guarantee (MIG) and reducing their entitlement to the Pension Credit due for introduction in two years.

The MIG tops up the basic state pension for people with no other income. From this month the basic pension is £72.50 for a single person and £115.90 for couples. Pensioners who qualify for the income guarantee get this topped up to £92.15 and £140.55.

From April 2003 the basic pension is forecast to be £77 for single pensioners and £123 for a couple, with the MIG at £100 and £154 respectively. In 2003 the Government forecasts that the Pension Credit will top up income for people with modest savings - at a rate of 60p for each £1 of private income, tapering out at incomes of £135 a week for single people and around £200 for couples.

But pensions experts believe this amounts to a tax on saving, at a rate of 40 per cent, and will deter people from putting money aside.

They say the appeal of the stakeholder has been weakened by big increases in the basic state pension and the introduction of the new means-tested pensions. These were brought in by the Government after the stakeholder was conceived, to placate pensioners angry at the erosion of state pensions.

Tom Ross, who chairs the advisory body, the Pension Provision Group, told The Observer he was 'very torn' about the benefits of pension savings for people on lower incomes.

'If I were lined up against the wall I would probably say there are more risks in not saving than saving,' he said.

It was impossible to know whether the present state pension regime would remain in future. But if he was a financial adviser trying to help someone in this income group, Ross 'wouldn't touch it [the stakeholder] with a bargepole'.

His views echo those in a recent report by the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries. Deborah Cooper, a member of the Institute's pension provision task force, said people on median earnings of about £13,000 would have little hope of saving enough to escape the means test trap.

If they could afford to save, they would probably be better off doing so through an Individual Savings Account, where they could get at their money if they needed it.

The uncertainty over the way the stakeholder pension will affect means-tested benefits poses a dilemma for financial advisers. Few have yet decided how to deal with questions from people on lower incomes.

But Tom McPhail, of adviser Torquil Clark, says the stakeholder holds little appeal for lower earners.

A single person who can not afford to accumulate a stakeholder fund big enough to generate an income of more than £135 a week (in today's terms and assuming a basic state pension of £77 plus £60 a week from a stakeholder pension) would not benefit by starting one.

A 30 year old would need to save £50 a month to achieve this, a 40-year old would have to put aside £85 a month and a 50 year old £165.

'If you are in those age bands and thinking "I can save at least that much between now and retirement on a regular basis", do it and save as much as you can above that.

'But if you are 50 and struggling to save, don't do both. Stick [the money] in an Isa.'

However, the picture is different for people - primarily the young with good career prospects - who are on low incomes now, but who expect their earnings to rise.

McPhail says a 30 year old struggling to save £50 a month now but expecting better times ahead should choose differently from someone of the same age who knows they will always struggle to find that money.

webTitle: Impersonation, the fastest rising form of fraud

fields.headline: Being you, being me
fields.standfirst: Impersonation, the fastest rising form of fraud, is all too easy to commit, writes  Jason Deign
fields.trailText: Impersonation, the fastest rising form of fraud, is all too easy to commit, writes Jason Deign
fields.body:
Abraham Abdallah impersonated some of America's wealthiest celebrities and tried to defraud them of up to $10 million before he was caught last month.

On the surface the case of Abraham Abdallah, a New York dish-washer who posed as Steven Spielberg, Oprah Winfrey, Ted Turner and other members of the Forbes rich list, using information gathered on the internet, could be dismissed as just another 'only in America' story. However, there is worrying evidence that Abdallah's was simply the highest-profile example of an increasingly common type of fraud that is aided by the spread of electronic communications and affects thousands of ordinary people in Britain.

Impersonation is the fastest rising category of crime tracked by Cifas (the Credit Industry Fraud Avoidance System), which acts as an early warning system for banks, building societies and other financial institutions. In the period from January to October 1999, Cifas logged 1,572 cases of false identity fraud. Over the same months last year this number leapt to 8,739 - a rise of 456 per cent.

The rise of impersonation fraud has so alarmed observers that it will be getting a special mention in the National Criminal Intelligence Service's annual UK Threat Assessment, to be published in July.

'If this rate of increase continues,' says Cifas, 'this type of fraud will become the most serious, with significant financial losses within a short space of time.'

Impersonation fraud is divided into piggy-backing, where the 'victim' colludes with the imposter, for example, fraudulently to collect benefits claims, and hijacking, where the victim is unaware of the identity of the impostor. It is the second variety, as practised by Abdallah on America's billionaire set, that appears to be driving the current boom in false identity, thanks to the increasing ease with which criminals can provide convincing fronts for themselves using modern technology.

'They've always been there,' says a source at Cifas, 'but there's been an explosion in recent years. It relates to the distance of persons from service providers. With the growth of call centres, and the internet, the old days of a bank manager sitting across the desk from an applicant are long gone.'

This anonymity is perfect for the identity hijacker. And becoming someone else is less of a problem than one might expect. Fleur Strong, of the National Criminal Intelligence Service, says: 'It's not that difficult to do and if you're not greedy, you won't necessarily get caught out.'

Once a criminal has one item of personal information, such as the account details from a credit card slip, they can usually get hold of others that will help build up a full, false identity. Items such as addresses and phone numbers can be found on the internet, and government organisations do not cross-reference applications for identity documents such as driving licences.

Equifax and Experian, the major UK credit reference agencies, will provide personal credit information for little more than a £2 fee. Furthermore, says Strong: 'You can be pumped for a lot of information if you are just chatting with someone. People will happily give out details like their mother's maiden name to someone they met in a pub or club.' All the criminal needs is a delivery address they can claim the victim has moved to, and they are ready to start making credit card and bank account applications on the victim's behalf.

In theory, if the ruse is carried out carefully enough, the victim might never know. And, since impersonation per se is not a crime, if the fraudster kept credit card payments up to date it is technically possible they would not even be liable to prosecution.

If the fraud is discovered, the onus is on the party that has suffered a material loss, usually the bank or credit card issuer, to push for prosecution. They are also obliged to notify Cifas, which then posts an alert against the victim's credit file to make sure that all future applications in that name are checked with its legitimate holder.

Banks claim they are bracing themselves for a potential wave of identity hijackers. Heather Scott, corporate communications manager at Intelligent Finance, says: 'We believe we do all we're regulated to, and more besides. Our people recognise that where there's no face-to-face contact, there's a greater risk of this kind of fraud, so we go to greater lengths to make sure we deal with it. Our systems have been built to be as robust as the technology will allow.'

But Richard Tyson-Davies, head of public affairs for the credit card body Apacs, says fraudulent applications are a minor concern for the industry, compared to annual losses of £100 million through counterfeit cards.

He says the level of fraudulent applications dropped by 10 per cent last year, while credit card fraud overall went up by 55 per cent.

This, combined with the Cifas figures, could be an indication that Cifas is helping to intercept an increasing number of imposters and cutting the level of reported application fraud.

However, Cifas says that while its service is important, 'individual companies need to do verification checks, and there is a trade-off between these and the speed of the production line'.

My credit card took a £3,800 hit

David Vindel, 31, of west London, opened his Christmas statement from MBNA, an American credit card issuer in the UK, to find an unexplained £3,800 against his account.

The amount was for an MBNA cheque, which the card company regularly issues to customers to pay off household bills and other costs. 'I've never used one of their cheques,' he says, 'so I contacted them, and their fraud department said they would try to get the cheque back for verification.'

MBNA said this would take two weeks, but it took twice that time. While the amount was in dispute, the bank continued to charge him interest.

At the same time, further evidence showed an identity hijacker was at work. MBNA intercepted another cheque, this time for £2,500, and Vindel received a welcome pack from Intelligent Finance, the Halifax-backed internet bank, for a bogus account in his name. With the pack, IF returned a fake payslip in Vindel's name, drawn against a non-existent company and quoting a non-existent tax code. Then followed a letter confirming a £15,000 loan.

While IF quickly made amends after he contacted them , and claims the welcome pack and loan were pre-approved, subject to further checks - Vindel was frustrated by the lack of response from MBNA, which was still sending him new cheque books even though he had specifically requested not to receive them any more.

'Every time I contacted them I had to explain my situation over again,' he says. 'I was charged interest for over three months.'

Eventually he wrote directly to MBNA chief Greg Phillips and the dispute was settled in days. However, Vindel feels let down by the bank's keenness to offer credit and its relaxed attitude to fraud.

An MBNA spokesman said that the company was taking his concerns 'very seriously' and would be reviewing its procedures.

fields.headline: Passport, tickets... and form E111
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles  on how to get free health care abroad
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles on how to get free health care abroad.
fields.body:
If you are travelling to Europe this Easter, make sure you pack form E111. Available from post offices, this entitles travellers to free medical treatment in a European Union country if they fall ill or have an accident - as long as the country they are visiting has signed a reciprocal arrangement for health services.

Many holidaymakers travelling to Europe use the E111 form instead of buying travel insurance. But make sure you know exactly what E111 will cover you for. It may be a good idea to have both.

In some countries, such as Switzerland, Cyprus and Turkey, you are not covered by E111 at all. In those where you are the terms of the reciprocal agreements vary considerably. Some countries will require you to pay for treatment upfront; in others, treatment may be free or at a reduced cost.

Outside the EU another 21 countries offer emergency medical cover to travellers with E111 forms. These include Australia, Barbados, the Czech Republic, Malta, Poland and Russia.

Each participating country offers overseas visitors the same emergency medical cover it would give its own citizens. The same applies for foreigners visiting Britain. The form, which should last for life, also covers spouses and dependent children up to the age of 16 (or 19 if they are in full-time education).

However, extra travel and accommodation expenses and any repatriation costs are not covered. Neither are common holiday hazards such as cancellation or your bags being stolen. This is why it is important to have travel insurance as well.

Even though travel insurance may be more comprehensive, it is still worth getting form E111 because you may not have to pay for treatment upfront if you have it. You could also be saved the bother of dealing with the paperwork required in an insurance claim. Some insurers will even waive the medical excess if you have an E111.

Different countries vary in their willingness to accept the form, so do not take no for an answer. France and Germany have a good record, Spain less so. You may be asked to back it up with proof of UK residence and your NHS medical card so take those with you, too.

E111 forms are available free from post offices in Britain. You can fill in the form on the spot and cashiers will stamp it to validate it. You will need your national insurance number and your passport.

Getting reimbursed for money you have spent while under the protection of an E111 may not be so easy, however. Reclaiming from the DSS could take months, and you will need proof of all the money you have spent.

 Pupils on school trips should be included on their parents' E111 and should take the original form with them.

 Form E111 will not cover you for free or reduced-cost treatment if you are going to another EU country specifically for medical care, or if you require treatment for a pre-existing condition. For this, you will need an E112 form, which is not issued automatically but requires authorisation from the Department of Health.

fields.headline: Your life - or  your money
fields.standfirst: Insurance can now be an each way bet, reports  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Insurance can now be an each way bet, reports Jill Insley.
fields.body:
It's easy to let life insurance slip way down the list of your priorities if you are cash-strapped and have heavy demands on your income.

Recent research by Eagle Star showed that 25 per cent of UK adults choose not to buy life insurance because they think it is too expensive while others believe they don't need it. And 21 per cent of those without insurance had at least one child under the age of 15.

One of the discouraging aspects of straightforward 'term' life insurance is that if you live until the end of your policy, you seem to get nothing for your money. But a few insurers are now trying to attract reluctant customers by selling life policies that repay part of the premiums if they survive - cashback term insurance.

This type of insurance is usually sold through direct mail or affinity groups. However, don't simply sign up with the first company that drops a leaflet through your door. Three insurers - Cornhill, Eagle Star and Homeowners Friendly Society - repay half the premiums if you are still alive at the end of the term. But the amount of insurance cover (the sum assured) you receive for your premiums varies quite dramatically.

Eagle Star is by far the most competitive for non-smokers aged either 30 or 40 and of either sex, offering almost three times as much cover as Cornhill for a male 30-year-old non-smoker. This is because its underwriting takes the kind of work you do into account, and the figures it has produced for the table below are based on someone working in an office. Homeowners and Cornhill do not underwrite according to occupation, basing their figures on average risk for the whole UK population.

Eagle Star's policy will repay a small amount of the premiums once 13 have been paid. It also offers a variety of term lengths, and bases its calculations on the amount of cover you want, rather than the size of premium you are prepared to pay.

Homeowners, which markets its Credit Union policy through four organisations (Riverside, Glasgow Council, Scot West and White Rose), is better for older smokers. A similar policy for non-credit union members provides half the cover published in the table below. Its policy lasts for a standard 15 years, and is based on the amount you want to pay, rather than the amount of cover you need (cover is capped at £120,000). No cashback is paid before the end of the policy.

Both Eagle Star's and Homeowners' policies will pay out on diagnosis of a terminal illness as well as death during the policy's term. Homeowners pays out half the sum assured on diagnosis and the remainder on death provided it happens within the term of the policy, while Eagle Star pays out the full amount to someone whose illness will cause death within 12 months and within the term of the policy.

No tax is payable by the policyholder on cash paid back at the end of the term. However, the sums involved are small - you can expect £1,800 on a £20 a month,15 year policy. Independent financial advisers argue that straightforward term insurance is cheaper and therefore much better value. John Beale of Wolverhampton discount broker TQ Direct says: 'You would be better off using your money to buy a greater amount of ordinary term insurance, or spending less on insurance premiums and saving the difference in an interest-bearing deposit account.'

webTitle: Heather Connon: Make tracks away from trackers

fields.headline: Make tracks away from trackers
fields.trailText: Markets are increasingly volatile; falling prices, globalisation and intensifying competition are making it harder for companies to increase profits.
fields.body:
In last week's column I said inertia investing was dead. The old strategy of buying shares and holding them while they rose in value is no longer appropriate. Markets are increasingly volatile; falling prices, globalisation and intensifying competition are making it harder for companies to increase profits. Investors have to be able to spot the winners and, just as important, know when to sell out.

That is fine for those who invest directly in shares. Brokers' commissions have fallen sharply, so active trading is not as expensive as it once was. But most private shareholders hold shares indirectly, through unit or investment trusts.

Switching between funds is expensive. Not only do you usually have to pay an initial charge, as high as 5 per cent, on new subscriptions, but the bid/offer spread - the gap between what you can sell units for and the price you have to pay for them - is also high. Investment trusts, which are bought and sold like shares, have no initial charges or bid/offer spread. But the discount - the gap between the share price and the value of the assets - will rise and fall depending on the sector's popularity.

Nor is it easy to work out what is in your unit trust. Most managers send out newsletters only twice a year - if at all. While these will show the biggest holdings, that will not be enough to analyse strategy or performance. But that does not mean inertia rules for unit trust investors. You have to be just as careful about selecting a manager as you are about picking a share - and just as ruthless in deciding when to sell.

In falling or turbulent markets there's no sense in being an index-tracker. At best they just follow the market down, but dealing costs mean performance will usually be worse than that. Many so-called active funds are trackers in disguise.

Factors such as market turbulence, the switch from growth strategies to value and back again and the technology bust have made it so hard for managers to beat the index that many have given up trying. Instead, they follow the herd with, perhaps, a few minor bets on the side - but levy charges as if they were actively managing your money.

What investors should be looking for now is managers willing to take a bet - hopefully a winning one. That means looking for funds with a definite strategy. Jason Hollands of Best Invest points to Artemis or ABN Amro's Selection, which have distinctive and, for the moment, successful investment styles. Gartmore, too, is launching a series of Focus funds, investing in only 30 or so stocks.

Backing such funds is higher-risk than simply buying a general trust and hoping. Be prepared to bail out if the performance deteriorates rapidly for no obvious reason, or if the manager changes or the firm itself merges or is taken over.

fields.headline: Justice for Dredd
fields.standfirst: The British artists behind the US superhero are at last winning acclaim, says  John Windsor, and their work is still cheap
fields.trailText: The British artists behind the US superhero are at last winning acclaim, says John Windsor, and their work is still cheap
fields.body:
Judge Dredd, the ruthless American comic book superhero who acts as policeman, judge, jury and executioner in a post-nuclear New York, was made in Britain.

It is, however, American collectors who drive the world market for superhero comic books, the lengthy stories aimed at adults, as opposed to the shorter ones for children. Until recently, it was the books themselves that drew the biggest bucks. But now the value of their pre-press artwork is rising.

An original, unpublished page of Superman artwork from the Thirties recently fetched a record $77,000 at Sotheby's New York branch.

Now original artworks by the brilliant 'new wave' of a dozen or so British-based artists who have drawn Dredd since he first blasted crimi nals to pieces in the IPC comic 2000AD in 1977 could rise in value.

They used to be hurled into skips by publishers after use, but are now demanded back by the artists, whose work is about to be acknowledged by an exhibition at London's the Victoria and Albert Museum.

The UK retail price for a black-and-white page of Dredd published in the past 10 years is still only £60, though a page by an artist with a big following among Dredd fans, such as Brian Bolland or Mike McMahon, fetches £150.

Something by Dredd's original designer, the Spaniard Carlos Ezquerra - who gave the judge his Greek-warrior crash helmet with medieval executioner's mask and Harley-Davidson motorbike - is worth between £200 and £1,000, and more if it is a colour page from an early episode by Dredd's top scriptwriter, John Wagner.

The work can be found in comic bookshops, at collectors' fairs, through mail auctions, on the internet, or direct from the artists.

I bought a page from Brett Ewins, who has drawn Dredd for 16 years. A fellow collector, the animator Rufus Dayglo, showed me his treasure trove of 2,000 originals, mostly by fellow Dredd artists.

Some of Dayglo's prized pieces will be shown in the exhibition, 'Art Droids 2000AD', in the Henry Cole wing of the V&A from 31 May to 2 September.

The works' potential value to collectors lies in the intrinsic quality of the art and in Dredd's growing reputation as an icon of popular culture.

The British art that brought Dredd to life was more flamboyant than the staid realism of American comic book art. It was - still is - cinema compared with their photography, full of explosions of action and clever tricks using perspective and light.

Dredd's artists were perfectionists, spending up to two days on a page, for which they were paid peanuts. Small wonder that in the Eighties, American publishers began to poach them. Most were lured towards other publications, other heroes. Bolland, for example, found himself drawing Batman in the American publish DC Comics' 1988 graphic novel The Killing Joke. But the art they left behind tells the story of their burgeoning reputations, and this is enhancing its value.

The granite-jawed judge, who continues to enforce the law weekly in 2,000AD, has a mythic status in popular culture that is likely to equal that of Superman.

Unlike Superman and Batman, he is not a sanctimonious do-gooder. He is a nasty character, lucky to have the law on his side. He is a product of unsettled times when there was popular demand for authoritarian political leadership.

When Judge Dredd was thought up in 1977 by Pat Mills, then editor of 2000AD, unemployment and inflation in Britain were rising, the unions were dominant, mugging was a new word and Margaret Thatcher was two years away from becoming Prime Minister.

Dredd, conceived as a future cop who shoots people for dropping litter, is the most feared of a regime of genetically selected judges handing out instant justice to the bored, anarchic, mostly unemployed population of 400 million in a 2122AD New York, called Mega-City One.

For him, democracy is 'a cancer eating at the heart of our society'. He says people 'need rules to live by - I provide them. They break the rules, I break them.'

Wagner has at times tempered Dredd's rigid intolerance with a touch of self-doubt, even mercy. He is blessed too with self-parody.

Brett Ewins, who was taught fine art at Goldsmiths College by Michael Craig-Martin, who also tutored Damien Hirst, says: 'Dredd made a mockery of science fiction. He was really quite satirical, even camp. We satirised big corporations, including fast food, and nearly ended up in court with McDonald's.'

Which may help to explain why Dredd artwork prices have yet to take off in the US: most Americans' sense of humour does not extend to pastiche. But US collectors are becoming more sophisticated, and Dredd has all the makings of a new Superman for intelligent adults.

Among the work Ewins is offering for sale are two Dredd stories drawn for the 1978 and 1979 2000AD annuals. One is nine pages in black and white, priced at £450. The other, eight colour pages, costs £800. When he drew them, artists were fighting to have their names published and his pay was only £30 a page.

I bought from him, for £50, an early page of his Bad Company space-war series, written by Pete Milligan, also a Goldsmiths graduate, which is still running in 2000AD. My page illustrates the potent early influence on Dredd artists of the British war comics of the Sixties and Seventies.

Bad Company was launched as a comic in 1988 by Ewins, Milligan and Jim McCarthy, brother of Brendan, a Dredd artist. Milligan, who, thanks to an introduction by Ewins, made his comic debut writing the Rogue Trooper story in 2000AD, now scripts Hollywood movies.

Ewins and Steve Dillon, another Dredd artist, founded Deadline the same year. It ran for seven years, and is now a collector's item. Ewins is offering for £500 the original colour cover of the first issue, featuring the sexy, shaven-headed heroine Tank Girl, set Down Under. Australians may detect a note of mockery. Tank Girl was conceived and drawn by Jamie Hewlett, who was discovered studying at an art school, where Ewins was teaching.

Such interwoven biographies add provenance to original artwork. It does help to know, when buying Dredd artwork, that Mel Gibson has bought the TV rights to another Milligan-Ewins-Dillon character, the detective Johnny Nemo.

Ewins' next venture is a limited-edition comic book, Station to Station, aimed at the collectors' market, and featuring Frankie Stein, precursor of the punk cult, drawn by Ewins and written by Stein himself.

Rufus Dayglo says: 'Occasionally, I've paid too much for artwork, but only because I liked it.' He paid £2,500 for the 16-page colour Dredd story 'The Vampire Effect', from the 1982 2000AD annual. It was 'one of the best pieces of artwork I've seen'. See it at the V&A.

 For details of comic fairs and artwork for sale, see the monthly magazine Comic International (subscriptions 01621 877 231). Brett Ewins: admin@brettewins.co.uk. Artwork is sold at Comic Book Postal Auctions (020-7424 0007) and Vault Comic Auctions.

webTitle: Save your boss £50,000. Tell him to set up a pension

fields.headline: Save your boss £50,000. Tell him to set up a pension
fields.standfirst: Firms are muddled over stakeholders, says Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Firms are muddled over stakeholders, says Maria Scott.
fields.body:
If you work for a company that has at least five staff and has made no moves towards setting up a pension scheme, approach your boss now. You may even earn yourself a bonus by saving your company a hefty fine.

These firms must designate one of the new stakeholder pension schemes for their workforce by 8 October if they do not have a company pension scheme.

A leading firm of pensions advisers warned last week that employers that had not started preparing already risk missing the deadline and landing fines of up to £50,000. In some circumstances managers, including payroll staff, could face personal fines of up to £5,000.

Around 400,000 companies are expected to be affected by the new legislation. They are increasingly aware of their obligations, though a poll by Prudential published last week showed that 17 per cent of them had no intention of offering a scheme, or were unsure of whether they would.

Another survey, by Marks & Spencer, showed that two thirds of small businesses had yet to take action, though 44 per cent wrongly believed the deadline for offering a scheme was last Friday.

Ian Greenstreet, a pensions lawyer with Hammond Suddards Edge, said that despite the rule about firms with five employees, there was no legal definition of an employee so companies with large numbers of temporary workers might need advice to ensure they did not break the law.

The legislation will be policed by the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority (Opra), which will rely heavily on reports by whistle-blowing employees, rather than [doing] active checking for compliance', an official said.

Employers are required to designate a scheme for their workers and arrange for contributions to be deducted from the payroll, but they do not have to contribute.

Companies face fines of up to £50,000 for failing to comply with the legislation but Greenstreet says that directors and even payroll managers can be fined up to £5,000 if the failure to offer a scheme is deemed to be due to a breach of duty, neglect or connivance. Managers, however, cannot be fined if the company has been already penalised.

webTitle: Want a tax break? Be a sperm donor

fields.headline: Want a tax break? Be a sperm donor
fields.trailText: Highly-paid employees who bump up their incomes with freelance earnings will be able to use the stakeholder pension to boost their retirement fund.
fields.body:
Highly-paid employees who bump up their incomes with freelance earnings will be able to use the stakeholder pension to boost their retirement fund. A firm of financial advisers, Torquil Clark, has spotted a loophole in the stakeholder rules that will benefit better-paid employees. The adviser has dubbed the stakeholder the 'sperm donor's pension' because sperm donation is one of the 'freelance' activities it says male employees could do to qualify for the tax break.

Those earning £30,000 a year or more from salaried work, but who are paid as little as £1 a year from freelance work can start a stakeholder scheme. They can put £2,808 a year in, which will be bumped up to £3,600 by tax breaks. Higher rate taxpayers can claim an additional £648.

The stakeholder rules prohibit employees earning more than £30,000 from putting money into both a stakeholder plan and a company pension, but people in this position could qualify for the tax break by taking on freelance work.

On this basis, Torquil Clark says sperm donation could qualify as a freelance occupation, along with car washing, gardening, even giving directions to someone in the street in return for a £1 fee.

The Inland Revenue confirms that this loophole exists. But Torquil Clark believes it could be closed. It calculates that it could cost up to £1 billion in extra tax relief.

Tom McPhail of Torquil Clark says: 'I think we have a case of the law of unexpected consequence.'

The huge potential of stakeholder pensions as a tax break for people outside the Government's original target group was further underlined last week when insurer Standard Life said it had opened a plan for a four-month-old baby. Stakeholders can be bought by parents and grandparents for children and Standard Life said it believed baby India Woodhams (right) was the first person in the UK to have opened a new stakeholder pension. Her parents, who live in west London, took out the policy on the advice of India's grandfather, who works for the financial services arm of stockbroker Greig Middleton.

webTitle: Maria Scott: New pensions a bad deal for women

fields.headline: New pensions a bad deal for women
fields.trailText: Stakeholders, supposedly the last word in pension planning, have been dismissed as sexist.
fields.body:
Stakeholders, supposedly the last word in pension planning, have been dismissed as sexist.

Oonagh McDonald, head of an organisation campaigning for pension reform, has complained to the Equal Opportunities Commission about the low returns women stand to get from stakeholder pensions, compared with men. Women live longer than men on average so annuities - which will provide income from stakeholders - pay less. Women might be nearly £1,000 a year worse off.

At present 90 per cent of annuities are bought by men, but the balance will alter in future as more women build their own pension funds. Men are catching up because women's life expectancy - with all those high-pressure jobs - is not lengthening at the same rate as men's. And experts in this area forecast that were women and men to get the same deal now, both would probably see rates fall.

The Government has conducted a half-hearted review of annuities, which are also under a cloud because of their generally low rates and the fact that they normally die with the purchaser. But a wider review is necessary to clear the air.

If the industry was able to prove that rates for men and women will eventually fall naturally into line women might feel slightly easier about committing themselves to a stakeholder pen sion. But McDonald has highlighted a flaw in the package being sold to women through the stakeholder. There are already enough hurdles to cross on the road to a pension - low inflation, stretched budgets, erratic incomes - without the added knowledge that you will do worse than your husband or male colleagues. Women might shun stakeholders or save elsewhere, so they keep their options open.

Equal annuity rates for men and women would rely on a pooling of risk between the sexes. Unfortunately, the call for equalised rates comes at a time when sharing of risk is unfashionable in the insurance industry. If insurers had their way, genetic tests would consign certain groups to the insurance scrap heap.

The Treasury Select Committee that has just reported on genetic testing recommends, quite reasonably, that the industry and the Government should be considering new ways to protect the losers.
