fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on Writings on an Ethical Life by Peter Singer, Whisper of the Blade by Erik Durschmied, and Outcasts of the Islands by Sebastian Hope
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on Writings on an Ethical Life by Peter Singer, Whisper of the Blade by Erik Durschmied, and Outcasts of the Islands by Sebastian Hope
fields.body:
Writings on an Ethical Life
Peter Singer
(Fourth Estate, £15)

You know that Singer, a founder of the movement known as "animal liberation", must be doing something right when his critics stoop to outright misrepresentations, as did a certain fox-hunting ginger philosophe recently. This greatest-hits volume is a good opportunity to get it from the horse's mouth. Nor is it untimely: the claim by British agribusiness that the slaughter of millions of healthy cows and sheep is an "animal welfare issue" looks, if possible, even more risibly Laputan in the glare of his logic. Singer's foundational claim is that species is not an ethically substantive difference. Causing animals to suffer is not OK just because they are non-human animals: you'd better have some other good reason. This leads to notoriously bold questions: might it be preferable to save the life of an adult gorilla rather than that of a severely brain-damaged human infant? We also get Singer's rigorous views on charity and abortion. He can often seem to be congratulating himself just for thinking the unthinkable, but at least he's thinking, rather than guzzling wine and whingeing about the loss of a purely imaginary Albion.

Whisper of the Blade
Erik Durschmied
(Hodder, £14.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Durschmied's species of popular history mixes widescreen pans with close-up dirt, blood and foible - his The Hinge Factor was a clever application of pseudo-chaotic micro-causality to military crises (in effect, the beating of a butterfly's wings may change the course of an empire). The current romp considers the bloody lives of revolutionaries - Robespierre; Pancho Villa; Che Guevara and Fidel Castro; Trotsky, Lenin and Stalin. In style it is reminiscent of a good literary thriller. No grand theory; just good storytelling.

Outcasts of the Islands
Sebastian Hope
(HarperCollins, £17.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

When Hope first saw South East Asia on a map, he decided, like the young Charlie Marlow gazing at Africa, that one day he would go there. This engaging travelogue recounts his life among the nomadic fishermen of that region, known as Sea Gypsies. Hope befriends and lives on a boat with a fisherman called Sarani, and his anecdotes range from the alarming to the pleasingly comic. "No, of course the boat does not have a ghost," Sarani replies in irritation to Hope's naive questioning. A liberating breeze of salt air riffles the pages, but the Conradian promise of his title is left unfulfilled by the occasionally sentimental narration.

webTitle: Audio: The Life and Works of Beethoven, written and read by Jeremy Siepmann

fields.headline: The Life and Works of Beethoven, written and read by Jeremy Siepmann
fields.standfirst:
(Naxos, £11.99, 300mn)
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: Naxos is uniquely fortunate among audiobook producers in being able to plunder the other half of the business, the Naxos music catalogue
fields.body: Naxos is uniquely fortunate among audiobook producers in being able to plunder the other half of the business, the Naxos music catalogue. But how should it use this wonderful resource - by sticking to a straight biography, with musical punctuation, of a fascinating character, or by a solid stab at analysing Beethoven's developing art for the general listener? When he sticks to biography - troubled youth, Heiligenstadt Testament, eccentricities, deafness etc - Siepmann is fine. But instead of some simple account of the music and method, he falls back on the old tosh about wrestling with fate and the "moral" nature of Beethoven's oeuvre. Presumably this is for fear of deterring the general listener, which is a pity. The four cassettes are decently doused in the music. The carload of kids I was driving became frantically excited at Jeno Jando's vigorous Appassionata finale.

fields.headline: Back to the bard
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at Shakespeare's Language by Frank Kermode, and Trimble by Henry McDonald
fields.body:
Shakespeare's Language
Frank Kermode
(Penguin, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the 1970s and 1980s, Kermode was literary criticism's equivalent of a trendy bishop, hanging out with post-structuralists and other Gauloises-smoking outlaws. Now, as a retired prof, he has put the years of living dangerously behind him and returned to his style of 50 years ago: that of a trad Renaissance specialist. Thoroughly old-fashioned in method, Shakespeare's Language marginalises the modish concerns of new historicism and feminism as "secondary" to appreciating and evaluating the Bard's dramatic poetry. Fascinated by the increasing obscurity of the tragedies and late romances, it's entertainingly ready to harrumph that he sometimes simply wrote bad verse.

Trimble
Henry McDonald
(Bloomsbury, £8.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This impressive biography is particularly good on David Trimble's political roots among the "Reservoir Prods" of atavistic ultra-loyalism, beginning with the young law don plotting with paramilitaries in the 1970s Vanguard Movement and culminating in the infamous 1995 Drumcree victory jig with Ian Paisley. Just three years later he would be campaigning against his former core supporters for a referendum "Yes" vote, equally symbolically holding hands with John Hume and Bono. McDonald illuminatingly compares him to John Major, who similarly became a hate-figure for the right-wingers who were his original backers.

fields.headline: Haunted angel
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery looks at Miss Garnet's Angel by  Salley Vickers, The Question Of Bruno by Aleksandar Hemon, Caught by Henry Green, and Gimme More by Liza Cody
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at Miss Garnet's Angel by Salley Vickers, The Question Of Bruno by Aleksandar Hemon, Caught by Henry Green, and Gimme More by Liza Cody
fields.body:
Miss Garnet's Angel
Salley Vickers
(HarperCollins, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Julia Garnet, all her life a teacher, is left stranded on retirement by the sudden death of Harriet (her companion, not lover). She has the shape, the air and the biography of a Brookner heroine as she sets tentatively off to Venice to live a little. Vickers is, however, unexpectedly generous to Miss Garnet, allowing her to step out of her rented flat in the Campo Angelo Raphaelo to embrace Venice and friendship, and to discover the Zoroastrian underpinnings of the Apocryphal story of Tobias and Raphael. Vickers writes plainly, effectively and warmly. Her heroine is a wonderful snub to publishing's current belief that the over-35s are not worth writing for or about.

The Question Of Bruno
Aleksandar Hemon
(Picador, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Hemon was born in Bosnia, went to the US in 1991, and taught himself to write in English. When fiction crosses the Danube, critics scratching for a suitable adjective to describe Eastern European otherness go for "Nabokovian" or hint at kinship with Kundera. Hemon gets compared to both on the cover of his first collection of short stories. As he writes in artifice-rich prose about loss, exile, and the peculiar tangles of Balkan history (Tito, Stalin and Archduke Ferdinand), those comparisons make sense. He excels at that superficially unserious style that communism bred, but some may find his stylistic gymnastics and clotted prose unsettling.

Caught
Henry Green
(Harvill, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

One of a quartet of "London" novels republished by Harvill, Green's book is more curiosity than essential read. It is set during the Blitz and centres on Richard Roe, a diffident man who comes to London from a well-heeled country estate to volunteer for the Auxiliary Fire Service. Roe, the archetypal, tight-lipped English widower, who "wished that he had never made a point of not kissing Christopher", his five-year-old son, is contrasted with the professional fireman, Pye. Neither the war as whole, nor even the Blitz, impinges much on the narrative - both men are frighteningly at sea in personal emotional anguish - but fear hangs like a pall over this sombre novel.

Gimme More
Liza Cody
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Birdie is a composite of every real and mythical rock girlfriend - a little bit of Marianne meets Angie and Courtney - yet now widowed and wrinkled, she still knows how to take on the industry suits and hang on to her cut. When Dog Records come sniffing after a film and demo that her lover, Jack, supposedly made before his death, she plays it "like the cobra coiled round the treasure chest". Rock'n'roll doesn't usually transfer well to the page, but this thriller is carried by the ultra-cynical voice of Birdie and Cody's ability to create fictional lyrics, gigs and bands that won't make you wince.

fields.headline: Life sentence
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  reads Martin Amis's Experience from behind the sofa
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard reads Martin Amis's Experience from behind the sofa
fields.body:
Experience
Martin Amis
(Vintage, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

One hesitates to give this book more publicity, after this newspaper's decision to reproduce its cover on the front page (my children find it particularly compelling, staring in disbelief at the fag, half the size of his face, in the young Amis's gob), and after Amis's recent calumnies against my profession (again, in this paper); but affecting not to notice it would be signally perverse. It is possibly Amis's best book; it is also necessary.

There are times when it appears gloriously ill-advised. Five years ago, his vicissitudes were the stuff of that degrading kind of public debate the press in this country specialise in: the teeth, the mistress, the money, the agent. But mainly the money. We were beginning to forget about all that (the national stupidity has its compensatory benefits), and here he comes raking it all up again, an almost aggressive defence of what hardly needed, if we all thought about it, to be defended. The part of the book I find the most fascinating, yet also the one that I want to read through half-closed fingers, hiding behind the sofa, as it were, from the spectacle of my own prurience, is where he deals with the end of his friendship with Julian Barnes. He quotes the entire text of his reply to Barnes's letter to him, the one which ended with the words "fuck off". He then writes:

"For the first time in these pages I sense the twist of rancour in me, and my hands, as I write, feel loath and cold. But I had to assert it, to my readers, and also to my friends. It was said that I turned away - and I don't do that. I won't be the one to turn away."

A few things might strike you on reading this, once you recover from the hot flush of embarrassment at having read something so private (and which, moreover, will eventually be read by who knows how many thousands of others). I suggest: a kind of awe at the risky showmanship of his very prose style; the feeling that he and Julian probably aren't going to make it up now; and the great lengths to which he will go in order to satisfy his readers, who here are given priority over his friends. You should consider yourselves honoured.

But that isn't the heart, or even the sinews of Experience . That would be two things, the most directly stimulating, for Amis, being the discovery that his cousin, Lucy Partington, had been one of the victims of Frederick West. That this emerged at around the time of all the other rubbish about his private life - during the period when everyone was being told to hate him - can't have made matters any more bearable.

Then there is the strange fact that he is, on top of everything else, Kingsley Amis's son. Or, more accurately, everything else is on top of that. As a memoir of the man, it is poignant, honest (a word to Kingsley, on hearing his judgment on Mandela: "your views would get you chucked out of a bar called the Kaffir-Flogger"), and, it should hardly need to be said, painfully funny. This kinship has placed him at the centre of this country's literary vortex for the last quarter of a century; the extraordinary thing is that, at the same time, he has the talent and the ability to be the best possible candidate for such a position. In one sense, this isn't even a book: it's an event. What a relief that it's as well-written as it is.

It is possibly Amis's best book; it is also necessary. There are times when it appears gloriously ill-advised. Five years ago, his vicissitudes were the stuff of that degrading kind of public debate the press in this country specialise in: the teeth, the mistress, the money, the agent. But mainly the money. We were beginning to forget about all that (the national stupidity has its compensatory benefits), and here he comes raking it all up again, an almost aggressive defence of what hardly needed, if we all thought about it, to be defended. The part of the book I find the most fascinating, yet also the one that I want to read through half-closed fingers, hiding behind the sofa, as it were, from the spectacle of my own prurience, is where he deals with the end of his friendship with Julian Barnes. He quotes the entire text of his reply to Barnes's letter to him, the one which ended with the words "fuck off". He then writes: "For the first time in these pages I sense the twist of rancour in me, and my hands, as I write, feel loath and cold. But I had to assert it, to my readers, and also to my friends. It was said that I turned away - and I don't do that. I won't be the one to turn away." A few things might strike you on reading this, once you recover from the hot flush of embarrassment at having read something so private (and which, moreover, will eventually be read by who knows how many thousands of others). I suggest: a kind of awe at the risky showmanship of his very prose style; the feeling that he and Julian probably aren't going to make it up now; and the great lengths to which he will go in order to satisfy his readers, who here are given priority over his friends. You should consider yourselves honoured. But that isn't the heart, or even the sinews of Experience . That would be two things, the most directly stimulating, for Amis, being the discovery that his cousin, Lucy Partington, had been one of the victims of Frederick West. That this emerged at around the time of all the other rubbish about his private life - during the period when everyone was being told to hate him - can't have made matters any more bearable. Then there is the strange fact that he is, on top of everything else, Kingsley Amis's son. Or, more accurately, everything else is on top of that. As a memoir of the man, it is poignant, honest (a word to Kingsley, on hearing his judgment on Mandela: "your views would get you chucked out of a bar called the Kaffir-Flogger"), and, it should hardly need to be said, painfully funny. This kinship has placed him at the centre of this country's literary vortex for the last quarter of a century; the extraordinary thing is that, at the same time, he has the talent and the ability to be the best possible candidate for such a position. In one sense, this isn't even a book: it's an event. What a relief that it's as well-written as it is.

fields.headline: The Eavesdroppers
fields.trailText:
There are no trains this afternoon.

Nothing is coming

From under the second-hand bathwater sky...
fields.body:
There are no trains this afternoon.
Nothing is coming
From under the second-hand bathwater sky,
Through the zinc-tasting air,
Over the low hum of half-expectation
That hangs at knee-height where the tracks run away
Past frosty docks and groundsel
At the unadopted edges of allotments.
The clocks have shut down.
Deep in the roofing-felt shanties,
Sputtering quietly next to the kettles
The old gadgeesÍ transistors explain
That the racingÍs abandoned
And this is our chance ïto enjoy once again
The remarkable day in 1957 when EnglandÍ click -
No trains. But this end of the city
Is lending an ear - ïhousewives and the unemployedÍ,
The idle student eking out his blow,
The morticianÍs receptionist
Bent to her Angela Carter
(A slow day for death), and me doing this.
Never think nobody cares
For that thundery corridor
Painting its Forth into Scotland and back,
For the drizzly grind of the coal-train
Or even the Metro, that amateur transport,
Sparking and chattering every verse-end.
Where and for that matter who
Can we be without them and the world
They continually carry away,
To which, now itÍs silent, we find
We have spent our lives listening?

webTitle: A life in writing: Donna Leon

fields.headline: Going incognito in Italy
fields.standfirst: Donna Leon tells Peter Kingston why she prefers to bask in anonymity
fields.trailText: Donna Leon tells Peter Kingston why she prefers to bask in anonymity
fields.body:
Next year, the residents of Pellestrina, a tiny fishing village on the thin tongue of land between Venice and the sea, are in for a shock, particularly the folk who run the main restaurant. Proud though they are of their grub, they will wonder at the sudden flocks of German and Austrian tourists crossing the lagoon looking for a table.

The answer lies in A Sea of Troubles , the 10th in Donna Leon's series of thrillers starring Commissario Guido Brunetti, which will come out in German translation in summer 2002. It is set in Pellestrina, where the Venetian detective solves the murders of two clam fisherman. And naturally, he takes his lunch seriously.

The real Pellestrinesi won't appreciate all this, because not a word of Leon's best-selling series has been translated into Italian. The books sell very well in Austria, Germany, and the UK - the ninth book, Friends in High Places , is now out here in paperback - but she doesn't want them published in Italy, the country that has become her home - surely an odd stipulation.

Leon, a slight, lean salt-and- pepper-haired American in her late 50s, laughs. "Because I don't want to be famous where I live. Nobody in Venice knows who I am. My neighbours know I'm Signora Leon. My friends know I write but they don't read it. Nobody has any idea of the extent of the success."

It has all been rather accidental. The idea for her first book, Death at La Fenice (1992) came while chatting to the conductor Gabriele Ferro at the Venetian opera house. He was badmouthing the German maestro von Karajan for his fascist sympathies. "We started talking about killing von Karajan and I thought: 'What a great idea for a murder mystery.'"

For her detective hero, Brunetti, an intellectual whose favourite reading is Xenophon, she borrowed a name that had caught her eye on a tombstone on Venice's cemetery island. But the novel lay in a drawer for two years. "I'm absolutely without ambition," Leon explains. A friend nagged, so she entered it for the 1991 Japanese Suntory crime fiction competition, and won.

HarperCollins snapped it up and gave her a contract for two more. "They published my first five books so badly that it wrecked my chance of a US career." Authors often blame publishers for sluggish sales, but she is adamant that those American editions did so poorly compared with the millions notched up in Europe because of shoddy production. "They were cheap and vulgar, but what would you expect from America?"

It's a shock to hear an American trash her native land, even one who has been expatriate most of her life and makes the old distinction about being a New Yorker, not an American. "I could never live in America. It's cheap and vulgar. Its politics disgust me. Its role in the world disgusts me. They are people obsessed with the acquisition of increasingly meaningless objects."

Since the age of 23, after a doctoral thesis on Jane Austen, she has taught English language and literature abroad in Switzerland, China, Saudi Arabia and Iran, which she left as its revolution began. She moved to Italy, this time working for the University of Maryland, which had the contract to teach degree programmes in all American military bases in Europe.

On settling in Venice, she quickly became part of her best friend's extended family in the city. "I live there because it is paradise. It's the only place I want to live, the only place I feel at home. I think looking good is important and I like to eat." Most contacts in life are superficial, she argues. "So why not have them be superficial and pretty?"

Her recreations are Italian: strolling about the city and chatting. And that, she says, has been the extent of her research, talking and listening to Italian friends for 35 years. Most of her characters' "unexamined prejudices" are typical Italian views - "The government is corrupt, the police is corrupt, the Mafia runs everything; these filter over the dinner table to me or across the chink of the cappuccino. Most of my friends in Italy believe this is true, they just can't prove it."

Brunetti is an honest cop. But when he solves his cases, few people end up in choky (although a few get mysteriously "blown away"). Nor can he expect public cooperation, relying on calling in favours and on family contacts more than on getting a decent witness statement from a cynical population.

She has asked Italians who have read the books in German or English if she has got things right. "They say: 'It's not only right but it's very creepy that somebody who isn't Italian can know so much.'"

Through no strict daily work regime she produces a book a year. She writes when she feels like it, usually finishing a scene at a sitting. Her one rule is always to start the next scene before she switches her computer off.

Wealth means no longer having to teach. It also allows more time for reading and for satisfying her other passion, baroque opera, of which she sees three or four productions a month. She will go anywhere to catch a decent Handel opera, planning years ahead. She has already got her name down for Rodalinda with Renee Fleming in New York in 2004.

Italian government and institutions, as she sees them, are hardly superior to the American ones she so dislikes. And is the meaningless consumerism in the US really worse than the Italian obsessions with clothes and food?

"I'm a puritan recidivist. Occasionally I find myself taking a dim view of some of their excesses, but I know in my heart that they are right and I'm wrong."

webTitle: Review: States of Denial by Stanley Cohen

fields.headline: Everyday atrocities
fields.standfirst: Victoria Brittain  discovers how we live with horrors in States of Denial: Knowing About Atrocities and Suffering by Stanley Cohen
fields.trailText: Victoria Brittain discovers how we live with horrors in States of Denial: Knowing About Atrocities and Suffering by Stanley Cohen
fields.body:
States of Denial: Knowing About Atrocities and Suffering
Stanley Cohen
355pp, Polity, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As a child in 1950s Johannesburg, Stanley Cohen saw from his bedroom window the old Zulu man employed as a "Night Watch Boy" huddled over his charcoal fire, rubbing his hands together to keep warm. Why, the child wondered as he slipped between his grandmother's flannel sheets, brought from Poland, did the old man have to sit out there? "Why had our family (and everyone like us) been allocated black men and women (who were called 'boys' and 'girls' or just 'natives') as domestic servants? Where were their wives, husbands and children?" As he lay under his cosy eiderdown, Cohen began the thought process that led to this troubling book.

With ideas like these lurking in his child's mind it is hardly surprising that as an adult Cohen did not live in apartheid South Africa. There was no easy answer to his other obsessive question: "Why did others, even those raised in similar families, schools and neighbourhoods, who read the same papers, walked the same streets, apparently not 'see' what we saw? Could they be living in another perceptual universe - where the horrors of apartheid were invisible and the physical presence of black people often slipped from awareness?"

The same obsession (the word is Professor Cohen's own) haunted him when, in the 1980s, he went to live in Israel after 20 years in Britain. He soon found that the liberal peace movement he had assumed would be his home was not an arena where he could exist in intellectual comfort; his place was on the far-left margins. He began to work on human-rights issues, in particular torture, and had to ask himself whether Israel was a uniquely horrible society in accepting that torture was normal: predictable, not news, and no cause for outrage.

But he could not escape what he knew of the universality of everyday horror well beyond South Africa and Israel: genocide in Rwanda, murders of street children in Brazil, children starving to death in Somalia, a civilisation destroyed in Iraq courtesy of the United Nations, women raped as part of the war strategy in the Balkans, and so much more. His old preoccupations were back: how do people react to unwelcome knowledge, and particularly to knowledge about atrocities? And how do the victims and the perpetrators see these atrocities?

States of Denial is based on hundreds of theoretical references in sociology and psychology, woven together with both private and public experience of how "the past comes back to haunt you", as Archbishop Desmond Tutu described the clinical and political effect of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

Looking at the perpetrators of atrocities - from Nazi Germany to apartheid South Africa via the years of military dictatorship in South America - Cohen notes acidly "the unedifying ways in which most people comply with authority". Denial of responsibility inevitably follows one of four paths: obedience to superiors, conformity with society, necessity or splitting of the personality. He quotes Hannah Arendt's claims that the mendacity of Eichmann's character was integral to the whole of German society, shielding it from reality. Similarly, the 1968 My Lai massacre in Vietnam was, for the ease of American consciences, defined as a crime of obedience. Individual responsibility and morality are minimised.

Cohen wants more troubling information made available to more people. "Someone has to inform us exactly how many children in the world are still dying of measles, are conscripted as 12-year-olds into killer militias, are sold by their families into child prostitution, are beaten to death by their parents."

In the central argument he draws from this review of horrors that ordinary people find it possible to live with, Cohen is original, wise and essentially optimistic. He believes that denial is the normal state of affairs, and that what he calls "the Oxfam/Amnesty view", in which the outsider is asked to take action, is the exception. "Why people don't shut out is more interesting than why they shut out."

Looking at why, for instance, individuals in Europe helped Jews during the Nazi period despite the tremendous risks, he identifies the common factor behind their altruism. The helpers had, spontaneously, a sense of self as part of a common humanity, which he calls "inclusivity". Cohen looks towards a practical utopia where "a deep shame of passivity" would become a mobilising norm of social life. He dreams of a global community in which "the obligation to assist others in danger or distress was a powerful imperative". There are, of course, such communities in the world, but because they are rural and premodern they are usually invisible to the "global community".

webTitle: Review: Them: Adventures with Extremists by Jon Ronson

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.standfirst: Are 12ft lizards running the world? Louis Theroux investigates Them: Adventures with Extremists by Jon Ronson
fields.trailText: Are 12ft lizards running the world? Louis Theroux investigates Them: Adventures with Extremists by Jon Ronson
fields.body:
Them: Adventures with Extremists
Jon Ronson
352pp, Picador, £16.99

There is a version of history that holds that the world is secretly run by a shadowy cabal of predominantly Jewish international financiers and politicians who meet several times a year to decide which wars to start, which countries to bankrupt, which gun-owners to oppress, and so on. This view, which has been around at least since the late 19th century, when it was popularised in a hugely influential piece of anti-semitic propaganda, The Protocols of the Elders of Zion , exists in various versions - with “Jews” occasionally being replaced by “Bilderbergers”, “New World Order”, “Illuminati” or “12ft lizard creatures”. Though undoubtedly nutty, its paranoid and exciting “top secret” flavour has meant it continues to appeal to a motley crew of self-styled “researchers” and evangelists on the fringes of society, including Ku Klux Klansmen, militias, certain fundamentalist Muslims and an ex-Coventry goalkeeper called David Icke.

For Them: Adventures with Extremists , reporter and documentary film-maker Jon Ronson spent several years in the company of a few of these fringe-dwellers, in an attempt to understand their mindset and to see to what - if any - extent their fears were founded in fact. The resulting book is a funny and compulsively readable picaresque adventure through a paranoid shadow world, with Ronson playing Sancho Panza to a cast of obsessives. Ronson has a deft, ironic touch and a brilliant way with scene-setting and direct speech - much of the action is so neat and pacy it reads almost like a novel - and it is one of the book’s great merits that it never takes itself too seriously. Conspiracy investigators tend to be incompetent and petty in direct proportion to the delusional grandeur of their ambitions, something Ronson is not slow to pick up on. “I KNOW WHAT YOU’RE UP TO!” one investigator screams at his colleague. “Make a big show of shouting down the phone! Steal the limelight! And then Jon will write about you !”

In one of the book’s funniest chapters, Ronson accompanies an ultra-right-wing conspiracy investigator named Big Jim Tucker as he attempts to infiltrate a meeting of the Bilderberg Group (a semi-secret council of international industrialists and statesmen, and a favourite bugbear of the paranoid fringe). They end up being chased by scary-looking security personnel in dark glasses and Ronson panics, trying to get the British Embassy to rescue him. “I am essentially a humorous journalist,” he pleads down the phone. “I am a humorous journalist out of my depth.”

But Ronson also has a point to make about the way beliefs in general tend to demonise “them”, where “them” might be diabolical Jews, 12ft lizards, or indeed the weirdos who believe in diabolical Jews and 12ft lizards. Exhibit A in the fringe-dwellers’ case for the existence of a shadowy all-powerful cabal is the true-life story of the Weavers, a family with admittedly far-out religious views who, yes, consorted with neo-Nazis and who moved to the remotest corner of northern Idaho to be as far as possible from the “Zionist Occupational Government”. Vicki Weaver and her son Sammy were shot in cold blood by federal marshals in a paramilitary-style raid. Conspiracy theorists have ever since argued that this is proof that the world is indeed run by a secret oligarchy; Ronson’s compelling case is that what happened was made possible because the Weavers were repeatedly described in the media as “white supremacists” and therefore in some way worthy of extermination.

Another chapter examines the strange history of David Icke, the footballer turned BBC commentator turned Green Party spokesman turned self-proclaimed son of God. Ronson finds Icke on a lecture tour of Canada, pursuing his new calling as an investigator of the secret elite of lizard shape-shifters (the Queen and Ted Heath are among those under suspicion) who run the world. Icke’s “theory” is basically The Protocols of the Elders of Zion with a new cast and a few script changes. Not surprisingly, Icke has come under suspicion of anti-semitism; as his tour progresses he finds his readings heavily picketed and his radio interviews cancelled. Icke vehemently repudiates the accusations, and reading Ronson’s account it is difficult not to conclude that, while we are right to be on our guard against paranoid anti-semitism, we should also be on our guard against the paranoid excesses of anti-anti-semitism. Not only might it be unfair to Icke, but by implying that he is so dangerous that he has to be censored, the watchdogs are giving a patina of seriousness to ideas that are - let’s face it - very, very silly.

As the book progresses, what emerges is the degree to which the real-life Bilderberg Group and the researchers who campaign against it are negatives of each other. Intentionally or not, the alleged bodies of world domination do create suspicion and resentment with their cloak-and-dagger mentality, their self-importance and their alarmism. It is no surprise to learn that some Bilderbergers quite like the idea that they are secretly running the world: it flatters their vanity. Towards the end of his investigation, Ronson finds himself referred to approvingly on the internet and in underground newspapers by fringe researchers and New World Order believers. He suggests he has passed through the looking glass and is now “one of them”. I think this is going a little far. If pressed, and for all its flaws, I’d say I’m on the side of the existing international liberal-democratic system and against the notion that lizards might be running the world, and I suspect Ronson feels the same way. Still, it is to his great credit that he’s given “them” such a fair-minded - and entertaining - evaluation.

Ronson has a deft, ironic touch and a brilliant way with scene-setting and direct speech - much of the action is so neat and pacy it reads almost like a novel - and it is one of the book’s great merits that it never takes itself too seriously. Conspiracy investigators tend to be incompetent and petty in direct proportion to the delusional grandeur of their ambitions, something Ronson is not slow to pick up on. “I KNOW WHAT YOU’RE UP TO!” one investigator screams at his colleague. “Make a big show of shouting down the phone! Steal the limelight! They end up being chased by scary-looking security personnel in dark glasses and Ronson panics, trying to get the British Embassy to rescue him. “I am essentially a humorous journalist,” he pleads down the phone. “I am a humorous journalist out of my depth.” But Ronson also has a point to make about the way beliefs in general tend to demonise “them”, where “them” might be diabolical Jews, 12ft lizards, or indeed the weirdos who believe in diabolical Jews and 12ft lizards. Exhibit A in the fringe-dwellers’ case for the existence of a shadowy all-powerful cabal is the true-life story of the Weavers, a family with admittedly far-out religious views who, yes, consorted with neo-Nazis and who moved to the remotest corner of northern Idaho to be as far as possible from the “Zionist Occupational Government”. Vicki Weaver and her son Sammy were shot in cold blood by federal marshals in a paramilitary-style raid. Conspiracy theorists have ever since argued that this is proof that the world is indeed run by a secret oligarchy; Ronson’s compelling case is that what happened was made possible because the Weavers were repeatedly described in the media as “white supremacists” and therefore in some way worthy of extermination. Another chapter examines the strange history of David Icke, the footballer turned BBC commentator turned Green Party spokesman turned self-proclaimed son of God. Ronson finds Icke on a lecture tour of Canada, pursuing his new calling as an investigator of the secret elite of lizard shape-shifters (the Queen and Ted Heath are among those under suspicion) who run the world. Icke’s “theory” is basically The Protocols of the Elders of Zion with a new cast and a few script changes. Not surprisingly, Icke has come under suspicion of anti-semitism; as his tour progresses he finds his readings heavily picketed and his radio interviews cancelled. Icke vehemently repudiates the accusations, and reading Ronson’s account it is difficult not to conclude that, while we are right to be on our guard against paranoid anti-semitism, we should also be on our guard against the paranoid excesses of anti-anti-semitism. Not only might it be unfair to Icke, but by implying that he is so dangerous that he has to be censored, the watchdogs are giving a patina of seriousness to ideas that are - let’s face it - very, very silly. As the book progresses, what emerges is the degree to which the real-life Bilderberg Group and the researchers who campaign against it are negatives of each other. Intentionally or not, the alleged bodies of world domination do create suspicion and resentment with their cloak-and-dagger mentality, their self-importance and their alarmism. It is no surprise to learn that some Bilderbergers quite like the idea that they are secretly running the world: it flatters their vanity. Towards the end of his investigation, Ronson finds himself referred to approvingly on the internet and in underground newspapers by fringe researchers and New World Order believers. He suggests he has passed through the looking glass and is now “one of them”. I think this is going a little far. If pressed, and for all its flaws, I’d say I’m on the side of the existing international liberal-democratic system and against the notion that lizards might be running the world, and I suspect Ronson feels the same way. Still, it is to his great credit that he’s given “them” such a fair-minded - and entertaining - evaluation.

webTitle: Review: Electric Light by Seamus Heaney

fields.headline: The view from Olympia
fields.standfirst:
In his new collection Electric Light, Seamus Heaney's poetic procedures are beginning to look like mannerisms, finds Robert Potts
Read Sonnets From Hellas
fields.trailText: In his new collection Electric Light, Seamus Heaney's poetic procedures are beginning to look like mannerisms, finds Robert Potts
fields.body:
Electric Light
Seamus Heaney
81pp, Faber, £14.99/£8.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In his Guardian review of Seamus Heaney's last collection, The Spirit Level (1996), Ian Sansom praised faintly, saying that it was "worth reading out of habit and affection". He described it as "a poetry that is so utterly reliable and reassuring that you just can't gainsay it: it's like motherhood and apple pie". Those who do complain about it, he continued, "always end up sounding churlish, short-tempered, jealous or mad". But there were some worried voices, sanely and politely stating their reservations about a writer who was monumental long before he was awarded the Nobel prize in 1995.

Monumentalism must carry its own burdens, of course. Yet at the risk of sounding churlish or mad, it has to be said that his new collection, Electric Light, exhibits more of the weaknesses that have been discerned, and fewer of the strengths, than any of his recent collections.

Heaney has always been a gift to the academic community, in that a "career" has been discernible from volume to volume. Critics love narratives of development as much as they love to pick out "major themes". Since Heaney's work has continually commented on itself, and also commented retrospectively on itself in the occasional revision or self-accusation (particularly in the sequence "Station Island"), this has made it easier to buttress the career narrative with quotes from the corpus.

Death of a Naturalist (1966), the outstanding debut that made Heaney's name, was a volume that - like Tony Harrison's early work - played off articulacy and literariness against the unbookish taciturnity of family and "tribe". Later, with North (1975) , the Troubles were tackled (unavoidably, given the period), for instance in the poem "Whatever You Say, Say Nothing", which some found too untransformatively journalistic, but which I still find as powerful as when I first read it:

The famous

Northern reticence, the tight gag of place

And times: yes, yes. Of the "wee six" I sing

Where to be saved you only must save face

And whatever you say, you say nothing.

Heaney pleased many readers by producing an apparently politicised poetry; he dismayed partisans by not taking a clear position; and he was praised for not polemicising or sloganeering by those (particularly, one notes, the British) who felt that while treatment of the subject was unavoidable, it was not a poet's job to analyse the situation, propose solutions, and sort the whole thing out.

North was a determining moment. He had been under vast pressure to take a stance on "the Irish thing", as he referred to it in the poem quoted above. He has written about that pressure ever since. In "Flight Path" (The Spirit Level), challenged by an IRA man ("when, for fuck's sake, are you going to write/ Something for us?"), he replies "if I do write something, I'll be writing for myself". That poem was published in 1996 but refers to the events of 1979 - "the gaol walls all that month were smeared with shite". Indeed they were, and two years later, Bobby Sands was the British MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone for all of a month, before he finally starved to death.

It's fair enough that Heaney had no obligation to write about such matters, directly or obliquely. His care, when writing about an Ireland of which the hunger strikes and sectarian killings are as much a part as the bogs and the old farming communities, is understandable: he wanted to be a poet, not the "Papish propagandist" that an Ulster newspaper dubbed him anyway. But when the political is introduced - in that pentameter about the H-Block prisoners, for example - it is only in the context of what Heaney will or will not say. The drama we perceive is that of his dilemma as a writer, not Northern Ireland; we are encouraged to worry as much about the role of the artist in a political situation as we are about the political situation itself.

His other approach to the subject, also much admired, was to find in the myths and bogs of Ireland metaphors and symbols of tribal violence. Critics who have accused him of ignoring the situa tion are easily refuted; those who find these symbols and metaphors ill-judged, too easily finding an artistic resolution of the acute and insoluble problem, are less easy to argue with. Here is poet Carol Rumens on Heaney's "Mycenae Lookout", a description of the Trojan War and peace which we are clearly invited to take as an oblique reference to the peace process in 1990s Northern Ireland: "As to whether it 'says something' about the political nightmare in Northern Ireland, the terms, as so often, seem too general. Perhaps readers and writers should be more wary of seeing such classical reworkings as 'fitting emblems' of any adversity but that of the original time and place."

Now, there is no shortage of self-criticism (or apparent self-criticism) in Heaney's work. In "Station Island", the dead cousin he years earlier memorialised in "The Strand at Lough Beg" ripostes: "You confused evasion and artistic tact . . . / I accuse you / . . . for the way you whitewashed ugliness and drew / the lovely blinds of the Purgatorio / and saccharined my death with morning dew". It's true, too: in the earlier poem, there were references to Sweeney and Dante, two of Heaney's favourite resources, and a cleansing image. In "Station Island", Heaney seems to accept the accusation (he doesn't answer back, and the poem is full of statements of guilt, self-loathing, apology), but in fact is released by the shade of Joyce, who tells him "don't be so earnest, // so ready for the sackcloth and the ashes. / Let go, let fly, forget."

And fly he does - into the metaphysical, away from all that soil and rural memory, away from that satisfying thickness of alliteration and onomatopoeia he brought to frogspawn, blackberries and peat. In Seeing Things (1991) and The Spirit Level (the punning titles express an equilibrium between material and spiritual that has become something of a trademark), Heaney discovered a desire to "credit marvels". The first poem in Electric Light spells this out again. We return to Toomebridge and, economically, Heaney reminds us of all that the place means to him: the borderline

Where the checkpoint used to be.

Where the rebel boy was hanged in '98.

Where negative ions in the open air

Are poetry to me. As once before

The slime and silver of the fattened eel.

Heaney's commentators are going to be hard-pressed to see this volume as a development in a career. It restates all Heaney's themes and approaches to date, and in doing so manages to make many of them look like mannerisms. Despite the earlier wrestle over how to write about sectarian murder, now "The Augean Stables" refers to a more recent murder, that of Sean Brown, a friend of Heaney's who was gunned down during the peace process by loyalist wreckers.

It only "refers" to the murder because the bulk of the poem is taken up with Greece, where Heaney heard the news - Olympia with its "green willows, the lustral wash and run of river shallows", and his "favourite bas-relief" of Athene showing Heracles where to divert the Alpheus to cleanse the Augean stables. The water images are actually associated with the murder only by Heaney's fortuitous presence in Olympia; they are then forcedly yoked with it by the image of Brown's blood being hosed off the tarmac outside a sports club. I may be alone in finding this employment of art and lyricism inappropriate and distasteful, and I may be alone in not finding the cleansing image of the myth any help at all when it comes to the political situation. This does not mean that I want Heaney to make a political statement, still less propose a solution; it is simply a question of how seriously Heaney took his self-accusation about "The Strand at Lough Beg".

Heaney, in this new collection, refers often to his literary and artistic models, mentors or favourites: Virgil, Dante, Beowulf (understandably, since he translated it), Patrick Kavanagh, Brodsky, Hughes, Zbigniew Herbert. The last three are elegised, and Brodsky's elegy is written in the metre with which Auden elegised Yeats. Disconcertingly, its first few stanzas discuss the metre before getting round to the man. (It is hardly a criticism to say that it is a pale shadow of the Auden, though the metrical lapse nine lines from the end is unfortunate.) The presence of the pantheon has become more observable in Heaney's corpus as he has been more securely placed in it himself. That is, Heaney - as a poet, teacher and academic - has always been interested in traditions, but now seems comfortably cosseted in them. They become emblems of instant authority.

As in "The Augean Stables", there is another troubling aspect to this, remarked upon before by critics: how Heaney, mythologising himself and his subjects, thrusts a borrowed significance onto them ("I woke to the world there like Telemachos"). Trying to make something freshly significant out of everyday material (which is one of the roles of poetry), he is sometimes overtly urgent and straining. In "Lupins", where he wants an image of steadfastness, he writes, punningly: "They stood. And stood for something. Just by standing." That's telling us; and telling us rather than showing us. As the critic Barbara Hardy once wrote of Heaney, sometimes "he calls to other images in order to have his say, not to make them strangely familiar or familiarly strange through meeting opposition and difference. This is domination, not discovery." The enlisting of ghosts to say his lines is another striking example of this, the worst case being "The Journey Back", from Seeing Things : "Larkin's shade surprised me. He quoted Dante" - to which one responds, yes, that certainly would be a surprise. The more common case, extended in this latest book, is of the simple pastoral description opened out, rather too quickly, into metaphysical assertion. In other cases, we are onlookers as Heaney describes his environment or an event, then tells us how it made him feel, or what it reminded him of. At times (as in the peculiar meanderings of "The Loose Box"), he seems to question or even mock this tendency, but he doesn't replace it with anything else.

For a poet who wants to avoid being prescriptive - whether about politics or the spiritual - ambiguous, balanced symbols of nature and transcendence are overwhelmingly tempting. "Perch", with the rhythm, alliteration and assonance that have always been an enjoyable aspect of Heaney's craft (as they were with Hughes's), describes the fish as "little flood-slubs, runty and ready . . . guzzling the current, against it, all muscle and slur". But the metaphysical point is to contrast their stasis with the movement of the river. They are still points in a Heraclitean flux, "in the everything flows and steady go of the world". It is an attractive poem, an arresting image, beautifully phrased. And the volume as a whole plays with oppositions between drift and solidity, just as previous volumes set up oppositions between working with language and working the land, or between ground and flight, or between the material and the spiritual.

It is done with the solid craftsmanship that one will always admire in Heaney, and that has deservedly made him a popular and major poet; and it displays a passionate enthusiasm, whether for people or land or language, that has always been engaging and admirable. But in this volume there is perhaps a too-easy reliance, born of facility, on now-traditional symbols, whether Heaney's own or from what Larkin called "the myth-kitty". They are used to present a spiritual earnestness rather than evoking it and to wrench from family anecdote a transcendence that doesn't seem wholly earned (indeed, as Peter McDonald noted of The Spirit Level , "by now, Heaney's family history, in even its most trivial moments, is beginning to look overdetermined").

Over and again, as in his lectures, Heaney vigorously affirms the role of the poet, while remaining vague as to what that role is: not to cure or heal but as "some dutiful contemplative, pivoting his understanding in an attempt to bear his portion of the weight of the world, knowing himself incapable of heroic virtue or redemptive effect". At times one is reminded of Roy Campbell's lines: "You praise the firm restraint with which they write - / I'm with you there of course: / They use the snaffle and the curb all right, / But where's the bloody horse?" It is as if in the absence of political engagement, and with the decision instead to seek out appropriate and representative symbols to which, as Heaney himself puts it, an audience might say "yes, that's it" in recognition, what is on offer is a quasi-pastoral, mostly secular Catholicism; a belief in and desire for transcendence.

Heaney has criticised Larkin's pessimism, but the only difference between "negative ions" and "the deep blue air/ that shows nothing, and is nowhere, and is endless" is a spiritual optimism, a sense of celebration and hope. Heaney's poems say "yes", the "enormous yes" of Larkin's poem "For Sidney Bechet", which Heaney wishes had been more present in Larkin's work. But yes to what, exactly? In a postmodern age, confronted with pressing and global ethical and political questions, this is a premodernist, nostalgic poetry reaching back to romanticism: nature, God, the ineffable, the sublime. Reliable, reassuring: yes, yes. But something more, surely, is required.

webTitle: Review: Border Crossing by Pat Barker

fields.headline: Disputed borders
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi ventures into Pat Barker's moral war zone in Border Crossing
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi ventures into Pat Barker's moral war zone in Border Crossing
fields.body:
Border Crossing
Pat Barker
216pp, Viking, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In Border Crossing , her ninth novel, Pat Barker returns to the central relationship that propelled her Regeneration trilogy on the effects of the first world war: that between psycho-logist and patient. But here the repressed and recovered memories are not those of soldiers shell-shocked in the trenches, but those of a peacetime murder by a child. In a resolutely unsensational yet disquieting novel with clear echoes of the Mary Bell and James Bulger cases, Barker probes not only the mystery of "evil" but society's horrified and incoherent response to it.

The book opens in a derelict area of Newcastle's docklands, when Tom Seymour, a child psychologist, plunges into the Tyne to rescue a young man from drowning. The would-be suicide turns out to be Danny Miller, whom Seymour's expert witness had helped convict as a 10-year-old child for robbing and murdering an elderly woman in her home. Twelve years on, released with a new name and identity, Danny appeals to the psychologist to help him remember, and hence understand, his crime.

The dangers of the process of recall after years of self-protective numbness - like putting someone with hypothermia "next to a blazing log fire" - builds suspense, as does the elusiveness of Danny's character and motivation. There are shades of Billy Prior from Barker's Booker-winning The Ghost Road in his "trustless", bisexual, manipulative charm. Intelligent and articulate (he is completing an English degree begun behind bars), Danny is smoothly plausible yet controlling. He blames Seymour for his sentence, and has a record of destroying the careers of "over-involved" care-workers, in one case through accusations of sexual harassment. "He was very good at getting people to step across that invisible border," says one character of the way Danny lures people into breaking the rules. "Lambs to the slaughter."

Seymour, the humane yet fallible psychologist (who recalls Rivers from Regeneration), is writing a book on "moral thinking in children with conduct disorder". His growing self-doubt over his testimony on the 10-year-old Danny's moral maturity reflects today's disquiet over young children being tried in adult courts. Danny's recollections of beatings by his soldier father in a "toughen-up-the-lad campaign" do not absolve him; but as he tries systematically to rebut Seymour's testimony, they put into question his childhood grasp of morality. Seymour recalls an incident from his own childhood, when the bullying of a toddler beside a pond could have led to disaster but for the chance intervention of a passing adult. Tellingly, he feels no responsibility: "In spite of the connecting thread of memory, the person who'd done that was not sufficiently like his present self."

Less gritty in tone than much of Barker's work, the novel is imbued with a pervasive melancholy (despite a comic jab at writers' workshops). The hazards of reconstructing the past are echoed in Seymour's marriage, on the rocks partly through the couple's failed attempts to conceive (he describes his impotence as "ovulation- prediction-kit droop"). "The snag in his present life ran back into the past and unravelled it. Because they were splitting up, it was easy to believe they'd never been happy."

Barker depicts a range of attitudes towards rehabilitation, redemption and the notion of evil. The system is based on the rehabilitation of offenders, but this novel suggests both the inadequacy of those efforts and how hard people find it to believe in change. While Seymour's dreams reveal suppressed fear of his "borderline psychotic" charge and Danny at times appears as a kind of stalker, his anger and mistrust might be seen as rational reactions to a trial he could scarcely follow and incarceration in an adult prison ("they should just come right out with it . . . I sentence you to be raped"). When news reporters blow Danny's cover, both he and Seymour, in demand for TV soundbites, become "hunted". Images of snared rabbits and rapacious foxes recur, though Barker steers away from allowing Danny to style himself as a victim. He is haunted by the "real" victim, the elderly Lizzie ("She's got a right to quite a few of my brain cells"), and Barker makes sure that she forms the final image.

"How desperate people were," reflects Seymour, "for an explanation - any explanation, as long as it was simple - and how difficult it was to supply one. No, not difficult, impossible." An insistence on the enigma at the heart of the crime, its unknowability, can seem like cheating, yet the withholding of answers creates its own haunting resonance. Is Danny "cured", or is he a walking time bomb? Like an Escher drawing, Danny's image changes before our eyes as he reflects the reader's fears and projections. As Barker turns the spotlight back onto our own attitudes, Border Crossing asks questions we can only answer for ourselves.

webTitle: Review: Five Quarters of the Orange by Joanne Harris

fields.headline: Cooking the books
fields.standfirst: There's more to life than the tasty tarts of Joanne Harris's Five Quarters of the Orange, says  Tom Jaine
fields.trailText: There's more to life than the tasty tarts of Joanne Harris's Five Quarters of the Orange, says Tom Jaine
fields.body:
Five Quarters of the Orange
Joanne Harris
432pp, Doubleday, £12.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

First Chocolat , then Blackberry Wine , now oranges. If the next is called Walnut , Joanne Harris will have the full dessert. A preoccupation with food makes her list of child characters in this latest bulletin from the French countryside read like an index to a recipe book: Cassis, Reine-Claude, Framboise, Pistache, Noisette, P che and Prune (Blackcurrant, Greengage, Raspberry, Pistachio, Hazelnut, Peach and Plum - guaranteed to be bullied).

The heroine, Framboise, tells a twin-track story of a village up the river Loire from Angers. Long ago in the war, she and her brother and sister were involved in a little innocent collaboration (more black market than death squads) that went horribly wrong. From trading scraps of information for Gauloises, they spiralled through witnessing German rumpy-pumpy in the village bar (with one dead body on the pavement) to fleeing the parish pursued by a mob who were convinced that the children's mother had informed on the apparent slaying of a German soldier by the Résistance.

Of course, nothing is quite what it seems. Thirty years later, the now-widowed Framboise returns incognito to her birthplace, restores the burnt-out farmhouse, opens a sensationally successful creperie and kicks off another saga. This time, her nephew and his wife, a failing food writer, are out to get a piece of her culinary action by inducing her to share with them her inheritance: a book of grandmother's recipes intertwined with gnomic musings on the events of the war years. So the device of the struggling caterer, first used in Chocolat , is brushed off for Anjou. Nephew plots to smother her trade; old woman fights back. She wins in the end, though not without yielding the secrets of her past to her neighbours.

Harris writes at length. The story has (just) enough action to avoid tedium and induce some sort of tension, but the pace is jog rather than sprint and the relief at getting to the end is that of arrival, not understanding. The apparent charm of the author - Chocolat was a runaway success - seems to lie in her evocation of a French never-never land where things may occasionally turn nasty, but saccharine always flows.

Her big problem is her plotting. She is not especially cerebral, and developments hinge on events rather than emotions, so those events have to ring true to be believed. They don't. Take granny's recipes, for instance. We are told that the hopeless food-writer would kill for them, that they made the reputation of Framboise's cr perie, that Paris restaurant critics were bouleversés by their glory. But cuisine bourgeoise , which is what she cooked, has no secrets: everyone knows the rules for clafoutis or greengage tart. All the stupid niece-in-law had to do was go out and buy Tante Marie in the Kitchen .

Or consider the heroine, in the first part of the yarn a nine-year-old Anjou peasant with the emotional precocity of a 1990s teenager (and, what's more, already menstruating). This waif creates devious stratagems to induce migraines in her mother (this is where the orange of the title comes in); pursues a pike of mythic dimensions with the determination of a great white hunter; and falls for a German soldier (with not a lot of puppy in the love). What a monster - yet still a wonder in the author's eyes.

Underpinning the action is food. Presumably this is what sold Chocolat, too: food equals good. (But nouvelle cuisine equals highly unreliable.) You must be all right if you can make rillettes, stuff a pike, and get your jams and jellies to set. This seems a crushingly simple view of life. Not all good cooks are lovely people, and those who use cooking to make themselves martyrs to the cause of love and affection are usually odious manipulators. But I suspect that this is Harris's secret weapon. Every reader of a cookery column is in reality plotting his or her glorification on the altar of domestic bliss, and this novel reinforces the notion.

fields.headline: A mother of a complex
fields.standfirst: Julie Myerson  mops up uncontrolled Oedipal ooze in Disobedience by Jane Hamilton
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson mops up uncontrolled Oedipal ooze in Disobedience by Jane Hamilton
fields.body:
Disobedience
Jane Hamilton
272pp, Doubleday, £12.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

So here's the picture: you're a 17-year-old boy, buzzing with the usual cocktail of moodiness, curiosity and hormones. At music summer camp, after an evening of adagios, you find yourself going the whole way with a willing, luscious, fiddle-playing blonde. Even better, she's eager to stay in touch. You're all set up: first girlfriend, sex on demand, a real life opening up before you. So what do you now spend all your time thinking about? Your mother. Uh-oh.

Henry Shaw is a boy with a problem: he has a mother fixation as big as the Ritz. He lives in the Chicago suburbs with his history-teacher father, pianist mother and oddball sister. Elvira is a devoted Civil War re-enactor - the kind of hardcore fanatic who, at the tender age of 13, dresses full-time as a (male) soldier and spends weekends wading through muddy fields clutching a genuine 1853 Enfield musket. Their father, a book-bound Civil War obsessive himself, encourages this passion, while their mother frets that "this tomboy phase is going to last the rest of her life".

Henry, on the other hand, is considered to be a "wonderful boy, a model son". As the only computer-literate member of a technologically oblivious household, he helps his mother set up her internet account. Accidentally typing in her password instead of his own one day, he's shocked to discover emails from a lover. Appalled but at the same time unable to resist feeding his torment, he embarks upon a year of eavesdropping. The snooping is understandable enough, but Henry's response - feverish, obsessive, all-consuming - isn't. Into this preoccupation with his mother's furtive sex life he pours all the emotional energy that could and should be going into his own nascent one.

Her adultery - only only ever viewed through Henry's confused adolescent eyes - is not, of course, what the book is about. Neither does it matter that her lover is never a very concrete presence, because Hamilton is interested only in Henry's reaction to him. The trouble is, his response is just too weird and worrying. You know it, I know it, even he (it's hinted) is beginning to know it. But it's just not clear whether the author knows it. There is nothing wrong with splattering a novel with all this Oedipal ooze if the author is willing to get in there, rummage around and explore it. But Hamilton seems bafflingly bent on passing her tale off as a mere insightful little vignette of teenage sensitivity and familial betrayal. Maybe this book has at its heart something tangled and manic, but it's obscured by her strange reluctance to touch, taste and inspect it.

All the same, there is plenty to admire. The eccentric beginnings of Elvira's re-enactment saga build to a kooky and gloriously well-realised climax, though it barely impacts on Henry. The parents' fraught relationship with their difficult daughter rings touchingly true, and is told with vicious humour and sadness. Hamilton can and does relay the shabby emotional chaos of family life with real comic panache. But that's the subplot, and its significance in the novel is clearly secondary.

Meanwhile, what's wrong with young Henry - and why? Does the adult Henry who narrates the novel still have mother trouble? By not even beginning to answer these questions, Hamilton lets us down, leaving us with a novel almost as fey and disappointing as her The Short History of a Prince , which was (for me anyway) infuriatingly unprepared to throw down its ballet pumps and Actually Say Something. It's especially galling, given that Hamilton's A Map of the World is still one of the most exhilaratingly uncompromising novels I've read (if you haven't yet, it's Anne Tyler with aggro, Roth with humanity). I'd love to know what's happened, why she's running so scared - why, when she has proven herself capable of real, muscular genius, she now insists on giving us nothing but these weedy, soppy boys.

fields.headline: Keeping up with the Joneses
fields.trailText: Not generally known as great cineastes - you have to keep quiet and you're not allowed to take your glass in - publishing's best wannabe luvvies turned out for a preview of Bridget Jones: The Movie this week
fields.body:
 Not generally known as great cineastes - you have to keep quiet and you're not allowed to take your glass in - publishing's best wannabe luvvies turned out for a preview of Bridget Jones: The Movie this week. Of most interest was the book-launch party scene, during which the audience craned their necks to take in the acting skills of extras Julian Barnes, Salman Rushdie and Alain de Botton. Barnes and de Botton, like that silent barmaid in EastEnders, had non-speaking parts, but Salman had a good three or four lines. It did, most agreed, have the ring of truth about it, despite the rather far-fetched scene in which Rushdie leans intently towards Ms Jones and enquires, "What do you think?" Most unlikely.

 And while we're on the subject of lit-film, the Loafer is trying desperately to get into the spirit of the forthcoming Pandaemonium, whose subject is the relationship between Romantic pals Coleridge and Wordsworth. But if that sounds like a yawn after you've seen Renée Zellweger in fishnet tights, then think again, for Pandaemonium is nothing if not up-to-the-minute. Director Julien Temple reassures us that W and C were "the pop stars of their day", while Linus Roache - or "Coleridge" - finds the whole thing "incredible trippy and visionary". Samantha Morton, the actress who plays Dorothy Wordsworth, confides that her favourite poem is Coleridge's "Love", which is "almost like hip-hop or rap". A bit confusing, since she also likens the pair to punks or "original" hippies. Does anyone remember Gothic?

 Super-agent Ed Victor - famed for his services to party-going and his 15% commission - is to turn author. Vermilion will publish his guide to staying slim while living high on the hog, entitled The Obvious Diet. Nigella Lawson will introduce, and Victor's A-list mates Marie Helvin, Erica Jong and Sir Ranulph Fiennes will all chip in. That'll be whale-blubber and cottage cheese croquettes, then.

 We are delighted to include the following facsimile document. Our Lord moves in mysterious ways.

Press statement

Due to circumstances beyond our control, Waterstone's, Norwich has cancelled the David Icke event scheduled for May 14th.

Please contact us for information about our many other forthcoming events.

webTitle: Review: Houdini's Box by Adam Phillips

fields.headline: Flights of fancy
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on great escapes of mind and body in Houdini's Box by Adam Phillips
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on great escapes of mind and body in Houdini's Box by Adam Phillips
fields.body:
Houdini's Box
Adam Phillips
160pp, Faber, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

We should, perhaps, begin at the very beginning. Nestling among the epigraphs from Wittgenstein and a work entitled Compulsion Neurosis , we come across a brief, illuminating sentence taken from Marion Milner's An Experiment in Leisure with which the psychoanalyst Adam Phillips chooses to send his new book into the world: "My sole concern was to borrow forms, no matter from where, by which my own preoccupations could declare themselves."

Leaving aside the biography of Winnicott and the collections of poetry and psychoanalytic papers that he has edited, this is the eighth time Phillips has felt compelled to explore his preoccupations and to share them with us; on this occasion, those concerns are so complex that they require him to borrow biography, cultural history, case study and literary criticism. And all, it appears, in order to open our eyes to the fantasies and fears that lead some of us to exist in an almost permanent state of flight, albeit uncertain of what we are escaping from and where we think we're going. It's a diagnosis that we may resist, but that Phillips patiently, and in tones of quiet urgency, insists is central to our self-knowledge.

Phillips, like the man whose case study streaks through these pages, is dogged by his own virtue; and, like Houdini, he has something of the proselytiser about him. It's unthinkable that Phillips is not aware, as he eloquently unfolds the life of the master illusionist, of the parallels between them, so widely are the clues scattered. He describes Houdini variously as a lifelong adherent to a "personal religion of performed ingenuity", as a showman who "held a mirror up to his audience, that was at once disruptive and reassuring", or as a professional mystifier whose success depended on gaining people's confidence. As neat insights into the bizarre life of a man whose success demanded simply that he devise self-tortures ever more convoluted and seemingly inescapable, these descriptions have the ring of truth. But how far can they also be applied to the ingenious, esoteric interpretations of the psychoanalyst and the "honest deceptions" of the psychoanalytic writer?

It is not hard to see why Phillips is drawn to Houdini: like the best kind of entertainer, he appeals in an extraordinarily wide range of ways. For Phillips, his life and his act - which are, at times, one and the same thing - offer a series of hugely suggestive parodies and inversions. Having arrived in America as a tiny child in the 1870s, Houdini witnessed his father, a former rabbi, fail to find the crock of gold; his response, "a violent parody of assimilation", was to work himself almost to death. Against his father's mystical Jewish tradition, Houdini assembled an unrivalled library of magic books, both restoring what his father had been forced to sell and adding his own counter-cultural interests. It was, Phillips suggests, both homage and rewriting, an ambiguous appropriation that nudged at but just about stayed within the bounds of orthodoxy.

As did "the work". Houdini's assaults on the world of escapology provide enough material for several different, and equally convincing, readings. Phillips sees him as the paid transgressor of a society newly obsessed with artefacts of containment and confinement (handcuffs, straitjackets); as the performer who furnishes his audience with mimes of madness and criminality, the possible end of which is his own death; and as the "Don Juan of his own devices", whose "revelation was always himself" but who was locked into the cycle of repeatedly endangering and saving himself. Aside from the tricks themselves - from the initial box escape of "Metamorphosis" to the vividly named "Chinese Water Torture Cell" - there is Houdini's self-publicity, his unswerving deter mination to thumb his nose at the symbols and instruments of law and order while loudly proclaiming his adherence to its spirit.

Phillips tickles out these peculiarities - both in Houdini and in his rapt audiences (who, surely, were tempted above anything by the prospect of a fatality) - with his customary urbanity and confident eye for the incongruent. When Houdini trumpets as his most realistic stunt a setup that involves him being strapped to a hospital bed, wound in sheets and doused in hot water (so the sheets would shrink), Phillips wonders what the real experience alluded to could possibly be. As for Chinese water torture, he muses, "what exactly is the 'regulation manner' for locking people up in cabinets full of water?"

Phillips's rehearsals of Houdini's life are captivating, but they are, in some sense, a sideshow to the book's more serious concerns. As ever, Phillips is keen to discuss the wider implications of his researches and, in a chapter given over to claustrophobia and related neuroses, he extends his gaze backwards to "the failed breakout" of Adam and Eve and sideways to encompass the world of that "characteristically modern escape artist", the neurotic. Do we flee from what we fear because it is real, or does it become real because we flee it? In this topsy-turvy world where "everything that you thought was important about yourself isn't, and everything you considered to be unimportant is crucial" - where what we really need to do is escape escaping - Phillips insinuates himself as our authoritative guide, our friendly interpreter of fear and fantasy.

Except that, occasionally, he fails. By far the most riveting magic trick in Houdini's Box is the reproduction, or at least approximation, of Phillips's sessions with a reluctant - or resistant - patient. In themselves, they are something of a mystery, for they include what we must assume to be near- verbatim accounts, complete with verbal tics, hesitations and blind alleys, of therapeutic exchanges. Are these transcripts of tape recordings? If so, is the participant aware that he is being recorded, and does he alter his behaviour accordingly? If not, does Phillips have an almost flawless memory for dialogue? Is the entire relationship partially or wholly fabricated?

In these tense, frequently antagonistic sessions, Phillips offers himself both as the magician whose trick fails to enthrall its audience, and as the victim of a trick. His patient, a man who seeks out women in order to reject them, casts Phillips in a similar role. "I wasn't sure if I was a fashion accessory, or a prosthesis," the analyst recalls. "He had told me to keep quiet, and made me want to show off."

As for the man, he asks some of the questions any self-respecting sceptic would pose. "Do you think this does any good?" he challenges. "Don't you get bored of this?" And, out of nowhere, "Do you think wanking's radical?" He brings his analyst a series of irreverent cartoons based on their encounters, tells Phillips he's patronising and finally sends him a Dear John letter. He had, he said, found the experience "unexpectedly interesting", but felt, on balance, that it might be better to stop.

We are not entirely sure how Phillips reacts to this disappearing man, in private at least. In public, he turns him into a book; and books, both men agree, have contributed much to their professional and personal lives. It's an engaging and unsettling transformation - and one that, like Houdini's stunts and the vanishing acts of the other amateur escape artists featured here, we will have to ponder hard in order to fathom its implications.

fields.headline: Tickets to ride
fields.standfirst: ... your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.trailText: New York | Los Angeles | Hong Kong
fields.body:
Six top destinations

New York: £228
Air India from Heathrow. Valid for departures until May 31. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Trailfinders (020-7937 5400).

Los Angeles: £241
Northwest Airlines from Gatwick via Detroit or Minneapolis. Must be booked by April 18. Valid for departures April 11 - 30. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Quest Travel (0870 4445552).

Hong Kong: £425
Royal Brunei from Manchester via Dubai, Calcutta and Bandar Seri. Must be booked by May 30. Valid for departures April 21 - June 14. Minimum stay three nights, maximum 30 days. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

Sydney: £487
Olympic Airlines from Gatwick via Athens. Must be booked by April 17. Valid for departures until June 30. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

Paris: £114
British Airways from Bristol. Tickets must be bought at least three days before departure. Valid for departures until December 31. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Trailfinders (020-7937 1234).

Amsterdam: £85
KLM from Stansted. Valid for departures until March 31 next year. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

The pick of the rest

Mumbai: £344
Kuwait Airways from Heathrow via Kuwait. Valid for departures April 19 - May 31, No minimum stay, maximum six months. Trailfinders (020-7938 3939).

Prague: £91
Czech Airlines from Stansted. Valid for departures until October 31. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Travellers must be under 26 or have valid international student identity cards. usitCampus (0870 2401010).

Orlando: £199
Monarch Airlines charter from Gatwick. Departs April 26 for 14 nights. Cosmos (0870 9084299).

Bangkok: £347
Royal Jordanian from Heathrow via Amman. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures April 15 - June 30. Minimum stay one six days, maximum 45 days. Airline Network (0800 727747).

And the rail alternative

Paris/Brussels: £70. Lille £60
Eurostar from Waterloo. Must be bought at least 14 days before departure. Minimum stay one Saturday night or two other nights. Eurostar (08705 186186).

NB Fares can change rapidly. These were available in reasonable quantities at the time of writing, but they can sell out in a sudden rush.
