fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Spain | Jamaica | Indonesia
fields.body:
Europe

Spain: Andalucian Adventures(01453 834137) organises walking and painting holidays in the Subbetica, the Alpujarras and, new for this year, the Sierra de Aracena from £579pp, including seven nights' full-board and wine with dinner, all tuition/guiding and excursions.The price does not include flights to Malaga which cost between £70-£200 and are available from 15 different UK regional airports. The single supplement is £58 for the week.

France: Charter the all-inclusive six-berth La Tortue hotel barge on the Canal du Midi. In July or August, it costs £1,600pp from The Barge Company (01275 474034) including an extra night at the hotel Domaine d'Aurillac, near Carcassonne.

France: Belle France (01797 223 777) is offering a new six-night cycling holiday in Haute Provence, with guests cycling 10-16 miles a day while luggage is transferred to the next hotel. It costs from £514pp (self-drive with short ferry crossing) or £639 travelling by Eurostar, or flying London- Marseille, and includes six nights' half-board, bicycle hire and route guides.

France: Seven nights in June for two adults and up to three children in a mobile home by the sea in Brittany, the Vendée, Charente Maritime or Languedoc Roussillon costs £219 including mid-week sailings Portsmouth-Le Havre (£299 Plymouth-Roscoff). Matthews Holidays (01483 285213).

Caribbean

Jamaica: Book by April 30 and save up to £540 on a week in the all-inclusive four-star Breezes Golf and Beach Resort. The new price for departures May 1-July 20 is £889, including flights. British Airways Holidays (0870 6000500).

Asia

Indonesia: Trailfinders (020-7938 3939) is offering 10 days in The Bali Dynasty hotel, Tuban, for £598pp (based on two sharing) including flights from Gatwick to Bali. Valid until June 30.

India: Fly out from Manchester airport on April 14 for seven nights at the all-inclusive three-star Maria Rosa resort in Calangute Beach, Goa for £569pp. Details from Thomas Cook Direct (0870 7570490).

South America

Peru: See all the sights in a week - the Urubamba Valley, Cusco, Pisac, Ollantaytambo, Lima and Machu Picchu. Destination South America (01285 885333) has an eight-day trip for £1,600pp, including international and domestic flights, accommodation, some meals, transfers and transport.

Shetland Folk Festival

Date: April 26-30.

Location: Shetland Islands, Scotland.

Description: A big community-based festival, with local and international musicians.

Contact: 01595 694757.

Amsterdam Museum Weekend

Date: April 21-22.

Location: Amsterdam, Noord-Holland, The Netherlands.

Description: The one weekend when you can visit the Van Gogh Museum, Stedelijk Museum of Modern Art and the Rembrandt-packed Rijksmuseum for free.

Contact: 0031 20 670 1111.

San Francisco International Film Festival

Date: April 19-May 19

Location: San Francisco, California, US.

Description: The best soca music in the world.

Contact: 001 876 927 8662.

E-mail: jamaicacarnival@homeviewjamaica.com

fields.headline: Golden age of travel
fields.standfirst: Besides being over 50, what else do people who go on Saga Holidays have in common?  Bernard Kops travels thousands of miles by coach, train and vintage aeroplane to find out
fields.trailText: Besides being over 50, what else do people who go on Saga Holidays have in common? Bernard Kops travels thousands of miles by coach, train and vintage aeroplane to find out.
fields.body:
Below us, the crystal sea surpasses all superlatives. We are on top of Table Mountain above the beautiful city of Cape Town. The vivid violet jacaranda, the blatant bougainvillea and frangipani are a dazzling canvas. We are cheating; escaping the rain and heading for the southern sun. How marvellous. The over fifties on their Saga saga begin to unwind, start to chat with one another.

The long, hard trek lies ahead: 2,000 miles by coach, taking in this vast jigsaw of a country. It promises to be strenuous.

"Very nice," the retired GP remarks; a splendidly-attired Monsieur Hulot in his pristine safari suit. "Very nice," his pretty wife replies. I soon learn that he is the leading light of his local Conservative Association.

Des, our excellent tour guide, has a lived-in face. He immediately makes us feel at ease. He tells me he really enjoys guiding the over fifties. "They've lived lives; they're far more interesting."

We wander off. The streets in the Malay district open their arms, welcoming. I stroll alone with Erica, admiring the pastel-shade houses. John Betjeman would have had a ball along here. People beam when we say good morning. We go down to the waterfront. Back home, we were warned about strolling alone, but I've felt more threatenedoin the Kilburn High Road.

On the way back to the hotel, I notice gangs of little boys near the traffic lights. High spirited, giggling street orphans jive-arsing about, in and out of their cardboard homes. They can be no more than six or seven years old. I drop them a few Rand and one turns triumphant cartwheels of delight. This image will constantly shadow us. But we remind each other that we are here to enjoy ourselves.

The next day, we are leaving; all excited by the odyssey ahead. The Paarle estate, Knysa, Stellenbosch. Kirstenbosch is a Henri Rousseau botanical garden. And all the 901 species of birds, their little eyes-blinding beauty. Darting constantly. Ooohs and ahhhs resound.

We pass through the Outeniqua canyon. The second largest in the world. John Ford would have had a field day here. And we reach Outshoorn. "Sudden the desert changes,/The raw glare softens and clings,/Till the aching Outshoorn ranges/ Stand up like the throne of Kings," sang Rudyard Kipling. Here 120 years ago, Russian Jewish and Boer pioneers invented the ostrich-feather industry. In the morning, at an ostrich farm, I get uncomfortably close to a fearsome creature. I'm told its brain is smaller than its eyeball. One kick from his leg and it's curtains. At lunchtime, I get my revenge and eat my ostrich. He is delicious.

Wilderness is another pretty town lost in time. In the beginning, an Englishman proposed to his lady love. "I'll marry you if you take me to the wilderness," she responded. So he built a little house here, named it Wilderness, and thus this town was born.

And so our long trek is under way, and there is this constant packing and unpacking. One or two days in any one place. And later all the places merge. Hotels coalesce into one. And the further we go, the more familiar and nicer everyone becomes. I'm worried. I'm starting to like the Daily Telegraph doctor. I'm even getting to like Brian who was once a Regimental Quarter Master Corporal in the Life Guards.

Towns, people, places flash by. There's nothing like a long coach journey to cause masks to slip.

South Africa is a country of stunning impressions. The monkeys carrying and clutching babies, pinching breakfasts from our plates. The peaceful pretty pastel towns. But just outside are the ubiquitous shanty towns. The indestructible impoverished people smile as we flash past. They wave. Erica and I wave back. Onward.

We reach the Garden Route and I begin to lose chronology as the impressions come thick and fast. Port Elizabeth! Our disparate group is now splitting off, separating from the herd and eating together. The Daily Telegraphs! The Mails! The Mirrors! When they hear I am writing this for the Guardian, they hoot. The whole dynamic changes.

Erica and I also find kindred spirits. There are four widows on this odyssey and two feisty Scottish ladies, Pauline and Joyce, who may as well be widows. They vilify their footloose husbands with such wonderful venom. And they gossip wickedly about the rest of us.

Our little enclave also gossips. Gossip is as enjoyable as reading. It is the cement that binds us. We discuss each one of our compatriots, speculate upon their sex lives. If any.

We fly to Durban. The Hilton hotel is bliss; it's wonderful to unwind, shower and unpack a few things. We warm to our widows. Mrs Pfeffer is an exceptional woman. She turns out to be an ex-Czech Catholic. She has a metal knee, is 75, hobbles but never complains. She swears by Saga. "I feel safe. I was in extremis in Buenos Aires and they flew me home. They could not do enough." She is valiant, cultured and erudite. A few new friends make all the difference.

Daphne, another widow, is urbane, beautiful, rich and amazingly generous. A near-death experience changed her life. Daphne travels all the time. Travelling seems to be the occupation of well-to-do widows. How Daphne always manages to look so well turned out beats me. Her clothes are never creased yet she has been living out of a suitcase just like the rest of us.

We move on to KwaZulu where the high-kicking warriors put on a virile but quasi-tourist performance. Still, we've all got to earn a living.

Later, we reach and pass through the majestic Drakenbourg range of mountains. Nobody is flagging yet, even though we sometimes cover more than 200 miles a day.

The lodge at Malelane on the Crocodile River. The Kruger National Park. Zebras! A female giraffe turns her back on us and pees so elegantly. In the early-morning, a phalanx of 50 or more female elephants surround their babies and thunder towards a water hole. They are amazingly elegant and incredibly fast. And there they stand in a druidical circle, drinking their fill. There is a breathtaking silence. It is a mystical Blakean moment.

The journey is almost over and we slowly wend our way into Pretoria. The Kruger memorial reminds me of Golders Green crematorium writ large. Des gets very emotional recounting the story of the Great Trek. Somehow you have to admire those Voortrekkers.

Seven of us extend our holiday as the others leave for the airport. The goodbyes are awkwardly negotiated. Very English. But the two Scottish ladies kiss us warmly. We fly on to Victoria Falls. Words become clichés when you stand before one of the most beautiful and awe-inspiring places on earth.

T his is Zimbabwe and it is falling apart. But the Victoria Falls Hotel is an oasis of luxury and Edwardian splendour. We spend two days out of real life and conscience.

On the Tarmac before us is a Douglas DC-4 Skymaster, built in 1945. The pilot tells us the piston went this morning but he think it's now repaired and airworthy. Our laughter is tinged with fear. It proves to be a journey of a lifetime, or more like a death time. I die 3,000 times before we reach Pietersburg, where we are resurrected to join The Pride of Africa, an Edwardian choochoo. It is pristine and elegantly glides right out of the past. We fall into our lavish suite, indulge in embarrassing luxury; we are to travel for two days and be pampered like royalty. But I protest when we are expected to dress for dinner: "I'd rather die."

"Bernard! You're scruffy," says Brian. Later, he knocks on the door and hands me a clip-on. I wear it to please him. "That's better. Now you look lovely." He pats my shoulder.

"But your trousers are still baggy," murmurs the ex-headmistress of a Tottenham primary school.

At dinner there are roses, champagne and candlelight. And ostrich meat.

"The world in one country," the Saga brochure said. You can say that again and more.

We are ever so slowly chugging back to Pretoria in our choochoo train. Now it is almost over for us. I feel depressed, but on our way to the airport we stop for a "comfort break". A beautiful sound lifts us. We are drawn to an open window of a schoolroom. Inside, fresh-scrubbed children sing Sugarbush. They giggle when they see us, then go straight into another song: You Are My Sunshine...

This country must surely contend for being the most beautiful on earth.

We wave goodbye to the others at Heathrow. Perhaps one or two friendships will endure, but we will lose contact with the rest. Ships that pass. Holidays are like that.

Way to go

Saga Holidays (call free on 0800 056 5880) offers 17 nights in South Africa (also available in 2002) from £1,599 per person, including 15 breakfasts, 8 lunches and 14 dinners, insurance and cancellation cover, return scheduled flights, airport taxes, fees and charges. Highlights include game viewing in the Kruger National Park, a visit to a Zulu Kraal and a train ride along the Garden Route. There is also the opportunity to spend an extra 2 nights in Coastal Cape Town from £79, three nights to Victoria Falls by air for £649 (only available in 2002) or four nights visiting Victoria Falls and travelling on Rovos Rail's Pride of Africa (two nights on board) from £1,149.
fields.bodyText: Below us, the crystal sea surpasses all superlatives. We are on top of Table Mountain above the beautiful city of Cape Town. The vivid violet jacaranda, the blatant bougainvillea and frangipani are a dazzling canvas. We are cheating; escaping the rain and heading for the southern sun. How marvellous. The over fifties on their Saga saga begin to unwind, start to chat with one another. The long, hard trek lies ahead: 2,000 miles by coach, taking in this vast jigsaw of a country. It promises to be strenuous. "Very nice," the retired GP remarks; a splendidly-attired Monsieur Hulot in his pristine safari suit. "Very nice," his pretty wife replies. I soon learn that he is the leading light of his local Conservative Association. Des, our excellent tour guide, has a lived-in face. He immediately makes us feel at ease. He tells me he really enjoys guiding the over fifties. "They've lived lives; they're far more interesting." We wander off. The streets in the Malay district open their arms, welcoming. I stroll alone with Erica, admiring the pastel-shade houses. John Betjeman would have had a ball along here. People beam when we say good morning. We go down to the waterfront. Back home, we were warned about strolling alone, but I've felt more threatenedoin the Kilburn High Road. On the way back to the hotel, I notice gangs of little boys near the traffic lights. High spirited, giggling street orphans jive-arsing about, in and out of their cardboard homes. They can be no more than six or seven years old. I drop them a few Rand and one turns triumphant cartwheels of delight. This image will constantly shadow us. But we remind each other that we are here to enjoy ourselves. The next day, we are leaving; all excited by the odyssey ahead. The Paarle estate, Knysa, Stellenbosch. Kirstenbosch is a Henri Rousseau botanical garden. And all the 901 species of birds, their little eyes-blinding beauty. Darting constantly. Ooohs and ahhhs resound. We pass through the Outeniqua canyon. The second largest in the world. John Ford would have had a field day here. And we reach Outshoorn. "Sudden the desert changes,/The raw glare softens and clings,/Till the aching Outshoorn ranges/ Stand up like the throne of Kings," sang Rudyard Kipling. Here 120 years ago, Russian Jewish and Boer pioneers invented the ostrich-feather industry. In the morning, at an ostrich farm, I get uncomfortably close to a fearsome creature. I'm told its brain is smaller than its eyeball. One kick from his leg and it's curtains. At lunchtime, I get my revenge and eat my ostrich. He is delicious. Wilderness is another pretty town lost in time. In the beginning, an Englishman proposed to his lady love. "I'll marry you if you take me to the wilderness," she responded. So he built a little house here, named it Wilderness, and thus this town was born. And so our long trek is under way, and there is this constant packing and unpacking. One or two days in any one place. And later all the places merge. Hotels coalesce into one. And the further we go, the more familiar and nicer everyone becomes. I'm worried. I'm starting to like the Daily Telegraph doctor. I'm even getting to like Brian who was once a Regimental Quarter Master Corporal in the Life Guards. Towns, people, places flash by. There's nothing like a long coach journey to cause masks to slip. South Africa is a country of stunning impressions. The monkeys carrying and clutching babies, pinching breakfasts from our plates. The peaceful pretty pastel towns. But just outside are the ubiquitous shanty towns. The indestructible impoverished people smile as we flash past. They wave. Erica and I wave back. Onward. We reach the Garden Route and I begin to lose chronology as the impressions come thick and fast. Port Elizabeth! Our disparate group is now splitting off, separating from the herd and eating together. The Daily Telegraphs! The Mails! The Mirrors! When they hear I am writing this for the Guardian, they hoot. The whole dynamic changes. Erica and I also find kindred spirits. There are four widows on this odyssey and two feisty Scottish ladies, Pauline and Joyce, who may as well be widows. They vilify their footloose husbands with such wonderful venom. And they gossip wickedly about the rest of us. Our little enclave also gossips. Gossip is as enjoyable as reading. It is the cement that binds us. We discuss each one of our compatriots, speculate upon their sex lives. If any. We fly to Durban. The Hilton hotel is bliss; it's wonderful to unwind, shower and unpack a few things. We warm to our widows. Mrs Pfeffer is an exceptional woman. She turns out to be an ex-Czech Catholic. She has a metal knee, is 75, hobbles but never complains. She swears by Saga. "I feel safe. I was in extremis in Buenos Aires and they flew me home. They could not do enough." She is valiant, cultured and erudite. A few new friends make all the difference. Daphne, another widow, is urbane, beautiful, rich and amazingly generous. A near-death experience changed her life. Daphne travels all the time. Travelling seems to be the occupation of well-to-do widows. How Daphne always manages to look so well turned out beats me. Her clothes are never creased yet she has been living out of a suitcase just like the rest of us. We move on to KwaZulu where the high-kicking warriors put on a virile but quasi-tourist performance. Still, we've all got to earn a living. Later, we reach and pass through the majestic Drakenbourg range of mountains. Nobody is flagging yet, even though we sometimes cover more than 200 miles a day. The lodge at Malelane on the Crocodile River. The Kruger National Park. Zebras! A female giraffe turns her back on us and pees so elegantly. In the early-morning, a phalanx of 50 or more female elephants surround their babies and thunder towards a water hole. They are amazingly elegant and incredibly fast. And there they stand in a druidical circle, drinking their fill. There is a breathtaking silence. It is a mystical Blakean moment. The journey is almost over and we slowly wend our way into Pretoria. The Kruger memorial reminds me of Golders Green crematorium writ large. Des gets very emotional recounting the story of the Great Trek. Somehow you have to admire those Voortrekkers. Seven of us extend our holiday as the others leave for the airport. The goodbyes are awkwardly negotiated. Very English. But the two Scottish ladies kiss us warmly. We fly on to Victoria Falls. Words become clichés when you stand before one of the most beautiful and awe-inspiring places on earth. T his is Zimbabwe and it is falling apart. But the Victoria Falls Hotel is an oasis of luxury and Edwardian splendour. We spend two days out of real life and conscience. On the Tarmac before us is a Douglas DC-4 Skymaster, built in 1945. The pilot tells us the piston went this morning but he think it's now repaired and airworthy. Our laughter is tinged with fear. It proves to be a journey of a lifetime, or more like a death time. I die 3,000 times before we reach Pietersburg, where we are resurrected to join The Pride of Africa, an Edwardian choochoo. It is pristine and elegantly glides right out of the past. We fall into our lavish suite, indulge in embarrassing luxury; we are to travel for two days and be pampered like royalty. But I protest when we are expected to dress for dinner: "I'd rather die." "Bernard! You're scruffy," says Brian. Later, he knocks on the door and hands me a clip-on. I wear it to please him. "That's better. Now you look lovely." He pats my shoulder. "But your trousers are still baggy," murmurs the ex-headmistress of a Tottenham primary school. At dinner there are roses, champagne and candlelight. And ostrich meat. "The world in one country," the Saga brochure said. You can say that again and more. We are ever so slowly chugging back to Pretoria in our choochoo train. Now it is almost over for us. I feel depressed, but on our way to the airport we stop for a "comfort break". A beautiful sound lifts us. We are drawn to an open window of a schoolroom. Inside, fresh-scrubbed children sing Sugarbush. They giggle when they see us, then go straight into another song: You Are My Sunshine... This country must surely contend for being the most beautiful on earth. We wave goodbye to the others at Heathrow. Perhaps one or two friendships will endure, but we will lose contact with the rest. Ships that pass. Holidays are like that. fields.headline: Get your kit out
fields.standfirst: Mini travel glasses
fields.trailText: Mini travel glasses.
fields.body:
My reading glasses cost a fortune and I don't want to lose them on holiday. Why not buy a pair of mini travel glasses?

More expense! What's special about them? There are two sorts. Minifold glasses fold up to the size of a single lens and fit into a sturdy flip- top case, 40x80x15mm. Microvision Readers pack even smaller into a 12.5x15x 12mm aluminium case. Both are perfect for reading menus and fine print.

Can you get them made up to a prescription? Of course. You can choose between five correction levels from +1 to +3.50.

Are they comfortable? There are specially-designed silicon nose and temple tips.

Any nice colours? Minifolds are pewter or white gold with a pewter or tortoiseshell case. Microvisions come in a choice of five colours, including a shiny copper pink with matching metallic case.

Expensive? £49.99 each plus £3.99 p&p from Presents for Men (01295 750100).

fields.headline: Camp followers
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor, your red coat on the internet, looks at holiday camps on the net
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor, your red coat on the internet, looks at holiday camps on the net.
fields.body:
Don't knock the holiday camp. Nowadays it offers parents the opportunity to leave their kids in someone else's care and couples the chance to escape children entirely. Not all these places are holiday camps in the traditional sense, but they all offer a self-contained resort environment. All the prices quoted are based on a week in May for at least one person sharing a room.

Butlins
Cheapest deal: £53 for a week's self-catering in Skegness
The Butlins resorts in Minehead, Bognor Regis and Skegness may be cheap, but they do offer splash pools, crazy golf, funfairs, tenpin bowling, sports courts, cinemas and branches of Burger King. So don't scoff.

Center Parcs
Cheapest deal: £125 for a week in Erperheide, Belgium, excluding travel (discounts of 20-25% on hovercraft, ferries and Eurotunnel)
As well as the three English centres, all set in forests, Center Parcs runs 10 Parcs in France, Belgium, Holland and Germany. All are based around the 84-degree AquaDome and offer plenty of sports and spa facilities. A helpful, sunlit website.

Club 18-30
Cheapest deal: £159 for a week in Ibiza, including flights
If you suspect you might be Up 4 It, go to the late offers page. Basic accommodation details and the chance to send in your own photos of drunken revelry in your hotel room.

Club Med
Cheapest deal: from £231in the Limousin, excluding flights
An excellent place to start if you don't know where to go. The Design Your Own Holiday option at the bottom of the screen suggests suitable villages (from more than a hundred) for different kinds of Gentil Membre - for instance, groups of friends, a couple with a baby and waterskiing enthusiasts. Excellent virtual resort tours, too.

Sandals (Internet Explorer only)
Prices not listed
"Created exclusively for people in love." There are no singles supplements at these all-inclusive Caribbean resorts - indeed, there are no singles at all. Eating, scuba diving, swimming and golf play a major role, as do hammocks, "love baskets" and gazebos. Plenty of loving detail here, but no booking or price lists, and it is not clear whether gay and lesbian couples are welcome; photographic evidence suggests otherwise.

Mark Warner
Cheapest deal: from £544, including flights
Mark Warner runs several beach resorts in the Mediterranean and the Aegean. Three resorts in Corsica, Italy and Turkey are reserved for adults during most of the year, and sporting facilities (especially tennis) are especially good. A well-thought-out informative site.

Peng Travel
Cheapest deal: from £255 for Club Aphrodite in Languedoc-Roussillon, including Channel crossings.
Naturists, for obvious reasons, like to holiday in a sympathetic and private environment. Peng Travel is also an agent for the French resort of Cap d'Agde as well as organising naturist holidays in Croatia, Spain, Florida, Lanzarote and the Caribbean.

 Email your comments to Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Home call | The down side | Discounted out
fields.body:
Home call
The English Tourism Council this week launched a campaign to encourage Easter holidaymakers to take trips throughout England. The campaign, an attempt to rescue the domestic tourist industry from the disaster created by the foot-and-mouth epidemic, emphasises that more than three-quarters of visitor attractions in England are open. The English tourism industry is losing an estimated £250 million a week. For further information of what attractions are open go to www.openbritain.gov.uk.

The down side
Half of all holidaymakers put airport delays at the top of their dread list, ahead of extra charges (16%), dirty accommodation (11%) and poor service by holiday reps (7%). Two-thirds of delayed passengers wrongly believe that tour operators and airport staff are solely or jointly in charge of their welfare, when in fact it is the sole responsibility of the airline, according to a survey done for Travelcare, a travel retailer. One in five people do not take their full annual holiday entitlement, according to another survey, this one from Travel Choice. Some 40% said that they were too busy at work. Younger people without children were more likely not to take their full entitlement.

Discounted out
Market leader Thomson Holidays is reducing its dependence on so-called discounts to sell its holidays. Discounts by major operators in January reached 50% and many people were concerned that original prices were unrealistic. Thomson managing director Shaun Powell said this week: "Holidaymakers and travel agents have told us that they want to simplify the minefield that is holiday pricing. Discounts used to be at sensible levels but now they are excessive." Thomson claims it is offering holidaymakers the bottom line for this summer's holidays and is not offering the usual range of discounts.

Dutch hop
Easyjet started a daily service from Gatwick to Amsterdam this week. Fares start at £43.20 return including tax.

Free Express
Heathrow passengers who check their bags in at Paddington over the Easter break (April 13-16) will travel free on the Heathrow Express. Eighteen airlines, including British Airways Lufthansa, Qantas, SAS, bmi british midland and United, now have check in facilities at the train station.

fields.headline: Italian without tears
fields.standfirst: Joanna Moorhead finds a place more informal than a hotel and more restful than self-catering
fields.trailText: Joanna Moorhead finds a place more informal than a hotel and more restful than self-catering
fields.body:
Having children changes everything, but nothing changes quite as radically as your holiday. Holidays BC - remember them? The lazy, wine-soaked days when you flopped in the sun reading some fat novel before taking in a bit of culture and then ambling along to a local eaterie?

Now think back to your last holiday. It could be difficult, because it probably isn't filed under "holiday" in your memory at all. Look under "endurance test", "childcare marathon", "appalling car journeys" or perhaps even "major marital disputes". If you can't find it anywhere, it could be because it was so awful that you've simply blanked it out.

But various friends had been to Villa Pia. "A real holiday," they said, despite struggling there with toddlers and pushchairs and grumpy older kids who'd rather have been en route to Disneyland. "A proper rest," said one. "So laid back," said another. "We actually got a chance to talk," said a third.

Villa Pia, a large beige-stoned 18th-century villa perched on an Umbrian hillside in the upper Tiber valley and surrounded in all directions by glorious views, is the home of Morag Cleland, her partner Kevin Begley and their three children. It is also, for seven months of the year, a holiday venue catering largely for stressed-out British parents and their offspring: a place to recharge the batteries, for the children to have a bit of freedom and to meet some new friends while you take in a bit of culture or simply chill out in the hammock in the villa's sunken courtyard.

It would be wrong to call Villa Pia a hotel. Imagine some friends have moved to a big house in Italy and invited you to stay, and you'd be nearer the mark. Imagine when you arrived that they'd invited lots of other people you didn't know but found you had things in common with (well, kids at least) and you've got the concept in a nutshell.

We finally turned down the villa's drive in the darkness of the evening, having endured a nightmarish journey from Bologna airport punctuated with fights on the back seat and cries of "are we nearly there?" which started before we'd got the keys into the ignition. Opening the door into the farmhouse kitchen was like stumbling on a party: "What are you having to drink?" asked Kevin as soon as we were over the threshold, and the children were spirited off for much-needed chicken and roast potatoes.

Villa Pia was born four years ago after Kevin and Morag, who used to live in Surrey, realised there was a gap in the market for hard-pressed parents wanting a holiday that was more informal than a hotel, but more restful than self-catering. It was a gap they seem extraordinarily well-qualified to plug: in a previous life Kevin was a chef at the Dorchester, while Morag was a therapist. No surprise, then, that you get good food and sympathetic conversation in abundance.

Mealtimes are the social highpoints of the day, starting with a help-yourself breakfast around the kitchen table, through to a buffet lunch, kids' tea at 6pm and adult supper at 8.30pm. Everyone eats together at a long table, so inevitably you can find yourself sitting next to someone you might not want to spend two hours with, but the mix is big enough for the communal living not to get boring (Villa Pia can cater for up to 40 houseguests including children).

The atmosphere is easy-going - it's the sort of place where you can leave your muddy shoes in the hall after a tramp through the hillside, and if you fancy some music you just put something you like on the CD player in the clutter-strewn hall. The bedrooms are large and most have extra beds in case you want to keep a close eye on the kids: all have bathrooms. In the kitchen, a huge fridge is packed with wine from the local vineyard, beer, fruit juice and milk - you're free to help yourself and your kids to whatever you want, whenever you want it.

Morag, whose youngest child is just five months old, is almost always on hand to dispense advice about where to go and what to see. In fact it's more a question of what to miss out: Villa Pia is surrounded by cultural gems. Florence is 30 minutes away by train: Perugia, more interesting to the kids in its role as Italy's "chocolate city" than for its medieval art, is about an hour's drive, and Assisi, birthplace of St Francis, a little further away.

When we finally managed to tear our children away from the swimming pool, the woods ("brilliant for making dens in", according to the kids) and the courtyard playroom, we plumped for Siena in neighbouring Tuscany. Sightseeing and young children don't exactly go hand in hand, but do your homework first and you can manage to see the essentials and still come away with your sanity intact.

Siena is ideal in that there's only one place you've got to see and that's the Piazza del Campo: buy your kids a hunk of pizza and you can sit and admire the architecture while they chomp away in the sunshine. Round the corner is the black-and-white striped marble Duomo ("just like a zebra," said my six-year-old), and they all behaved passably well for a quick 10-minute tour - not what you'd have done BC, of course, stuffed as it is with Renaissance art, but as good as you'll get in the circumstances. Particularly good for little ones is the fact that the most accessible part of the cathedral, its floor, is littered with marble panels depicting all kinds of fascinating subjects from prophetesses to she-wolves.

Our other big day out was to Gubbio with its perilous cable-car journey up the mountain to the Basilica of Saint Ubaldo. It's a six-minute ride, with fabulous views behind you to the city if you dare open your eyes - great for toddlers who can stand and peer through the railings as you rise up over the terracotta rooftops. In the church there's a further treat for the children - the chance to view the remains of old Ubaldo himself as he lies in state in a glass casket above a marble altar. "Did he always look that ill?" asked the six-year-old. Let's hope not.

Five minutes beyond Lippiano is Monterchi, a hill town famed for its fresco by Piero della Francesca. The Madonna del Parto, shows Mary about to give birth and is the only major Renaissance depiction of the pregnant Virgin - amid the busloads of tourists are occasional pilgrimages of Italian mothers-to-be who come to pray at the sacred picture.

What's great about an art gallery that houses just one work, as Monterchi's does, is that it is entirely manageable even for a couple with daughters in tow aged eight, six and two. Indeed, this was my six-year-old's first go at artistic interpretation: "She doesn't look that happy to be having a baby, does she?" said Elinor, while her big sister Rosie chimed in with, "Well, Elinor, she didn't exactly want to have Jesus, did she? The Angel Gabriel talked her into it."

And when you tire of sightseeing, you know there'll be a glass of wine waiting for you at Villa Pia.

Way to go

Villa Pia, 06010 Lippiano, Italy. Tel 0039 075 850 2027 for more information. Villa Pia is open from the end of March to October and costs £440 per adult and £180 per under-12 per week, full board (under twos are free). We flew to Bologna with Go (0845 6054321,) for £78 each return, and hired a car through Autos Abroad (08700 667788) for £229 for seven days.

Everyone eats together at a long table, so inevitably you can find yourself sitting next to someone you might not want to spend two hours with, but the mix is big enough for the communal living not to get boring (Villa Pia can cater for up to 40 houseguests including children). The atmosphere is easy-going - it's the sort of place where you can leave your muddy shoes in the hall after a tramp through the hillside, and if you fancy some music you just put something you like on the CD player in the clutter-strewn hall. The bedrooms are large and most have extra beds in case you want to keep a close eye on the kids: all have bathrooms. In the kitchen, a huge fridge is packed with wine from the local vineyard, beer, fruit juice and milk - you're free to help yourself and your kids to whatever you want, whenever you want it. Morag, whose youngest child is just five months old, is almost always on hand to dispense advice about where to go and what to see. In fact it's more a question of what to miss out: Villa Pia is surrounded by cultural gems. Florence is 30 minutes away by train: Perugia, more interesting to the kids in its role as Italy's "chocolate city" than for its medieval art, is about an hour's drive, and Assisi, birthplace of St Francis, a little further away. When we finally managed to tear our children away from the swimming pool, the woods ("brilliant for making dens in", according to the kids) and the courtyard playroom, we plumped for Siena in neighbouring Tuscany. Sightseeing and young children don't exactly go hand in hand, but do your homework first and you can manage to see the essentials and still come away with your sanity intact. Siena is ideal in that there's only one place you've got to see and that's the Piazza del Campo: buy your kids a hunk of pizza and you can sit and admire the architecture while they chomp away in the sunshine. Round the corner is the black-and-white striped marble Duomo ("just like a zebra," said my six-year-old), and they all behaved passably well for a quick 10-minute tour - not what you'd have done BC, of course, stuffed as it is with Renaissance art, but as good as you'll get in the circumstances. Particularly good for little ones is the fact that the most accessible part of the cathedral, its floor, is littered with marble panels depicting all kinds of fascinating subjects from prophetesses to she-wolves. Our other big day out was to Gubbio with its perilous cable-car journey up the mountain to the Basilica of Saint Ubaldo. It's a six-minute ride, with fabulous views behind you to the city if you dare open your eyes - great for toddlers who can stand and peer through the railings as you rise up over the terracotta rooftops. In the church there's a further treat for the children - the chance to view the remains of old Ubaldo himself as he lies in state in a glass casket above a marble altar. "Did he always look that ill?" asked the six-year-old. Let's hope not. Five minutes beyond Lippiano is Monterchi, a hill town famed for its fresco by Piero della Francesca. The Madonna del Parto, shows Mary about to give birth and is the only major Renaissance depiction of the pregnant Virgin - amid the busloads of tourists are occasional pilgrimages of Italian mothers-to-be who come to pray at the sacred picture. What's great about an art gallery that houses just one work, as Monterchi's does, is that it is entirely manageable even for a couple with daughters in tow aged eight, six and two. Indeed, this was my six-year-old's first go at artistic interpretation: "She doesn't look that happy to be having a baby, does she?" said Elinor, while her big sister Rosie chimed in with, "Well, Elinor, she didn't exactly want to have Jesus, did she? The Angel Gabriel talked her into it." And when you tire of sightseeing, you know there'll be a glass of wine waiting for you at Villa Pia. Way to go Villa Pia, 06010 Lippiano, Italy. Tel 0039 075 850 2027 for more information. Villa Pia is open from the end of March to October and costs £440 per adult and £180 per under-12 per week, full board (under twos are free). We flew to Bologna with Go (0845 6054321,) for £78 each return, and hired a car through Autos Abroad (08700 667788) for £229 for seven days.

fields.headline: Sunken treasures
fields.standfirst: If you can't stand the heat, and we mean the searing heat of the Outback or the Sahara Desert, you can always dive for cover in one of the world's underground hotels
fields.trailText: If you can't stand the heat, and we mean the searing heat of the Outback or the Sahara Desert, you can always dive for cover in one of the world's underground hotels.
fields.body:
Can't stand the heat and dust? Staying underground is cool. Not that cool, however, which is why troglodyte communities, miners and monks were originally attracted to cave dwellings, enjoying miraculous natural insulation against extreme temperatures. Nowadays, converted caves, canyon hotels and even underwater rooms can add an exotic dimension to the holiday experience. Claustrophobes need not apply.

Coober Pedy, South Australia

Go down under, Down Under. Coober Pedy is a small but famous mining town along the beaten Alice Springs to Adelaide track. Famous not only for its opal production ("the Opal Capital of the World") but also for its underground lifestyle. Miners soon discovered the advantages of living underground to escape the heat of the summer (temperatures regularly hit 35C in the shade) and winter's cold desert nights. The underground "dugouts" provided comfortable even temperatures, and almost half the city's population still lives underground, their homes excavated into hillsides rather than dug from shafts. On any city tour you'll be treated to a below-ground cinema, home, church, museum and opal mine.

After this it makes sense to stay underground. Desert Cave is probably the most popular option, the world's only underground four-star hotel with restaurant, bar, pool, sauna, spa and gym cut out of the sandstone. You can sleep either underground or, in case of panic, one of a few above-ground suites.

 Tailor Made Travel (01386 712050) can arrange most holiday combinations to Australia. A two-day trip to Coober Pedy from Adelaide costs £352 including return flights, one night at the Desert Cave, airport transfer and a four-hour tour of the mining town. For a free copy of the Australia Travellers Guide, phone 0906 8633235 or visit www.australia.com

Matmata, Tunisia

Holidaymakers to Tunisia tend to fall into two camps. Those who come to flop on the Mediterranean at one of the sun-drenched resort hotels along the north-east coast. And those with a sense of adventure who prefer to experience the Sahara, the culture and the still desert nights. For the latter, the underground houses of Matmata are a must.

The Berbers who first inhabited this central southern region were troglodytes who, in the 4th century, created an almost invisible village. Although buildings have now extended above it, many of the 50 underground houses are still in use and three of the largest have been converted into hotels. Star Wars fans will recognise Luke Skywalker's sunken desert home, and perhaps the Hotel Sidi Driss, used for the alien jazz club sequence.

 Explore Worldwide (01252 760100) features one night in a cave hotel as part of its Ancient Carthage and Camel Safari trip. The 15-day tour costs from £565pp, including flights, transport, most meals, an Explore leader, driver, camel tenders and a cook during the three-day camel trek.

Cappadocia, Turkey

It took a few million years of volcanic activity from the three tall (but now peaceful) peaks in the region, and then a few more million years of weather erosion to bring us to today's dreamy scenery known as Cappadocia. Ancient Cappadocia was a huge province, but today's tourist visits are based on the rock cities, and the valley of Goreme, which lie between Nevsehir and Urgup 11 miles to the east. Tufa, blown into futuristic formations, fills the valley, between the lush gardens, citrus orchards, olive groves and vineyards.

If you're short on time, at least visit the Goreme open-air museum where more than two dozen churches make up the largest monastic complex in the region, all hewn out of the cliffs and crags, joined by stairs, paths and tunnels. Then there are the underground cities (six discovered so far, three excavated and lit for visitors). Each one accommodated several thousand inhabitants, with underground springs and elaborate ventilation systems. Derinkuyu is the best known, dropping at least 15 floors. The cities are interconnected by a network of tunnels, some as long as six miles.

 Tapestry Holidays (020-8235 7777), which tailors holidays throughout Turkey and Greece, has found the best place to stay, the beautiful and highly unusual Cave House Terrace. It consists of three properties: two hotels (seven rooms each) with a similar, third planned for this summer; and a self-catering house. Most people choose three to five days in Cappadocia followed by either Istanbul or a week on the coast. Sample price: four days in Cappadocia, one week on the coast costs £1,050 including flights, transfers and accommodation throughout. Prices include a personal guide at Cappadocia - strongly advised but not essential.

Loire Valley, France

Book a room in a rock. Les Hautes Roches Hotel in the Loire Valley offers just that, although it's a far cry from Fred Flintstone. This grand Relais Chateaux hotel is a converted monastery, standing against an imposing backdrop of soft tuffeau rock on the banks of the Loire River at Rochecorbon.

Many of the caves in this region, once excavated for their stone, are now recycled as wine cellars, mushroom farms and restaurants - Les Hautes Roches is most famous throughout France for its 15 troglodyte bedrooms and its gorgeous terraces overlooking the water. Caves also, by definition, provide fine cellarage - expect fine vintages on the menu. The Vouvray area is littered with dégustation-vente signs, and tastings are easier to come by here than anywhere else in the Loire Valley.

 Travelscene (020-8424 9648) features Les Hautes Roches as part of its self-drive short breaks programme. Two nights from £185pp including ferry. To book direct, call Relais Chateaux (00800 20000002) or the hotel: 86 quai de la Loire, 37210 Rochecorbon, Vouvray (00 33 2 47 52 88 88). Double rooms from Ffr650.

Grand Canyon, Arizona

There's underground. There's deep underground. And there's mind-bogglingly deep underground. Phantom Ranch, the only accommodation option actually inside the Grand Canyon, stands at the bottom of the inner gorge. Its cabins, corrals and outbuildings clustered around a central lodge stand just to the east of the point where Bright Angel Creek meets the Colorado River, a beautiful spot landscaped with huge cottonwood trees and fruit orchards. Guests stay in either cabins (reserved for the use of riders on Fred Harvey mule trips), or in 10-bunk dormitories, basic but comfortable. These cost $22 a night with bedding. Visitors inevitably arrive weary, having travelled down the canyon either on a mule, on foot or by rafting the Colorado, so hearty meals are available with dishes such as Hiker's Stew, and 12oz New York steaks served in the canteen.

 The waiting list is long, so you need to book at least 10-12 months in advance. Call 001 520 638 2631 direct or ask Ranch America (01923 671831) to help - it can package all manner of holidays in Arizona and elsewhere in America.

Cave Country, Andalucia

More than 300 people live in caves around the Hoya de Guadix plain area of Andalucia, making it the largest community of cave dwellers in Europe. It lies north-east of Granada, a dry, barren limestone area, semi-desert in places, quite unlike the snow-clad mountains of the Sierra Nevada that tower in the distance. There's no shortage of cave accommoda tion for visitors. Cuevas de Galera, overlooking the village of Galera, has 20 fascinating caves to choose from, each recently renovated to sleep from two to eight, and each named after a famous Moorish visitor to the area. These caves used to be dwellings, stables or grain stores and have been sensitively transformed using traditional furniture, bright Arab colours and fabrics. Cuevas Laveranda has more of a hotel feel to it, its 11 rooms carved out of the dry rocks of the Baza-Huescar valley with views over the pine forests and craggy peaks.

Those who prefer to self-cater may be happier in Cuevas Pedro Antonio de Alarcon, half a mile from the historic town of Guadix, where 19 cave apartments come kitted out with kitchenette, bathroom, TV and telephone.

 Mundi Color (020-7828 6021) offers some 50 cave rooms and apartments in Cave Country. Prices start at £17pp per night B&B.

Chez Vous, France

If you fancy self-catering as a troglodyte, Brittany Ferries (0870 5360360) can help. As part of its French holiday cottage programme, it offers three houses cut into the rocks along the river Loire. One is an authentic single-storey troglodyte house at the untouristy town of Langeais, built into the caves with all mod cons, minutes from an impressive chateau. The house is reached by climbing 20m down steps from the main road. The central heating, dishwasher, microwave, barbecue and cool cave garage have presumably been added since the days of the original inhabitants (one week from £228).

Further along the river at Asnières near the flower-filled town of Vendôme is a two-bedroomed cave-dwelling gîte, which has been skilfully built into the rocks by the stonemason owner (one week from £180). The third is a chambre d'hôte hotel close to the fascinating old town of Doue la Fontaine. Carved out of a rocky outcrop, the hotel has a heated outdoor pool, garden, terrace and bicycle hire. From £37pp a night half-board.

Gîte prices are per property, excluding ferry. Contact Brittany Ferries for both sea crossing and accommodation arrangements.

Key Largo, Florida

Florida may start off with Disney's razzamatazz, but the further south you travel, the mellower it becomes until, by the time you've left Miami and crossed the bridge into Bogart and Bacall's Key Largo, life is so laid-back you're nearly horizontal. The first and longest island of the Florida Keys, Key Largo is also famous for the John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park whose 78 square miles reef is North America's only living coral reef and is home to over 600 species of tropical fish. Visitors can snorkel, rent boats and tour in a glass-bottomed vessel. But those with diving certificates have an opportunity for closer encounters, at Jules' Undersea Lodge (001 305 451 2353). This tiny hotel is anchored 30ft below the water and can only be accessed by diving through tropical mangrove. Imagine staying in a submarine and you get the picture, except that these rooms are well equipped with private baths, round windows, and are linked to land by an intercom system. Can't dive? The hotel offers three-hour crash courses (£55), compulsory for beginners before they unpack. One night with gourmet dinner costs £250.

...and a couple you can sleep near

Havasu Canyon, Arizona

Havasu Canyon lies 35 miles north of Grand Canyon village. The land belongs to the Havasupai Indians who long ago decided against any road-building in the area, so most residents and tourists arrive by mule, horse or on foot. The star attractions are the canyon's four stunning waterfalls - Navajo Falls, Havasu Falls, Beaver Falls and Mooney Falls, the largest at 196ft. You can camp in the canyon on the delightful Havasu Campground, reserving a place in advance through Havasupai Tourist Enterprises (001 520 448 2121). The campsite is set in an especially narrow and high-walled section of the canyon, stretching for almost a mile as far as Mooney Falls, with tents pitched in clearings in the woods either side of the stream.

It's certainly primitive but drinking water is safely provided by fresh springs in the canyon wall. And when it's time to return to reality, one of the cluster of horses tethered at the entrance will carry you back up the hill.

 American Adventures & Roadrunner (01892 512700) tailors packages to include camping both within and just outside US national and state parks and operates small group trips through the Havasu Canyon area following set itineraries. It does not, however, feature Havasu Campground which has to be booked direct.

Temples of Ellora, India

The World Heritage-listed cave temples at Aurangabad in western India (above) are one of the world's umissable sights. Over five centuries, generations of Buddhist, Hindu and Jain monks carved monasteries, chapels and temples from a 2km escarpment and decorated them with elaborate sculptures. The caves are almost Egyptian in style, very like Abu Simbel inside and heavily painted with hieroglyphs. There are 34 in all, 12 Buddhist, 17 Hindu and five Jain. The best of all is the Kailasa Temple, the world's largest monolithic sculpture, dedicated to Shiva and hewn from the rock by 7,000 labourers over a 150-year period. Official guides can be hired outside Kailasa Temple.

 As part of a 24-night trip in India and Nepal, from Mumbai to Kathmandhu, Dragoman (01728 861133) includes camping around Ellora, although you cannot sleep inside the caves. The trip costs £700 plus a kitty of $250 including everything but flights, travelling in 24-person overland tour vehicles carrying two leaders and all camping gear.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Arizona

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Arizona
fields.standfirst: Miranda Sawyer
fields.trailText: Miranda Sawyer.
fields.body:
Why: It looks exactly like you'd hope - it has all these ridiculous, odd-shaped rocks sticking up in the air, mountains that are funny shapes and verdant valley floors. I first went there about two years ago, and then I liked it so much I went back again a year ago. We went into a bar and started playing pool and ended up playing with the bar owner. He was so nice and we got on so well, we ended up staying in his house which was great - a round house with a hot tub. It was weird because in America it's quite hard to find people to get on with - people are either incredibly straight, or they're a heroin addict. It's hard to find people in between.

The best thing: The scenery and the people. This one bar has live rock, which sounds terrible, but because it's close to LA you get great bands. And, of course, you can easily go to Las Vegas and Colorado.

A perfect day: Get up, go and have coffee in this place called the Happy Bean. Then I'd wander off into the Zion Valley itself and walk around for a bit. If I was feeling really energetic, I'd hire a mountain bike and go out for a ride. In the evening, I'd play pool and get drunk.

My advice: Go off-season and talk to people. If you go in the winter, you can go to the Grand Canyon and there's no one there. Hire a car - a convertible. There's no point banging about in a hard top car. Get a convertible, put a woolly hat on and go in January.

Getting there: A seven-night fly-drive to Los Angeles with British Airways Holidays (0870 2424243) costs from £440 per person (inclusive of taxes) for departures until April 30 based on two sharing, including return scheduled flights from Heathrow, hire of a convertible for the duration and free UK connecting flights from most regional airports.

 Miranda Sawyer's book, Park and Ride, is published by Abacus, £6.99, and is out now.

The best thing: The scenery and the people. This one bar has live rock, which sounds terrible, but because it's close to LA you get great bands. And, of course, you can easily go to Las Vegas and Colorado. A perfect day: Get up, go and have coffee in this place called the Happy Bean. Then I'd wander off into the Zion Valley itself and walk around for a bit. If I was feeling really energetic, I'd hire a mountain bike and go out for a ride. In the evening, I'd play pool and get drunk. My advice: Go off-season and talk to people. If you go in the winter, you can go to the Grand Canyon and there's no one there. Hire a car - a convertible. There's no point banging about in a hard top car. Get a convertible, put a woolly hat on and go in January. Getting there: A seven-night fly-drive to Los Angeles with British Airways Holidays (0870 2424243) costs from £440 per person (inclusive of taxes) for departures until April 30 based on two sharing, including return scheduled flights from Heathrow, hire of a convertible for the duration and free UK connecting flights from most regional airports.  Miranda Sawyer's book, Park and Ride, is published by Abacus, £6.99, and is out now.

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Ordering herbal tea in Spain and deterring thieves with a bucket.
fields.body:
When ordering herbal tea in Spain, ask for "mint" or "camomile" rather than "mint tea" or "camomile tea" as this causes confusion.
Rachael Davies

When travelling by car in areas of high risk from theft, carry a plastic bucket covered with a piece of sacking. Whenever the car is left parked without proper surveillance, fix a notice in the window stating: "Attention! Bees in transit."
D Heald

The 15ml storage case supplied with most contact lens solutions is the perfect size for enough cosmetics etc for weekend trips.
J Pemberton

In response to Yasmin Stefanov-King's Travel tip (March 31): I have holidayed in Moscow twice in the last year, and I have never seen Red Square other than open and free to enter or closed off so wonder if your correspondent paid a pensioner unnecessarily to get in. Also, I would counsel travellers not to try to be too 'clever' as I found strict controls, particularly when visiting Lenin's tomb."
Alan Phillips

"Having read Men Yen Lai's travel tip, I would like to offer my own equally useful one: When travelling abroad, take a pizza with you, just in case you can't find anywhere to eat."
Mark Tredgett

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: NYC Tourist Resources
fields.trailText: NYC Tourist Resources
fields.body:
A list of links. Why is that so exciting?

Because New York City has plenty of websites; but this one, which is run by mayor Rudy Giuliani's office, is by far the best. And according to the site, more than 957,000 Britons visited New York in 1999 - more visitors than from any other country.

How so?

It's the one site that links to the pick of the rest of the city guides. Activities for Kids, for instance, refers you to a page of advice and recommendations for keeping children happy in the city. Did you know that the ferry to Staten Island is free, or that New York has an art museum intended especially for children?

I don't have any.

Then try the suggested itineraries for shoppers (with advice on scams to avoid), first-time visitors, the Museum Mile and Outdoor New York.

Predictable stuff.

Follow the sports link to search for baseball games, or visit www.ilovethebronx.com, which has several hundred good reasons to visit the quarter. Even the Fun Facts section is more interesting than most: we learn that NY has 12,184 licensed cabs, 18,000 eating establishments and that the average cost of a dinner with tax, tip and drink was $33.17 last year.

Any drawbacks?

Unfortunately, the links section is full of company sites that have probably paid for a listing. If you want to find, say, the official Central Park site or the Empire State Building online, you're better off at www.citidex.com, the Yellow Pages of New York.

fields.headline: La Terrace, Folkestone
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort savours a little bit of France - in Kent
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort savours a little bit of France - in Kent.
fields.body:
Telephone: 01303 220 444
Address: La Terrasse, Sandgate Hotel, The Esplanade, Sandgate, Folkestone, Kent
Rating: 18.5/20

The subject of this week's review is La Terrasse, Sandgate Hotel, The Esplanade, Sandgate, Folkestone, Kent. Sandgate, Folkestone, Kent... what other names speak so eloquently of bourgeois decencies, propriety and tact? Sandgate, the shining epitome of seaside sobriety; Folkestone, a bastion of Daily Mail Britain; in Kent, its heartland. Most of all, however, I love that word "esplanade". It has magic in it. It has a seemly, orderly ring. It suggests Edwardian elegance, lemon light and the hiss of tidy Channel breakers on a shingle beach.

The Sandgate Hotel, looking out over the esplanade, has all of these qualities. More important, on the evening that Hermione and I stepped out of a howling blizzard that was raging through southern England, it had a blazing wood fire and the kind of seats from which it is difficult to lift yourself, so deeply do you sink into them, so cosseting is their embrace.

But there is nothing showy about the Sandgate Hotel, none of the gimcrackery of five-star flash. Instead, it has all the quiet virtues of respect for the enduring luxury of comfort that you seem to get only with a family-run establishment - or, as is the case with the Sandgate Hotel, a hôtel de famille. Yes, the Sandgate Hotel - and its restaurant, La Terrasse, in particular - are in air and in essence a little corner of France on the very edge of the other side of the Channel.

What other conclusion could you possibly come to when faced with service of such raffish French charm, and with dishes such as coquilles St Jacques po?lées aux truffes noires du Périgord, pomme ratte du Touquet et jus truffé monté au beurre? Monté au beurre (enriched with butter): doesn't that phrase send a shiver of pleasure down to your very withers?

Tron?on de turbot rôtie aux cèpes, sauce à la lie de vin rouge; noisettes de chevreuil, sauce Grand Veneur au chocolat amer et garniture chasse; moelleux "pur Cara?be" Valhrona tiède, crème d'amandes amères et place au café grillé. This is French cooking of a very specific kind, rooted firmly in a region, buffed and burnished to a handsome sheen by the disciplines and standards of the haute cuisine kitchen.

The chef - who is also the co-proprietor along with his wife, Zara - is Samuel Gicqueau, who comes from the Vendée, a place of wind and water. It may be this, or the proximity of the sea on his own doorstep, that accounts for the large proportion of fish dishes on the menu. From among them, Hermione selected the carpaccio de coquilles St Jacques au caviar oscietra, tagliatelle de concombre à la crème fra?che accidulé et ciboulette. I could scarcely contain my excitement at the sight of fricassé d'anguilles, pommes ratte du Touquet écrasée à l'ail et artichaut. Eel, eel, I could sing a hymn to the eel as a fish to eat. Most people squirm at the very thought. I smack my lips in anticipation.

But eel has to be handled carefully. It is a fish of liver-thrashing richness. Unless the fat is cooked out of it, it can taste like greasy blotting paper. This eel had been rendered to a state of crisp perfection. The outside had a light, friable rime that gave way to a succulent, firm flesh of distinctive flavour.

The garlic, artichoke and potatoes provided earthy doo-wah-wah backing to the piscine richness, with a well-moulded chicken stock lubricating the elements.

Hermione's carpaccio of scallops was more refined and, if anything, even richer. It is easy to forget just how filling fish actually is. The surface of a large plate was covered in wavelets of thin, opalescent slices of scallop, which had that penetrating sweetness you get only with very, very fresh shellfish. There had been no stinting with the caviar studding this lagoon of scallops, which was sprinkled with sea salt that crunched agreeably between the teeth. In fact, the dish would have been too salty had it not been for the bland but crunchy tagliatelle of cucumber.

From there, she progressed on to the noisettes of venison with the classically appropriate red wine-based sauce Grande Veneur that had been given new life and oomph by the addition of chocolate. This was grand cooking. The venison was mellow flavoured, cooked enough not to offend the sensibility that baulks at blood, not over-cooked to make life difficult for the dentally challenged.

If that dish was like the brass section of an orchestra, my canon d'agneau de Romney Marsh rôti, jus simple au romarin et tian de légumes aux saveurs de Provence provided the strings. In the midst of foot-and-mouth mayhem, it was cheering to be reminded just how good British meat is when sourced with care, butchered with skill and cooked with real respect for its qualities. All M. Gicqueau had done was to provide the lamb with the accompaniments to show off its herbal sweetness, depth of flavour and natural tenderness. The gravy was a superb example of self-effacing support, its own balance helping to bring out the shining quality of the meat, and the vegetables robust enough to bring a change of direction without upsetting the equilibrium of the whole.

If ever a dinner called for a pudding, this was it: for me, the chocolate and almond cream thingy proved irresistible, while Hermione cleared her palate with pomme soufflé au calvados, beurre de cidre au pommeau et son croustillant glacé. Both of these dishes were on a par with what had gone before, and very quickly went the same way.

It's not often these days that I come across a menu on which I want to eat every dish, but I would have happily permed any of the seven first courses, seven main courses and five puddings, and still come out purring.

As befits such a place, the wine list is also almost exclusively French - well, the most serious part of it is, anyway - but when those wines are of such consistent excellence, why on earth would you complain? They go exceptionally well with the dishes. Certainly our bottle of Alain Graillot's Crozes-Hermitage stood up with great elegance and force to the battering our dishes gave it, and was worth every one of its 29 pounds. On top of that, we had a glass of this and that, water and such, so that the liquid element of the bill came to £46. The food came to £92, and so the total was £138.

Now, £138 is more than a day's wages where I come from, but finding French cooking in England of such quality is rarer than an Andy Cole goal in an England shirt.

· Open Lunch, Wed-Sun, 12.15-1.30pm; dinner, Tues-Sat, 7.15-9.30pm Menus Midweek lunch/dinner, £22 for three courses; Friday dinner-Sunday lunch, £31 for five courses. Cards All major credit cards. Wheelchair access (no wheelchair WC).

fields.headline: Himalayan high life
fields.standfirst: You can now do the best bits of Nepal - from soaring views to an elephant safari - in one hit.  Sarah Barrell finds the perfect introduction
fields.trailText: You can now do the best bits of Nepal - from soaring views to an elephant safari - in one hit. Sarah Barrell finds the perfect introduction.
fields.body:
The propellers of our tiny plane make prayer-wheel rotations up and out of the Kathmandu Valley. Ahead lie clouds full of treacherous skewer-peaked mountains, and below are the beady painted eyes of the city's Buddhist stupas.

Domestic air travel in Nepal takes you to a spiritual plane: Buddha Air, Cosmic Air and Shangri-La Airways are your choice of carriers; nowhere is there a better reason to shun unhurried terrestrial transport for a quick hit of high-altitude panorama.

Above our destination, Pokhara, the Annapurna range thrusts sharp, snowy peaks 8,000m towards to the heavens. Everest, in eastern Nepal, is higher, but Pokhara offers uniquely accessible, uninterrupted mountain viewing from their subtropical base right up to Machhapuchhare, the Fish Tail, the region's most distinctive triangular peak. Searching for the summit, even from our position on a hilltop ridge 1,000ft above the Pokhara Valley, it's as if someone has realigned the horizon; no matter how many times you look, your eyes settle several degrees too low.

After a dusk walk through monsoon river channels, I retire to our lodge's library to read antiquated mountaineering literature. The Story of Man at Altitude, complete with intrepid black-and-white base-camp pictures accompanies me to an early bed in preparation for a 6am expedition, to the viewing terrace.

There, the dawn clouds blush pink and obligingly part to reveal Dhaulagiri, Machhapuchhare and the five Annapurna peaks. As the sun struggles above the mountains, I can't tear my eyes away. But we have a raft to catch. I leave, walking backwards like a reverential courtier and hop in a jeep to make a coccyx-crushing journey along unsealed roads to the river.

By noon, I am soaked and the mountains are obscured by a charging veil of white water and mossy over-hanging rock; the Seti River gorge rises above us tall as skyscrapers, its emerald roof gardens over-spilling.

According to our guide, Captain Dahn Gurung, these waters are "only a grade two", but at the front of the boat I'm swallowing more than enough water to convince me otherwise (badly timed girlie screaming). In between soakings, there's ample time for twitching: me squirming in my wet trousers and a boatload of bird spotters behind. Nepal is home to some 800 species. And as we head south, so do they on their autumnal journey from central Asia to India. Dahn delicately points out teeny iridescent kingfishers and bank-nesting sand martins that I would have otherwise missed.

But stranger creatures ply the river. As the game of ornithological I Spy gets technical, I drift off, daydreaming; ahead of us lies bubbling water tumbling over what looks like the edge of the world. I am remembering the Utter East from CS Lewis's The Voyage of the Dawn Treader, when, what should drift by but a Monopod smoking a cigarette. Actually, it's a very cool kayak resembling a sultan's shoe. It ducks past us, sports-car black with fenders shinier than the shades worn by its owner whose torso pokes out the top.

Dahn was leader of the national team that won the world triathlon championship for running, cycling and river rafting in 1993, and I'm glad that we have a sporting hero to put us ashore at our tented camp. Capsize at this remote point on the river and it's a two-hour (steep) uphill climb to anything approaching the nearest village; and roads. You'd be better off swimming.

Such glorious isolation makes for a blissful night's sleep - that and some wine-fuelled campfire singing, drowned out eloquently by the camp's chef on a two-sided drum. And the next morning (smug with a day's experience under our squelching life-jackets) we are more than ready for the "cheese-grater", the worst of the Seti's rapids.

By process of osmosis, I have become one with the river, but too soon we are through the white-water and the Seti flattens as we rejoin civilisation. I feel reluctant to leave my soggy seat and do road-battle with the honking shrines-on-wheels that are Nepali buses. But in a flash of gaudy four-wheeled transport (even tractors are painted with psychedelic Aum signs), we are at Tharu Safari Lodge, on the edge of Royal Chitwan National Park.

It's hard to believe that the Terai, Nepal's southern flatland, bordering India, was once covered in thick malarial jungle. Today, after liberal sprinklings of DDT and population shifts from resource-hungry hills (and India) the region represents some 70% of the country's arable land. Tharu lodge, built as a traditional grass and clay "longhouse", sits in the middle of a busy string of rural villages.

I gingerly take a ride on one of the lodge's beautiful horses and run into a rush-hour herd of sacred cattle. But these villages around the buffer zone of the national park have wilder creatures to worry about than clumsy westerners on horseback; the grassy fringes of the jungle are a natural habit for "chital" (spotted deer) and a prime feeding ground for the Bengal tiger.

The following morning, at Tharu's sister lodge, Tiger Tops, I climb aboard something a little bigger, an elephant by the name of Samser Bahadur ("brave as the biggest tiger"). We crash through 12ft pink-flowering elephant grass, tracking fresh tiger prints. Autumn, with its mild climate, is the preferred time for elephant safaris but the season's long grasses present a needle-in-a-haystack challenge for those trying to spot leopard and tiger. "This is a very different experience to Africa," explains lodge manager Marcus Cotton. "The Big Five aren't laid out for you here; the thrill is very much in the chase."

Rhinos are less bashful, however. We've been on elephant back, rolling through the jungle like a primordial bulldozer, for no more than five minutes when we come across two of the battle-clad beasts. We get within 10 metres before they make the sound of a waste-disposal unit on overdrive and disappear into the undergrowth. The next two, a mother and baby are less impressed by Samser's nosey trunk and make to charge us. Alarming even sitting atop 40 tons of elephant.

As we make our way back to the lodge, a flesh-eating mugger crocodile eyes us from the riverbank (it may have been the fish-eating gharial but without binoculars, I about to check).

As dusk sheaths the jungle in an eerie mist, we hear the scream of jackals, perhaps warning of a tiger attack. Though we haven't seen a whisker, tigers are here in impressive numbers thanks largely to Nepal's pioneering anti-poaching campaign. Some 120 are watched over by a battalion of the Nepalese army (800 soldiers in 32 checkpoints throughout the park).

Later that day, while I experience what has to be the most blissful plane delay in history, Vayu, a local villager and former safari guide, regales me with tall tiger tales. Idling on the "runway" at Meghauli Airport - a lush stretch of grass that doubles up once a year as the World Elephant Polo pitch currently maintained by grazing goats - I listen to stories of feline stealth. One improbable cat burglary involved the theft of an infrared camera, used to monitor the tigers' behaviour. It was found days later, badly chewed, and the only proof left on tape was a glorious display of a stripy behind.

Way to go

Himalayan Kingdoms (01453 844400) runs 13-day First Class Tours costing £2,395 per person and includes return flights, accommodation (four nights' B&B at Dwarika's Hotel in Katmandu, full board elsewhere) transfers, all guides and activities.
