Actually, it's a very cool kayak resembling a sultan's shoe. It ducks past us, sports-car black with fenders shinier than the shades worn by its owner whose torso pokes out the top. Dahn was leader of the national team that won the world triathlon championship for running, cycling and river rafting in 1993, and I'm glad that we have a sporting hero to put us ashore at our tented camp. Capsize at this remote point on the river and it's a two-hour (steep) uphill climb to anything approaching the nearest village; and roads. You'd be better off swimming. Such glorious isolation makes for a blissful night's sleep - that and some wine-fuelled campfire singing, drowned out eloquently by the camp's chef on a two-sided drum. And the next morning (smug with a day's experience under our squelching life-jackets) we are more than ready for the "cheese-grater", the worst of the Seti's rapids. By process of osmosis, I have become one with the river, but too soon we are through the white-water and the Seti flattens as we rejoin civilisation. I feel reluctant to leave my soggy seat and do road-battle with the honking shrines-on-wheels that are Nepali buses. But in a flash of gaudy four-wheeled transport (even tractors are painted with psychedelic Aum signs), we are at Tharu Safari Lodge, on the edge of Royal Chitwan National Park. It's hard to believe that the Terai, Nepal's southern flatland, bordering India, was once covered in thick malarial jungle. Today, after liberal sprinklings of DDT and population shifts from resource-hungry hills (and India) the region represents some 70% of the country's arable land. Tharu lodge, built as a traditional grass and clay "longhouse", sits in the middle of a busy string of rural villages. I gingerly take a ride on one of the lodge's beautiful horses and run into a rush-hour herd of sacred cattle. But these villages around the buffer zone of the national park have wilder creatures to worry about than clumsy westerners on horseback; the grassy fringes of the jungle are a natural habit for "chital" (spotted deer) and a prime feeding ground for the Bengal tiger. The following morning, at Tharu's sister lodge, Tiger Tops, I climb aboard something a little bigger, an elephant by the name of Samser Bahadur ("brave as the biggest tiger"). We crash through 12ft pink-flowering elephant grass, tracking fresh tiger prints. Autumn, with its mild climate, is the preferred time for elephant safaris but the season's long grasses present a needle-in-a-haystack challenge for those trying to spot leopard and tiger. "This is a very different experience to Africa," explains lodge manager Marcus Cotton. "The Big Five aren't laid out for you here; the thrill is very much in the chase." Rhinos are less bashful, however. We've been on elephant back, rolling through the jungle like a primordial bulldozer, for no more than five minutes when we come across two of the battle-clad beasts. We get within 10 metres before they make the sound of a waste-disposal unit on overdrive and disappear into the undergrowth. The next two, a mother and baby are less impressed by Samser's nosey trunk and make to charge us. Alarming even sitting atop 40 tons of elephant. As we make our way back to the lodge, a flesh-eating mugger crocodile eyes us from the riverbank (it may have been the fish-eating gharial but without binoculars, I about to check). As dusk sheaths the jungle in an eerie mist, we hear the scream of jackals, perhaps warning of a tiger attack. Though we haven't seen a whisker, tigers are here in impressive numbers thanks largely to Nepal's pioneering anti-poaching campaign. Some 120 are watched over by a battalion of the Nepalese army (800 soldiers in 32 checkpoints throughout the park). Later that day, while I experience what has to be the most blissful plane delay in history, Vayu, a local villager and former safari guide, regales me with tall tiger tales. Idling on the "runway" at Meghauli Airport - a lush stretch of grass that doubles up once a year as the World Elephant Polo pitch currently maintained by grazing goats - I listen to stories of feline stealth. One improbable cat burglary involved the theft of an infrared camera, used to monitor the tigers' behaviour. It was found days later, badly chewed, and the only proof left on tape was a glorious display of a stripy behind. Way to go Himalayan Kingdoms (01453 844400) runs 13-day First Class Tours costing £2,395 per person and includes return flights, accommodation (four nights' B&B at Dwarika's Hotel in Katmandu, full board elsewhere) transfers, all guides and activities.

fields.headline: Fresh air mags
fields.trailText: British Airways and Virgin Atlantic relaunch their inflight magazines.
fields.body:
Both British Airways and Virgin Atlantic relaunched their inflight magazines last week with the April issue. The costly revamps, complete with redesigns, launch parties and celebrity editors were designed to draw attention to this overlooked artform. Why? Well, it's all about branding and loyalty; about making the passenger feel as if they belong in that upright seat sipping a gin and tonic while flicking through the kind of style mag you'd pick up on the high street.

Virgin hired Ekow Eshun, former Arena editor and TV cultural commentator, to revamp Hot Air, now 13 years old. Eshun, as you might imagine, is not a "10 things to do in Barcelona on a weekend break" editor. In fact, he brazenly declares, "I'm not interested in doing an 'inflight' magazine". This explains why Hot Air looks more like the bastard offspring of The Face and Wallpaper* with its cover shot of the view up Angelina Jolie's nostrils. The word inflight does not appear. Nor does the Virgin logo.

Jolie, Jared Leto and Subbuteo are the kind of deliberately kooky thirtysomething subjects that fill Hot Air. There is a piece about golf, but it's about golf for the under-35s and it addresses the problem of what to wear if you're too cool for Argyle sweaters. Slightly outsize and printed on super-cool coarse paper rather than sleekly glossy, it's a smart, stylish magazine whose only gesture to travel is tips on how to pack a weekend bag properly.

But being sufficiently avant-garde for the thirty-somethings risks alienating their parents. Virgin head of media Lysettse Gauna says its passengers are on average between 35 and 40 anyway.

High Life, from BA, is more instantly recognisable for what it is. That BA logo on the cover for a start. But, just as Jude Law - the pouting cover star - is in more conventional pose, the features list is a more predictable mix of travel-based reportage: Sri Lanka, Florence, Indian food, Seville and Dubai to name a few. While there are strokes of rebellion (Will Self writes on Britain), there's nothing to upset the parents and there's even an amusing piece about Jack Nicklaus. The back section is reassuringly filled with route maps and TV listings for the inflight channels.

It's a good, substantial and well-produced magazine aimed at a wide range of people. Which, I suppose, is what BA is.

If you're Virgin, you've got to be a bit edgy. If you're BA, you can just sit in the middle ground and soak up the rest. And, let's face it, nobody ever chose an airline by which magazine they get to read.

webTitle: Chris Bart-Williams: A watch | My own chef | My gold necklace

fields.headline: I never travels without...
fields.trailText: A watch | My own chef | My gold necklace
fields.body:
A necessity: A watch - preferably a Patek Philippe. I feel totally naked without one. It's not really about always knowing what time it is; I just reckon that having a good timepiece on your wrist is the finishing touch to a person.

A luxury: My own chef. He'd have to be a dab-hand at Italian, West Indian and Chinese food.

A memento: My gold necklace. It's special because my mum gave it to me about 11 years ago for my birthday. And it's always brought me luck.

If only: If I ever found myself marooned on a desert island, I think I'd enjoy the company of Halle Berry, Rene Russo and Elle Macpherson.

 Chris Bart-Williams, captain of Nottingham Forest, was a presenter at this year's Choice FM awards.

webTitle: Sonnets from Hellas by Seamus Heaney

fields.headline: Sonnets from Hellas
fields.body:
1 Into Arcadia
It was opulence and amen on the mountain road.
Walnuts bought on a high pass from a farmer
Who'd worked in Melbourne once and now trained
water
Through a system of pipes and runnels of split reed
Known in Hellas, probably, since Hesiod -
That was the least of it. When we crossed the border
From Argos into Arcadia, and farther
Into Arcadia, a lorry load
Of apples had burst open on the road
So that for yards our tyres raunched and scrunched
them
But we drove on, juiced up and fleshed and spattered,
Revelling in it. And then it was the goatherd
With his goats in the forecourt of the filling station,
Subsisting behond eclogue and translation.

2 Conkers

All along the dank, sunk rock-floored lane
To the acropolis in Sparta, we couldn't help
Tramping on burst shells and crunching down
The high-gloss horse-chestnuts. I thought of kelp
And foals' hooves, bladderwort, dubbed leather
As I bent to gather them, a hint of ordure
Coming and going off their tainted pith.
Cyclopic stone on each side of the path.
Rings of defence. Breached walls. The looted conkers
Gravid in my satchel, swinging nicely.
Then a daylight moon appeared behind Dimitri
As he sketched and squared his shoulders like a centaur's
And nodded, nodded, nodded towards the spouses,
Heard but not seen behind much thick acanthus.

3 Pylos

Barbounia schooled below the balcony -
Shadows on shelving sand in sandy Pylos.
Wave-clip and flirt, tide-slap and flop and flow:
I woke to the world there like Telemachos,
Young again in the whitewashed light of morning
That flashed on the ceiling like an early warning
From myself to be more myself in the mast-bending
Marine breeze, to key the understanding
To that image of the bow strung as a lyre
Robert Fitzgerald spoke of: Harvard Nestor,
Sponsor and host, translator of all Homer,
His wasted face in profile, ceiling-staring
As he schooled me in the course, not yet past caring,
Scanning the offing, Far-seeing shadower.

4 The Augean Stables

My favourite bas-relief: Athene showing
Heracles where to broach the river bank
With a nod of her high helmet, her staff sunk
In the exact spot, the Alpheus flowing
Out of its course into the deep dung strata
Of King Augeas' reeking yard and stables.
Sweet dissolutions from the water tables,
Blocked doors and packed floors deluging like gutters...
And it was there in Olympia, down among green willows,
The lustral wash and run of river shallows,
That we heard of Sean Brown's murder in the grounds
Of Bellaghy GAA Club. And imagined
Hose-water smashing hard back off the asphalt
In the car park where his athlete's blood ran cold.

5 Castalian Spring

Thunderface. Not Zeus's ire, but hers
Refusing entry, and mine mounting from it.
This one thing I had vowed: to drink the waters
Of the Castalian Spring , to arrogate
That much to myself and be the poet
Under the God Apollo's giddy cliff -
But the inner water sanctum was roped off
When we arrived. Well then, to hell with that,
And to hell with all who'd stop me, thunderface!
So up the steps then, into the sandstone grottoes,
The seeps and dreeps, the shallow pools, the mosses,
Come from beyond, and come far, with this useless
Anger draining away, on terraces
Where I bowed and mouthed in sweetness and defiance.

6 Desfina

Mount Parnassus placid on the skyline:
Slieve na mBard, Knock Filiocht, Ben Duan,
We gaelicized new names for Poetry Hill
As we wolfed down horta, tarama and houmos
At sunset in the farmyard, drinking ouzos,
Pretending not to hear the Delphic squeal
Of the steel-haired cailleach in the scullery.
Then it was time to head into Desfina
To allow them to sedate her. And so retsina,
Anchovies, squid, dolmades, french fries even.
My head was light, I was hyper, boozed, borean
As we bowled back down towards the olive plain,
Siren-tyred and manic on the horn
Round hairpin bends looped like boustrophedon.

fields.headline: Taking Stock
fields.standfirst: Shaking off its expensive tag, the Swedish capital is fast becoming one of Europe's hippest cities
fields.trailText: Shaking off its expensive tag, the Swedish capital is fast becoming one of Europe's hippest cities.
fields.body:
Stockholm has traditionally been viewed as an expensive destination, but the rise of low-cost airlines and the strength of the pound means there's never been a better time to visit. And Stockholm hotels, packed during the week with business people and bureaucrats,are prepared to discount at weekends.

What to see

First buy a Stockholm Card (Skr220/£15 for 24 hours, children £4 from any tourist office or the Hotellcentralen at Central Station) which gives you unlimited access to virtually all the city's museums, unlimited travel on buses, trams, ferries and the metro system (T-bana), as well as substantial discounts on boat trips and tours.

At the top of your itinerary must be a wander round the Old Town, Gamla Stan, with its maze of narrow cobbled streets and tall honey-coloured buildings. The Riksdaghuset (Parliament House) has free guided tours in English at 1.30pm at weekends. Close by is the baroque royal palace Kungliga Slottet. The 15th-century Storkyrkan (The Great Church) is the nearest Stockholm gets to a cathedral, with a far more ornate interior than you might expect of a Lutheran church.

From the southern end of Gamla Stan, take the ferry to Djurg rden. This large green island used to be a royal hunting park but now houses the Skansen, the world's first open-air museum. Cottages and working villages show typical Swedish dwellings and lifestyles from centuries past. There's also an enclosure of Nordic animals, including elk, bear and wolf. But the must-see on this island is Vasamuseet where the restored 17th-century warship Vasa is housed. After sinking on its maiden voyage in 1628, this massive ship was preserved in mud for over three centuries. In an incredible feat of engi neering, the ship was raised intact in the 60s and brought to its new home. Truly awesome.

Where to eat

Eating out needn't be pricey. As well as the ubiquitous tunnbrödrulle - a delicious snack consisting of a frankfurter, mashed potato, salad and relish rolled up inside a bread pancake, costing about £2.20 - most restaurants offer a fixed-price lunch - dagens rätt - for a little over £4. Great value traditional Swedish lunches are also served in the beer halls of Södermalm.

If you're on a tight budget, head for the underground market Hötorgshallen on Hötorget, a square on Norrmalm's main street Kungsgatan. At the back is a fantastic stall-come-café serving an amazing fish soup for around £4 including bread and salad, and if you're really hungry refills are free. Expect to queue.

Evening meals are generally more expensive, and wine starts at around £15. On Gamla Stan, you can eat very well at reasonable prices at Costas (Lilla Nygatan 21, no need to book, around £35 for two with beers).

Probably the best restaurant on Gamla Stan is Leijontornet (Lilla Nygatan 5, tel 00 46 8 14 23 55), a vaulted cellar under the Victory Hotel; the centrepiece is a 13th-century section of the city wall. The menu combines traditional Swedish dishes with modern European cuisine, but at around £40 for three courses, it doesn't come cheap, although there is a fixed-price menu at about £30 a head, and the bistro upstairs is cheaper.

Berns (Berzelli Park, Nybroplan, tel: 00 46 8 566 322 22) has been popular with Stockholmers since the 19th century; local writer August Strindberg drew the inspiration for his novel The Red Room from here. The bistro next door offers a reasonably-priced alternative to the main restaurant's formality; three courses shouldn't set you back any more than £22.

Bars and nightlife

Stockholm claims to have more bars per capita than any other European city. Beer is slightly more expensive than the UK, around £2.50-£3 for a 400ml glass, and comes in three strengths; avoid the weakest unless you plan to be drinking all day.

Take the T-bana to Medborgarplatsen and head for Pelikan (Blekingegatan 40). This fantastic old beer hall has an implausibly high ceiling and is full of character.

The nearby Kvarnen, (Tjärhovsgtan 4) is another a bohemian watering-hole, where journalists and artists mingle with supporters of local football club Hammarby.

Behind is Södermalm's trendiest bar, the seriously minimalist H20.

It's also worth visiting Gondolen (Stadsg rden 6, T-bana Slussen), a penthouse bar at the northern end of Söder malm, opposite Gamla Stan. Entrance is via a lift and the bar affords fantastic views of Stockholm, especially at night.

Most of the best clubs are in Norrmalm. They're open until 5am and drinks cost much the same as in the bars. The trendiest is Spybar (Birger Jarlsgatan 20, tel: 00 46 8 545 037 04, fax 00 46 8 545 03709). Popular with visiting celebs, you either need to be one of the beautiful people to get in or blag your way on to the guest list. To do this, send a fax to the number above, two days in advance. Admission is around £7.

Otherwise, aim for Sturecompaniet (Sturegallerian 30, tel: 00 46 8 611 78 00), a club on several floors with a huge Gothic atrium that serves as a dance floor. Mainly dance music, admission costs about £6.

Where to stay

Aim for the Old Town if possible; it's charming, compact and - best of all - central.

On Gamla Stan, Lady Hamilton Hotel (Storkyrkobrinken 5, tel: 00 46 8 506 401 00) combines antique charm with all modern luxuries. Double rooms from £130.

The Rica City Gamla Stan (Lilla Nygatan 25) is an elegant hotel with reasonable rates (doubles from £85). Its sister hotel in Norrmalm (Kungsgatan, tel: 00 46 8 723 72 20) offers doubles at just £53 if you don't want a view.

And AF Chapman (tel: 00 46 8 463 22 66) is a fully-rigged sailing ship, now centrally moored and doubling as a youth hostel. Prices from £13.50 per night.

Incredible hotel weekend deals can be found at www.stockholm-hotels.demon.co.uk, and www.stockholmguesthouse.com offers great rates for B&B.

Getting there

Ryanair (0870 1569569) from London Stansted to Skvasta (90 mins by coach to Stockholm) from £18 return plus taxes (we paid £77 each). SAS (0845 6072772) from Heathrow, Gatwick, Birmingham, Manchester, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen from £98 return.

 The Swedish Travel and Tourism Council's information line is 020-7870 5600; 24-hour brochure line: 01476 578 811; or e-mail: info@swetourism.org

fields.headline: Hop picker
fields.standfirst: Anne McHardy plots the best routes and the best deals
fields.trailText: Anne McHardy plots the best routes and the best deals.
fields.body:
The first glimpse that tens of thousands of travellers have of France is Calais' spaghetti swirl of road between belching refineries. But, although lacking the picturesque qualities of Roscoff, St Malo or Dieppe, the port is not without advantages.

The volume of traffic means that if you miss your booked crossing or if your carrier is on strike at Dover or Folkestone, you have easier alternatives than the horrors that my family has endured of a forced drive from Newhaven to Dover when problems have hit the Newhaven-Dieppe route.

Competition at Calais between rival carriers P&O Stena, SeaFrance, Hoverspeed and Eurotunnel has led to price benefits for the consumer. All have different styles. P&O is the brashest with more shopping, but with Club Class seclusion and priority booking available. SeaFrance bills itself as France already, with brasseries right in the bow and crashing waves through the windows to add spectacle. Hoverspeed with upgraded faster craft, has plush on-board facilities and first class for priority loading and food.

Eurotunnel has the fastest crossing, minimal weather problems, plus the advantage for pet owners or the disabled of travelling in your car, without the hassle of leaving Fido alone or negotiating stairs yourself. Its club class is pricey - but lets you queue jump to board the next crossing ahead of non-club cars. Useful at peak time.

Ports further south offer better ambience for the first cup of French coffee and less time, petrol and temper expended on motorways, but noticeably fewer bargains.

All the Calais operators had book-early-for-summer packages and now the new range of offers is beginning to percolate through, although officially summer brochure prices prevail. P&O is offering a £30 meal voucher with some fares, for instance. Eurotunnel has insurance deals. Depending on how busy the season proves, more offers will surface. When you are booking, check for new offers. No brochure price is immutable.

Remember also that price should be weighed in the balance with the cost of a long road slog. And all cross-Channel operators have other offers, often with stopovers, and deals are to be found through membership clubs, from caravan owners to vintage cars, to the carriers' own frequent travellers' schemes. Look out for loss leaders, especially from the new internet companies.

Sometimes, there is nothing better than a stop over. French hotels are generally better and cheaper than British ones, as are B&Bs, Chambre de Hôtes. There are stop-over packages aplenty. Some are determinedly French; those of Chez-Nous as determinedly English or English speaking. Apart from the mid-July to mid-August French holiday weeks, particularly the ultimate Continental Bank Holiday of August 15, if you are equipped with a Logis, or Gîte or camping site guide - most available from the French tourist office, Maison de la France - problems finding accomodation are rare.

This side of the Channel, the first decision is the choice of ports. If you live in Edinburgh, Dover is a lousy option when you have P&O North Sea in Hull. They take you overnight to Zeebrugge, and from there the drive to Paris is more scenic than the M1 through Birmingham and only 20 miles further than Calais to Paris.

Similarly, Portsmouth, Plymouth and Poole all suit some better. St Malo and Roscoff, quaint small ports both, deliver you into Brittany or the south of Normandy, but for the Mediterranean, a better bet is Le Havre, Caen or even Calais and the motorway network. For Paris, Calais, Caen or Le Havre have direct motorways, but Dieppe is closest and only 20 miles from the motorway.

Brittany Ferries, operating Plymouth-Roscoff, Portsmouth-Caen, and Poole- St Malo, has a range of midweek deals - and an advantage that P&O lost when it split into separate operations. You can take one port out and another in, say Caen out, if you fancy a meander, taking advantage of the wealth of journey-breaking offers, from chateaux to campsites, and Roscoff return. A joint arrangement with the smallest of the carriers, Condor Ferries, operating from Poole to St Malo via the Channel Islands, offers a fourth permutation for foot passengers.

For them, Condor Ferries provides an interesting crossing, especially if you fancy a couple of days in the Channel Islands. Cars cannot be disembarked, but Condor is the only carrier offering duty free, since the Channel Islands remain "foreign" for Customs.

It seems madness that P&O Stena, P&O Portsmouth and P&O North Sea cannot sell a joint return package, say Dover-Calais out, Cherbourg-Portsmouth home. You can buy two singles - but that rules out cheap packages. P&O Portsmouth can do its own mix - say Bilbao one way and Le Havre the other, for the Normandy beaches or Bayeux and its tapestry. Bilbao, useful for the South of France, seems expensive, about £300 extra for a family, but it is a 36-hour trip, therefore a mini-cruise, for those who fancy cruising. But for three related companies not to be able to offer combined deals seems like missing a trick.

Across the Channel, the question of diversity is exercising French unions and politicians, concerned that the number of ports is shrinking. Dieppe town council is up in arms about the Newhaven crossing. The French railway company, SNCF, which owns SeaFrance, used to operate the route, but the company shows no interest now. The only operator is Hoverspeed which runs a seasonal fast-craft service from March 31 to the end of October. Hoverspeed has declared that it is committed to Newhaven-Dieppe, but since it pulled out of Dover-Boulogne last September, leaving Boulogne with no passenger carrier, the French are wary.

Seine-Maritime Department, Dieppe's parent authority, is negotiating with the owners of Hoverspeed, Sea Containers, to buy the Newhaven Port. With an Italian carrier, Corsica Ferries, it plans to restart a traditional ferry service, closed three years ago by P&O Stena.

Boulogne has the advantage over Dieppe of being as easy to reach from Calais Port as is Calais town centre, but it is still a pity we passengers have lost the option of going straight into its harbour.

Hoverspeed, which says it could not justify maintaining two operations 20 miles apart, has invested this year in new Superseacats, which went into operation Dover-Calais and Dover-Ostend last month. A three-year-old Seacat will upgrade Newhaven-Dieppe. The Dover-Calais journey time will be cut to 40 minutes, the shortest sea crossing, only five minutes longer than Eurotunnel.

fields.headline: Clifford Shull
fields.standfirst:
Nobel prize-winning physicist whose work helped to unlock the secrets of the atom

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Nobel prize-winning physicist whose work helped to unlock the secrets of the atom.
fields.body:
Over the past 50 years, research by academic and industrial scientists in microelectronics, plastics, pharmaceuticals and other fields has depended on the technique of neutron scattering to reveal the detailed arrangements of atoms in solids and liquids.

Clifford Shull, who has died aged 85, was a pioneer of this method of unlocking the most intimate secrets of the structure of materials that were difficult to probe by any other means. He shared the Nobel prize for physics in 1994 for his discoveries.

Shull's research in neutron scattering began in 1946 at the American Atomic Energy Commission laboratory at Oak Ridge, Tennessee, using one of the world's first nuclear reactors. He and his colleagues devised a way of deflecting neutrons ejected in the nuclear reactions into a beam that they then aimed at the material they wanted to study. By analysing the pattern of neutrons bouncing off the material, they were able to discover the juxtaposition of atoms in a wide range of materials.

Neutron scattering overcame the limitations of x-rays in analysing many materials, and was the first technique to detect the position of hydrogen atoms and measure magnetic fields around atoms.

Shull shared his Nobel prize with Bertram Brockhouse, who had independently invented a variation of the same technique. Shull's method answered the question of where atoms "are"; Brockhouse's told us what atoms "do".

Shull was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the youngest of three children. His father owned a small hardware store. He began to take a serious interest in physics in his final year at high school, and, in 1933, won a scholarship to the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University), in Pittsburgh, to study physics. The institute had a strong reputation in engineering and physical sciences, and Shull was initially drawn toward aeronautical engineering as a possible career.

His interest in physics sharpened under the tuition of a brilliant lecturer, Harry Hower, then head of the physics department. He graduated in 1937, and took a research and teaching post at New York University, where he was encouraged to join a research project of a nuclear physics group headed by Frank Myers and Robert Huntoon, who were building a 200keV Cockroft-Walton generator for accelerating deuterons.

Shull was later involved in accelerating beams of electrons for experiments, for which he got his PhD in 1941, and researching an early approach to using neutron interactions with materials as a method of analysis.

The idea of using neutrons to unlock the secrets of the atomic nucleus was first recognised by physicists in 1932, when Chadwick discovered the neutron. Since it had no electric charge, the neutron could easily penetrate the charged nucleus. The big breakthrough had to wait until streams of thermal, slow-moving neutrons were available from nuclear reactors.

Meanwhile, in 1941, Shull joined the Texas Company research laboratories, which specialised in developing high-performance aviation fuels and lubricants. The work became increasingly important after the United States entered the second world war that December.

He wanted to join the Manhattan Project, developing the atomic bomb, but was obliged to stay at the Texas Company throughout the war years. Once hostilities had ceased, however, he got a job at Oak Ridge, pursuing the exciting developments in nuclear physics going on within the Manhattan Project. He joined Ernest Wollan, who had been at the laboratory since its formation, and had assembled a rudimentary device for obtaining neutron diffraction patterns of crystals and materials.

Between them, they created the techniques that would earn Shull his Nobel prize. Then, in 1955, he left for academic life and a highly productive research career at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The techniques Shull and Wollan developed made neutron scattering a revolutionary research tool, which, in recent times, has led to the construction of high-tech ceramic superconductors and the detailed study of the structure of viruses, which could improve medical treatment for many illnesses. But by first studying simple compounds - such as table salt - they discovered that neutrons were deflected in a distinctive pattern when they struck a sample of material. It was this that allowed the researchers to determine the sample's atomic structure.

Shull also initiated studies with neutron diffraction to investigate the properties of metals, including how they became magnetised. That research led to new magnetic materials for products ranging from computer, audio and video components to refrigerator magnets.

At the start, neutron analysers were relatively simple, using the small nuclear reactors available to researchers after the second world war. Successive developments have led to large and powerful installations, specially built for studies of condensed matter in Britain, France and the US.

Wollan died a decade before the Nobel was awarded. Shull is survived by his wife, Martha-Nuel Summer, and three sons.

 Clifford Glenwood Shull, physicist, born September 23 1915; died March 31 2001.

He graduated in 1937, and took a research and teaching post at New York University, where he was encouraged to join a research project of a nuclear physics group headed by Frank Myers and Robert Huntoon, who were building a 200keV Cockroft-Walton generator for accelerating deuterons. Shull was later involved in accelerating beams of electrons for experiments, for which he got his PhD in 1941, and researching an early approach to using neutron interactions with materials as a method of analysis. The idea of using neutrons to unlock the secrets of the atomic nucleus was first recognised by physicists in 1932, when Chadwick discovered the neutron. Since it had no electric charge, the neutron could easily penetrate the charged nucleus. The big breakthrough had to wait until streams of thermal, slow-moving neutrons were available from nuclear reactors. Meanwhile, in 1941, Shull joined the Texas Company research laboratories, which specialised in developing high-performance aviation fuels and lubricants. The work became increasingly important after the United States entered the second world war that December. He wanted to join the Manhattan Project, developing the atomic bomb, but was obliged to stay at the Texas Company throughout the war years. Once hostilities had ceased, however, he got a job at Oak Ridge, pursuing the exciting developments in nuclear physics going on within the Manhattan Project. He joined Ernest Wollan, who had been at the laboratory since its formation, and had assembled a rudimentary device for obtaining neutron diffraction patterns of crystals and materials. Between them, they created the techniques that would earn Shull his Nobel prize. Then, in 1955, he left for academic life and a highly productive research career at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The techniques Shull and Wollan developed made neutron scattering a revolutionary research tool, which, in recent times, has led to the construction of high-tech ceramic superconductors and the detailed study of the structure of viruses, which could improve medical treatment for many illnesses. But by first studying simple compounds - such as table salt - they discovered that neutrons were deflected in a distinctive pattern when they struck a sample of material. It was this that allowed the researchers to determine the sample's atomic structure. Shull also initiated studies with neutron diffraction to investigate the properties of metals, including how they became magnetised. That research led to new magnetic materials for products ranging from computer, audio and video components to refrigerator magnets. At the start, neutron analysers were relatively simple, using the small nuclear reactors available to researchers after the second world war. Successive developments have led to large and powerful installations, specially built for studies of condensed matter in Britain, France and the US. Wollan died a decade before the Nobel was awarded. Shull is survived by his wife, Martha-Nuel Summer, and three sons.  Clifford Glenwood Shull, physicist, born September 23 1915; died March 31 2001.

webTitle: Hundreds more pupils to get TB test

fields.headline: Hundreds more pupils to get TB test
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A screening programme for hundreds of Leicester school pupils at risk from tuberculosis is to be brought forward after three new cases were added to the 30 already diagnosed.
fields.body:
A screening programme for hundreds of Leicester school pupils at risk from tuberculosis is to be brought forward after three new cases were added to the 30 already diagnosed.

The decision was made by health officials yesterday after the latest victims of Britain's worst outbreak of TB for 20 years were diagnosed with the disease. The cases involve two children aged between 11 and 14, and a 15-year-old girl, who had been vaccinated several years ago

The three are all pupils at Crown Hills community college, where most of the out break has been concentrated. Students aged 14-16 are to be tested for TB next Wednesday, after a 15-year-old girl, who had previously been vaccinated, tested positive for the disease.

Philip Monk, consultant in communicable diseases at Leicestershire health authority, said yesterday: "Given this evolving situation, I am clear that bringing forward the screening programme is the right thing to do. This is a responsible precautionary move."

Dr Monk added that those confirmed with the disease were not infectious.

The public health minister, Yvette Cooper, said last night: "The NHS response is being carefully regulated by Leicestershire health authority with support from surveillance experts.

"They are rigorously testing people for TB and when cases are found they are urgently tracing those who may have been in close contact. This will mean that anyone who might be at risk can be identified and treated as quickly and effectively as possible."

The outbreak is a particularly virulent strain and health officials have warned that up to 5,000 pupils from six schools which feed into Crown Hills may have to be screened.

The crisis began when one child developed TB last August. A second case in October and a third last month prompted the Leicester health authority to mount a major screening programme.

Skin-prick tests were carried out on all pupils aged from 11 to 14 after two of the three diagnosed cases were found to be infectious.

Ninety-three per cent of the children at the 1,200 pupil school are of Asian origin, and the number of cases in Britain is rising among people who are born abroad or whose parents were.

Some Leicester parents have voiced anxieties at the temporary halt to BCG vaccinations two years ago which was caused by a shortage of vaccine, but the programme for schoolchildren will be restarting. In London, vaccinations for 13-year-olds have already begun again. Catch-up vaccinations for those who missed out are also promised in the summer.

TB, which is caused by a bacteria that attacks the lungs and is spread through the air, is highly contagious.

But the Leicester outbreak is unusual because children usually contract is from close contact with adults and not from peers. There are 200 cases of active TB each year in the county and 7,000 nationwide.

webTitle: When Hobson's choice is no choice at all

fields.headline: When Hobson's choice is no choice at all
fields.standfirst:
'Incentive' scheme to house key workers has opposite effect on London teacher

Ask Aristotle about David Blunkett
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Vomit spread out of the lifts and the stairwell stank of urine. The entrance to the towerblock was vandalised and open. Windows were broken and covered with chickenwire.
fields.body:
Vomit spread out of the lifts and the stairwell stank of urine. The entrance to the towerblock was vandalised and open. Windows were broken and covered with chickenwire.

Five flights up, along a corridor, the one-bedroom flat was not too bad, although it had cracks in the walls and badly needed a paint. Hobsons Place is not the worst towerblock in east London and it may not even be the worst in Tower Hamlets.

To David Shackson, 31, a special educational needs and history teacher at Morpeth comprehensive in nearby Bethnal Green, it was a strange way of offering an incentive to stay working in the borough.

Hobsons Place was offered him through the council's key workers' scheme - low-cost housing for public sector workers. He saw a notice in December and thought it might reduce his £110-a-week rent, out of his £25,000-a-year salary.

Priority

With a reference from his headteacher, he was soon on a waiting list and awarded "300 priority points"; to this day he has no idea what that means. In February, he was told a property was available in Hobsons Place. A woman from Tower Hamlets Community Housing, the association which owns the block, showed him round. The flat was £56 a week until it was refurbished, when it would be £80; the council is promising a £4m refit of the block starting next month. He had to take the property straight away, regardless of his month's notice, or be struck off the list. Hobsons Place became Hobson's choice. But he turned it down.

"I have worked in Tower Hamlets for six years and I have visited many council properties. Today I was taken to one of the worst I have seen," Mr Shackson said in a letter to the council's lettings coordinator. "Had I been starting my first teaching position, the sort of person for which I would hope your scheme was targeted, I would not only have refused the flat but would also have reconsidered working in Tower Hamlets."

He added: "I applied to the scheme in good faith in the belief that it was there to provide affordable housing to teachers in the area in which they work ...My experience has proven that the scheme was not genuine in this purpose."

He says he is not fussy. Across the way is Ramar House, another towerblock, where he would have been happy to go, because there is a porter and much better security.

When the Guardian made inquiries, Tower Hamlets replied speedily and frankly. The scheme started in December, with 50 council and housing association homes. The council had 104 calls, 42 applications, and made 13 offers; eight were accepted and five refused. The scheme is open to teachers but is to take in health workers, police and the fire brigade. The council acknowledges that the scheme enables these workers to jump the list. A teacher couple from New Zealand has accepted the flat offered to Mr Shackson.

"There is a shortage in the borough, 15,500 households on the list," said a council spokesman. "In terms of people it could be five times that. We get 2,000 lets per year - there is enormous pressure. We offer what we offer anyone else on ourlist. There is pressure to turn round property quickly and also pressure to get applicants to accept or not accept the offer."

Rob Lantsbury, for the housing association, said: "Unfortunately a lot of housing in Tower Hamlets is in similar condition ...It's fair to say it's going to look a lot different in six months' time."

This week the education secretary, David Blunkett, announced £35m for next year to schools in 58 authorities with recruitment problems. Tower Hamlets is getting £696,000. But this can be spread widely - housing subsidies, support for childcare, travel costs, recruitment campaigns, or, most likely, extra pay.

Ministers say schools can best decide how the money is spent. "They can use it if they want for housing," an education department spokesman said. "They can innovate where there are problems. We are just trying to stimulate ideas."

Some gaps are being filled piecemeal. In a report this week, the National Housing Federation highlighted Northwick Park in Harrow, north-west London, where 668 units have been built for health workers, mostly flats but 40 two- and three-bed homes. In Hoxton Square in Hackney, 48 flats are being provided as affordable homes for key workers.

Sceptical

The government is spending £250m on new and improved housing for key workers over three years. Its aim is to house 10,000 workers, though the federation is sceptical. Organisations are bidding to run schemes, but lenders have been very reluctant to commit and give extra leverage by offering low-cost mortgages.

The average start for teachers in inner London is going up to £20,000, and many experienced teachers will be just short of £30,000 with London weighting. But according to the federation, rents average £200 a week for a one-bedroom flat and an average London house costs £150,000. Meanwhile the National Institute of Social and Economic Research estimates that 60,000 workers in key services will leave London over the next 10 years. A report by the University of North London identified many teachers leaving London after five years to buy homes. About 40% expect to have to leave.

"If the government is serious, they have got to build up new housing," says Mr Shackson. "The intentions are right, but it's really appalling to be keeping council tenants on the waiting lists to make available places for key workers." In the meantime, he is staying where he is.

"Its not going to force me to leave the job. I'm getting by. I probably will apply for promotion - the extra money will cover things. I've got that option, but for anyone just beginning the salary rate is atrocious. I don't know how they survive."

webTitle: Tories and teachers scorn Blunkett claim over smaller classes

fields.headline: Tories and teachers scorn Blunkett claim over smaller classes
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText:
The government said yesterday that it was on course to meet its target for smaller infant classes a year early, but critics insisted that secondary school class sizes were the highest for more than 20 years.
Ask Aristotle about David Blunkett
fields.body:
The government said yesterday that it was on course to meet its target for smaller infant classes a year early, but critics insisted that secondary school class sizes were the highest for more than 20 years.

Fewer older primary school pupils are in classes of more than 30 and the average size of a comprehensive class has remained at 22 after three consecutive years of rises up to 2000, according to the education secretary, David Blunkett.

He said the figures showed that critics of the government's pre-election pledge to ensure no infant was in a class larger than 30 by 2002 were "talking nonsense" when they said it merely shifted the problem further up the school.

"People said it would have a knock-on effect on juniors and pupil-teacher ratios would go up. They have in fact come down. The [junior] pupil-teacher ratio just nudged 0.1% down last year. We will see that, I am absolutely certain, accelerated."

Mr Blunkett said the proportion of infants in classes of more than 30 had fallen from 485,000 or 29% in January 1998, to just 2%.

The number of eight- to 11-year-olds in classes of more than 30 fell 67,000 in the year to January according to the figures, which apply to England only and were produced by the office for national statistics.

But there were 36,000 five-, six- and seven-year-olds in classes of more than 30 in January 2001 - up from 30,000 in September 2000. Government sources said this minor rise was to be expected, as some five-year-olds started primary school in January.

Secondary pupil-teacher ratios fell slightly from one teacher for every 17.2 students last year to one for every 17.1 in January 2001 - the first improvement in 10 years. This was despite teacher shortages in some areas and rising pupil numbers. Average class sizes for 11- to 18-year-olds were unchanged at 22%, up from 21.7% in 1997, while for five- to 11-year-olds they fell from 27.1% in 2000 to 26.7%.

But opposition MPs and teachers' leaders claimed secondary classes now at their biggest for 25 years. The Liberal Democrat education spokesman, Phil Willis, said the announcement was "government spin of the worst kind", and that the secondary pupil-teacher ratio had simply levelled, not fallen.

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "The government has put its focus on class sizes for five-, six- and seven-year-olds and what we have seen as a result is that class sizes elsewhere in the education system have been rising. I don't think when in the 1997 election Tony Blair unveiled his posters saying class sizes will be smaller that parents thought that four years into a Labour government we were going to see secondary class sizes at their highest for 25 years."

The Secondary Heads Association said it continued to be dismayed at the failure to reduce class sizes in secondary schools. Its general secretary, John Dunford, said: "Secondary heads remain concerned that pupil-teacher ratios are still higher than at any time since 1975."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Government claims to have halted the decline in secondary school staffing are pretty limp and better left unmentioned if this is the best it can do."

webTitle: £620m from Brussels primes Galileo navigation satellites

fields.headline: £620m from Brussels primes Galileo navigation satellites
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The European commission is putting up £620m to help develop and deliver Galileo, Europe's contribution to the next-generation global navigation satellite service, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The European commission is putting up £620m to help develop and deliver Galileo, Europe's contribution to the next-generation global navigation satellite service, it emerged yesterday.

European transport ministers have given approval for the project - which is likely to be established as a private-public partnership.

The project is designed to introduce greater safety in air traffic management and air navigation, as well as better train safety control, road traffic management and other surface transport applications.

The European Union said yesterday that it would provide consistent services throughout Europe by developing and deploying up to 30 earth orbit satellites.

Officials from the EU said that the satellite system would "change the way we live and work by offering commercial markets positioning and timing information. They will be accurate enough to pemit safety-critical applications - even in urban areas".

During the next few months, the European space agency is to recruit temporary management who will be responsible for starting up the programme. The EC has signed a deal with 10 leading space and service companies in the region to provide additional financial backing over the next three years.

The EU said yesterday that Galileo would end its dependence on US control of key technologies. It said the project could create 146,000 jobs throughout Europe.

It said that the financial returns would be lucrative, creating returns of 20 times the initial investment. The jobs will be in communications, navigation and surveillance.

The EU said that the main benefits will be a boost in exports in technology and communications - to an estimated value of £13bn within 10 years. Britain would be expected to receive between 10-30% of the money.

Transport experts said last night that the project would also ensure that defence operations were not entirely dependent on the US.

fields.headline: The coast is clear
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith heads for the best walks by the sea
fields.trailText: There are many different kinds of coastal walking, from trudging through sandy dunes to crunching across pebble beaches, to wandering along airy promenades along switchback cliffs, making the coast one of the most fascinating of walking destinations. The following are some suggestions for varied coastal walks throughout the country.
fields.body:
There are many different kinds of coastal walking, from trudging through sandy dunes to crunching across pebble beaches, to wandering along airy promenades along switchback cliffs, making the coast one of the most fascinating of walking destinations. The following are some suggestions for varied coastal walks throughout the country.

Bamburgh, Northumberland

The dramatic outline of William Armstrong's mock-medieval castle soaring above the sweeping sandy beach at Bamburgh on the Northumberland coast will seem familiar to many. It has been used as the backdrop to countless films, from The Lion in Winter to many more recent historical epics.

What we see of the castle today is largely the creation of the 1st Lord Armstrong of Cragside, a gritty northern industrialist who bought the castle in 1894 and completed a thoroughgoing restoration in 1903. The site itself, on a bold crag of Whin Sill basalt, is, however, very ancient, and fortresses here date back to the Iron Age.

There are fine walks on the firm golden sands as far as Seahouses to the south (about three miles) and out to Budle Bay with its lighthouse to the north. If you have the time, don't miss Billy Shiel's invitation for a boat trip out to the rocky Farne Islands, the final outcrop of the Whin Sill, from Seahouses, and enjoy close-up views of grey seals, cormorants, guillimots and kittiwakes.

Contact: Bamburgh Castle (01668 214515). For Billy Shiel's boat trips to the Farnes, call 01665 721006.
Recommended pub: The Lord Crewe, Bamburgh.

Blakeney Point, Norfolk

Seven glorious miles of shingle-walking awaits the visitor to Blakeney Point on the north Norfolk coast. At its western end, the point curves inland like a crooked hand to protect the maze of mud flats and salt marshes of Morston and Stiffkey Marshes and the National Nature Reserve (closed) of Holkham.

Access to the Point is either by ferry from Morston, or a four-and-a-half-mile walk along the shingle bank from Cley Eye on Cley Beach. On the walk, you will pass a range of classic coastal habitats, from sand and pebble beaches, to salt marsh and sand dunes.

More than 260 species of birds have been recorded at Blakeney, and the spit includes breeding colonies of common, Sandwich, Arctic and little terns, ringed plover and oystercatchers - truly the clowns of the coast. But one of the wildlife highlights of any visit to Blakeney will be sighting the common and grey seals which breed off the point of the spit, and can often be seen at close range from the ferry boat.

Further south down the North Sea coast, Dunwich Beach (National Trust) is also open, where little now remains of the once-important medieval port of Dunwich. This was a thriving township with 5,000 inhabitants and boasting three churches, but it fell victim to the erosion of its cliff-top position by the North Sea over several centuries.

Contact: Joe Read at the National Trust on 01263 740241; the ferry operators at Morston are John Bean on 01263 740038, or Jim Temple on 01263 740791.
Recommended pub: The Anchor at Morston.

Dungeness, Kent

The shingle promontory of Dungeness in Kent is one of the strangest landscapes in Britain. The five-mile foreshore running north from the shanty-town village is backed by the massive, threatening Lego blocks of the twin Dungeness nuclear power stations. The eccentric collection of railway carriageways, prefabs and huts, including the former home of the writer and artist Derek Jarman and various other artists and fishermen, must be one of the oddest settlements in the country. There are also the remains of no less than three lighthouses which have been built on this most dangerous of Channel coasts.

The shingle foreshore itself makes for difficult walking, but a concrete road runs parallel to the beach leading past the strange concrete listening posts, the forerunners of radar. The whole of this otherworld landscape seems, like your footing, to be constantly on the move. Even the toughest of plants have a battle to survive on this inhospitable terrain, but some national rarities, such as the edible sea kale, sea campion, thrift and the aptly-named stonecrop, can be found here, eking out a living from the barren pebbles.

Dungeness is an important bird habitat, attracting a rich variety of wildfowl and waders in the gravel pits behind Denge Beach, and rarities such as the dark-hooded Mediterranean gull and Sandwich terns on the shingle. Even the humming power station buildings provide nest sites for black redstarts.

You can either walk south from Dymchurch to the Bird Observatory at Dungeness past Greatstone and Littlestone on Sea, catching the Romney, Hythe and Dymchurch Railway back to your starting point. Or you could do the whole thing in reverse.

Contact: Rye TIC, The Heritage Centre, Strand Quay, Rye, (01797 226696).
Recommended pub: Delicious fish and chips at The Britannia, Dungeness.

Formby, Lancashire

The red squirrels of the rather grandly named Formby Hills, north of the Mersey estuary, are busy mating at the moment, so there's a good chance to see them while they are off-guard. The Squirrel Walk, through the ancient Scots pines of this 500-acre National Trust property, is still open to visitors, as is the six-mile coastal walk, which will take you north to the genteel Victorian and Edwardian resort of Southport.

The Formby Hills are said to be the fourth largest sand dune system in Britain and although they are impressive, they do not reach any great heights. This popular National Trust property includes inter-tidal sand flats and the dunes are backed by Scots pine plantations, planted at the turn of the last century in an attempt to stabilise them. It was also the site of the first lifeboat station in the country, opened in 1804.

There are many walks through the dunes, which is also the home of the rare natterjack toad, creeping willow and dewberry. But no horses are allowed and all dogs must be kept on a lead, with walkers restricted to the coastal fringe. And if you are really lucky, and there at low tide, you might just catch a glimpse of signs left by the first visitors to this beautiful spot, over 5,000 years ago. Fossilised human footprints and animal hoofmarks dated to the Neolithic period have been found in the inter-tidal sediments.

Contact: The National Trust (01704 878591).
Recommended pub: The Pine Woods, Wicks Green, Formby.

Pembrokeshire Beaches, Dyfed

It's no wonder that the Pembrokeshire coast is the home of British surfing. Great rollers crash in unhindered after their 3,000-mile journey across the Atlantic on to a range of superb beaches of golden sand, backed by multi-coloured cliffs.

And although you can't enjoy the pleasures of the wonderful Pembrokeshire Coast Path at present, most of the beaches which can be reached by road are open to the public to walk on, paddle in, or simply watch the Welsh beach boys as they ride in on the endless surf.

One of the best and certainly the wildest is Freshwater West, near Castlemartin, an impressive sweep of dune-backed sands which receives the biggest waves in Pembrokeshire. At high tide, however, most of the sand is submerged and only a pebble and shingle bank remains; at low tide, the remains of a 6,000-year-old drowned forest are sometimes revealed. Freshwater West has something for everyone, for at the southern end of the beach, near a restored seaweed-collector's hut, there is an abundance of rock pools to keep the children, and many adults, occupied.

Nearby is secluded West Angle Bay at the entrance to the Milford Haven waterway, where there are more rock pools for the kids to explore, and to the east, beyond the Castlemartin Army ranges, are the National Trust beaches of Broad Haven. Just inland from here are the famous Bosherton Lily Ponds on the Stackpole Estate, the home of otter, waterfowl and waders.

Contact: Pembrokeshire Tourism on 01437 760980.
Recommended pub: The Sloop at Porthgain.

The site itself, on a bold crag of Whin Sill basalt, is, however, very ancient, and fortresses here date back to the Iron Age. There are fine walks on the firm golden sands as far as Seahouses to the south (about three miles) and out to Budle Bay with its lighthouse to the north. If you have the time, don't miss Billy Shiel's invitation for a boat trip out to the rocky Farne Islands, the final outcrop of the Whin Sill, from Seahouses, and enjoy close-up views of grey seals, cormorants, guillimots and kittiwakes. fields.headline: That yolk isn't funny anymore
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: A Leicester courier firm, 24-7, woke me early this morning with the most wonderful letter of my life
fields.body:
Saturday, March 31

I'm glad to see the end of this accurs-éd month. William went into the back garden to try out his new red wellingtons. Minutes later, he had to be rescued by me and Glenn after sinking up to his waist in the squelching bog that used to be the lawn.

Michael Fish told me and my fellow British TV gogglers at lunchtime today that the previous 12 months had been the wettest since records had been kept. I said to Michael, "I'm not surprised, Mike."

I was about to tell him about William's near miss when I realised, to my horror, that Michael Fish would not have been able to hear me. I must get out more.

As I was cooking the boys' Quorn burgers tonight, I had a sudden brainwave, and phoned Pandora on her direct number at the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. She answered at once. For a joke, I pretended to be the chief vet of Norfolk. I said, "Moi dear gal, oi'm the chief vet of Norfolk. Oi'm sorry gal, but Oi've got bad news, there's been a serious outbreak of beak and claw down here. More than 11 million chickens and turkeys are affected."

She gave an audible gasp. Then said, "Christ, what next? Is it safe to eat the eggs?"

I answered in my newly acquired Norfolk accent, "No, my dear, they must be gathered from their coops, stamped, DO NOT INGEST. THIS EGG IS CARRYING THE BEAK AND CLAW VIRUS'."

There was silence and she stifled a sob. She then shouted across the office, "Get me Tony, at once!" She then spoke urgently to somebody nearby, and I heard a male voice shout, "Fuckin' 'ell, there's beak 'n' claw in Norfolk!" He sounded hysterical.

I was starting to regret my deception, but when Pandora asked me if she should arrange for the poultry to be slaughtered and the eggs to be buried, for some reason I answered, "Put the birds out of their misery, by all means, but the eggs could come in useful - for throwing at politicians during the run-up to the general election."

After I'd slammed down the phone, I was ashamed of myself. Pandora was so proud of her recent promotion to junior minister for poultry. I tried to ring back, but the phones in her office were permanently engaged. What I had intended to suggest to her was that, rather than destroy infected sheep, instead each household in Britain be given a skinned and disembowelled carcass to put in the freezer. After all, foot and mouth presents no danger to we homo sapiens. (To keep things fair, vegetarians could be given a token for a bag of turnips or something.) This would surely win votes for new Labour.

Sunday, April 1, April Fool's Day

A Leicester courier firm, 24-7, woke me early this morning with the most wonderful letter of my life:

Dear Adrian Mole,

My name is Louise Moore. I am an editor at Penguin Books UK Ltd. I will cut quickly to the chase. While lunching in the Ivy yesterday with Will Self and Martin Amis, I could not help but overhear a conversation at the next table between two agents. They were discussing your unfinished manuscript, Krog From Gork. I was gripped by the story of how Krog invents man's first language, thus enabling him to tell his wife that he loves her.

Penguin would like to offer you £1m for a two-book deal. Please ring me at 9.30am on Monday.

Yours sincerely Louise Moore.

Monday, April 2

My birthday cards were illustrated by the usual symbols of masculinity: vintage cards, foaming tankards and fishing rods.

At 9.30 precisely, I rang Ms Moore's number. Pandora answered. "April Fool, you birthday boy bastard,"she shouted before slamming down the phone.

fields.headline: Pill warning to Scottish Catholics
fields.trailText: Scottish Catholics are to be warned by their bishops that taking the morning-after pill, authorised for sale to over-16- year-olds by the government earlier this year, is the equivalent of a "chemically induced abortion".
fields.body:
Scottish Catholics are to be warned by their bishops that taking the morning-after pill, authorised for sale to over-16- year-olds by the government earlier this year, is the equivalent of a "chemically induced abortion".

In a pastoral letter, signed by all eight bishops, to be read out at masses in coming weeks, congregations will be told: "The church cannot remain silent on this issue, given the serious nature of what is being proposed."

It will exert moral pressure on Catholic doctors and pharmacists as well as parents and teenagers to refuse to sanction the use of the pill, calling on them "to reflect on what is being proposed and to exercise their conscientious right of objection."

It is estimated that more than 700,000 of Scotland's 5m inhabitants are at least nominally Catholic.

The statement adds: "By offering over-the-counter potentially abortifacient drugs to 16-year-olds, parental rights are being undermined and family bonds weakened.

"If our teenagers feel they are so unimportant that we can leave this aspect of their healthcare to a 10 minute chat in a busy pharmacy, with a pharmacist who cannot carry out any physical examination, or consult medical records, we are sending out a regrettable and dangerous message to a highly vulnerable group."

The letter is being sent out in the name of Cardinal Thomas Winning, leader of the church in Scotland and president of its bishops' conference, who has led a long campaign against abortion rights, even funding young women who opt not to terminate their pregnancies. He has condemned the government for not banning abortion.

The pastoral letter claims that attempts to cut teenage pregnancy rates may inadvertently push up rates of teenage sexual activity, sexually transmitted diseases and abortions.

webTitle: The Greatest Show on Earth, Royal Albert Hall, London

fields.headline: Night of a thousand copycats
fields.standfirst:
The Greatest Show on Earth
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Greatest Show on Earth
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.body:
A mere three weeks after the release of their debut single, Hear'Say have already inspired two tribute acts. The arrival of Near'Say or the optimistically-named Hear To Stay at a corporate function near you is the latest evidence that the tribute band phenomenon is expanding at an alarming rate.

Ten years ago, the concept was virtually unknown in the UK. Today, virtually anyone who has ever released a record has a doppelganger act hawking the clubs.

And on this night, before an audience of giggling girls in deely boppers and soberly besuited fortysomethings which looks disturbingly like a hen night has gatecrashed the Tory party conference, the Albert Hall hosted a veritable Live Aid of tribute acts.

This Lord's Taverners charity event featured an Elvis impersonator whose voice between songs lurches from Memphis to Mile End, neatly demonstrating the schizophrenia of his profession, a terrible Abba tribute called Fabba, the Counterfeit Stones and the Bootleg Beatles.

The latter are particularly impressive. The point is not physical similarity (behind the suits and wigs, they look no more like the Beatles than they do Bob Marley and the Wailers) but, bolstered by a brass section and 19 years' stage experience, their sound is a skilful, uncanny imitation.

The Bootleg Beatles are ruthlessly professional, but the Counterfeit Stones best illustrate the mass appeal of the tribute band. Music journalists and obsessive record collectors like to think rock music is a challenging, provocative art. The average music buyer thinks rock music is a form of light entertainment, as challenging and provocative as Blind Date or Heat magazine.

With their parodic moves and risque patter about Bill Wyman's relationship with Mandy Smith, the Counterfeit Stones represent the ultimate in low-risk, high-return rock-as-light-entertainment. Why go to a Rolling Stones concert when you can enjoy the Counterfeit Stones for half the price, confident you won't have to sit through 10 new album tracks before they play Satisfaction?

Indeed, at a time when real rock artists are edging closer to light entertainment - witness Robbie Williams's onstage pantomime of self-deprecating winks and grimaces - the Counterfeit Stones may even capture the spirit of the age as accurately as their subjects once did.

fields.headline: The fine art of politics
fields.standfirst: A passionate hillwalker with a love of romantic poetry, he is also a shrewd operator in the corridors of power, where he has won respect in the traditionally unpopular role of culture minister
fields.trailText: A passionate hillwalker with a love of romantic poetry, he is also a shrewd operator in the corridors of power, where he has won respect in the traditionally unpopular role of culture minister.
fields.body:
For someone who had supposedly just been demoted, Chris Smith looked pretty cheerful when he was appointed secretary of state for national heritage in 1997. His last post in opposition had been shadow health secretary, but the arts world had lobbied Tony Blair for Smith's appointment, having been impressed with his shadowing of heritage in the mid 90s. As the prime minister put it to him, "you're a victim of your own success". So a smiling Smith stepped outside 10 Downing Street, made a bullish statement about the importance of the creative industries, scrapped the dreadful heritage name and launched the ministry of culture, media and sport.

There was no doubt he was the best candidate. He had a PhD in romantic poetry, his love of hill walking fitted with the tourism part of the job, his support for Arsenal covered sport, and as a regular gallery, concert, theatre and cinema goer, he had a genuine love and appreciation of the arts. And just as importantly, he was a seasoned politician. His initial claim to prominence might have come in 1984, when he became the first openly out gay MP at Westminster, but since then he had held a series of significant shadow frontbench posts covering the treasury, environment and social security, as well as heritage and health.

However, soon after his appointment things began to turn sour, with theatrical knights taking it in turn to heap abuse on him. "We hoped that this government would make us feel treasured. They haven't," intoned Sir Peter Hall, solemnly. Equally unsettling were the persistent rumours that Peter Mandelson was stalking his job.

"The first two years were undoubtedly difficult," Smith now acknowledges, "mainly because we kept to Tory spending plans. There was a period when I could hardly go to an awards ceremony without being berated from the stage by some panjandrum complaining that government was not putting enough money in the arts."

But it wasn't just a lack of cash that took the gloss off Smith and the then voguish concept of Cool Britannia (which Smith goes out of his way to distance himself from, pointing out that it was his Tory predecessor, Virginia Bottomley, who jumped on that particular bandwagon, using the words five times in press releases during her last year in power). Disproportionately time-consuming were the fall-out over fat cats running the lottery, the ongoing Millennium Dome saga, funding crises at Covent Garden, and disputes over the new Wembley. The absolute low point of Smith's tenure came in 1998 when he published a book of his speeches, Creative Britain. Perhaps it was the Damien Hirst book jacket, or the mood of the times, but Smith and the book were slaughtered by reviewers. "An insult to its readers", said one; "unpublishable maudlin trash", said another.

But three years on, and the world has changed again. While many of his colleagues in government struggle to maintain their reputations, Smith is apparently riding high. He is not only one of the few ministers to have been at the same post for the entire life of this government, but he has also synchronised a series of policy triumphs with the electoral timetable. At the moment when it matters most, Chris Smith has all his ducks in a line.

Melvyn Bragg - who, it should be said, is also a Labour peer - recently itemised some of Smith's achievements in a newspaper article: a seven-year secure financial base for the BBC; free museum access for all, which has already increased visitor numbers by 20% for children and 40% for pensioners; hugely increased funding, which has meant extra money for regional theatre; partnerships between arts professionals and schools in deprived areas; and a pledge that all children will have access to musical tuition. In the pipeline are ambitious proposals for the major artistic institutions, as well as for individual artists. "The polite, rather fastidious arts lover has delivered," wrote Bragg. "Now that the smoke has cleared, Chris Smith can be seen as the unlikely bespectacled hero in a western, the guy who won the shoot-out."

Seeing Smith arrive at his Trafalgar Square office, he unwittingly plays out a perfect tableau to illustrate his job. In one hand he holds a ministerial red box, in the other a dinner jacket. "I'm going to the National Gallery trustees dinner this evening," he explains, "but I suppose these two things do sort of sum up the job."

In the same way, the art that he has chosen from the government collection for his office also provides a potted biography. A portrait by Scottish artist Craigie Aitchison connects with his Edinburgh upbringing; a large etching of Lake Windermere by Norman Ackroyd chimes with his love of romantic poetry and hill walking; and some architectural shapes by Langlands and Bell, who exhibited in the definitive BritArt show, Sensation, provide a reminder that he is not afraid of the cutting edge. There is also a bright blue Howard Hodgkin lithograph, an Epstein bust of the conductor Klemperer to reflect his interest in music, and the politician's common touch is evidenced by a red, white and blue papier-mache raven made by the children of a school he visited.

Smith, who is 50 later this year, is a slighter figure than he appears on television and confidently projects a sense of understated straightforwardness. He is the second son of Colin Smith, a Whitehall civil servant, and Gladys, a maths teacher. The family lived in Watford until Smith was 10, and then moved to Edinburgh when his father was transferred to the Scottish Office and his mother became head of maths at a girls' school. The couple, now both retired, still live in Scotland and Smith's elder brother, Roger, teaches physics at a school there. Friends say the atmosphere in the home was, "fairly serious and obviously academically inclined". It was a Christian household, and Smith has been an active member of the Church of Scotland since his teenage years. Smith says that, while there was a lot of reading at home, it was through school that he was really exposed to the arts. "A teacher helped out at the Edinburgh Festival, so we got tickets to concerts and other events. I remember seeing Ian McKellen in both Richard II and Edward II sometime in the late 60s. There is no better antidote to being in the smoke-filled corridors than to be standing on a mountain with half the country laid out before you. It really does put everything else into perspective." Smith's passion for politics and climbing were forged at the same time. He had been impressed by the optimism surrounding Harold Wilson coming into office in 1964, and in America by the Kennedy and then Johnson administrations, the civil rights protests and anti-Vietnam war movements. The issues that still most animate him are those of basic equality of opportunity. In his current job, he has been a fervent supporter of increased access to cultural institutions.

They regret that what they call the stillness of the old museums has gone. That is an exclusive argument about keeping the best things for the privileged few. It is perfectly possible for someone to have a high-art experience, even if they don't have a high-art background."
