"He knows that if you are really looking for democracy, then that should apply to health and education, and also to culture. Until regions are served with first-class work, then you don't have a democracy, and he is genuinely committed to this."

As a student reading English at Cambridge in the late 60s, Smith was elected president of the union and chairman of the Fabian society. He took part in his share of demos, but recalls that much of the protest at Cambridge was remarkably genteel. "There was once a sit-in which lasted three or four days and was enormous fun. But when the vanguard of the invading students first entered the building, they actually stopped and held up the students behind them while they rolled up the William Morris carpet so it wouldn't get damaged."

A contemporary was Rabbi Julia Neuberger, who remembers him as, "very clever, even among a lot of very clever people. You could talk to Chris about things you wouldn't talk to other people about. We really would have conversations about Wordsworth." She echoes the view that he is largely unchanged. "I still sometimes want to play the Jewish mother with him and tell him to get more sleep," she laughs, "which is exactly the same as it was when we first met."

Smith says that at Cambridge, he asked himself if he wanted a life in politics. The answer was, "yes, probably", but he felt he had to do other things first. After gaining a double first, he embarked on a PhD about ideas of solitude in 18th-century poetry, with particular emphasis on Wordsworth and Coleridge. He then spent a year at Harvard as a Kennedy scholar.

"I was mainly working on my thesis, but I also hugely enjoyed the experience of being in America. I admired the American way of seeing how something could be done rather than ways that it couldn't. I was there in 75/76, which was post-Watergate and coming up to the bicentennial and presidential elections." He worked on Arizona democrat Mo Udall's failed presidential campaign and, on returning to Britain, thought about joining the civil service. "But I had the perspicacity to know that I would not want to spend my life serving a Tory government. So I worked in housing instead."

He was taken on as a graduate trainee by the government quango, the Housing Corporation. Nine months later he left to work for the Shaftesbury housing association, a Christian-based organisation that provides sheltered homes for the elderly and disabled. Smith says that even now, when he passes a building he was partly responsible for, he has a small surge of pride.

Mick Sweeney, now director of a housing association, was a colleague of Smith and a fellow branch official of their union. "He didn't put himself about like the stereotype of a politician on the make," recalls Sweeney. "He took his work very seriously, and he believed in providing low-cost housing to people. I think it's quite refreshing that someone like Chris has got the position that he has." So unassuming was Smith that when, some years later, another housing colleague attended a conference at which the Labour social security spokesman was speaking, he was amazed that, "it was that Chris Smith who came on stage. It just never occurred to me that it could be the same person."

In fact, Smith had begun climbing the political greasy pole when he was elected as an Islington councillor in 1978. The following year he stood in the general election in the unwinnable Tory seat of Epsom and Ewell, and afterwards jokingly confided that his biggest concern while canvassing was to avoid falling in the suburban swimming pools.

At Islington he became Labour whip and chair of the housing committee. It was an extremely difficult time, with a split Labour group, over half of whom eventually defected to the SDP. Acrimonious meetings would often carry on through the night as the differing factions cajoled reluctant councillors to vote their way, and it is a measure of Smith's toughness that he survived politically, let alone prospered. His cabinet colleague, Mo Mowlam, says he's always been strong but, "he's tough in a way that doesn't seem tough. Remember that he got through the dome as the minister responsible. He's not a table-thumping toughie, but he doesn't give in."

Islington council during this period was the spiritual home of what the tabloids liked to call the loony left. The red flag literally flew over the town hall and the widespread perception that councils such as Islington were more interested in political posturing than providing services reflected badly on Labour nationally. How does he look back on those years? "Well, I'm proud of many of the actual achievements, such as estate renovation programmes, rehabilitation of street houses, and some children's services," he says. "But I'm not proud of the murky politics. There was a lot of unpleasantness, a lot of sheer difficulty in getting decisions made."

He says that, as a chair of housing and a housing professional, he became ever more conscious that it was decisions taken by central government that dictated what he was able to do. "While I had taken socialism on board intellectually, it was while I was a councillor in Islington that I saw people living in poor housing and in poverty and became convinced that government exists to work for people like these. I really wanted to get closer to where the decision-making was in order to make a difference." His chance came at the 1983 general election, when he was selected to stand against the sitting Islington MP, George Cunningham, who had defected from Labour to the SDP. It was such a close contest that on his way to the count, Smith's agent advised him to prepare two speeches. After a recount, he eventually won by 363 votes.

It was 18 months later that he came out as gay, but contingency plans were in place for the election. "It was a reasonably well known fact that I was gay, as I'd made no particular secret of it. If it had emerged during the campaign, I would have said yes." As an MP he wanted to say something publicly as a way of putting the issue to rest. When, in November 1984, the Conservative-controlled council in Rugby dropped a policy banning discrimination on the grounds of sexuality, Smith was asked to address a protest meeting. A few minutes before he spoke, he decided that this was the moment. His opening line was: "My name is Chris Smith. I'm the Labour MP for Islington South and Finsbury, and I'm gay."

While his statement was reported in the press, it didn't spark a tabloid frenzy, and it was four months before the Sun even mentioned it. However, in the next general election campaign in 1987, Smith canvassers had a script as to what to say if anyone raised it. "The first point," he says, "was, 'isn't it a refreshing change to have a politician who is honest'. The second line was, 'he's a good MP who works hard for everyone'. And the third one, if people really persisted, was, 'you're not telling me you're prejudiced, are you?' No canvasser ever had to get to line number three, and I won with an increased majority."

Colin Richardson, the editor of Gay Times, says Smith's coming out was obviously important. "But even more important was when he was re-elected. There was a fear that even though he had what should have been a safe seat, it would rebound. But it was the opposite."

Smith has said he didn't really realise he was gay until his early 20s, and he didn't tell his parents until shortly before the Rugby statement. "They lived in Scotland and I was in London. We never really had the chance to have that rather difficult conversation." He says that they were initially concerned, "but subsequently they have been wonderful. They always ask about Dorian when I speak to them on the phone."

Smith's partner is Dorian Jabri, a consultant advising companies on ethical investment. Jabri was communications director for the teacher training agency when he first met Smith in 1988 at a lobby of MPs about section 28. Jabri then asked Smith to speak at a conference, and a few months later they were living together. There was a minor press flurry shortly after the 1997 election, when Jabri was invited to a Buckingham Palace function as Smith's partner, but mostly their social life is fairly low-key. Strikingly, considering Smith's job, they still regularly attend cultural events where they actually pay for themselves. Their most recent private evening out was to see Fiona Shaw's Medea a few weeks ago.

Smith says: "After the 1984 statement, I made a deliberate point of being absolutely prepared to plunge into issues that affected the lesbian and gay community; be it raids on bookshops, police entrapment or the start of section 28. But at the same time I made it clear I wasn't a one-issue politician. I also wanted to talk about the economy and housing and pensions and poverty."

Richardson says that he has struck a good balance. "He's maintained a high profile as a gay politician, been supportive of gay rights organisations, and has turned up to most of the gay rights votes that his schedule will permit. When you hear MPs say they won't be a one-issue politician, you worry they are not going to be a gay MP at all. But he has shown that you can be true to your principles and still be an extremely effective politician. He's not diminished by it; in fact, I think it has added to his stature."

He characterises himself as soft left at the time, and didn't vote for Tony Benn in the divisive deputy leadership contest of 1981. He took them on in a 20-minute public slanging match. "I got a lot of support from ordinary members and we didn't see [the Militants] again."

But the leader he was closest to was John Smith, and on his desk is a picture he took of Smith on a Scottish mountainside five weeks before he died. "I still can't fully get over the sense of loss," he says. "It is very hard in both personal and political terms. What he had achieved was to put across to the electorate that passionate belief in social justice with a sense of economic competence. He had convinced people that it was both possible and necessary for the two to sit together in any sensible government, and it took root in people's minds as to what the Labour party stood for."

After John Smith's sudden death, he quickly decided to support Blair, who he not only saw as someone who could win for Labour but as someone who had a radical streak. Chris Smith also supported the whole New Labour project, although he stresses that, "the one thing I was very keen to ensure we didn't do was to lose the absolutely fundamental belief in social justice". Much was read into his invitation to Cherie Blair's 40th birthday party, in terms of him officially joining the Blairite coterie.

As an opposition frontbencher in the 90s, it was said that while he was competent, the Tories never thought he posed a real threat. However, Stephen Dorrell, whom he twice shadowed at heritage and health, describes Smith as, "always perfectly honourable. If he wasn't willing to do something, he said so, and if he was willing to do something, then he did it."

Perhaps part of the reason for any ineffectualness in opposition was that he was so frequently moved between briefs. At social security, he was the first of a string of people Blair asked to "think the unthinkable" in restructuring the government's vast expenditure. Mutterings from Gordon Brown's camp imply that all he did was work out schemes that would have cost billions, and Smith was moved on. He now acknowledges that he did have a policy disagreement with Brown on child benefit. Smith felt that withdrawing it from children over 16 might be a disincentive to education, but says now that he is completely in agreement with the amended policy that emerged in government, and that he and Brown work well together.

"It is a remarkably cohesive cabinet," he says. "There are very few disagreements on policy matters, and we all get on pretty well on a personal level." He is closest, politically and socially, to Mo Mowlam, who describes him as, "a decent human being who works incredibly hard and believes in what we are trying to do. He wants to help people, and is a principled guy who will find a way to achieve what he wants."

In particular, he has found a way round the major political anomaly of his post. Previous culture ministers have been hamstrung by the arm's-length principle of funding, by which the minister gets the cash out of the treasury but other organisations, such as the arts council, decide what it is spent on. Such has been Smith's influence on policy-making that, although the independence of funding has been maintained, he is very much seen by the big hitters in the arts world as the man who can get things done.

The philanthropic publisher and financier, Christopher Ondaatje, is impressed. Having worked with Smith after he donated £2.75m towards the new wing of the National Portrait Gallery, Ondaatje recently gave £2m to the Labour Party. He particularly praises the model of national institutions, the private sector and government working together. "Something seems to have happened in the arts in this country that is right. It hasn't happened over night, but Chris Smith has lent his support and enthusiasm to a number of institutions that seem to have lead a cultural revolution in England. I am really very proud to have been able to work with him and to have done something worthwhile."

Smith operates on the politician's seemingly obligatory four or five hours' sleep a night, filling his days with meetings and his evenings with functions. He worries about the lack of time to refresh and re-think his politics. "It's one of the problems of being in government; not seeing the wood for the trees. You are constantly dealing with individual issues and problems, and you try to run the tactics and you forget the strategy. You have to make time to sit back and look at the big themes you are trying to put in place."

Julia Neuberger says she thinks there is still a really big book in him. "I thought he would write the big Wordsworth book, but I am not sure what it will be now. But after he retires I am sure he will write something important, maybe on cultural policy."

The notion of Smith having more time to spend with his Wordsworth and his walking has been a regular feature of political gossip, and more recently there have been rumours that his whole department is to be scrapped. But he insists the department's future is secure. "I've been told by the very highest authority that it is not going to happen," he states meaningfully, adding that while, of course, it is the PM's decision, he also hopes to have plenty more wear out of both his red box and his dinner jacket.

"We need to follow through. There are the creative partnerships between cultural organisations and schools. It will allow children to get the chance to work with arts professionals. Far too few children have these opportunities, which could be of major benefit to them. Then there's Culture on Line, by which people can interact with the best of cultural activity and resources. This will be the equivalent of the Open University in the 60s, or Channel 4 in the 80s. More trust in the excellent institutions, with longer grants and less interference, and a whole new agenda for school sport. There' s certainly more work to be done."


Life at a glance

Christopher Robert Smith

Born: 24 July 1951

Education: Cassiobury Primary School, Watford; George Watson's College, Edinburgh; Pembroke College, Cambridge 69-75, Harvard University 75-76

Family: partner Dorian Jabri

Career: Development Secretary, Shaftesbury Housing Association 77-80; Development Co-ordinator Society for Co-operative Dwellings 80-83.

Political career: Islington councillor, 78-83; MP Islington South and Finsbury, since 83

Posts held: Opposition spokesman on treasury and economic affairs 87-92, on environmental protection 92-94, on national heritage 94-95, on social security 95-96, on health 96-97; secretary of state for culture, media and sport since 97

Other posts: Executive of NCCL 86-88; executive committee of National Trust 95-97; Governor Sadler's Wells Theatre 87-97

Books: Creative Britain 98

Acrimonious meetings would often carry on through the night as the differing factions cajoled reluctant councillors to vote their way, and it is a measure of Smith's toughness that he survived politically, let alone prospered. His cabinet colleague, Mo Mowlam, says he's always been strong but, "he's tough in a way that doesn't seem tough. Remember that he got through the dome as the minister responsible. He's not a table-thumping toughie, but he doesn't give in." Islington council during this period was the spiritual home of what the tabloids liked to call the loony left. The red flag literally flew over the town hall and the widespread perception that councils such as Islington were more interested in political posturing than providing services reflected badly on Labour nationally. How does he look back on those years? "Well, I'm proud of many of the actual achievements, such as estate renovation programmes, rehabilitation of street houses, and some children's services," he says. "But I'm not proud of the murky politics. There was a lot of unpleasantness, a lot of sheer difficulty in getting decisions made." He says that, as a chair of housing and a housing professional, he became ever more conscious that it was decisions taken by central government that dictated what he was able to do. "While I had taken socialism on board intellectually, it was while I was a councillor in Islington that I saw people living in poor housing and in poverty and became convinced that government exists to work for people like these. I really wanted to get closer to where the decision-making was in order to make a difference." His chance came at the 1983 general election, when he was selected to stand against the sitting Islington MP, George Cunningham, who had defected from Labour to the SDP. It was such a close contest that on his way to the count, Smith's agent advised him to prepare two speeches. After a recount, he eventually won by 363 votes. It was 18 months later that he came out as gay, but contingency plans were in place for the election. "It was a reasonably well known fact that I was gay, as I'd made no particular secret of it. If it had emerged during the campaign, I would have said yes." As an MP he wanted to say something publicly as a way of putting the issue to rest. When, in November 1984, the Conservative-controlled council in Rugby dropped a policy banning discrimination on the grounds of sexuality, Smith was asked to address a protest meeting. A few minutes before he spoke, he decided that this was the moment. His opening line was: "My name is Chris Smith. I'm the Labour MP for Islington South and Finsbury, and I'm gay." While his statement was reported in the press, it didn't spark a tabloid frenzy, and it was four months before the Sun even mentioned it. However, in the next general election campaign in 1987, Smith canvassers had a script as to what to say if anyone raised it. "The first point," he says, "was, 'isn't it a refreshing change to have a politician who is honest'. The second line was, 'he's a good MP who works hard for everyone'. And the third one, if people really persisted, was, 'you're not telling me you're prejudiced, are you?' No canvasser ever had to get to line number three, and I won with an increased majority." Colin Richardson, the editor of Gay Times, says Smith's coming out was obviously important. "But even more important was when he was re-elected. There was a fear that even though he had what should have been a safe seat, it would rebound. But it was the opposite." Smith has said he didn't really realise he was gay until his early 20s, and he didn't tell his parents until shortly before the Rugby statement. "They lived in Scotland and I was in London. We never really had the chance to have that rather difficult conversation." He says that they were initially concerned, "but subsequently they have been wonderful. They always ask about Dorian when I speak to them on the phone." Smith's partner is Dorian Jabri, a consultant advising companies on ethical investment. Jabri was communications director for the teacher training agency when he first met Smith in 1988 at a lobby of MPs about section 28. Jabri then asked Smith to speak at a conference, and a few months later they were living together. There was a minor press flurry shortly after the 1997 election, when Jabri was invited to a Buckingham Palace function as Smith's partner, but mostly their social life is fairly low-key. Strikingly, considering Smith's job, they still regularly attend cultural events where they actually pay for themselves. Their most recent private evening out was to see Fiona Shaw's Medea a few weeks ago. Smith says: "After the 1984 statement, I made a deliberate point of being absolutely prepared to plunge into issues that affected the lesbian and gay community; be it raids on bookshops, police entrapment or the start of section 28. But at the same time I made it clear I wasn't a one-issue politician. I also wanted to talk about the economy and housing and pensions and poverty." Richardson says that he has struck a good balance. "He's maintained a high profile as a gay politician, been supportive of gay rights organisations, and has turned up to most of the gay rights votes that his schedule will permit. When you hear MPs say they won't be a one-issue politician, you worry they are not going to be a gay MP at all. But he has shown that you can be true to your principles and still be an extremely effective politician. He's not diminished by it; in fact, I think it has added to his stature." Smith became an MP at Labour's lowest point, but says he only once thought he would spend his whole career in opposition - when Labour failed to win Basildon in 1992. That confirmed John Major's unlikely victory. "I knew that the oppositionalist mentality of the early 80s had not served anyone well," says Smith. He characterises himself as soft left at the time, and didn't vote for Tony Benn in the divisive deputy leadership contest of 1981. He says the incident that finally persuaded him Labour had to change was at his constituency re-selection meeting in 1985. A caucus of Militant supporters disrupted the meeting by demanding that Smith oppose the party inquiry into the Militant-dominated Liverpool local party. He took them on in a 20-minute public slanging match. "I got a lot of support from ordinary members and we didn't see [the Militants] again." Smith says he was proud to then be part of the changes to the party begun by Neil Kinnock, and he still has a high regard for him as, "the person more than any other who saved the Labour party", and particularly for the dignified way he has conducted himself since resigning in 1992. But the leader he was closest to was John Smith, and on his desk is a picture he took of Smith on a Scottish mountainside five weeks before he died. "I still can't fully get over the sense of loss," he says. "It is very hard in both personal and political terms. What he had achieved was to put across to the electorate that passionate belief in social justice with a sense of economic competence. He had convinced people that it was both possible and necessary for the two to sit together in any sensible government, and it took root in people's minds as to what the Labour party stood for." After John Smith's sudden death, he quickly decided to support Blair, who he not only saw as someone who could win for Labour but as someone who had a radical streak. Chris Smith also supported the whole New Labour project, although he stresses that, "the one thing I was very keen to ensure we didn't do was to lose the absolutely fundamental belief in social justice". Much was read into his invitation to Cherie Blair's 40th birthday party, in terms of him officially joining the Blairite coterie. As an opposition frontbencher in the 90s, it was said that while he was competent, the Tories never thought he posed a real threat. However, Stephen Dorrell, whom he twice shadowed at heritage and health, describes Smith as, "always perfectly honourable. If he wasn't willing to do something, he said so, and if he was willing to do something, then he did it." Perhaps part of the reason for any ineffectualness in opposition was that he was so frequently moved between briefs. At social security, he was the first of a string of people Blair asked to "think the unthinkable" in restructuring the government's vast expenditure. Mutterings from Gordon Brown's camp imply that all he did was work out schemes that would have cost billions, and Smith was moved on. He now acknowledges that he did have a policy disagreement with Brown on child benefit. Smith felt that withdrawing it from children over 16 might be a disincentive to education, but says now that he is completely in agreement with the amended policy that emerged in government, and that he and Brown work well together. "It is a remarkably cohesive cabinet," he says. "There are very few disagreements on policy matters, and we all get on pretty well on a personal level." He is closest, politically and socially, to Mo Mowlam, who describes him as, "a decent human being who works incredibly hard and believes in what we are trying to do. He wants to help people, and is a principled guy who will find a way to achieve what he wants." In particular, he has found a way round the major political anomaly of his post. Previous culture ministers have been hamstrung by the arm's-length principle of funding, by which the minister gets the cash out of the treasury but other organisations, such as the arts council, decide what it is spent on. Such has been Smith's influence on policy-making that, although the independence of funding has been maintained, he is very much seen by the big hitters in the arts world as the man who can get things done. The philanthropic publisher and financier, Christopher Ondaatje, is impressed. Having worked with Smith after he donated £2.75m towards the new wing of the National Portrait Gallery, Ondaatje recently gave £2m to the Labour Party. He particularly praises the model of national institutions, the private sector and government working together. "Something seems to have happened in the arts in this country that is right. It hasn't happened over night, but Chris Smith has lent his support and enthusiasm to a number of institutions that seem to have lead a cultural revolution in England. I am really very proud to have been able to work with him and to have done something worthwhile." Smith operates on the politician's seemingly obligatory four or five hours' sleep a night, filling his days with meetings and his evenings with functions. He worries about the lack of time to refresh and re-think his politics. "It's one of the problems of being in government; not seeing the wood for the trees. You are constantly dealing with individual issues and problems, and you try to run the tactics and you forget the strategy. You have to make time to sit back and look at the big themes you are trying to put in place." Julia Neuberger says she thinks there is still a really big book in him. "I thought he would write the big Wordsworth book, but I am not sure what it will be now. But after he retires I am sure he will write something important, maybe on cultural policy." The notion of Smith having more time to spend with his Wordsworth and his walking has been a regular feature of political gossip, and more recently there have been rumours that his whole department is to be scrapped. But he insists the department's future is secure. "I've been told by the very highest authority that it is not going to happen," he states meaningfully, adding that while, of course, it is the PM's decision, he also hopes to have plenty more wear out of both his red box and his dinner jacket. "We need to follow through. There are the creative partnerships between cultural organisations and schools. It will allow children to get the chance to work with arts professionals. Far too few children have these opportunities, which could be of major benefit to them. Then there's Culture on Line, by which people can interact with the best of cultural activity and resources. This will be the equivalent of the Open University in the 60s, or Channel 4 in the 80s. More trust in the excellent institutions, with longer grants and less interference, and a whole new agenda for school sport. There' s certainly more work to be done." Life at a glance Christopher Robert Smith Born: 24 July 1951 Education: Cassiobury Primary School, Watford; George Watson's College, Edinburgh; Pembroke College, Cambridge 69-75, Harvard University 75-76 Family: partner Dorian Jabri Career: Development Secretary, Shaftesbury Housing Association 77-80; Development Co-ordinator Society for Co-operative Dwellings 80-83. Political career: Islington councillor, 78-83; MP Islington South and Finsbury, since 83 Posts held: Opposition spokesman on treasury and economic affairs 87-92, on environmental protection 92-94, on national heritage 94-95, on social security 95-96, on health 96-97; secretary of state for culture, media and sport since 97 Other posts: Executive of NCCL 86-88; executive committee of National Trust 95-97; Governor Sadler's Wells Theatre 87-97 Books: Creative Britain 98

fields.headline: Head of a Woman (Fernande), Picasso (1909)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Pablo Picasso (1881-1973), who, together with Georges Braque (1882-1963), undertook the greatest revolution in European art since the invention of perspective in Renaissance Florence. This was cubism, though the name - coined by Matisse - says nothing about what they were trying to achieve. In 1907 Braque visited Picasso's studio in the Bateau Lavoir in Montmartre, where the Spanish artist had lived since migrating from Barcelona to Paris in 1904. Although Braque was at first shocked by Picasso's use of African masks and jagged, flat compositions, the two of them pooled ideas over the next few years as they repudiated perspective in works of unrivalled density and power.

Subject: Fernande Olivier (1881-1966), Picasso's lover. Fernande - real name Amelie Lang - had worked as an artist's model in Montmartre and was an aspiring painter. She fell in love with Picasso when they smoked opium together. Picasso spoke of being caught by her beauty, but by 1909, when he made this head, the strain in their relationship was showing. That autumn they settled in a new flat, where Fernande's desire to be respectable got on Pablo's nerves. In 1911 he started seeing Eva Gouel. In 1912 the all-but-ostracised Fernande had an affair, giving Picasso an excuse to end their relationship. By the end of that year she was borrowing money from Gertrude Stein. In 1933 she published her evocative memoir Picasso and His Friends.

Distinguishing features: You can never exhaust the richness of this head. It is like a mountain range, a landscape. It is transformed every time you move your own head, walk around it, bend closer, taking in the rough surface with the marks of Picasso's touch, the warm softness of the plaster that contrasts with the sharp contours. It has been compared to an anatomist's flayed model in the way Picasso seems to see beneath the skin, revealing a tangle of tendons in Fernande's neck but it doesn't feel violent in that way at all.

They had spent the summer of 1909 in the Spanish mountains, where Picasso painted Fernande in a similarly faceted way, making this head almost as soon as he returned to Paris. The fractured texture of Fernande's face, her hair a system of gorges and upland ridges, is a metaphor for the way we experience another person. Like Rembrandt's most intimate portraits, it is about the mystery of being close to another human being. Picasso makes you recognise this by inviting your eye down into those channels and crevices, until you feel you are inside Fernande's head.

This is one of the seminal works of cubism, and in the state that Picasso liked it best. He moulded Fernande's head in clay, then made two plaster casts from which he authorised a series of bronzes. He never liked the bronzes as much as this raw plaster version. It is a key work in the development of cubism because it was the first time Picasso realised he could translate his new kind of painting into three dimensions this is one of his paintings from that time given solid form.

Solidity was what Picasso wanted in art: he wanted not just to see the world but to touch it. Fernande's head is a masterpiece because it perfectly realises his desire to represent not the surfaces of things but the essence, the structure - Fernande not just naked but experienced from within her own skin. You can no more feel you have exhausted this piece than know everything about another person.

Inspirations and influences: The impact of this work was immediate: the futurist painter Boccioni saw it and started experimenting with sculpture, producing his striding figure Unique Forms of Continuity in Space in 1913.

Where is it? Tate Modern, London SE1 (020-7887 8008).

fields.headline: Imperial College Management School
fields.trailText: Aspiring managers with technical and engineering skills looking for a final pit stop before hitting the fast track to boardroom success have a champion in Imperial College Management School (ICMS).
fields.body:
Aspiring managers with technical and engineering skills looking for a final pit stop before hitting the fast track to boardroom success have a champion in Imperial College Management School (ICMS).

The college owes its foundation to Prince Albert who backed the idea that some of the financial surplus generated from the Great Exhibition of 1851 be used to build the Kensington campus of which Imperial is a part. The college, which received its Royal Charter in 1907, has a mission to "advance knowledge for the benefit of industry and commerce".

With change and uncertainty forcing their way on to the business agenda, the Imperial MBA focuses on improving managerial ability to handle the current rapid pace of corporate upheaval. The management school maintains close links with many businesses in different sectors, seeking their advice in the development of its syllabus design and teaching. Not only was the school praised as excellent by the government's Teaching Assessment Audit Committee, but was also described as outstanding within this top category.

But it's the school's Entrepreneurship Centre that has recently become the talk of business education providers. Led by Professor Sue Birley, the centre focuses on the issues associated with creating and growing a modern enterprise and examines the various ownership models from start-ups and MBOs to franchising and family-owned businesses.

"It's an opportunity to unleash the entrepreneurial potential of our 10,000 students," says Sue. "We have an absolute goldmine of talent, ideas and technologies in this place, and all we need to do is find the route to the gold."

ICMS also runs an incubation service for a small number of talented graduates, which enables them to use premises and equipment free of charge. Most valuable, however, is the school's network of contacts, including venture capitalists. Greg Harding, a recent MBA graduate who is setting up Mellon Hostels, an international youth hostel network for the budget-conscious traveller, says it gave him the skills, resources and contacts to launch his business. "You can't get through doors by cold calling, but if you get referred, you can," he says.

Students could not ask for a more conducive location, situated in the 'museum quarter'of London's West End and college facilities include a library, computer suites and sports centre with gym and swimming pool.

All this may help explain why ICMS gets more than 900 applications for around 150 places on its full-time MBA programme. For application details write to the Admissions Office, Imperial College Management School, 53 Prince's Gate, Exhibition Road, London SW7 2PG.

webTitle: Holidays at home, from Chequers to the Highlands

fields.headline: Holidays at home, from Chequers to the Highlands
fields.standfirst:
Ministers opt to take breaks in the UK

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Ministers opt to take Easter breaks in the UK
fields.body:
Tony Blair's campaign to reopen as many footpaths as possible in time for Easter yesterday ran up against the magisterial authority of Buckinghamshire county council. The council's refusal to reopen its Chiltern walks means that the prime minister and his family will be marooned at Chequers over the holiday.

"We consider it a prudent course to take. We have had two areas affected by cases in [adjoining] Northamptonshire and Oxfordshire and four suspect cases here. They all got the all-clear, but we want to keep it that way," explained a defiantly off-message Terry Carter, Buckinghamshire's principal trading standards officer.

As Mr Blair beat the tourist drum in Yorkshire, trailed by TV crews from France, Japan and the US, John Prescott loyally went sailing on the foot and mouth-free Norfolk Broads yesterday. Senior colleagues rallied to the call to stay at home, cancelling all thoughts of a quick trip to the ski slopes or the Canaries during the gap created by the non-election.

Apart from Robin Cook, whose job as foreign secretary unavoidably takes him abroad, only the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, admitted to having even thought about a foreign outing over Easter.- but no longer. "He has cancelled a holiday in France," aides confirmed. "He will be boosting tourism in the province instead."

Paul Murphy, his Welsh counterpart, will be spending Easter in Dorset. While he is away, chief whip Ann Taylor and her family will be in Wales.

Most of the cabinet's Scots will be at home for the holiday. the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, will be in his Highland pile, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, at his North Queensferry home high above the Forth bridges when not working at the Treasury, and Alistair Darling with his family in Edinburgh.

Mr Blair had always intended to spend a few days at Chequers. It is set in genuine farmland, with grazing sheep and cattle sometimes in view from its mullioned windows, along with the armed police officers and Blair family football goalposts. Unfortunately for No 10, Buckinghamshire is full of mixed arable and grazing land.

In practice, the persistent footpath ban will affect cabinet members differently. Margaret Jay, leader of the Lords, has a country cottage in Ireland, but another in the Cotswolds, as does Michael Meacher, the many-homed environment minister.

Both are likely to find Gloucestershire's off-road paths still closed unless the government's appeal starts to make headway. Jack Straw, whose rural retreat is in Oxfordshire, will have to do his Easter walking on tarmac too. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is going to Suffolk - foot and mouth-free so far - as is Geoff Hoon, whose troops are busy burying the disease's victims.

David Blunkett couldn't visit the Peak District from his Sheffield home even if he wanted to - it got its first suspected case yesterday. But the lucky education secretary and his deputy, Estelle Morris, will be touring teachers' conferences in Cardiff and Jersey.

Mr Blair himself will do one such union conference, the AUT in Torquay, the most urban part of hard-hit Devon. William Hague will snatch a few days electioneering from a base at his Richmond, North Yorkshire, constituency home. Email update

fields.headline: Swan Inn, West Sussex
fields.trailText: The restaurant has a small menu, but everything we ate was delicious and unusual with good-sized portions.
fields.body:
Address: Lower Street, Fittleworth, West Sussex, RH20 1EN.
Tel: 01798 865429.
Web address: www.swaninn.com

First impressions: Fourteenth-century coaching inn in the middle of the South Downs. It is crowded with locals drawn by the cosy bar and the renowned food. Comfortable atmosphere with coal fires, low beams, uneven floor and walls, which are enough to make the sober feel slightly drunk.

The rooms: Ours was comfortable and quirky with (terrestrial) TV, tea- and coffee-making facilities and a map showing the main local attractions. And slightly hazardous, with a beam marked "mind your head" closely followed by a "mind the step" sign down into the bathroom.

The bed test: Fabulously comfortable four-poster in chintzy oranges and yellows.

Bathroom: Good size with a deep bath and shower.

Restaurant: A small menu, but everything we ate was delicious and unusual with good-sized portions. The restaurant is popular with locals and so it is vital to book, even when staying for the weekend.

The lounge: This doubles as the breakfast room. Wood- panelled walls are decorated with paintings done by guests in the 19th century who couldn't afford to pay their bills (not an option today, sadly). It is full of antiques and has a coal fire alight at breakfast time.

What is there to see within walking distance? The South Downs Way is just yards away taking you over spectacular Downland.

What is there to see within a 20-minute drive? The towns of Chichester and Arundel are nearby, as is the village of Bosham, where King Canute allegedly commanded the waves not to come in.

How much a night: Singles from £25, doubles with four-poster £60. May Bank Holiday and Easter special offers include two nights with breakfast and dinner, and a room with a four-poster bed, for £150 per couple.

webTitle: Falling US wages rekindle markets' recession fears

fields.headline: Falling US wages rekindle markets' recession fears
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Fears of a full scale recession in the US were rekindled yesterday after worse than expected employment figures, sending US shares sharply lower.
fields.body:
Fears of a full scale recession in the US were rekindled yesterday after worse than expected employment figures, sending US shares sharply lower.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the Nasdaq Composite indexes fell sharply. The Dow was down 181 points, or more than 1%, to just above 9,736 by lunchtime while the Nasdaq gave up more than 3%, or 60 points, to 1,724.

Non-farm payrolls fell by 86,000 in March, far worse than expected and the largest decline since the recession in 1991. Economists fear that the decline in wages will further deter consumer spending in the US and prevent a consumer-led recovery.

The surprising decline prompted economists to suggest that the US central bank would cut interest rates before its scheduled meeting.

The unemployment rate rose to 4.3% in March, the highest since mid-1999 although still a low figure. Analysts believe that the Federal Reserve will watch economic data to be released next week, including retail sales and consumer confidence, for signs of a recession.

Meanwhile the Japanese government yesterday gave the country's banks a two-year deadline to clear up the trillions of yens' worth of bad loans that have plagued the world's second biggest economy for more than a decade.

The time limit was part of an emergency economic package designed to halt a sharp slide in stock prices and prevent the country from slipping into its third recession in three years.

Amid the political uncertainty caused by yesterday's confirmation that the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, would stand down, analysts were sceptical that the far-reaching plans would be put into practice.

Under the package, banks will also be forced to write off their problem loans and to sell off a sizeable chunk of their stockholdings, which have traditionally cemented ties with corporate borrowers.

fields.headline: Mortgages turn back the clock
fields.standfirst: This week's move by the Bank of England left home loans at their lowest level since 1965. But, reports Patrick Collinson, not everyone gains yet
fields.trailText: This week's move by the Bank of England left home loans at their lowest level since 1965. But, reports Patrick Collinson, not everyone gains yet.
fields.body:
It was the year when Dr Who began his first battle with the Daleks, The Beatles topped the charts with Ticket to Ride, Help! and Day Tripper, and the price of a bottle of wine was just 27.5p, or 5s 6d in old money. And 1965 was also the last time that the mortgage rate was 6.5%.

Mortgage lenders were this week trumpeting the cheapest loans in a generation, as they swiftly followed the Bank of England's 0.25% cut in base rate to 5.5% with cuts in their variable rates.

Halifax cut its standard variable rate from 6.75% to 6.5%, while Nationwide went further and cut its base rate to 6.24%.

It is a far cry from the dark days of 1990, when mortgage rates peaked at 15.4%, prompting the worst property recession ever seen in Britain. Someone borrowing £60,000 in 1990 from the Halifax on an interest-only mortgage paid £634 per month, even after a £95 subsidy from the taxpayer in the form of the now-abolished Miras. Today, Halifax only charges £325 per month for the same mortgage.

More falls are also on the way; it is widely expected that as inflation undershoots the Chancellor's minimum 1.5% level, the Bank of England will be forced to cut base rate further, by as much as another 0.5% this year.

Halifax has promised that its new standard variable rate will track the Bank of England rate, suggesting that it could go as low as 6%. The headlines will then read "lowest mortgages since 1960".

But amid the hype, it is becoming increasingly difficult to get to grips with what homeowners really are paying on their mortgages. The lowest variable rates are now offered by Nationwide, HSBC (6.25%) and Intelligent Finance (6.25%), which have opened up a considerable gap ahead of most of the building societies which converted to banks, such as Northern Rock and Alliance & Leicester, whose variable rates are 7.25%.

Up to a third of Britain's 11m mortgage holders are on fixed rates, and will therefore see no change as a result of this week's rate cut. More recently buyers have largely opted for discount loans, which will benefit. Many are on two-year, 2% off deals, which is bringing some rates down to less than 5%. At that level, a £100,000 mortgage costs little more than £400 per month to service.

Nationwide reopened its war of words with Halifax, accusing the lender of passing the benefits of its new 6.5% rate to only a small number of customers.

Halifax, Nationwide and Abbey National all split their variable rates into SVR1 and SVR2 last month, with borrowers in discount and capped deals tied to the old SVR1, with the rest transferred to, or invited to transfer to, a new, lower SVR2.

Nationwide said this week that 530,000 of its 890,000 borrowers will enjoy its new 6.24% base rate, with the balance locked into fixed or discount deals. "We don't believe that Halifax has more than 150,000 of its 2.5m borrowers on their new rate," claimed a Nationwide spokesman.

Halifax admitted that only 100,000 borrowers have so far switched to its new base rate, but said that 400,000 will move over the next few months.

A spokesman said: "Unlike Nationwide we do not have anyone in extended lock-in periods and the remainder of our borrowers are on special deals, the majority of which are on lower rates than 6.5%.

"Halifax is focused on providing customers with a good deal. Nationwide, on the other hand, seem to be anxious to win their election."

However, both Halifax or Nationwide continue to refuse to switch customers who took out discount deals before March to switch to the new standard variable rates without paying hefty penalties, as highlighted in Jobs & Money.

Mortgage holders claim the move is in breach of contract, and have taken their cases to the Office of Fair Trading and the Banking Ombudsman, which are yet to rule on the matter. The figures in the table below show the difference between old and new standard variable rate payments at the two lenders. So what is the best mortgage for home buyers now, and what sort of rate should you expect to pay? Ray Boulger of Charcol says: "Some people may be holding out in the hope that fixed/capped rates fall further, but our advice is not to wait as there are already good products out there offering low rates which already factor in further base rate cuts which may or may not materialise.

"Furthermore, some of these rates are loss leaders, but as lenders will progressively have less fat to cream off their existing borrowers as new-style standard variable rates are reduced to around 0.75%-1% over base rate, I expect new offers to become less competitive in the main."

Mr Boulger is currently recommending that borrowers opt for mortgages which are a mix of fixed rate plus a tracker rate which moves in line with base rate.

Charcol has a remortgage product which is fixed at 4.7% until 2003, then switches to 0.6% over base rate until 2004. Birmingham Midshires has a five-year fix at 5.79% until 2006, which gives the option to switch at any time to base rate plus 1% for the remaining mortgage term. Charcol believes the best pure fixed rate is Bristol & West's three-year loan pegged at 5.15% to 2004.

fields.headline: Sacred rights
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on the pitfalls of direct translation
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on the pitfalls of direct translation.
fields.body:
In a recent report about a dispute between two Italian novelists, Ippolita Avalli and Susanna Tamaro, we said the narrator in a book by Ms Avalli had thrown a tantrum during mass and called the congregation "whitewashed tombs". A reader was immediately in touch to say: surely this is a mistranslation and should have been "whited sepulchres"? It probably should have been, because although our correspondent's translation was literally correct it deprived the expression of any real force as invective. Didn't it?

I suspect that behind the complaint was the suspicion that our correspondent had not recognised the source of the expression. There is a recurring background lament that no one at the godless Guardian knows the Bible, a reflection of the argument that our increasing inability to read the Biblical or classical allusions in paintings, for example, renders the contents of the National Gallery in London virtually meaningless.

What Ms Avalli's protagonist actually called the people in church was "sepolcri imbiancati", a quotation from, to be specific, Matthew 23:27. The nearest office copy of an English-Italian dictionary (dated 1990) has the following entry: Un sepolcro imbiancato - a whited sepulchre, a hypocrite.

In the noble and, in this case, self-explanatory English of the King James version, this is: "Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye are like unto whited sepulchres, which indeed appear beautiful outward, but are within full of dead men's bones, and of all uncleanness."

The New English Bible, honourably in pursuit of more accessible meaning at some expense to the poetry, says, "You are like tombs covered with whitewash." The New Oxford Annotated Bible (1994) offers this version: "Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs [our correspondent's very phrase], which on the outside look beautiful, but inside they are full of the bones of the dead and of all kinds of filth."

There is a useful footnote: tombs were whitewashed before Passover so that Jewish travellers might not unwittingly touch them and become ceremonially unclean.

As usual we are watching words in motion, in this case the receding of a phrase quoted to lend a grand Biblical authority to an accusation of hypocrisy. Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable says: "A whited sepulchre: a hypocrite, especially one who conceals wickedness under a cloak of virtue, etc." We shall wait a little while, I think, before it is replaced by an entry for "whitewashed tomb". It falls rather limply on the air.

However, it escaped the Guardian's daily corrections column. So did the following because, even though it resulted from a slip of the finger on the keyboard, and though the author, an expert on aspects of the countryside, could be heard clapping a hand to his forehead when it was pointed out to him, it was not absolutely wrong.

This is what he said, in the context of a piece exploring the possibility that foot and mouth disease may provide an opportunity to change the approach to sheep farming: "The old 'weathers' can lead the flock to safety when the snow clouds gather."

This brought a complaint from a reader who said "weathers" should be wethers and that there was no need to enclose it in quotes because it was a perfectly legitimate word. Mistakes of this kind are often seen by readers, especially those who live in the lands beyond the M25, as symptoms of our separation from the countryside. We have to exonerate this particular contributor, who reaches Farringdon Road with a convincing amount of mud on his boots.

The reader who complained is right, of course, although it seems rather picky to find fault in such a beautifully descriptive sentence - beautifully descriptive, that is, if you know what a wether is.

The Oxford English Dictionary is, as usual, very entertaining on the subject. Its first definition is "a male sheep, a ram; especially a castrated ram. See also Bell-wether" (which we shall in a moment). It gives examples of this use from the ninth to the 19th centuries, with the spelling wether shedding all variants by the present time, including the most common one, which was "weather". The latter was the version that Shakespeare used in his poem The Passionate Pilgrim: "My weathers bell rings dolefull knell"; and as a metaphor for a eunuch, in the Merchant of Venice: "I am a tainted Weather of the flocke, Meetest for death."

And so to bellwether. The OED offers three definitions: the leading sheep of a flock, on whose neck a bell is hung; a chief or leader (contemptuous); and a clamorous person, one ready to give mouth.

A final quotation (also courtesy the OED) from the philosopher GH Lewes (1847): "Men are for the most part like sheep, who always follow the bell-wether." On that note I shall ring off.

fields.headline: Reputations at stake
fields.standfirst: When giving your opinion on a plant, it's best to be frank, says Christopher Lloyd. Even if that means describing them warts and all
fields.trailText: When giving your opinion on a plant, it's best to be frank, says Christopher Lloyd. Even if that means describing them warts and all.
fields.body:
When it comes to recommending plants, telling the whole truth about the things we grow seems to be one of the most difficult hurdles for gardening writers to clear. Personal reputation becomes wrapped up in the plants, the inference being, "If I recommend these to you, there is no room for criticism; any criticism of the plant is a slur on me." Put like that, it seems ridiculous, and yet this is the way it works and the reader is left with an unbalanced picture of the plants in question.

Cromwell told his portraitist to paint him warts and all, and this is by far the most helpful way to present plants, too, whether they are being recommended or simply being described, leaving the reader to decide whether to try them out.

Just now, we are in the full "glory" of the camellia, a greatly underrated shrub, we are told. Whether underrated or not, it has undoubted assets. It is evergreen with a cheerful gloss on its leaves and its well-constructed flowers are in bright, clean colours, making a good spring display. Provided your soil is on the acid side of neutral and the site is reasonably sheltered, its cultivation presents no problems. That said, I think we also need to realise that in many varieties the flowers are not shed on dying but continue to clutter up the bush, which is particularly noticeable when the healthy blooms are white. Furthermore, the flowers are round and blobby, and are dotted over the bush in a rather childish presentation that is without overall cohesion. Still, a large bush in full bloom can provide quite an exciting landscape feature.

Narcissi, usually called daffodils when yellow with trumpets, have received a great deal of attention from breeders. On the whole, this has not impaired their robust constitution. They seem to lend themselves ideally to competitive exhibition, as the bloom, once open, behaves predictably. It will always face the same direction and the stem will remain rigid, not taking on awkward curves, as tulips do. Varieties with large, prosperous-looking blooms and overlapping petals are readily available, and make a great show. Unfortunately, they are both coarse and clumsy, too. The leaves have been enlarged at the same time as the flowers, and the mess presented by a large daffodil after flowering is a picture of decay in the spring garden for many weeks.

Tulips, so popular in Holland, have been treated as poor relations by breeders in our country, one reason being that to raise a new variety from seed takes many years. This does not appeal to the amateur. There is probably also an element of jealousy of the Dutch, who seem to have made such a corner in tulips that the RHS takes little notice of them. You will not find tulip trials at Wisley, though narcissus is present in force.

The modern, square-shouldered tulip lends itself to mass bedding, which is appropriate in some formal settings but makes a dull flower out of one that is full of personality. Ironically, many of the most captivating tulips are no longer allowed to be marketed, because their broken colours have been discovered to be caused by a virus. So the tulip family, fascinating as it is in its range of colours and combinations, is hamstrung not only by regulations but also by the kind of human taste that finds no beauty in irregularity and waywardness, in both of which the tulip excels.

Cookery articles that talk all round the subject but never get down to a cut-and-dried recipe irritate me. I must not be similarly guilty. If you enjoy a big, bright, blowsy yet easily grown camellia, try ÔMercury', which both Fergus and I love, vulgar though it may be. It is semi-double and red. Its vicious habits can be overlooked. If you need refinement, 'Cornish Snow' is quite a charmer, with masses of small, single flowers, and there is nothing clumsy about the bush.

Within the genus Narcissus, I gravitate more and more to the small-flowered species or to hybrids quite close to them. Their leaves tend to be unobtrusive and are easily absorbed both in a border or in a meadow. I like the hoop-petticoat daffodil, N. bulbocodium, best in its pale yellow variety, citrinus. N. cyclamineus is remarkable for the way it lays its ears back so that perianth and trumpet are both in the same plane. N. minor is an obliging little yellow trumpet (half the size of our native Lent lily, N. pseudonarcissus), and good in turf or in a border with late snowdrops and scillas or chionodoxas.

Among tulips, I love the informality of most of the parrots, with their ragged petal edges and often rather bent or twisted stems. My favourite has to be ÔQueen of Sheba' - beautiful at every stage, from newly opened and slender to wide as you can imagine, bronzy orange with yellow margins and a murky greenish centre. Irresistible.
fields.bodyText: When it comes to recommending plants, telling the whole truth about the things we grow seems to be one of the most difficult hurdles for gardening writers to clear. Personal reputation becomes wrapped up in the plants, the inference being, "If I recommend these to you, there is no room for criticism; any criticism of the plant is a slur on me." Put like that, it seems ridiculous, and yet this is the way it works and the reader is left with an unbalanced picture of the plants in question. fields.headline: The sorcerer and his apprentice
fields.standfirst: Emanuel Ungaro is the last of his breed - an old school fashion designer who learned his trade at the shoulder of a great couturier. Now aged 68, this living legend is himself training a successor, Giambattista Valli, to carry on the tradition. Charlie Porter meets them at their Paris atelier
fields.trailText: Emanuel Ungaro is the last of his breed - an old school fashion designer who learned his trade at the shoulder of a great couturier. Now aged 68, this living legend is himself training a successor, Giambattista Valli, to carry on the tradition. Charlie Porter meets them at their Paris atelier.
fields.body:
Emanuel Ungaro is a very serious man - devoted to fashion, of course, but more likely to talk about Freud than the cut of a frock. Indeed, there is a portrait of the psychoanalyst on his desk, and on a poster on the wall, in big letters, is Freud's eternal poser: "The great question . . . which I have not been able to answer, despite my 30 years of research into the feminine soul, is 'What does a woman want?'" It is a question you'd think Ungaro would be well placed to answer, given his experience of 40 odd years' experience of dressing women. "Do you study Freud?" asks the 68-year-old couturier, as if this was as obvious as asking which football team you support. Don't think of me as just a designer, he seems to be saying - I'm much more than that. Ungaro is one of the last in the grand tradition of couturiers. He is in charge, but has enormous respect for his staff, and hopes this confidence is reflected in the clothes. "This house has a strong sense of ethics and vigour in the search of quality, of that I'm sure. I was born like that." And now he is ensuring the tradition lives on - in his house, at least. His appointment of 34-year-old Giambattista Valli as creative director has brought a new vibrancy and glamour to the Ungaro label.

Ungaro was born in Aix-en-Provence to Italian parents - his father was a tailor. He came to Paris aged 22, determined to enter the fashion industry. "I remember I had no money, I had nothing. I was renting a room from this old aristocratic man on a small street on the Left Bank. But I remember once, late at night, standing on the street, eating at a hotdog stall. In my head, I was building my couture house, believing that some day I would have one." He quickly found work with Cristobal Balenciaga, the great Spanish couturier. Balenciaga was highly regarded by his peers, an intellectual whose work was never populist like that of Chanel or Dior. For Ungaro, the training was the best imaginable. "Balenciaga never talked. You had to learn and take from it the sense of quality. He was a very alone, very silent man. I never met her, but I heard that Chanel was a genius and a monster. Balenciaga was a genius, but not a monster. He was fantastic to be with. But then you have to go it alone, and it is very difficult to start from nothing with four workers."

Ungaro's first collection, in 1965, was restricted to daywear only, because his tiny studio had no room to accommodate any space-taking dresses. He started on his own at an important time for fashion. Alongside Yves Saint Laurent, he helped to establish ready-to-wear as a viable alternative to couture. But founding a house was as difficult then as it is for young designers today. "The moment you have no money, you have to work," he declares.

"I worked 18 hours a day, every day of the year, no vacation. I lived for years in a small studio. I had no luxury habits, and I bought my first car, a Mini Morris, when I was 40. But I didn't mind. I love to work. I was born into a very modest family, it was not a complication for me." Steadily, with no rush or boastful fanfare, Ungaro built a reputation for his way with colour and print, and not for going too far into the extremities of cut or trend. He has always been about flattering the women he dresses, rather than seeing them as design experiments. This makes sense, since Ungaro is that rare thing: a heterosexual fashion designer. Married, he has a 10-year-old daughter with his wife, Laura, who is also the director of communications for the house and responsible for the brand's family atmosphere.

For more than 30 years, Ungaro remained independent from the conglomerates that now control fashion. His business was successful, but had expanded as much as it could. Unlike most of the other French labels, all of Ungaro's profits came from clothes rather than bags or shoes. This meant there was a ceiling to his house's profits.

His career high came in the taffeta-heavy 80s: his highly decorated, ruched, starchy dresses-with-a-sense-of-occasion suited the times. The 90s were not such a good match; the house of Ungaro was never going to embrace grunge. After a period of introspection, Ungaro saw that the need to revive his house was vital. In 1996, he gave up his fiercely-held independence by entering into partnership with Italian label Salvatore Ferregamo (which is fashion-speak for Ferregamo buying a majority stake in Ungaro). The deal gave him the opportunity to reclaim his position on the global fashion scene. "Try to stay alone? Impossible," he says. "I could have stayed alone, of course, but with limited ambitions, and the day I'm not here, what happens with the house?"

Clearly, concern over the future of Ungaro house weighs heavily upon him. "Some day, I have to leave all of this and let people do what they want to do, because I can't be responsible when I'm in the coffin," he declares abruptly. "But it is not sad, what I'm saying. It's like family, when a father is trying to leave them the best in the world." And, just as he had to find a suitably understanding financial partner to ensure he kept full creative control, so he needed to employ the right sort of new talent for the house. After all, in the past few years many of the Paris houses have been hotbeds of rumours about new, mismatched designers causing uproar in the ateliers.

That was never going to be the case in Ungaro's atelier in avenue Montaigne. Ungaro found Valli at Krizia in Italy. Laura asked him to do some sketches, demonstrating how he would fit into the style of the house. Valli handed in the work, then went on holiday to India. "They called me there and said that Mr Ungaro wanted to see me right away," Valli remembers. The pair got on straight away: "You know, in most of the houses, they bring in somebody new who doesn't think about what is the real story," says Valli. "They build up their own, but it doesn't fit with the style of the house. But with Mr Ungaro there is never a case of me or you. I always propose what I think is right for Ungaro. I never propose the trend of the moment."

Five years on from the Ferregamo deal, expansion is well underway. This month, the UK's first Emanuel Ungaro boutique opens on a prime piece of Bond Street real estate. The huge store is a statement of new confidence, instilled by Ungaro's new creative director. The Ungaro look is still recognisably there, but Valli has brought a lighter touch - the fluid, embellished clothes look at their most fresh when thrown together with some denim and a pair of high heels. The move has paid off, with sales rocketing and the clothes being worn by such celebrities as Jennifer Lopez, Britney Spears and Sarah Jessica Parker.

"People used to be afraid of him," says Valli. While Ungaro is immaculately presentable in his atelier uniform, Valli looks like he hasn't been to bed, and his cords are so dirty and torn around his ankles it's as if he's just spent a weekend at Glastonbury. "When I arrived," he says, "they were giving the impression that [Ungaro] was inaccessible. Everyone was struck because I was wearing sneakers, and everyone was saying, 'Definitely no gum, no sneakers'. But we met, and he was really waiting for someone to talk to him. Everyone had been putting wool around him, which meant people were afraid to bring in new things. I have opened the windows of the house on what's going on outside, and now he says how he loves having all these young people around him."

But for all these new ideas, there is still a rigid order to the house. Valli is interviewed separately, because it would be wrong for him to talk to the press in Ungaro's presence. It is also specified that, however great Valli's influence has been, Ungaro is still very much the designer. This is no ordinary case of a venerable house finding new blood, as has happened at the likes of Dior and Givenchy. Ungaro, one of the true couturiers, who started out with Balenciaga, is training Valli to be the last designer to come from that tradition of learning under the eye of the greats.

There is a sense of relief at Ungaro that the arrangement is working so well, since no other house has managed to maintain the tradition. "He has this chance to be one of the last in couture," declares Ungaro. "He has this chance to have a master. If you look what's happening at the other houses, no one is doing that. Givenchy left with no one taking his place [Hubert de Givenchy never approved of Alexander McQueen, and has remained silent about his replacement, Julien Macdonald]. Coco Chanel, no one was there, Monsieur Dior did - he trained Saint Laurent, but now look what's happening at YSL with Tom Ford . . ."

For Valli, the wealth of accumulated knowledge is astounding: "It was such a great occasion for me to find so pure a couturier, somebody who grew up with Balenciaga. Through him, I learn from Balenciaga - that's stunning."

Now, on the studio floor of the house, there is an easy balance between Ungaro's studio - pristine, neat and expansive - and the room that houses Valli and the others on the design team - cramped, teeming with sequin trays and mood boards, exploding with ideas. "I try to give the most of the proposition of fabrics, colours, prints," says Valli, "and then we start to work together on the idea of the story, and then it goes right away."

For his part, Ungaro says, "there's the other studio, and the door is always open. Everyone has the opportunity to come in and suggest ideas, colours, shapes, but the way I'm working is really special because I'm not sketching any more. Now I'm working directly on the model, on the house girl here, because I love the direct relation with the material and the body of the girl." Which, reading between the lines, suggests that Ungaro is happy that there is now someone to bring a contemporary edge that allows the house to move forward by instinct rather than guesswork. At the recent autumn/winter 2001 show in Paris, the new mood was palpable. While some shows by other similarly established houses were poorly attended, the Ungaro presentation of pretty, intricate, yet wearable clothes was a hot ticket. When Ungaro came to take a bow at the end, for the first time he brought out Valli to share the applause.

Obviously, there are occasional disagreements between the two - "It can be very serious, very tense," admits Valli - but there is an overriding harmony between the two studios, even if the larger room works to the sounds of Mozart, while the smaller one is partying to Debbie Harry in a world of popular culture that Ungaro himself does not understand, but that he acknowledges as vitally important.

"There are all these new girls dressing in Ungaro," says Valli, "like Sarah Jessica Parker or Jennifer Lopez. He sees these people from my generation, and he's looking on as a spectator. Britney Spears came into the office and we introduced her to Monsieur Ungaro, and it was so funny because sometimes he doesn't know about these things. He said to me, 'Who is Britney Spears?' I said, 'Ask your daughter'."

Does Ungaro think that Valli knows how lucky he is to be working in such a harmonious house? "I hope he does," he replies. "It's often not easy. I remember at Balenciaga, everyone was jealous of me. I was very young, very ambitious, and surrounded by very mean, very terrible people. But I don't just respect the people working for me, I love them, because I know they do their best, even when they make mistakes, because nobody's perfect. And that makes the strength of the house."

But the house's recent success doesn't mean the pressures on Ungaro are any less great. Somehow, it seems to make them worse. "I've no frivolity about it, you understand," he says. "It's more responsibility, in fact. Not that it's not my money, so I don't care; on the contrary, I care more than if it were mine. Before, I felt bad because I needed money to develop the house. Now the money's here, I've got to take care of it."

Of course, with Freud sat there next to him, this can sound arch, as he readily admits: "We are not surgeons, we are not trying to find the cure for cancer, we're trying to make fashion"

Now the money's here, I've got to take care of it." Of course, with Freud sat there next to him, this can sound arch, as he readily admits: "We are not surgeons, we are not trying to find the cure for cancer, we're trying to make fashion"

fields.headline: Bucks' land of make-believe
fields.trailText: It is not that Wycombe folk are unexcited about the prospect of their club reaching the FA Cup final. They are just exhausted after a run that began back in November with a first-round tie against Harrow Borough, and they also have their own, more genteel way of celebrating.
fields.body:
Lee Marshall, a street trader, was unaware that Wycombe survived a foot-and-mouth scare near the Wanderers' ground earlier this week. But, as another group of shoppers bustled past the town's Guildhall without a second glance at his stall containing hats, shirts and jesters' caps in the Wanderers' two-tone blue, he must have wondered if the ministry of agriculture officials who visited the town had vaccinated everyone against Cup fever.

"I've only sold one hat," moaned Marshall, who had driven down from Robin Hood country in search of his slice of Wycombe's FA Cup semi-final cake. "I've sold more West Ham gear in the centre of Nottingham."

On initial examination it might seem impossible to diagnose even a rise in temperature in High Wycombe over tomorrow's big match with Liverpool at Villa Park, let alone a full-blown fever. A single banner flies almost apologetically in front of the Guildhall, and WH Smith's window display consists of nothing more than a dozen balloons and a couple of flags.

It is not that Wycombe folk are unexcited about the prospect of their club reaching the FA Cup final. They are just exhausted after a run that began back in November with a first-round tie against Harrow Borough, and they also have their own, more genteel way of celebrating.

Councillor David Cox, chairman of the Wycombe district council, says: "I went to a concert on the night of the Leicester win and I said to the orchestra conductor at the interval that he ought to pay tribute to the achievement. He wasn't sure but at the end they all sang For They Are Jolly Good Fellows."

Wycombe people are also wary of outsiders, which is why Marshall was having such a bad day. It was a different story at The Wanderers In The Town store in the Octagon shopping centre, where a video of the Leicester game was on a permanent loop and where the manageress, Kerry Payne, reports that trade has almost doubled in the past three months.

She said: "We normally only have two girls working here. But we've had three of us working six days a week since the win over Wolves in the fourth round at the end of January. When we were given 5,000 tickets to sell, there was a 4-hour queue which stretched out of here, through the bus station and halfway to Tesco."

Councillor Cox says: "The Wanderers' success has brightened up the whole area. My theme for the year is for people to smile more and be more courteous to one another. The club have assisted me no end."

Wycombe's triumphs, he says, have put them on the map, though the town was once nearly wiped off it. Back in the 40s, when it discovered gridlock long before the term was invented, the government made one of those Mr Cholmondley-Warner-style information films entitled Wycombe: The Town That Almost Died Of Traffic.

There will not be a car on the streets next Thursday if Wycombe lose because Cox has already signed the road-closure notices to facilitate an open-bus celebration by the players, followed by a civic reception. But, as Chris Tarrant would say, he does not want to give them that.

Cox says: "If they get to the final or win the Cup, we will have to think of something better. But I don't think we can give the players the freedom of the town because we looked into that after Steve Redgrave won in Sydney."

More than 100 coaches will roll out of High Wycombe tomorrow, carrying most of the 19,000 fans. Among them will be the club mascot Bodger, though this is not because Wycombe has a tradition of turning out cowboy builders. The town is actually famous for its furniture making and bodger is a Buckinghamshire word for chair-leg turner. Hence also the club's Chairboys nickname, having been founded by a group of furniture workers in 1884. Alan Hutchinson came a bit after that but, as the club's longest-serving employee, he will get particular satisfaction when he takes his seat at Villa Park.

He says: "It seems incredible when you think that in 1985-86 we were relegated from the Gola League, which preceded the Vauxhall Conference, after one season. It took the statisticians 10 minutes to work out we had been relegated by 0.1 of a goal because three other teams finished on level points with us. That was our darkest hour."

Wycombe will probably have to find a new hero tomorrow since Roy Essandoh, the Irish Ghanaian who was recruited via the internet, is not expected to be selected. So perhaps the mantle will fall on another set of unlikely shoulders like George Clegg, on loan from Manchester United, or Guy Whittingham, signed on a free from Portsmouth on transfer deadline day.

The players are just back from a week in Mijas, Spain, which was supposed to be a bonding session but ended up in a Ryder Cup style, North v South golf competition, which the northern boys won. Their captain Steve Brown says: "It did us a lot of good. People ask if we will be overawed but most of us have never been in this position and are unlikely to be in it again. So we won't have time to be overawed."

The side will be led out by the manager Lawrie Sanchez's five-year-old son Jack, who is one of the mascots. Sanchez, who has reorganised his life around his son after the death of his wife Heather, said: "It will be nice for him to be a part of it. He's asked me if he can have the Cup if we win it and I told him he could.

"Ninety-nine times out of a 100 this game is a formality. They're one of the biggest teams in the world, we're the biggest team in Buckinghamshire. But you get very few life or career-defining moments and this is one for my players. At Leicester we had to lead them but now it's the other way round. They're confident they can do it."

Wycombe, who will run out with their famous clawed-swan symbol on their chests, are not just in it for the glory, since the club, having made £1m from the Cup run, have promised to double their £1,000 appearance money if they win. In case of failure, though, they should remember that the swan, according to mythology, is said to sing mellifluously in the minutes before its death.
