webTitle: Medical misuse of sedatives 'kills 200 a year'

fields.headline: Medical misuse of sedatives 'kills 200 a year'
fields.trailText: Doctors believe that at least 200 people a year die as a result of accidents linked to sedatives administered by hospital doctors before they carry out diagnosis or treatment.
fields.body:
Doctors believe that at least 200 people a year die as a result of accidents linked to sedatives administered by hospital doctors before they carry out diagnosis or treatment.

More than 1m patients each year are given medication to ease anxiety and help erase unpleasant memories of discomfiting procedures while remaining conscious.

But few doctors are trained to administer such drugs, and there is mounting concern that overdoses tip patients towards losing consciousness. Guidance on use of sedatives, along with other drugs such as painkillers, is not being followed.

A working party from dentistry, accident and emergency services, radiology and gastroenterology, will soon demand compulsory training in giving sedatives to accompany the procedures. These include endoscopy (using tubes to investigate internal organs) and some x-ray examinations; these should not need anaesthetists, who are in short supply.

Six years ago, an audit of procedures using endoscopes through the upper body and sedation suggested one in 2,000 patients died within 30 days, an alarming figure even allowing for numbers of high-risk and comparatively elderly patients involved.

As a consequence professional bodies issued guidance, but members of the working party believe these are often not followed. Another forthcoming endoscopy study by the British Society for Gastroenterology is expected to reinforce concern.

Rory McCloy, a member of the working party commissioned by the United Kingdom Academy of Medical Royal Colleges, said: "There are undoubtedly people dying because of the inappropriate use of sedation."

The figure nationally across all procedures was probably between one in 3,000 and one in 5,000, far higher than the one in nearly 200,000 associated with being given anaesthetics. "Doctors could go many years and never see a death, so they don't think there is a problem. It is like seatbelts: everyone drove round without them, thinking nothing would happen to them; the only way to change people's habits was to make it illegal not to wear seatbelts."

Dentists were now given good grounding in administering sedation but Mr McCloy, a consultant at Manchester royal infirmary, revealed that courses offered by the Royal College of Surgeons in the mid-1990s had to be can celled because so few volunteered. "There should have been thousands, from junior doctors up to consultants."

Many doctors did not know the side-effects of drugs or how long they remained in the body. Manufacturers gave guidelines, but doctors were multiplying doses so as to almost put patients to sleep. "If you put them to sleep, you have given them an anaesthetic. And if you are not an anaesthetist, you are in trouble."

News of the concern emerged yesterday as the husband of a patient who died in 1998 while undergoing a procedure involving an endoscope and sedatives began legal proceedings. Peter Wiles, a postal worker from Blackpool, Lancashire, who has children aged 15 and 13, alleges negligence by the Blackpool Victoria hospital in treating his wife, Deborah, 32.

Mr Wiles's solicitor, Diane Rostron, hoped that the case, launched at Preston county court, would focus attention on such procedures and lead to a public inquiry. An inquest into Wiles's death in 1998 returned a verdict of death by misadventure.

A spokeswoman for the hospital trust said it was investigating the claim and is cooperating with the family's solicitors."

webTitle: When Hobson's choice is no choice at all

fields.headline: When Hobson's choice is no choice at all
fields.standfirst: 'Incentive' scheme to house key workers has opposite effect on London teacher
fields.trailText: Vomit spread out of the lifts and the stairwell stank of urine. The entrance to the towerblock was vandalised and open. Windows were broken and covered with chickenwire.
fields.body:
Vomit spread out of the lifts and the stairwell stank of urine. The entrance to the towerblock was vandalised and open. Windows were broken and covered with chickenwire.

Five flights up, along a corridor, the one-bedroom flat was not too bad, although it had cracks in the walls and badly needed a paint. Hobsons Place is not the worst towerblock in east London and it may not even be the worst in Tower Hamlets.

To David Shackson, 31, a special educational needs and history teacher at Morpeth comprehensive in nearby Bethnal Green, it was a strange way of offering an incentive to stay working in the borough.

Hobsons Place was offered him through the council's key workers' scheme - low-cost housing for public sector workers. He saw a notice in December and thought it might reduce his £110-a-week rent, out of his £25,000-a-year salary.

Priority

With a reference from his headteacher, he was soon on a waiting list and awarded "300 priority points"; to this day he has no idea what that means. In February, he was told a property was available in Hobsons Place. A woman from Tower Hamlets Community Housing, the association which owns the block, showed him round. The flat was £56 a week until it was refurbished, when it would be £80; the council is promising a £4m refit of the block starting next month. He had to take the property straight away, regardless of his month's notice, or be struck off the list. Hobsons Place became Hobson's choice. But he turned it down.

"I have worked in Tower Hamlets for six years and I have visited many council properties. Today I was taken to one of the worst I have seen," Mr Shackson said in a letter to the council's lettings coordinator. "Had I been starting my first teaching position, the sort of person for which I would hope your scheme was targeted, I would not only have refused the flat but would also have reconsidered working in Tower Hamlets."

He added: "I applied to the scheme in good faith in the belief that it was there to provide affordable housing to teachers in the area in which they work ...My experience has proven that the scheme was not genuine in this purpose."

He says he is not fussy. Across the way is Ramar House, another towerblock, where he would have been happy to go, because there is a porter and much better security.

When the Guardian made inquiries, Tower Hamlets replied speedily and frankly. The scheme started in December, with 50 council and housing association homes. The council had 104 calls, 42 applications, and made 13 offers; eight were accepted and five refused. The scheme is open to teachers but is to take in health workers, police and the fire brigade. The council acknowledges that the scheme enables these workers to jump the list. A teacher couple from New Zealand has accepted the flat offered to Mr Shackson.

"There is a shortage in the borough, 15,500 households on the list," said a council spokesman. "In terms of people it could be five times that. We get 2,000 lets per year - there is enormous pressure. We offer what we offer anyone else on ourlist. There is pressure to turn round property quickly and also pressure to get applicants to accept or not accept the offer."

Rob Lantsbury, for the housing association, said: "Unfortunately a lot of housing in Tower Hamlets is in similar condition ...It's fair to say it's going to look a lot different in six months' time."

This week the education secretary, David Blunkett, announced £35m for next year to schools in 58 authorities with recruitment problems. Tower Hamlets is getting £696,000. But this can be spread widely - housing subsidies, support for childcare, travel costs, recruitment campaigns, or, most likely, extra pay.

Ministers say schools can best decide how the money is spent. "They can use it if they want for housing," an education department spokesman said. "They can innovate where there are problems. We are just trying to stimulate ideas."

Some gaps are being filled piecemeal. In a report this week, the National Housing Federation highlighted Northwick Park in Harrow, north-west London, where 668 units have been built for health workers, mostly flats but 40 two- and three-bed homes. In Hoxton Square in Hackney, 48 flats are being provided as affordable homes for key workers.

Sceptical

The government is spending £250m on new and improved housing for key workers over three years. Its aim is to house 10,000 workers, though the federation is sceptical. Organisations are bidding to run schemes, but lenders have been very reluctant to commit and give extra leverage by offering low-cost mortgages.

The average start for teachers in inner London is going up to £20,000, and many experienced teachers will be just short of £30,000 with London weighting. But according to the federation, rents average £200 a week for a one-bedroom flat and an average London house costs £150,000. Meanwhile the National Institute of Social and Economic Research estimates that 60,000 workers in key services will leave London over the next 10 years. A report by the University of North London identified many teachers leaving London after five years to buy homes. About 40% expect to have to leave.

"If the government is serious, they have got to build up new housing," says Mr Shackson. "The intentions are right, but it's really appalling to be keeping council tenants on the waiting lists to make available places for key workers." In the meantime, he is staying where he is.

"Its not going to force me to leave the job. I'm getting by. I probably will apply for promotion - the extra money will cover things. I've got that option, but for anyone just beginning the salary rate is atrocious. I don't know how they survive."

webTitle: Branson fails in claim for £18m lottery damages

fields.headline: Branson fails in claim for £18m lottery damages
fields.trailText: The prospect of a fresh court battle over the competition for the next national lottery licence emerged last night after Sir Richard Branson's claim for compensation was rejected by the regulator.
fields.body:
The prospect of a fresh court battle over the competition for the next national lottery licence emerged last night after Sir Richard Branson's claim for compensation was rejected by the regulator.

The national lottery commission, which presided over last year's protracted bid process, said yesterday that it saw no grounds for making any payment to Sir Richard's People's Lottery.

The Virgin tycoon was bitterly disappointed after the seven-year contract to run the lottery was awarded to Camelot and was seeking £18.5m in compensation to cover the costs of his failed bid.

Simon Burridge, who had been chief executive of the People's Lottery, said he was "amazed" by the reaction of the commission. "We thought they would have more sense but then we have overestimated them before," he said.

"Going to court remains very much an option. They have been saying this was a fair and open process. Well it wasn't fair but by God it will be open if we go to court. We have some pretty interesting evidence. They are gluttons for punishment."

Sir Richard's decision to claim compensation was sparked by a decision from the commission last August which named the People's Lottery as preferred bidder. At that point, the commission said the licence would be awarded to Sir Richard if his bid met certain conditions. The claim for com pensation relates to costs after that date.

Camelot muscled its way back into the competition through the high court and was eventually awarded the licence in December.

A statement from the commission said: "The commission does not accept that it has any obligation to compensate the People's Lottery. There is simply no legal basis for the claim." The People's Lottery, it added, had always been aware that it would have to bear the costs of its bid if it were unsuccessful.

It also suggested that the People's Lottery had tacitly accepted the judgment of the commission by deciding not to challenge the decision in court. The commission informed the People's Lottery in a letter from its lawyers on Thursday.

"For them to say we accepted the decision is palpable nonsense," Mr Burridge said. "They fudged the decision - one which they may think they made on a rational basis but who knows what they were thinking?"

Mr Burridge said he would be discussing the next step forward with Sir Richard and the People's Lottery lawyers in the next few days.

Sir Richard had been frustrated by the commission's reasons for awarding the next licence to Camelot which he said demonstrated it was so averse to risk that he had never stood a chance. Camelot, he said, had been effectively handed the licence in perpetuity.

Repeated delays in making a decision, and the fiasco in August, led to one of culture secretary Chris Smith's more difficult periods in office. He was criticised by an all-party committee of MPs last month for his role in appointing the commission.

The Virgin tycoon was bitterly disappointed after the seven-year contract to run the lottery was awarded to Camelot and was seeking £18.5m in compensation to cover the costs of his failed bid. webTitle: Passion? Idealism? Sorry, this is theatre

fields.headline: Passion? Idealism? Sorry, this is theatre
fields.standfirst: Olivier wanted drama 'to bring light to the world'. Today, making it to Broadway is far more important.  Michael Billington  reports
fields.trailText: Olivier wanted drama 'to bring light to the world'. Today, making it to Broadway is far more important. Michael Billington reports.
fields.body:
'Have you no morals, man?" says Colonel Pickering to Alfred Doolittle in Shaw's Pygmalion. "Can't afford them, governor," is his succinct reply. Substitute "ideals" for "morals" and you have the dilemma facing many directors of artistic institutions struggling to survive in a long-under-funded culture.

Looking back to the theatre of the 1960s, I am struck by how many people brought a quasi-religious zeal to their calling. Olivier, on assuming the directorship of the National Theatre, called it a "pearl of a job" and vowed total abstinence for a year in order to meet its demands. George Devine at the Royal Court famously said one chose one's theatre as one chose one's church and, in Olivier's words, "liked to train his disciples' minds and send them out to bring light to the world". Hard to imagine anyone using that kind of messianic language today.

In fairness, passion itself is not dead. You can talk to a number of directors - Jude Kelly, say, in Leeds, Ian Rickson at the Royal Court, or Philip Hedley at Stratford East - and the light of missionary zeal comes into their eyes. But too often our big institutions, the National and the RSC, adopt the market-speak of the 1980s and talk of "product" and "strategies" rather than the burning importance of the work itself. Even the current brouhaha over Trevor Nunn's alleged earnings from My Fair Lady has been swathed in legalistic verbiage. And when I met Sir Christopher Hogg, chairman of the National Theatre board this week, he both conceded the role of the National had changed since the 1960s and defended Nunn's financial deal by saying, "One should be so lucky to have a public-private partnership in which you enlist well below market-cost the services of someone of the class of Trevor."

The words "public-private" are significant: this is the precise phrase that we now apply to air traffic control or the London underground. It is as if the language of politics and the market has invaded the theatre. It also raises a fundamental question: is the National, conceived as a world library of drama and a radical alternative to the commercial theatre, gradually becoming a classier version of the West End? Has it lost sight of its original visionary idealism?

Without wishing to pick over old bones, I would simply point to two alarming precedents. The last three shows in the Lyttelton - Noises Off, Life x 3 and My Fair Lady - have all, in effect, been co-productions virtually certain of a commercial transfer; there is all the difference in the world between productions such as Copenhagen or Blue/ Orange that transfer because of their unforeseen success and productions that are conceived from the outset as exploitable hits.

The other question concerns Nunn's own ambivalent role as both the National's artistic boss and director of some of its most temptingly commercial prospects (as well, of course, as a number of less profitable shows). In a sense, his very talent leaves him vulnerable, however unfairly, to the accusation of using the National as a commercial launchpad. His roster of productions for the next 16 months, for instance, is formidable: having overseen the Drury Lane transfer of My Fair Lady, he'll direct The Relapse, South Pacific, Oklahoma on Broadway, a Tom Stoppard trilogy and Glenn Close in A Streetcar Named Desire. All but The Relapse are seen inside the National as potentially huge earners for both the institution and the director.

Joan Bakewell, a member of the National Theatre board, regards as "preposterous" the idea that Nunn's choice of work is dictated by purely commercial considerations; she points also to his enthusiasm for bringing work in from the regions and to the National's multifarious access programmes. Hogg describes the arrival of My Fair Lady and South Pacific in one year as "a matter of chance more than anything" and points to the fact that the assumed profits will make other things possible. All the same, the close juxtaposition of two Broadway blockbusters strikes me as a public relations disaster: they may bring in the customers but they will increase the perception that the National is turning into a musical-dominated, quasi- commercial organisation.

Hogg's answer to all this is that the National has not lost sight of its basic principles but that it has to change with the times. "The reality," he says, "is that our grant will be 36% of our total costs in the current year, whereas in the past it has been well over 60% - it has come down steadily as the grant has been held in real terms or diminished. What has also changed is the whole political and cultural environment in which we operate. We watch that all the time and try to change the institution accordingly."

In what way? "If necessary we go into continuous runs in order to balance the books, which is our sacred, overriding rule. The balance of the repertory also constantly changes. The advent of the musical is easily the most marked difference between now and the 1960s, while there are probably fewer European classics. But our aim is to produce theatre of the highest quality, to mix mainstream classics, new plays and musicals and to be as accessible to as wide a range of people as possible."

A 2,500-seat theatre complex has to exist in the real world, and I would not question all of the Nunn-Hogg priorities. But it makes me wonder if an alternative vision of the National is not possible: one closer to the original Olivier ideal. Why, for instance, is it assumed that musicals are the only way of attracting a popular audience? Isn't the need to embrace world drama just as "sacred" a duty as that of balancing the books? And is a Broadway transfer the ultimate theatrical goal?

What we need is a new broom. And, while everyone is tight-lipped about Nunn's successor, my understanding is that, when his current contract expires in September 2002, he will stay on for an indeterminate period to pave the way for the new appointee. Nicholas Hytner, Howard Davies, Jude Kelly and John Caird are all in the frame - given that Sam Mendes and Stephen Daldry are busy pursuing their film careers - and the odds on Kelly are shortening daily. Whoever gets the job, however, I hope they banish marketplace rhetoric and remember that even the biggest artistic institutions survive only if personal ambition is balanced by a selfless idealism.

fields.headline: £30m cash boost for psychiatric wards
fields.trailText: Dilapidated psychiatric wards are to be modernised in a £30m refurbishment programme that the government has called the "biggest ever boost" to in-patient mental health care.
fields.body:
Dilapidated psychiatric wards are to be modernised in a £30m refurbishment programme that the government has called the "biggest ever boost" to in-patient mental health care.

The improvements over the next two years are designed to end the indignity of mixed sex wards and increase measures to stop patients committing suicide.

Many wards are in a poor state of repair and cannot meet even basic requirements for the safety, privacy and dignity of patients. A survey of patients by mental health charity Mind last November found that many in-patient units were depressing, bleak, unsafe and not therapeutic.

This year, £5m will be allocated directly to mental health trusts for revamping facilities. The money will come from extra NHS finance announced in the Budget. A further £25m will be announced next year.

Health minister John Hutton said that priority was being given to improving standards.

"The £30m investment will ensure that patients are treated in more therapeutic and modern settings and demonstrates this government's commitment to in-patient mental health care," he said.

"Improving the wards will also help improve the public image and perception of mental health services - and that will help break down the stigma that currently exists."

Money will be targeted on the most run-down wards, including:
 £500,000 for Portsmouth healthcare trust to change sleeping arrangements and improve lighting;
 £107,000 for St Helen's and Knowsley trust to replace furniture and improve safety and security;
 £175,000 for Haringey's mental health trust for redecorating and to create single bedrooms and separate men's and women's toilet and washing facilities.

"It's tremendous news," said Matt Muijen, director of the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health. "Any money spent in this area is very welcome. I can't think of any other initiative targeting acute services."

However, he said that: "The issue is not just about refurbishment - one has to be more radical.

"Most hospitals are not fit for the care they need to supply, so it's about rethinking the role, it's about 24-hour care for people with severe and enduring mental illness and whether that's in wards or hospitals is another question."

The refurbishment comes as part of broader package to improve in-patient care which includes:
 A project group, reporting to government's mental health task force, to look at how to achieve high-quality in-patient care;
 Guidance on dealing with substance misuse in mental health settings;
 In-patient care to get priority in the mental health research programme.

Professor Louis Appleby, the government's national director for mental health, said: "The improvement of the wards will not only aid general therapy but also address issues regarding mixed sex facilities and suicide prevention measures."

The following trusts will get money in 2001-02:
Portsmouth healthcare NHS trust
West Berkshire priority care NHS trust
Avon and Wiltshire partnership mental health trust
East London and city mental health trust
Haringey mental health trust
County Durham and Darlington priority services NHS trust
Middlesbrough, Teesside and North-East Yorkshire trust
Worcester community NHS trust
Coventry healthcare trust
Shropshire community NHS trust
North Birmingham mental health NHS trust
South Birmingham mental health NHS trust
Hertfordshire partnership NHS trust
Rotherham priority health services NHS trust
Doncaster and South Humber healthcare trust
North Sefton and West Lancashire community NHS trust
Tameside and Glossop community and priority services NHS trust
St Helens and Knowsley hospital NHS trust

webTitle: Who do Eurosceptics think they are kidding?

fields.headline: April fool? Who do Eurosceptics think they are kidding?
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Hardly surprising that little attention is given to the euro in the week the election is postponed, foot and mouth rages on, the United States and China lock horns and the nation is consumed with anticipation over who killed Phil Mitchell. Very surprising that in such a week, the Sun gives so much space to coverage of Germany.
fields.body:
Hardly surprising that little attention is given to the euro in the week the election is postponed, foot and mouth rages on, the United States and China lock horns and the nation is consumed with anticipation over who killed Phil Mitchell. Very surprising that in such a week, the Sun gives so much space to coverage of Germany.

But the Sun, crowing over its election postponement "exclusive", was in no mood to thank the government for thinking of it first when it decided to release the news. You would have thought gratitude and common decency would have persuaded it to go easy on its euro crusade, if only for a week.

Other Eurosceptic newspapers found it easy enough to put to one side their "save the pound" obsession. But the Sun could not miss a heaven-sent chance to demonstrate that its passion over the euro could not be neutered by a government leak.

So when 75% of Germans (as polled by the Allensbach Institute for Public Opinion) said they wanted to keep the mark rather than go over to the euro at the end of the year, the Sun devoted a news story, a leader, and a commentary article to the subject. The leader asked Sun readers how they would feel if their pensions, mortgages and savings were all to be switched into euros. It was "quite disgraceful" that the Germans had not been able to vote on this, but the British had cause to celebrate, because they would get a chance to vote on the euro.

The Sun's political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, supported the leader line, reporting "an explosion of German anger towards the sickly euro, months before it replaces the deutschmark for ever". Top economists, he said, were fighting a hopeless last battle in Germany's constitutional court to abort the switchover. "As the clock ticks, German politicians are looking enviously at Britain's decision to keep the pound until voters agree in a referendum to join."

The Times took up the same theme, if in a less strident way. Its reporter, Roger Boyes, visited an event designed to enthuse Germans about the euro. He found two men dressed as mice distributing chocolate euros to children, and generating very little interest indeed. Real euro coins were laid out before the indifferent public. "To touch the euro is to understand it," said the head of the Bundesbank, Ernst Weltecke. But nobody wanted to.

Perhaps the most significant story for the euro in Britain appeared in the Telegraph: "Goldman Sachs, the American investment bank, has told its clients that it does not think Tony Blair could win a referendum on the euro, and the chance of Britain joining is less than 50%."

Goldman Sachs had circulated a research note to its major clients which included this negative message for the euro-enthusiasts: "Given all the hurdles on the way - ensuring economic convergence, winning a referendum, negotiating an acceptable entry rate - we judge the odds in favour of the UK joining EMU in the lifetime of the next parliament are still less than 50%."

The Sunday Telegraph, one of the more Eurosceptic papers, ran two characteristic stories, one suggesting that Europe was planning to ruin the fun for chalet girls, the other suggesting that the European commission was bringing in new legislation "recognising individuals' rights over their own voices and distinctive mannerisms". This would prevent Rory Bremner from impersonating Tony Blair or William Hague. Since it was April 1, clearly one of these was a joke. Since it was the Sunday Telegraph it was not immediately obvious which this was.

Actually it was the story suggesting that Rory Bremner's political satire would be outlawed. Which left the chalet girls as the "serious" story: The story said the French authorities intended to implement the code de travail, the "thick red book of 1,862 pages which contains the embodiment of French employment law".

Although "not a single complaint" had been received, one Christian Desfontaine felt obliged to look after the welfare of the chalet girls anyway, and that meant paying them a proper wage. But, according to the Sunday Telegraph, this would simply result in ruining their fun by stopping their employment. This is the sort of thing Europeans do, in the eyes of the Eurosceptics.

&#149 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: A nation of property addicts needing a fix

fields.headline: A nation of property addicts needing a fix
fields.standfirst: From Islington to the Isle of Skye, flats or mansions, new or refurbished, we are in love with owning a house - as seven out of 10 of us do. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: From Islington to the Isle of Skye, flats or mansions, new or refurbished, we are in love with owning a house - as seven out of 10 of us do. Elizabeth Langton reports.
fields.body:
Paddy and Mandy Godfrey live in the heartlands of the chattering classes, in desirable Gibson Square, Islington. Like many people they stand to make a huge profit if they sell their house.

They moved into the house, purchased in 1964 for £6,000, at a time when Islington was considered downmarket. But times have changed, their home is now worth almost a million and Islington has become one of the most desirable places to live in the capital.

The Godfrey's are among the homeowners featured in a new Channel 4 series called Home Stories, which explores the rise of the home owning classes and its impact on the landscape. In a series of four programmes, winners and losers in the property game talk about their experiences. We hear from country dwellers and urbanites and those who like loft living.

Britain's love affair with property has become stronger over the past 20 years: nearly 70% of us now own our own homes. In areas where demand for housing is high we're prepared to pay many thousands for what are often quite modest abodes.

Clare Paterson, the series' producer, says we're now a nation of property addicts and the point of the series is to look at how that has come about and how fast. "There was a time, not that long ago, when a trip to the building society to ask for a mortgage meant putting on a smart dress - you thought they were really doing you a favour if they considered it."

Within a generation something that was considered risky and a very big deal is now taken for granted by the majority of the population, she says. And our hunger shows no signs of abating. The stock market may be jittery, but house prices are rising again, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors report published in February. The housing market is set to rise by 6% in the coming year, said the surveyors.

And this week the Nationwide also said that prices were picking up, increasing by 1.4% in March.

The debate about what kind of houses we should build and renovate, which programmes like Home Stories feed into, continues apace. While the transformation of industrial warehouses, and even local authority tower blocks, into chic apartments has continued largely unquestioned, there are plenty of flash points.

Outside the major cities, architects' berate volume house developers for a lack of imagination when it comes to building modern homes. They complain that new developments are little more than an amalgam of Victorian and Georgian styles with a dash of double-glazing.

In their defence, builders argue that they only provide what locals and planners want. As Ann Lever, associate sales and marketing director in the north west region of Countryside Properties, says: "They set out to build homes that look, well-established, not new."

Countryside is recreating a formal Georgian square on an 85-acre brown-field site to the north of Warrington, Cheshire, in the former grounds of Winwick Hospital. The development, at Nostell Place, will consist of a tree-lined boulevard, comprising grand two and three-storey Regency-style houses. The aim is to "create a typical Cheshire village that looks as if it has evolved over time".

Ms Lever says local consultations show people want buildings in keeping with their surroundings. "Residents want traditional-looking homes," she says. "We try to achieve it - whether it is the colour of the render or some other feature. The point is to ensure the properties don't stick out. Trees are also important to people and we plant hundreds and thousands of them.

"Time and again, people say they love elegant town houses and Victorian and Georgian elevations."

Town houses also suit modern living, Ms Lever believes. Three floors means there's plenty of room for the family to spread out, room for someone to work quietly at home, or room for an elderly relative to live independently.

To create the right look, the company spends a fair amount on the exterior elevations, says Ms Lever. Nostalgia may be the order of the day for the exterior. But inside their home, today's buyers want wooden floors, American fridges and range cookers with two ovens and six burners. Houses at Nostell Park, range from £315,000 to £369,950.

In the countryside, locals are very sensitive about the impact of new homes upon the environment. Last month, the Guinness Trust received the Civic Trust rural housing award for a scheme that transformed a development of glorified beach huts into family housing.

Jaywick in Essex is a collection of holiday chalets, built between the wars, which over time became permanent homes for their residents. The bungalows were not built to last and over time have become increasingly dilapidated.

The Guinness Trust has built 40 new homes on the site, called Lotus Way, which reflect the beach-hut feel of the area. The design of the buildings won a RIBA award for the architects Pollard, Thomas and Edward. The new homes are the first stage of a larger regeneration project involving the trust and other local agencies.

Other homes there need attention and the infrastructure is badly in need of updating. But the new homes have been welcomed as proof that regeneration can produce affordable housing that meets local needs and still be architecturally interesting.

The UK's changing demographic is also having an impact on housing. Elderly people are living longer than ever before. By 2050 it is predicted that couples will live about 40 years after their children have left home. With this in mind developers are building homes for a new generation of empty-nesters, says Sunley Homes.

The company's development, Cherry Orchard Mews, off church road in Littlebourne, Kent, consists of eight two and three-bedroom cottages set around a rose garden and a water feature. The company claims the buildings provide the equivalent floorspace to that offered by larger homes and are ideal for downsizers who do not want to compromise on living space. The cottages start at £170,000.

In London, where pressure on housing is immense, builders await the mayor Ken Livingstone's housing guidance, due shortly. It is expected to include increased targets for affordable housing. Whatever the homes of the future look like, there is a general consensus that more of them need to be affordable.

Homeowners want and expect to make money on their properties, says Clare Paterson. And for now, thoughts of risky ventures, or memories of the property crash of the late eighties, have been firmly consigned to the backs of our minds.

 Channel 4's Home Stories 8pm, April 12.

fields.headline: 'Detailed' help short on detail
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: This week the government has been bombarding the public with an advertising campaign aimed at rescuing rural tourism from the effects of the foot and mouth epidemic.
fields.body:
This week the government has been bombarding the public with an advertising campaign aimed at rescuing rural tourism from the effects of the foot and mouth epidemic.

It claims that 80% of Britain's attractions are open and ready to receive visitors. The multimillion pound campaign in newspapers and on radio promises "detailed information" on which attractions are available for visitors to enjoy, giving opening times and details of any restrictions.

A test of the service yesterday showed that it is un able to offer anything other than telephone numbers or website addresses of tourist bodies or the attractions themselves.

The tourist boards were unable to answer any of the Guardian's 10 questions on opening times or locations of popular attractions. The website has a list of 29 top attractions with details of restrictions due to the epidemic: only 11 are rural, while 14 are in London.

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions said the helpline and website were only a starting point and not meant to answer detailed inquiries.

webTitle: Croats attack Nato troops seizing bank

fields.headline: Croats attack Nato troops seizing bank
fields.trailText: Bosnian Croats stoned Nato peacekeepers and attacked staff of international organisations yesterday after police and troops seized a major bank used by Bosnian Croat hardliners bent on setting up their own mini-state.
fields.body:
Bosnian Croats stoned Nato peacekeepers and attacked staff of international organisations yesterday after police and troops seized a major bank used by Bosnian Croat hardliners bent on setting up their own mini-state.

Twenty-one peacekeepers were slightly injured in the melee in the southwestern city of Mostar, Nato spokesman Lieutenant Lars Anderson said. They were from the United States, Italy, France, Spain and Morocco, he said.

Four Bosnian civilians were injured, Mostar radio said. In Rome, officials said 11 of the injured peacekeepers were Italian paramilitary police.

The trouble started when armed UN and Bosnian police backed by Nato troops seized the Mostar headquarters of the bank, Hercegovacka Banka, and 10 branches throughout Bosnia-Herzegovina.

The hardline Croatian Democratic Union is believed to use the bank to promote its campaign to establish a separate Croat-run mini-state, said Ralph Johnson, deputy to the chief international administrator, Wolfgang Petritsch.

"I want to make clear that the international community's campaign to make sure that those who fund illegal structures are dealt with will continue," Mr Johnson said.

The raid triggered rioting in Mostar, 45 miles southwest of Sarajevo and a stronghold of the Croatian Democratic Union, known as HDZ.

During the takeover, mobs swarmed the bank's headquarters, beat police and international officials, destroyed records and looted the building, Mr Johnson said. Crowds attacked Nato vehicles, overturning several and setting one on fire. Gunshots rang out in the streets. Nato closed the main bridge across the Neretva River dividing the city into Muslim and Croat zones and called in reinforcements from around the country.

The HDZ called the raid "armed robbery", and the president of the bank's board of directors, Ante Ljubic, refused to accept the authority of the new manager, Tobi Robinson.

"We also request that Robinson and her armed escort immediately leave the units of Hercegovacka Banka and allow the legal administration to enter the bank," Mr Ljubic said.

In the Croatian capital, Zagreb, the Bosnian foreign minister, Zlatko Lagumdzija, backed the raid, saying the bank's management had long been "dubious".

The takeover could prevent "a dream of all extremists from coming true: that the national banks would be in one nation's hands and the national money in the pockets of national thugs," he said.

Tensions have been rising in Croat areas after the HDZ declared last month that it would break off its alliance with the country's Muslims and set up a Croat government. Under the 1995 Dayton peace agreement that ended the Bosnian war, the country was divided into a Serb-run mini-state and a Muslim-Croat federation.

After the war, the HDZ maintained parallel government institutions in southwestern Bosnia over the objections of international administrators. However, many Croats felt they had been shortchanged in the division of power.

Mr Petritsch fired the Croat president, Ante Jelavic, and other Croat officials last month over the secessionist threat. International officials suspected the HDZ of planning to finance its mini-state with proceeds from the Hercegovacka Banka.

webTitle: 2m animals in the queue for death

fields.headline: 2m animals in the queue for death
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
As Tony Blair and his deputy, John Prescott, toured
the countryside yesterday, reassuring the public that
Britain was getting back to normal, the astonishing
scale emerged of the backlog of animals still to be
slaughtered and disposed of because of the foot and
mouth epidemic.
fields.body:
As Tony Blair and his deputy, John Prescott, toured the countryside yesterday, reassuring the public that Britain was getting back to normal, the astonishing scale emerged of the backlog of animals still to be slaughtered and disposed of because of the foot and mouth epidemic.

The number has risen steeply to 2m, half a million more than five days ago, the last time official figures were available. It will take at least another six weeks to clear the backlog as the government gets further and further behind in coping with the crisis.

The majority of animals waiting to be killed, around 1.6m, are urgent welfare cases - stranded on farms and on hills where their condition is deteriorating because they cannot be moved to shelter for lambing or new grass.

But worse, from the point of view of controlling the epidemic, are the 400,000 animals that have been in close contact with the disease and which are supposed to be killed within 48 hours as a precaution. Many are still alive for up to a weeksimply because there is nowhere to dispose of their carcasses.

There are also 366,000 unburied and decomposing carcasses littering the countryside in areas which would normally be welcoming tourists at this time of year. These "carcasses yet to be disposed of" figures were removed last weekend from the Ministry of Agriculture's website to hide the extent of the problem.

All infected animals are supposed to be killed within 24 hours and those on neighbouring farms, normally involving five times as many animals, within 48 hours - but this is not happening.

The inability to kill all the livestock that may be affected risks a resurgence of the disease, Mr Blair has been told by Professor David King, the government's chief scientist.

The emphasis has been on killing infected animals to stop the disease spreading. Despite the failure to carry out the firebreak cull on neighbouring farms this policy appears to work. Only 33 new cases were identified on Thursday and just 26 by yesterday afternoon, bringing the total to 1,084.

Mr Blair spent the day in the York area to prove that tourism was still thriving. Mr Prescott was on the Norfolk Broads before visiting Shropshire and Cheshire.

Longleat safari park in Wiltshire will reopen today after a two-week postponement, and English Heritage announced that Stonehenge would reopen next week, though visitors must stick to the paths.

But elsewhere there were signs that the disease is still spreading into the heart of Britain's national parks and centres of tourism in the Lake District and Peak District of Derbyshire. In the Lake District several hundred sheep were found infected west of Penrith near Skiddaw mountain.

Vets were last night also investigating the source of an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the Scottish borders, 30 miles from the nearest previously confirmed outbreak.

 Representatives from the Chinese civil rights action group are to meet the agriculture minister Nick Brown today to discuss their community's annoyance over the allegation that a Chinese restaurant could be responsible for bringing foot and mouth to Britain. A mass demonstration is also planned by Britain's Chinese community in London tomorrow.

webTitle: Bush sees progress in Beijing talks

fields.headline: Bush sees progress in Beijing talks
fields.standfirst:
Face-to-face diplomacy keeps the temperature down but the two sides' view of events remains very different

Special report: China
fields.trailText: US officials held a second meeting with the 24 US aircrew detained by China on Hainan island yesterday as the pace of diplomatic activity between Washington and Beijing picked up.
fields.byline: John Gittings in Shanghai and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
US officials held a second meeting with the 24 US aircrew detained by China on Hainan island yesterday as the pace of diplomatic activity between Washington and Beijing picked up.

President George Bush told Americans that the crew were "doing just fine", and added: "We think we're making progress."

But Beijing reported that there had been another clash between US and Chinese planes off its coast only two days ago, and there were reports in Washington of strains between hawks and doves in the administration as the crisis dragged on.

"The crew is in great spirits. They are all together and are looking forward to being released and returning home," Brigadier Neal Sealock said after spending an hour with the 24 detained servicemen .

Brig Sealock, the US military attache in Beijing, reported by telephone to Mr Bush in Washington shortly after the meeting ended.

Unlike Tuesday's meeting between US diplomats and the crew, there were no Chinese officials present yesterday. A further meeting is expected today.

The secretary of state, Colin Powell, said the crew were being "cared for well" and that arrangements were being made to see them "on a regular basis until this matter is resolved."

He gave an upbeat account of progress in the round-the-clock meetings in the two capitals. They were discussing "rather precise ideas", he said.

"There has been movement in the discussions and negotiations. And we are encouraged at this point, and those discussions continue."

Publicly, the administration remained united behind the diplomatic path followed this week. But the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, known as a China hawk, was reported in the conservative Washing ton Times to have criticised the White House's "soft tone towards Beijing".

"Rumsfeld is worn out by the diplomats, all the statements of 'regret' and wants to stop the patty-cakes," the paper reported, quoting a defence source. "He and Powell are very much at odds over this."

President Jiang Zemin, who is touring Latin America, repeated his demand for a US apology, but in a more relaxed tone.

He said: "It is normal for people to ask forgiveness or say 'excuse me' when they collide in the street. But the American planes come to the border of our country and do not ask for forgiveness. Is this behaviour acceptable?"

US diplomats in Haikou, who had been buying fresh clothes and other supplies for the crew, were escorted to the guesthouse where they are being held in a motorcade of the black limousines with tinted windows used by all Chinese officials.

Earlier the US ambassador, Joseph Prueher, said in Beijing that the planned visit was "a good sign, and we are having good contacts."

Later he described the talks with Chinese officials as "fairly intense".

Meanwhile it was reported in China that 10 Chinese fighters had to "warn off five US spy planes" on Wednesday.

"Under the close watch of our aircraft," an unidentified source in Beijing said, "the US spy planes eventually scampered out of China's coastal areas."

The Hong Kong daily Wen Wei Po, which supports Beijing, claimed that 63 US surveillance aircraft had been detected "in Chinese coastal areas" since the beginning of the year, and said that the US had sent 950 such planes last year.

The English-language China Daily said that US reconnaissance of Hainan Island began in 1970, during the Vietnam War.

It said the US was refusing to apologise because it did not want to set a precedent.

webTitle: Pentagon paints picture of 'flashy' Chinese pilot

fields.headline: Pentagon paints picture of 'flashy' Chinese pilot
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: In Chinese eyes, Wang Wei was a victim, a hero and a man who died doing his patriotic duty. His death therefore requires an unqualified apology.
fields.byline: John Gittings  in Shanghai and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
In Chinese eyes, Wang Wei was a victim, a hero and a man who died doing his patriotic duty. His death therefore requires an unqualified apology.

To Americans, on the other hand, Mr Wang was a flash risk-taker who died when he went too far. His death requires expressions of regret and condolence, but not an apology.

As diplomats continued to seek a solution to China's continuing detention of the US EP-3 spy plane and its crew of 24 yesterday, the two countries painted a very different picture of the Chinese pilot who lost his plane, and probably his life, in last Sunday's incident over the South China sea.

The surviving Chinese pilot, Zhao Yu, described on television seeing his colleague's fighter plunge into the sea after a mid-air collision. The interview was presented as proof that the American aircraft intentionally bumped into Mr Wang's F-8 jet.

Mr Zhao said that when he and Mr Wang intercepted the spy plane the US pilot changed course twice. According to Mr Zhao the two fighters kept parallel to it, maintaining the same speed.

"At seven minutes past nine," he continued, "the US plane suddenly made a big move towards us and smashed into Wang Wei's aircraft. I saw the US plane's nose and left wing hit Wang, and at the same time the outer propeller of the wing crushed his tailplane." Mr Zhao then warned his colleague that the tailplane had been destroyed, and urged him to maintain the plane's attitude. Within seconds the plane was out of control, and Mr Wang decided to bale out.

Mr Zhao described with evident emotion how the plane suddenly disappeared. He descended to 3,000 metres and saw the fighter hit the sea, and also saw the ejection seat and parachute coming down. Having marked the location he returned to base 10 minutes before the US plane made an emergency landing on Hainan.

The Chinese media also put out interviews with members of Mr Wang's family who emphasised his skill as a pilot. "I am proud of my son; there was nothing wrong with his flying and the US should apologise and be responsible for the loss," said his father.

Officially, the Pentagon and other sources have been careful not to publicly criticise Mr Wang's actions last Sunday or his general flying record. Unofficially, however, US sources paint a very different picture.

In recent months, they say, Mr Wang had flown so close to US aircraft in the daily cat and mouse along the Chinese coast that he had been clearly photographed in his cockpit. In one picture, Mr Wang was shown holding a sheet of paper with his e-mail address written on it.

The US had protested to China in December and January about the risky buzzing of its surveillance aircraft. In one previous encounter, Mr Wang flew within 10 feet of an American aircraft, officials said. He was a pilot who liked to slip his jet underneath US spy planes and then accelerate upwards just in front of them. US versions of what the Pentagon resolutely refers to as an accident strongly suggest that this is exactly what happened on April 1, with tragic results.

"Obviously he was just being flashy and wanted to show off his stuff," an official told the New York Times.

The Pentagon appears to believe that Mr Wang flew under the EP-3 and then pulled ahead of it, clipping the plane's radar nose dome. The impact of that collision may then have sprayed debris into the first and third engines of the EP-3. The spy plane is reported to have dropped 8,000 feet before its pilot was able to bring it under control.

webTitle: Factions fight as Japan's PM quits

fields.headline: Factions fight as Japan's PM quits
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The former Japanese prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was poised to complete a political comeback yesterday as he moved to pole position in the race to replace the incumbent, Yoshiro Mori.
fields.body:
The former Japanese prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto was poised to complete a political comeback yesterday as he moved to pole position in the race to replace the incumbent, Yoshiro Mori.

After weeks of backroom manoeuvring, Mr Hashimoto publicly indicated his willingness to run in an election for president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, a post that usually brings with it the job of prime minister of Japan.

"I am very honoured to be considered," Mr Hashimoto, 63, said. "But it will be up to the members of my faction to make a decision about whether I should be their candidate."

The starting flag for the campaign was raised yesterday by Mr Mori, who announced that he will stand down in the face of dismal opinion poll ratings and an economy on the verge of recession.

"I think it is necessary to tackle mounting issues under a new administration," Mr Mori told the cabinet. He refused to hold a press conference to explain his decision, yet another example of the dismal presentation skills that have made his one-year premiership one of the most unpopular in Japanese history.

The LDP will choose his successor on April 24 in an election that could be the last chance for the party, which has ruled for all but one of the past 46 years, to reinvent itself.

As leader of the LDP's biggest faction, Mr Hashimoto is favourite to take a post from which he was forced to resign in July 1998 after leading the party to a humiliating defeat in elections to the upper house.

Famed for his skill at the martial art of kendo, and for his slicked-back hairstyle, Mr Hashimoto has a strong public image and is reported to be popular among women voters.

But his platform remains unclear. During his term in office, he raised the consumption tax in a disastrous attempt to improve public finances that plunged the world's second biggest economy into recession.

Japan's public debt has since ballooned to record levels, but Mr Hashimoto is rumoured to have toned down his advocacy for fiscal reconstruction to win the support of other faction leaders.

The strongest challenge is likely to come from the former health minister, Junichiro Koizumi, a political maverick with a reputation as a reformer.

"If you are afraid to lose, people say you are a coward," Mr Koizumi told supporters yesterday. "I have to take the action that will not disappoint."

A confrontation between the two would be a re-run of the LDP leadership election in 1996, which Mr Hashimoto won by a landslide, but the picture is far less clear this time.

After a series of poll setbacks, the LDP is in crisis. Reformers have launched revolts against the leadership and young MPs have strongly criticised elderly faction heads.

webTitle: Tokyo arrest in hostess kidnap killing

fields.headline: Tokyo arrest in hostess kidnap killing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The fast-living Japanese businessman suspected of the kidnap and dismemberment of hostess Lucie Blackman was formally arrested yesterday.
fields.body:
The fast-living Japanese businessman suspected of the kidnap and dismemberment of hostess Lucie Blackman was formally arrested yesterday.

Police will ask prosecutors to file charges against Joji Obara, 48, seven weeks after finding the British woman's body in a seashore cave close to an apartment he owns, and nine months after she disappeared.

Detectives say Obara invited Blackman, 21, for lunch on July 1 last year at the apartment in Zushi, an hour's drive south of Tokyo, where she worked in bar. "He plied her with spiked drinks, then assaulted her after she lost consciousness," said Tadao Sugawara, chief of the capital's serious crimes division. "When she died of drug poisoning, he mutilated her body and abandoned it."

Obara has been in jail since last October, facing trial for drugging and raping five other women, including a Canadian and an Australian hostess.

Unusually for Japan, where most suspects confess, Obara has denied these charges, and he has refused to discuss Blackman's case.

Police acknowledge they are relying on circumstantial evidence; according to local reports, detectives have traced Blackman's last call to a phone owned by Obara.

During a search of his apartment, investigators reportedly found a strand of her hair, sedatives, a photo of the victim on the day she disappeared, and videos of him raping more than 50 foreign women.

Blackman's family were informed from Japan of the arrest. Tim Blackman, who brought his daughter's remains home for burial last week, commended the police, but said the family would not attend the trial. "Many people at Lucie's funeral spoke of the chapter being closed, and for us that is very much the case."

webTitle: 'Britain is open,' beaming Blair tells tourists

fields.headline: 'Britain is open,' beaming Blair tells tourists
fields.standfirst:
Prime minister takes to the streets of York in an attempt to revive rural holiday industry

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Prime minister takes to the streets of York in an attempt to revive rural holiday industry
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday sniffed a set of replica Viking toilets to launch his campaign to kickstart the rural tourism industry. The irony was that he chose to visit a city attraction not hit by foot and mouth.

In contrast to previous stony-faced visits to farmers, Mr Blair beamed ecstatically as he and his wife, Cherie, arrived at the Jorvik Viking Centre in York.

As they made their way through 100 children with napkins on their heads pretending to be Nordic warriors, the Blairs brandished an instant camera, taking their own snaps as if on holiday. They grabbed people indiscriminately, shaking their hands, particularly those who looked like tourists.

At one stage, Mr Blair spied a Japanese man with a camera round his neck, rushed over and gave him a hug. When Haroshi Yamamoto told Mr Blair he was actually a London-based journalist for JHK Japanese Broadcasting Corporation, the prime minister said, "Oh", and his arm went limp.

Regional tourist boards estimate they are losing £200m a week because of the foot and mouth crisis, a figure that could quadruple over Easter. Yorkshire tourism lost around £75m last month. British tourism will lose at least £5bn by September, according to the British Hospitality Association.

Mr Blair yesterday announced a £6m government-funded campaign to tell the world that British tourism is alive and well during the foot and mouth crisis. As well as full page ads in British news papers, Mr Blair used interviews with American, French and Japanese media to proclaim that the British countryside was generally open for business.

Outside the Jorvik Viking Centre, in a square where the only sign of country life was the hanging baskets of pansies outside Boots the chemist, Mr Blair said the best way to stimulate tourism was to attract visitors rather than government compensation.

"The main thing tourism needs is people, trade and business. The most important thing to get across to people is that Britain is open and there is no problem with people coming over. We have simply got to get across a proper sense of perspective."

Asked if the correct perspective was actually that tourists might spread the disease on rural footpaths, Mr Blair said: "Of course it is essential that we ensure proper restrictions so that people do not go on footpaths near livestock farms."

A spokeswoman for the Jorvik Viking Centre said she was "not at all" worried by foot and mouth as the centre was in a popular city centre location. The museum will reopen tomorrow after a five-month closure and £5m refurbishment. It expects 500,000 visitors this year with no shortfall due to foot and mouth.

Matthew Wilson, a York tourist guide who runs city walks such as "Public Conveniences Through the Ages" said city tourism had not been hit in the same way that small country businesses had.

"We have had the normal numbers of tourists on city walks. We have even had farmers on walks. When I ask them why they have come to the city for walks, they say they have nothing else to do."

Vance Wittie, 41, a tourist from Dallas, said he was enjoying a trip around England despite US media had calling Britain a "green and contagious land".

"We had this trip booked, we were never going to cancel it," he said. He planned to spend part of his holiday on a farm in Gloucester.

Cumbria county council yesterday announced it was to rethink "no entry" signs on some footpaths, to attract tourists back to the region. But the local National Farmers' Union leader Steve Heaton advised caution.

Mr and Mrs Blair later visited the Bronte's parsonage at Haworth, a popular tourist destination which is 5km from the nearest foot and mouth case, and has signs in Japanese warning tourists to follow foot and mouth precautions.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, went sailing on the Norfolk Broads, and toured Shropshire and Cheshire to set an example for tourists.

fields.bodyText: Tony Blair yesterday sniffed a set of replica Viking toilets to launch his campaign to kickstart the rural tourism industry. The irony was that he chose to visit a city attraction not hit by foot and mouth. In contrast to previous stony-faced visits to farmers, Mr Blair beamed ecstatically as he and his wife, Cherie, arrived at the Jorvik Viking Centre in York. As they made their way through 100 children with napkins on their heads pretending to be Nordic warriors, the Blairs brandished an instant camera, taking their own snaps as if on holiday. They grabbed people indiscriminately, shaking their hands, particularly those who looked like tourists. At one stage, Mr Blair spied a Japanese man with a camera round his neck, rushed over and gave him a hug. When Haroshi Yamamoto told Mr Blair he was actually a London-based journalist for JHK Japanese Broadcasting Corporation, the prime minister said, "Oh", and his arm went limp. Regional tourist boards estimate they are losing £200m a week because of the foot and mouth crisis, a figure that could quadruple over Easter. Yorkshire tourism lost around £75m last month. British tourism will lose at least £5bn by September, according to the British Hospitality Association. Mr Blair yesterday announced a £6m government-funded campaign to tell the world that British tourism is alive and well during the foot and mouth crisis. As well as full page ads in British news papers, Mr Blair used interviews with American, French and Japanese media to proclaim that the British countryside was generally open for business. Outside the Jorvik Viking Centre, in a square where the only sign of country life was the hanging baskets of pansies outside Boots the chemist, Mr Blair said the best way to stimulate tourism was to attract visitors rather than government compensation. "The main thing tourism needs is people, trade and business. The most important thing to get across to people is that Britain is open and there is no problem with people coming over. We have simply got to get across a proper sense of perspective." Asked if the correct perspective was actually that tourists might spread the disease on rural footpaths, Mr Blair said: "Of course it is essential that we ensure proper restrictions so that people do not go on footpaths near livestock farms." A spokeswoman for the Jorvik Viking Centre said she was "not at all" worried by foot and mouth as the centre was in a popular city centre location. The museum will reopen tomorrow after a five-month closure and £5m refurbishment. It expects 500,000 visitors this year with no shortfall due to foot and mouth. Matthew Wilson, a York tourist guide who runs city walks such as "Public Conveniences Through the Ages" said city tourism had not been hit in the same way that small country businesses had. "We have had the normal numbers of tourists on city walks. We have even had farmers on walks. When I ask them why they have come to the city for walks, they say they have nothing else to do." Vance Wittie, 41, a tourist from Dallas, said he was enjoying a trip around England despite US media had calling Britain a "green and contagious land". "We had this trip booked, we were never going to cancel it," he said. He planned to spend part of his holiday on a farm in Gloucester. Cumbria county council yesterday announced it was to rethink "no entry" signs on some footpaths, to attract tourists back to the region. But the local National Farmers' Union leader Steve Heaton advised caution. Mr and Mrs Blair later visited the Bronte's parsonage at Haworth, a popular tourist destination which is 5km from the nearest foot and mouth case, and has signs in Japanese warning tourists to follow foot and mouth precautions. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, went sailing on the Norfolk Broads, and toured Shropshire and Cheshire to set an example for tourists. fields.headline: Cheap drugs for poor countries
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The world's biggest drugs companies are to provide medicines for poor countries at bargain prices after bowing to mounting global pressure to reduce the cost of their patented treatments.
fields.body:
The world's biggest drugs companies are to provide medicines for poor countries at bargain prices after bowing to mounting global pressure to reduce the cost of their patented treatments.

Dogged by the adverse publicity caused by attempts to punish developing countries for seeking cheap alternative drugs, the pharmaceutical industry has struck a deal with the European Union that will allow millions more each year to be saved from death from preventable diseases.

The proposal - backed by Clare Short, the international development secretary - involves a sliding scale of prices, ranging from cost prices for the world's poorest nations to substantial discounts for the middle-income countries of Latin America and Asia.

Industry sources privately admitted that a Johannesburg court case brought by 39 of the big drug companies to block the South African government's imports of cheap Aids drugs had been a public relations disaster.

Under the EU plan, which will be discussed at a meeting in Norway tomorrow of World Health Organisation and World Trade Organisation experts from around the world, drugs companies would commit themselves to supplying key medicines at the lowest possible prices.

Treatable diseases such as tuberculosis, pneumonia and malaria kill more than 10m people each year in the developing world but the costs of the drugs to attack them are beyond the reach of most developing countries' health budgets.

Many of the biggest companies have slashed the prices of Aids drugs since the South African court case began, in an attempt to restore their reputation. The EU plan would replace one-off discounts for specific countries with a comprehensive pricing agreement which would apply to all the world's poorest countries.

The industry has seized on the discount scheme as a lifeline to protect it from campaigners' demands for patent rights on drugs to be weakened so that poor countries can make their own cheaper copies. Although world trade rules allow for patents to be overridden in national health emergencies, many poor countries are too afraid of the drug industry's lobbying power to take advantage of the provisions.

Oxfam, which is calling for clarification of World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules so that poor countries are able to produce and import generic copies of essential drugs, said the EU plan was a step forward but did not go far enough.

"We welcome the European Union's push to negotiate a comprehensive agreement for discounted drugs but they shouldn't play into the game plan of the big pharmaceutical companies who are trying to deflect pressure for a more radical reform of WTO patent rules," said Justin Forsyth, head of policy at Oxfam.

Oxfam said that the discount pricing plan should not be seen as a substitute for existing provisions in WTO rules.

Patent rules will come under scrutiny later this year in Geneva and developing countries are expected to push for more flexibility in the trade related intellectual property rights agreement.

webTitle: EU told to buy strategic capability

fields.headline: EU told to buy strategic capability
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: European Union member states aiming to strengthen their defence must match action with rhetoric and acquire the strategic capabilities, ministers were told yesterday.
fields.body:
European Union member states aiming to strengthen their defence must match action with rhetoric and acquire the strategic capabilities, ministers were told yesterday.

Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy and security chief, said that a conference in November would seek new commitments in defence to address shortcomings in assets needed to support future European military operations, such as better intelligence hardware and communication systems.

"We can have committees and procedures but if we don't have capabilities we have nothing," Mr Solana, a former secretary general of Nato, warned after talks with EU defence ministers.

In its ambitious bid to create its own security and defence identity, and acquire some punch to match its economic weight, the EU has all but finalised a complex structure of military and diplomatic institutions in Brussels.

Last November, despite concerns by British Eurosceptics, the 15 member states pledged thousands of troops, 400 combat aircraft and 100 ships for a rapid reaction force to operate in future crises that do not involve Nato.

The 60,000-strong force, capable of being deployed for up to a year, is scheduled to be ready for peacekeeping and humanitarian duties by 2003. But problems concerning coordination with Nato have delayed progress.

The conference scheduled for November will look at sensitive and expensive military hardware such as intelligence capabilities, sophisticated communications, and heavy transport aircraft, the lion's share of which is currently provided by the US.

"We need to see real new commitments to address the shortcomings in these areas," Mr Solana said, recalling that European public opinion broadly supports having a more effective EU foreign and security policy.

"Ministers need to defend the need for adequate resources and must be the advocates with their own governments and parliaments."

Alain Richard, the French defence minister, played down earlier calls for the rapid reaction force to have its own planning capability, independent of Nato, a position opposed by other governments worried about damaging transatlantic relations - and grist to the eurosceptic mill.

Diplomats also brushed over a row about the appointment of a general from Finland, a non-Nato neutral, to head the EU's military committee in Brussels. Its military staff is headed by a German general with a British deputy.

Italy, which wanted the job for one of its own generals, had protested about the way votes were cast. The Finn's appointment is to be confirmed by foreign ministers in Luxembourg on Monday.

Addressing the problems with Nato, the German defence minister, Rudolf Scharping, urged Turkey to stop blocking the EU force.

Turkey, a veteran member of Nato which feels shunned by the EU, wants a bigger say in the rapid reaction force's decision-making, despite being outside the union. The EU says this is unacceptable because it would in effect give the Turks a veto on future operations.

"We hope Turkey will reconsider its policy and will take a cooperative line," Mr Scharping said. "It is in the interests of Turkey to take the perspective of cooperation with the EU."

fields.headline: Court in the act
fields.standfirst:
Greenpeace ordered off oil rig

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: A court order was last night served on Greenpeace activists who have secured themselves to a North Sea oil rig in protest over global warming, ordering them to leave.
fields.body:
A court order was last night served on Greenpeace activists who have secured themselves to a North Sea oil rig in protest over global warming, ordering them to leave.

Six members of the environmental campaign group climbed aboard the Sante Fe 135 oil rig 30 miles east of Aberdeen from the MV Greenpeace support ship at 6.30am.

The protesters were inside a 3m bell-shaped survival capsule which they hoisted up to the underside of the platform. Two members later abseiled down one of the rig's legs to paint the slogan "oil kills".

The rig is owned by oil and gas production group BG International which applied for the court order. A company spokeswoman said last night: "I can confirm that the court order has been served and acknowledged by Greenpeace and they have agreed to comply with the court order."

She said the matter had been dealt with by the high court in Edinburgh.

Greenpeace spokesman Rob Gueterbock, who is aboard the MV Greenpeace support ship, said the court order had been read out to them over the radio. He said: "I don't know what the people in the pod want to do, but at the end of the day our fight isn't with the courts. It's outrageous that these companies go scurrying off to the courts rather than facing the consequences of their actions."

Earlier Mr Gueterbock said it was a peaceful protest over the threat to global warming from the opening up of new oil fields.

Greenpeace calculates that it will only need one quarter of known oil, coal and gas reserves to be burnt before global warming results in catastrophic changes to the climate. It claims changes have already brought flood misery to Britain and threatens the lives of millions worldwide.

Mr Gueterbock said: "We want to stop BG from opening up this new oil field. We hope to stop this oil company from operating out here for as long as we can because oil is killing people and flooding homes."

webTitle: Branson fails in claim for £18m lottery damages

fields.headline: Branson fails in claim for £18m lottery damages
fields.standfirst:
Court battle looms after regulator denies compensation

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The prospect of a fresh court battle over the competition for the next national lottery licence emerged last night after Sir Richard Branson's claim for compensation was rejected by the regulator.
fields.body:
The prospect of a fresh court battle over the competition for the next national lottery licence emerged last night after Sir Richard Branson's claim for compensation was rejected by the regulator.

The national lottery commission, which presided over last year's protracted bid process, said yesterday that it saw no grounds for making any payment to Sir Richard's People's Lottery.

The Virgin tycoon was bitterly disappointed after the seven-year contract to run the lottery was awarded to Camelot and was seeking £18.5m in compensation to cover the costs of his failed bid.

Simon Burridge, who had been chief executive of the People's Lottery, said he was "amazed" by the reaction of the commission. "We thought they would have more sense but then we have overestimated them before," he said.

"Going to court remains very much an option. They have been saying this was a fair and open process. Well it wasn't fair but by God it will be open if we go to court. We have some pretty interesting evidence. They are gluttons for punishment."

Sir Richard's decision to claim compensation was sparked by a decision from the commission last August which named the People's Lottery as preferred bidder. At that point, the commission said the licence would be awarded to Sir Richard if his bid met certain conditions. The claim for com pensation relates to costs after that date.

Camelot muscled its way back into the competition through the high court and was eventually awarded the licence in December.

A statement from the commission said: "The commission does not accept that it has any obligation to compensate the People's Lottery. There is simply no legal basis for the claim." The People's Lottery, it added, had always been aware that it would have to bear the costs of its bid if it were unsuccessful.

It also suggested that the People's Lottery had tacitly accepted the judgment of the commission by deciding not to challenge the decision in court. The commission informed the People's Lottery in a letter from its lawyers on Thursday.

"For them to say we accepted the decision is palpable nonsense," Mr Burridge said. "They fudged the decision - one which they may think they made on a rational basis but who knows what they were thinking?"

Mr Burridge said he would be discussing the next step forward with Sir Richard and the People's Lottery lawyers in the next few days.

Sir Richard had been frustrated by the commission's reasons for awarding the next licence to Camelot which he said demonstrated it was so averse to risk that he had never stood a chance. Camelot, he said, had been effectively handed the licence in perpetuity.

Repeated delays in making a decision, and the fiasco in August, led to one of culture secretary Chris Smith's more difficult periods in office. He was criticised by an all-party committee of MPs last month for his role in appointing the commission.

Camelot's victory in the high court and subsequent campaign for a fair fight led to the resignation of the commission chairwoman, Dame Helena Shovelton, citing her "personal vilification" in the media. She was replaced by Lord Burns who has since promised a review of the process for awarding the next licence.

Camelot, which has run the lottery since it was launched in 1994, begins its new licence period in October. During the bidding contest it managed a masterful transformation from being one of Britain's most reviled companies to a position where it was winning sympathy as the underdog. Directors of the company have taken pay cuts and a higher percentage of proceeds will be awarded to good causes.

Much of the success was put down to the efforts of chief executive, Dianne Thompson, who famously described herself as a woman with "balls of steel".

Both Camelot and the People's Lottery said they would raise around £15bn for good causes over the period of the next licence.
