fields.headline: Fortune takes flight
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Even before Mike Lynch's delayed New York to London flight reached its cruising altitude yesterday, the share price of the company he founded was crashing down to earth.
fields.body:
Even before Mike Lynch's delayed New York to London flight reached its cruising altitude yesterday, the share price of the company he founded was crashing down to earth.

By the time Mr Lynch had crossed the Atlantic the academic - who, at 35, almost became Britain's first internet billionaire - had lost another £55m from a paper fortune now worth just £73m. As bad days go, and Mr Lynch has had a few recently, this one took the biscuit.

The most frustrating thing to him is likely to have been the way the City, with which he has a love-hate relationship, took the knife to the valuation of the company that he has nurtured from startup to multinational corporation.

Mr Lynch has harboured suspicions that financiers have never really understood his company or its highly complex technology ever since Autonomy was first rejected by the London stock exchange as being too small and too risky when he first tried to float it in 1998. But he will find some comfort in the £47m worth of shares he cashed in at the time of Autonomy's London flotation last November.

fields.headline: The dot.com implosion
fields.standfirst:
It is a case history of consumer power

More internet news
fields.trailText: What ever next? That is the question many businessmen are asking themselves as the meltdown of internet-related companies continues apace.
fields.body:
What ever next? That is the question many businessmen are asking themselves as the meltdown of internet-related companies continues apace.

The latest casualty, Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software group, was one of the very few UK high fliers that looked capable of beating US companies on their own battleground.

Yesterday, after admitting that quarterly orders would fall by 40%, its shares tumbled and at one stage the company, once valued at over £5bn, was worth under £300m on the stock markets. Autonomy is at least still in the game. Others have not been so lucky.

There is now a long list of failed dot.coms including, e-Toys, the flagship US "e-tailer" that filed for bankruptcy last month. It was once valued at an unbelievable $12bn. If e-Toys cannot survive, then what is so special about Amazon, the world's biggest bookstore? It is still losing serious money and burning through the cash it raised in happier times.

What is surprising is not that so many have crashed (50% of all new companies fail after four years), but that intelligent people put up vast sums to finance companies that had no obvious way to make money, simply because of the charisma then attached to the suffix dot.com.

Their shares rose to levels that would be regarded as quite ludicrous by normal old economy standards, yet investors continued to pour in as if the South Sea Bubble had married the Dutch tulip boom.

At one stage companies seeking funds were reported to be concealing the fact that they might make money because losing money was considered so cool in your business plan. In the event hardly any of them made a profit anyway. Even the new magazines that grew so fat out of predicting the the bubble would burst are now in trouble.

They did not think it could happen to them. The most common dot.com mistake was to ignore basic business disciplines. Companies that had set up flashy websites realised that they had to spend zillions to make people aware they existed. Then, surprise, surprise, they had to deliver those goods in an efficient - and expensive - manner. They all thought they had "first mover advantage" when a study of business history should have told them that second movers have the advantage.

We are now entering the era of the second movers. Expect to see several converging trends this year. More dot.coms will fail. They will either be gobbled up by old economy companies as an extra sales outlet (as John Lewis bought the UK end of the failed US Buy.com) or they will merge among themselves to create monopolies so they can charge higher prices. Watch out also for new companies exploiting the inherent strengths of the web rather than trying to sell old economy goods in what turned out to be a more expensive way.

Everyone - from Microsoft to Yahoo and Napster, the music swap shop, - is now trying to charge for services hitherto given away free as a result of the intense competition generated by a globalised net. Whether they will succeed is a moot point. The huge force of distributed buying power on the internet is so strong it could remain a consumers' heaven for a good while yet. One area producers hoped would turn into a money spinner was distance learning. No longer. This week the mighty Massachusetts Institute of Technology said it would make its courses freely available on the internet. Who would care to compete with MIT by charging money for inferior material? On the internet the consumer, not the producer, is king and looks unlikely to be dethroned this year.
fields.bodyText: What ever next? That is the question many businessmen are asking themselves as the meltdown of internet-related companies continues apace. The latest casualty, Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software group, was one of the very few UK high fliers that looked capable of beating US companies on their own battleground. Yesterday, after admitting that quarterly orders would fall by 40%, its shares tumbled and at one stage the company, once valued at over £5bn, was worth under £300m on the stock markets. Autonomy is at least still in the game. Others have not been so lucky. There is now a long list of failed dot.coms including, e-Toys, the flagship US "e-tailer" that filed for bankruptcy last month. It was once valued at an unbelievable $12bn. If e-Toys cannot survive, then what is so special about Amazon, the world's biggest bookstore? It is still losing serious money and burning through the cash it raised in happier times. What is surprising is not that so many have crashed (50% of all new companies fail after four years), but that intelligent people put up vast sums to finance companies that had no obvious way to make money, simply because of the charisma then attached to the suffix dot.com. Their shares rose to levels that would be regarded as quite ludicrous by normal old economy standards, yet investors continued to pour in as if the South Sea Bubble had married the Dutch tulip boom. At one stage companies seeking funds were reported to be concealing the fact that they might make money because losing money was considered so cool in your business plan. In the event hardly any of them made a profit anyway. Even the new magazines that grew so fat out of predicting the the bubble would burst are now in trouble. They did not think it could happen to them. The most common dot.com mistake was to ignore basic business disciplines. Companies that had set up flashy websites realised that they had to spend zillions to make people aware they existed. webTitle: Police test may expose false rape claims

fields.headline: Police test may expose false rape claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Police are developing a "lie detector" test to help them to root out false rape allegations, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Police are developing a "lie detector" test to help them to root out false rape allegations, it emerged yesterday.

A checklist of 15 features found in the statements of genuine rape victims is being fine tuned by a Midlands police force as a means of assessing the credibility of alleged victims, and it could be adopted by forces elsewhere.

The technique - described as "deeply worrying" by women's groups who fear that it presumes the victim is lying - was unveiled at the British Psychological Society's forensic psychology conference in Birmingham. It draws on well established German techniques for assessing whether children's sex abuse claims are genuine.

The so-called statement valid ity analysis works on the principle that accounts based on real experiences differ from those that are fabricated. By rooting out those differences, it is possible to get a strong indication of whether someone is lying.

The main differences, according to Detective Sergeant Chris Few, who compiled the "test" as part of his psychology MA at Leicester University, include the amount of detail given by alleged victims, and their willingness, or not, to blame themselves for the crime.

Those who are lying will give a bare account, so they can remember their story better, whereas those telling the truth will include superfluous detail.

Genuine victims will see nothing wrong in admitting they cannot remember everything, and will talk about their emotions at the time and the attacker's motive. Fabricators will try to make their account watertight and will not countenance feeling blame.

Women who have been raped will tend to give fairly clear descriptions of conversations, and put the rape in the context of their lives, whereas fabricators will confine themselves to describing the one event.

With research suggesting that 10%-41% of rape allegations are made up, Mr Few tested his technique by training 16 officers and asking them to assess four out of eight statements - half of which he was "100% satisfied" were genuine, and half of which were later exposed as fabricated. The officers made the correct assessments in 72% of cases, but 16 untrained officers had only a 50% success rate.

While admitting that it could not be used in court, Mr Few said: "It's a useful investigative tool, one of many."

But Julie Bindell, of Justice for Women, said: "This will no doubt form and endorse a stereotype that women make false allegations of rape, and that you can test whether a woman is telling the truth by her response to questions.

"We have a 6% conviction rate for rape, which either means 94% of women are lying or there are an awful lot of men getting off. I'd like to see a bit more attention paid to how we can test whether those men in the dock are telling the truth."

Mr Few denied that the test was based on the assumption that women were lying. "I would like to think that if it is widely used it will support as many unbelieved genuine victims as expose the others."

webTitle: Bhutto 'revved up' for return to power

fields.headline: Bhutto 'revved up' for return to power
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan's supreme court yesterday overturned a conviction for corruption against the former prime minister Benazir Bhutto and her husband and ordered a retrial.
fields.body:
Pakistan's supreme court yesterday overturned a conviction for corruption against the former prime minister Benazir Bhutto and her husband and ordered a retrial.

Mrs Bhutto, who has been living in self-imposed exile in London and Dubai, said the way was now cleared for her return to politics in Pakistan.

"I hope to return soon. This is the first important hurdle cleared," she told the Guardian. "I could fly back tomorrow but I would like my party to make the preparations first. I am very keen to become the next prime minister should the people vote for me."

Mrs Bhutto and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, were sentenced in April 1999 to five years jail and fined £6m. Both were accused of taking kickbacks in awarding a contract to a Swiss firm.

The Oxford-educated Mrs Bhutto, twice sacked as prime minister after accusations of misrule and corruption, left Pakistan shortly before the conviction. She still faces four other cases of corruption.

Her husband has been in jail in Pakistan for the past four years. Mr Zardari, a former senator, is accused of drug trafficking and involvement in the murder of his wife's brother, Mir Murtaza Bhutto, as well as other corruption cases. It is not clear if he will now be released.

During the six-week appeal the defence read from the transcripts of what they claimed were recordings of telephone conversations between the judge in the original trial, Justice Malik Qayyum, the then law minister, Khalid Anwar, and the head of the anti-corruption office, Saifur Rehman. They said the recordings showed that the verdict in the original trial had been fixed. The prosecution said the tapes were not authentic.

But in a brief hearing yesterday morning the seven judges hearing the case set aside the convictions and sentences and ordered a retrial. Mrs Bhutto said that given the new evidence she doubted the military would press ahead with a second trial. "It depends on the army now but this is a big setback for General Pervez Musharraf and the military regime," she said. "We are all revved up now. There is going to be a lot of mobilisation from my party."

If she does return to Pakistan Mrs Bhutto is unlikely to consider any accommodation with the army. Her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was overthrown as prime minister, was hanged by the last military dictator, General Zia-ul Haq, 22 years ago this week.

Political analysts say Gen Musharraf is preparing to make himself president and to give the army a major role in future civilian governments. The general said earlier this week that both the prime minister he overthrew, Nawaz Sharif, and Mrs Bhutto now "have no role to play in Pakistan's politics".

fields.headline: Zimbabwe workers threatened
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's self-styled war veterans stopped production at Zimbabwe's largest bakery this week at the start of a campaign to take political terror to the cities.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's self-styled war veterans stopped production at Zimbabwe's largest bakery this week at the start of a campaign to take political terror to the cities.

Police officers and agents of the Central Intelligence Organisation helped the militants to break into Lobel's Bakery and stood by as they threatened the 1,200 workers on Thursday. Workers were told to support Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party or face being beaten to death.

"We are terrified," said a Lobel manager. "We called the police for help. Instead they helped the war veterans to get into the factory."

Whites and supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change were singled out. The dispatch manager, Ian Nel, was charged with having defamatory material against Mr Mugabe and was held by police overnight.

"We are setting up structures ... aimed at penetrating every urban area as part of our campaign for the presidential ballot," said the leader of the "veterans", Chenjerai Hunzvi, referring to the election due in April 2002.

fields.headline: Russia's hell-hole enclave
fields.standfirst:
There is a centre of organised crime in the middle of Europe

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: On Monday in Luxembourg European Union foreign ministers are meeting to discuss the northern dimension of EU foreign policy with their colleagues from the seven partner countries involved.
fields.body:
On Monday in Luxembourg European Union foreign ministers are meeting to discuss the northern dimension of EU foreign policy with their colleagues from the seven partner countries involved.

The northern dimension draws together the totality of the EU's approach to northern Europe. It aims to deliver maximum benefits to the countries around the Baltic Sea by ensuring coherence and exploiting synergies between all relevant union policies and instruments. It is a key element in our relations with Russia and is increasingly important with the coming enlargement of the EU.

The Russian territory of Kaliningrad will be one focus of these talks, as it has been at virtually every meeting I have had with the Russian authorities over the past year.

It was raised by President Putin at his meeting with Europe's leaders in Stockholm last month and is on the agenda for next month's EU-Russia summit as well as at the Cooperation Council with Russia next week, where we shall discuss it with vice prime minister Khristienko, the Russian "Mr EU". It is a priority for the current Swedish presidency of the union. I visited the region myself with the Swedish foreign minister, Anna Lindh, in February.

Why this degree of interest?

The answer lies in Kaliningrad's geographical and political situation: a part of Russia but separated from the rest of the federation, sandwiched between Lithuania and Poland on the shores of the Baltic Sea.

EU enlargement will increase stability and democracy on our continent. Russia stands to gain from new opportunities which it will open up - and Kaliningrad, too, will be well placed to benefit.

But the accession of Lithuania and Poland to the EU also poses a number of practical questions for Kaliningrad in terms of transport links, trade, visas, border controls and so on. We need to find practical solutions to these problems.

Take visas and free movement, for example. At present the people of Kaliningrad move easily across Poland and Lithuania into Russia and there are some 9m border crossings each year. Not unnaturally, they are worried that this will change with the accession of Poland and Lithuania into the EU.

What sort of border controls will need to be introduced? What sort of visa controls? Will they find that they are no longer able to travel freely to and from mainland Russia?

These are serious and sensitive issues. I have no doubt they can be resolved to everyone's satisfaction. But the solutions are not obvious. They will require us to make imaginative use of the flexibility permitted by EU rules.

The European commission published a discussion paper on Kaliningrad in January. This paper addresses not only the various questions related to EU enlargement, but other more general problems faced by Kaliningrad which we want to help tackle.

We have already begun to discuss our ideas with the authorities in Moscow and my visit to Kaliningrad in February confirmed that they had been well received on the ground. And it is crucial to success in Kaliningrad that the local authorities are fully involved in discussions and alive to the new opportunities which will come with enlargement. That is why I particularly welcome the participation of Governor Yegorov of Kaliningrad in next week's northern dimension conference .

EU activity is being matched in Moscow. The Russian government held a special discussion on Kaliningrad on March 22. Kaliningrad's special economic zone has been extended for 10 years and measures have been agreed to help business, to develop local transport and to build up energy and telecommunications infrastructures.

These are all positive steps. But those who dream of Kaliningrad as a "Hong Kong of the Baltic" need to face up to some formidable obstacles. The region suffers from appalling pollution, for example, and extensive drug and health problems, including a very high incidence of HIV and tuberculosis.

It is also a centre of organised crime. Some estimates suggest that more than 50% of Kaliningrad's income now comes from "informal activity" (as it is euphemistically known).

The EU is providing financial and technical assistance to help Kaliningrad deal with these problems. In recent years Kaliningrad has received €15m of EU assistance. Another €15m is on its way.

Kaliningrad, the former Königsberg, is a fascinating place with an extraordinary and illustrious history. It was the birthplace of Immanuel Kant, who never left the city. It was where Frederik I, the first king of Prussia, was crowned 300 years ago and where Copernicus lived and shaped European thinking. I think Kaliningrad will be a great place again.

It can be a model of northern dimension cooperation. Recent developments on Kaliningrad also augur well for our wider relations with Russia.

 Chris Patten is the EU commissioner for external relations, and former chairman of the Conservative party

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article headed Jason and the arbitrators, Media pages 4 and 5, March 26, we misquoted the Daily Mail when we said that the newspaper described Bernard O'Mahoney as a "gangster".
fields.body:
In an article headed Jason and the arbitrators, Media pages 4 and 5, March 26, we misquoted the Daily Mail when we said that the newspaper described Bernard O'Mahoney as a "gangster". The Daily Mail report actually described O'Mahoney as "a 40-year-old ex-gangster who makes no secret of his background".

An article by Joanna Israelsohn marking St Patrick's Day, pages 4 and 5, Travel, March 17, made substantial and unacknowledged use of The Rough Guide to Ireland by Margaret Greenwood, Mark Connolly and Geoff Wallis. Several passages from the book, which is published by Rough Guides, were used with little alteration and without permission. Joanna Israelsohn apologises to readers of the piece and to the authors of the original.

In an article headed They think it's all over, page 24 (Finance), April 3, we said that Aston Villa shares were floated at £6.50 in February, 1999. In fact the issue price was £11.

The caption to a picture of the competition commission inquiry group for the Lloyds TSB/Abbey National merger, page 24, Finance, March 31, was incorrect. It should have read, from left to right: David Parker, Denise Kingsmill, Graham Hadley and David Jenkins.

In a piece about exorcism, page 104, Society, April 4, we spoke of the 22 dioceses of the Church of England, and the 44 dioceses of the Roman Catholic Church. That was the wrong way round. It is C of E 44, RC 22.

The readers' editor writes about whited sepulchres and bellwethers in today's Saturday Review.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Inarticulate idiots in kipper ties

fields.headline: Inarticulate idiots in kipper ties
fields.trailText: Watching Nick Brown talk about foot and mouth the other day, I thought once again how curious it is that Tony Blair, who is obsessed by competence should have kept Mr Brown in charge.
fields.body:
Watching Nick Brown talk about foot and mouth the other day, I thought once again how curious it is that Tony Blair, who is obsessed by competence, and whose points of reference are managerial skills and never ideology, should have kept Mr Brown in charge, for several weeks, of the worst farming crisis since the war. And he has left John Prescott running the trains, which have gone from dismal to appalling.

It wouldn't work in any other business. If you were trying to persuade someone to sell through your estate agency, or invest with your finance company, you would not usher them in to meet the dimmest, most incompetent member of staff, some inarticulate idiot in a kipper tie who proceeded to bluster and fulminate at you while showing no sign at all of having a clue about the job.

I suppose it's the way politics works. After all, when Argentina invaded the Falklands, the defence secretary was John Nott, of whom it was said: "If he runs the war like he runs his farm, the task force will soon be off the coast of Alaska." Ten years later, when sterling faced its own foot and mouth crisis, Norman Lamont was chancellor.

Speaking of famously dotty politicians, there's a new biography of Keith Joseph, written by Mark Garnett and Andrew Denham. It recalls many of the great stories associated with the man they called The Mad Monk - and that included his friends; others just knew him as Mrs Thatcher's John the Baptist.

A painfully honest and courteous man, he was in a sense too good for the world, at least for the world of politics. As industry secretary, he was asked to enthuse about the new Mini Metro, which was supposed to save Longbridge, yet again. He couldn't. "I'm afraid I don't have a car. Mine was stolen, and I never replaced it," was all he would say. On another occasion he toured a TV studio. "Tell me," he inquired, "do you think television is here to stay?" In a Scottish bird sanctuary he famously, and perhaps ironically, asked, "how do the birds know it is a sanctuary?"

I followed him for a day during the 1979 election, at a time when he was notorious as the man who seemed to have suggested selective breeding for the population and who thought unemployment not such a bad idea if it brought economic stability. He found campaigning impossible because he could not bear to interrupt anyone. "We can't go into this shop," he would say, "people are buying things."

He would be taken to fancy restaurants by journalists, and when asked what he'd like, replied "Cake, please. British Rail cake," by which he meant a slice of Dundee.

I had an unnerving experience last week. I had been invited for tea by Caroline Flint, a backbench Labour MP about whom my stern duty has obliged me to be rude once or twice in print. MPs quite often want to show journalists they are much nicer than we think, and I feel bound to accept these offers, even though on this occasion I was halfway through a vital sketch abusing Michael Portillo.

Ms Flint did seem perfectly agreeable, though she worried me by insisting we sat in the window of the Pugin Room, overlooking the river, and one table away from George Howarth, a Northern Ireland minister. Mr Howarth is the only MP who has ever sued me, and he won. We scowled at each other for 20 minutes before he left, to be replaced by Michael Portillo, who bade us a cheery good afternoon. "It's nothing personal," I stammered foolishly, wishing the ground would open up. I stared wildly around the room, looking for support or distraction. At that moment, in walked Michael Fabricant.

Suddenly I pictured myself with them all, standing outside the Pearly Gates.

"Well, Mr Hoggart," says St Peter, "we really can't make up our minds whether to let you in. So we've arranged to have four character witnesses give evidence ..."

I heard a touching story about the late Donald Dewar, who as first minister in Scotland was to encounter all kinds of famous people at the launch party for the last Edinburgh Festival before he died. Aides with photographs had helped him identify all the faces he was likely to meet, so it was with great confidence that he strode up to Dannii Minogue and introduced himself. After a while he turned to the chap beside her and inquired what he did. "Ah am a driver," the man replied.

"Wonderful!" said Mr Dewar. "I have a driver, too!"

"I doan' zink you understan'" said the fellow. "Ah am a racing driver. Mah name is Jacques Villeneuve."

Last December I mentioned on this page that most charity Christmas cards were awful - dreary, predictable designs that nobody would want to send to their friends or their family. I suspect some people really can't face the idea of sending most of the charity cards they see, and the only losers will be Clinton Cards and WH Smith, whose misfortunes I think I can cope with.

fields.headline: Charlie the sniffer dog
fields.standfirst:
The antics of the Wessexes have generated a frisson of amusement all week, with the prospect of more tabloid scoops to come. But there's a dark side to this comedy

So easily led
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The antics of the Wessexes have generated a frisson of amusement all week, with the prospect of more tabloid scoops to come. But there's a dark side to this comedy .
fields.body:
In classical portraits, the presence of a dog symbolises fidelity. In a cartoon in the Sun, the presence of a particular canine represents impending treachery. In recent caricatures of the Earl and Countess of Wessex in Rupert Murdoch's tabloid, an enthusiastic looking pooch has crouched in the corner of the frame.

His coat identifies him as Charlie, a sniffer dog employed by the Sun to attend celebrity events and detect the presence of cocaine, taking his own name from a street word for that substance. In the Wessex cartoons, Charlie is there to warn, encourage and advise, as the Earl's mother is supposed to do for her prime ministers. He warns especially of what might appear in the weekend's papers.

Charlie is the so far hidden element in the Edward and Sophie story. Until the middle of the week, there was one inexplicable factor in the latest palace scandal. Reported to have been tricked into fairly innocuous remarks by a News of the World reporter dressed as a sheikh, Sophie Rhys-Jones agreed, under Buck House supervision, to give an unofficial interview as a replacement. This was, to adapt gay parlance, a beard interview, designed to obscure her previous remarks. And yet, oddly, the official chat - in which she strenuously emphasises her husband's sexuality - seemed rather more embarrassing than the one it was supposed to kill.

Now a possible explanation is becoming clear, in newspaper rumour and public hints such as the cartoon Charlie. The beard piece was intended to suppress the publication not only of Sophie's original chat but of a separate interview with her PR partner, Murray Harkin.

The belief of the Sun cartoonist seems to be that Harkin told the fake sheikh of drug use within the Wessexes' circle. Only the weekend news will tell us if the caricaturist is being stupid, but it has been known for at least two years that the story the tabloids really want is royal Charlie (and by that they don't mean the Prince of Wales). In their dreams, the story would touch on royals rather younger than Edward and Sophie, but the world of the Wessexes would do for the moment.

While we wait to see if the cartoon Charlie will become the dog that didn't bark, there are various conclusions to be drawn from the meeting between the Queen's daughter-in-law and a pretend prince of the desert. The first is the naivety of whoever it was - and it seems to have been the palace's media chief, Simon Walker - who believed that an embarrassing interview could be made to vanish.

The suppression of stories was possible in the past - Churchill's stroke, the misdemeanours of the children of press barons - but this system depended on fear, the possibility of social and professional disgrace and the fact that paper can be efficiently burned. Now that compromising documents exist electronically, they exist forever among people who may even benefit professionally from passing them on.

While few would morally support the actions of the News of the World in sending a mock-up oil baron after Sophie, she was foolish not to understand that one of the initiation rites on becoming a celebrity is the cutting out of your tongue. Horrible though it is, the famous must now accept that any conversation they have is potentially public. For example, Michael Duberry, the Leeds United footballer cleared of conspiracy charges at Hull crown court this week, must now accept that any stranger who engages him in conversation or stands him a drink may be a newspaper reporter hoping for unguarded remarks about the case.

Even so, in one area, there should be sympathy for the Wessexes. For years, tabloid and other critics of the monarchy have complained about the cost to the taxpayer of supporting the royals. The logic of this is that they should do conventional jobs. And yet, with a hypocrisy outstanding even in the capital of double standards which journalism can be, the Murdoch tabloids seem determined to put Sophie Rhys-Jones out of work.

The argument is that she trades on her Royal connections, but why is that inevitably shocking? Sacked editors who set up PR companies trade on their journalistic and Murdoch connections. We surely need to choose whether to buy the royals' silence through the civil list or to let them out into the economy, with the losses of dignity which all business entails.

But this story isn't really about Sophie. What's happened is that newspapers have identified her as the weakest link in the royal family. Apart from the advisory presence of Charlie the sniffer dog in Sun cartoons this week, the most significant element in the paper was an editorial which expressed more open support for republicanism than any mainstream British newspaper ever has. This editorial went as far as to argue that the monarchy cannot survive.

For the first time, the private instincts of the Australo-American Murdoch have become the public policy of his papers. Whatever other substances those around the royals may have sniffed, the Queen is going to need her smelling salts this weekend.

fields.headline: Unholy words for Holy Week
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: In a recent survey, swear words and other derogatory terms remain seriously offensive for many people, especially words that slander or malign. The truth is that the words not only hurt; they maim, condemn - and even kill.
fields.body:
"Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me" has never been a true proverb. In a recent survey, swear words and other derogatory terms remain seriously offensive for many people, especially words that slander or malign. The truth is that the words not only hurt; they maim, condemn - and even kill.

One of the more curious features of the Holy Week narratives - normally ignored by the churches - is the amount of swearing and cursing that goes on in the last few chapters of the gospels. There cannot be much doubt that the Aramaic language of Jesus' time could probably match Anglo-Saxon four-lettered expletives word for word.

Holy Week begins, in Matthew's account, with Jesus cursing a barren fig tree - a cipher for the failure of His audience to realise, and respond to, the good news of the kingdom of God. Peter, for denying Jesus, "swears and invokes a curse upon himself". Jesus stands trial, accused of blasphemy. He, in turn, is insulted and mocked by his Roman guards. Judas knows he is cursed, and hangs himself. And anyway, the problem all began long before this, for "removing the curse of Adam" is what Good Friday and Easter are supposed to be all about.

The church has always had a slightly ambivalent attitude towards cursing. The Reformation in England led to the Anglican church dropping the practice of excommunication, and also disposing of the more ancient services of Malediction or Clamour (meaning "appeal for justice").

However, the Church of England allowed instead a public reading of Deuteronomy (ch28), within the context of a Service of Commination, which allowed a minister to recite a litany - a general register of God's cursing of certain types of sin and sinners. In medieval and Reformation times, there were also many instances of folk-religion curses - people, in all walks of life, praying for the forces of evil, or the vengeance of God, to be visited upon their enemies and neighbours.

The thinking behind these services, and the more informal practice, was simple enough. If God would bless those who a blessing was pronounced upon, would He not also curse those who had a curse pronounced upon them?

Modern commentators agree that cursing is an activity that has close associations with blessing. Indeed, the forms of words are frequently parallel. To bless someone, or something, is to raise them, or it, to its proper status before God, enabling fuller praise to be returned through the very thing that is blessed. Cursing is the opposite of this, a spiral of denigration, denial and, finally, the absence of hope.

Like a blessing, a curse is what linguistic scholars term a speech-act, since it is simultaneously a verbal utterance and a deed performed. In the very act of speaking, there is action. In cursing himself for denying Jesus, Peter attempts to complete his own perception of his separation from God. Likewise, the accusations levelled against Jesus, namely blasphemy, actually consign him to isolation, and then death.

In all the cursing and swearing of the gospel finales, we are, of course, left with one victim, Jesus, who himself becomes cursed by God - or consigned to evil. But this is not done by words alone; it is the silence from heaven that is deafening and defining. Jesus becomes cursed not by what is said, but by what is left unsaid. And Jesus knows it, too. Abandoned by nearly all to his ignominious fate, he cries, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me."

As Sydney Carter puts it in his hymn, The Carpenter, written from the point of view of one of the thieves also executed with Jesus: "God is up in heaven/and he doesn't do a thing/with a million angels watching/and they never move a wing."

It may seem strange that "the word made flesh" is finally condemned by God's silence. Yet in a strange way, it is the words of blessing that flow from the dying Jesus that give a clue to what is going on in the Crucifixion. To those who curse and mock Jesus, there are words of forgiveness. For the dying thief, there is an invitation to paradise.

The cross then starts to look like a place of cursing that is turned into something for blessing, and the close link between the two should not surprise us. It is ironic. Jesus, who is the true praise of God, is also, on the cross, the accursed of God. As Carter concludes his hymn, he reminds us of the foolishness of the cross: "It's God they ought to crucify instead of you and me/I said to the carpenter a-hanging on the tree."

Precisely. Here hangs one "who saved others, but cannot save himself". In choosing to be cursed with betrayal, torture, abandonment and death, the lamb of God becomes an apparently ordinary scapegoat. Our swearing, cursing and vilification is finally directed against God. And God's response is one of silence and then of blessing.

So, the message of Holy Week is that the cursing directed against one another and against God is wasted, for it is all absorbed in the cross. The cross is itself a speech-act - eloquent in its silence, abundant in its proclamation of blessing, and, then again, in its display of love and sacrifice, an utterance and an accomplishment.

The proof of this is in a throwaway remark by Luke, near the end of his gospel. After the appearance of Jesus on the road to Emmaus, the witnesses scurry back to Jerusalem to proclaim the Resurrection. They need not have bothered, for Luke tells us that Jesus has already "appeared to Peter".

What words were exchanged between them is not recorded. However, it is safe to assume that Peter, the man who cursed himself for denying any knowledge of Jesus, could begin to understand how this same Jesus, "the accursed of God", had become the instrument of God's blessing to humanity.

 The Rev Canon Dr Martyn Percy is director of the Lincoln Theological Institute for the Study of Religion and Society at the University of Sheffield.

fields.headline: BT gains credit-rating breathing space
fields.trailText: British Telecom has been given some breathing space through the postponement of a crucial meeting with credit rating agency Standard & Poors.
fields.body:
British Telecom has been given some breathing space through the postponement of a crucial meeting with credit rating agency Standard & Poors.

The meeting, which could determine whether the debt-laden company loses its top-bracket credit rating has been delayed from later this month to May. BT said the meeting had been delayed because of "diary conflicts".

A cut in BT's credit rating from its current A status would prove hugely embarrasing for BT. But the cut would also have the material effect of increasing the company's cost of borrowing. S&P warned in February that it was likely to lower BT at least one notch to A- and left open the possibility of a two-notch cut to BBB+.

Moody's, the other main credit ratings agency, also put BT on review for downgrade from A2, last month. The agency said that it could cut BT's rating by one or two notches, again threatening the loss of an A rating.

BT has built £30bn of debt but its plans to reduce the amount by £10bn by the end of the year have been knocked off course by the volatility of world stock markets. The company had hoped to float up to 25% of its directories business Yell and mobile phone division BT Wireless as a means of raising cash.

BT has since admitted that it is considering all options for both businesses including full demergers or, in the case of Yell, a sale. It emerged earlier this week that a consortium of venture capital firms made up of Apax Partners and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst has been given a period of exclusivity for negotiations. Yell, which owns the Yellow Pages, is expected to raise around £3bn.

Shares in BT slipped 0.5p to 528.5p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Microsoft liable to class action
fields.body:
Microsoft liable to class action

A US judge has ruled that a complaint against Microsoft which alleges that the software group overcharged consumers can move forward on the more onerous class action basis. The decision by a Minnesota state judge is a blow to Microsoft, which has recently gained ground in its appeal against last year's ruling that it had broken US competition law.

Earlier this year, Microsoft persuaded a district judge to dismiss 38 class action anti-trust claims on the grounds that the company could not be sued by consumers who bought their software from hardware manufacturers. The consumers argue that Windows, Microsoft's operating system, came installed on their computers.

EC launches Intel inquiry

Intel, the world's largest maker of computer chips, is at the centre of a European commission inquiry into whether the Silicon Valley powerhouse has abused its dominant position.

Brussels said it had received two complaints from Intel's competitors - Advanced Micro Devices and Taiwanese chipmaker VIA technologies - which had prompted a full investigation which could take over a year to complete.

At issue is the way Intel markets and distributes its Pentium processor chips, which power 80% of the world's computers.

Arcadia sells Wade Smith

Fashion group Arcadia yesterday sold the first of five brands it plans to dispose of as part of a restructuring programme. The group sold its Liverpool-based designer retail chain Wade Smith for £7m to its founder, Robert Wade-Smith.

Mr Wade-Smith sold the business, which operates four shops around the city as well as its own distribution centre, to Arcadia in 1998 for £17m.

Zoo time at the Groucho

Zoo Hotels submitted its formal attempt yesterday to scupper PR chief Matthew Freud's bid to take over the Groucho Club, the Soho hangout favoured by media types.

Zoo, a boutique hotel group headed by Benjamin Fry, offered a swap deal which would see Groucho shareholders given seven Zoo shares for every two they hold. Mr Fry's offer values each Groucho share at 358.75p and the club at £15.9m, compared to Mr Freud's cash offer of 266.75p per share. Groucho shares are worth 225p.

The Groucho board said that it prefers Mr Freud's offer because it is in cash. Mr Fry's offer is in shares.

Prudential will look at other targets in the US if its takeover of American General fails. It is adamant that its agreed offer is final, its chief executive, Jonathan Bloomer, said.

Prudential's offer for AG, launched in March, has seemed doubtful since the world's biggest insurer, American International Group, trumped it this week. Prudential is in constant contact with American General, the Texas-based firm, which would have to pay Prudential a break-up fee of $600m if it walks away.

Prudential's shares slumped about 15% after the deal was announced last month as investors feared the British insurer was paying too much.

webTitle: Notebook: Market enters the bargain basement

fields.headline: Marks enters the bargain basement
fields.standfirst: Second tier managers revolt
fields.trailText: There is something awe-inspiring about the steady implosion of what was the country's leading retailer, Marks & Spencer. And also something deeply sad.
fields.body:
There is something awe-inspiring about the steady implosion of what was the country's leading retailer, Marks & Spencer. And also something deeply sad.

The financial detail contained in the group management accounts, revealed in The Guardian today, is devastating. Marks is in far worse shape than outsiders even speculated. Just about every division is in freefall - and as the business burns, the management are trying to throttle each other. These internal figures are now in the public domain because (we suspect) second tier management are furious that the chairman's bonus is likely to remain intact when their own awards have been struck out. They feel they are paying the price for failure at the top.

According to the M&S document, net debt will have increased by £129m over the year, compared with a reduction of about the same amount the previous year.

The company now plans to return £2bn to shareholders and its operational gearing will rise. This is a risky strategy. If sales rise, the bottom line will benefit more quickly, but if they continue to fall - and there is absolutely no sign that M&S has the expertise at present to halt the slide - profits will be punished far more severely.

Marks clearly needs instant and radical action, and it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that the only way the company is going to get it is through a takeover - although, with 12 institutional shareholders holding more than 35% of the company, there are obvious barriers. But M&S certainly does need a new commerical culture imposed from outside.

Potential bidders will now have a much clearer idea about what they are taking on - and how little they might have to pay. With profitability per square foot of shop floor down by a quarter over the past 12 months (and still falling), the betting is it will not be the £7.5bn at which the market capitalised this company last night.

Power gap

Peter Hain, the new energy minister, was this week on the radio promoting the merits of "clean, green, self-sustained" power stations fuelled by renewables - especially windfarms, of which 18 were given the go-ahead. But by far his most intriguing remarks concerned nuclear power - arguably the cleanest fuel of all.

Sir Eric Ash of the Royal Society called for new nuclear power stations to help the UK meet both its energy needs and climate change targets, but Mr Hain was adamant: "I haven't seen any applications for licences for nuclear power stations and I doubt whether they will be forthcoming in current circumstances."

Nukes, he said, were a fad of the 1950s, 60s and 70s; green energy is now.

But nuclear power still seems destined for a comeback. Mr Hain was being disingenuous: once the election is cleared Labour in government will conduct an immediate appraisal of nuclear policy. The reason is clear. The 18 new windfarms could generate 1620MW of green electricity, as Greenpeace says, but the wind - which doesn't blow all the time - cannot provide "base load" for the UK's generating market. Few serious observers believe that ministers can hit their target of 10% of energy supplies from renewables by 2010.

What is more, our ageing nuclear power stations, belonging to British Energy or BNFL, are due to be gradually decommissioned. The whole fleet now provides a quarter of Britain's needs, at 12,536MW. But, by 2010, closures will have pushed that down to 7560MW, leaving a near-5000MW gap to be filled.

By what? On the most optimistic scenario, partly, but hardly entirely, by renewables. Coal (questionably), and gas (certainly), now the ban on new plant has been lifted. But, with gas prices soaring nobody is rushing to build, North Sea supplies are rapidly depleting, and the biggest alternative sources are in Siberia, Algeria and Iran.

Messrs Hain, Meacher and Prescott want to reduce our carbon emissions by a further 18m tonnes a year to comply with Kyoto commitments, but the nuclear "gap" could increase these by anything between 10m and 20m tonnes annually. So ministers will have to take a deep breath after June 7 and start thinking nuclear.

Putting aside, for now, the defining issue of waste-disposal, there's no evidence of BE and BNFL rushing in to fill the gap. The economics, in the absence of a stable generating market under the new Neta system and political/regulatory pressure on prices, do not stack up. BE, active this week in promoting its own windfarm, has not filed applications to Mr Hain for new build.

But, with California on their mind, ministers will have to address the nuclear option - and energy policy as a whole - from June 8. Or they will end up leaving an awful lot of people in the dark.

webTitle: Leaked papers reveal the devastating decline of M&S

fields.headline: Leaked papers reveal the devastating decline of M&S
fields.standfirst: Staff morale hits rock bottom in UK as French take to the streets
fields.trailText: Staff morale hits rock bottom in UK as French take to the streets.
fields.body:
A confidential Marks & Spencer management document seen by the Guardian has underlined the devastating decline of Marks & Spencer.

The document, which includes estimates for all aspects of the M&S business for the full year that ended on March 31, shows the disastrous reduction in profitability within the group.

Two months ago the group was internally forecasting an end of year profit of £430m - which is at the lowest level of City analysts' expectations. Their estimate was £59m below their prediction just three months previously, and the business has since suffered further blows.

One section, outlining crucial performance indicators, shows the return on capital invested by the company crashing from 17.5% to 15.2%. Last September - the document spells out - the company had expected a substantial recovery, which would have produced a 19.9% return on capital.

The company's costs, meanwhile, are on the increase. M&S predicted that by the end of the year, costs would have risen from £2bn to £2.08bn. The stores' operating costs as a percentage of sales were forecast to rise from 31.6% to 33%.

By the end of last year, its profits per square foot had crashed to £12.80 from £16.90 a year earlier - but the bombed-out clothing departments were faring far worse. In those departments, profits per square foot had slumped from £18.90 to just £9.40.

Clothing department profits per employee halved from £8,000 to £4,000.

Morale within the company is understood to have hit rock bottom, with many senior employees angry that they are to be denied their bonuses while chairman Luc Vandevelde is still in line to scoop a £650,000 performance-related cheque.

The £10m set aside to pay management bonuses at the beginning of the financial year has been released and will be used to boost profits instead. The company plans to hold its dividend at 9p.

The chairman's payment was agreed by the company's remuneration committee, led by former MI5 chief Dame Stella Rimington, when he joined the company last year. However, if it is offered - and if Mr Vandevelde accepts - several major shareholders are likely to protest.

There is also mounting disquiet about some internal appointments. Several long-serving insiders are unhappy with the salaries being offered to lure in outside talent such as Michele Jobling, the former chief executive of Liberty who has taken control of the childrenswear business, and Yasmin Yusuf, the ex-Warehouse executive who has been hired as M&S's new creative director.

Questions are also being asked about why Maurice Helfgott has been appointed to turn around the badly underperforming menswear department. He previously ran the ventures department, which has chalked up a £13m loss.

The ventures included ie Splendour.com, an online lingerie company, and Talkcast, a multimedia company, which have both failed to deliver. The "new concept" MSL lingerie shops, which were launched in Europe, lost £800,000 - and are now being shut down.

The position of Barry Morris, the head of womenswear, is also under the spotlight, as he has presided over a string of collections which shoppers have spurned.

One retail expert said: "I am surprised at the severity of these figures, and especially at the fact that it is lingerie and menswear, rather than womenswear, which are having the worst time."

The store chain cut prices in menswear by £32m - and far from generating extra sales, the move actually cut profits by more than £17m. Womenswear prices were reduced by £62m, but the new prices pulled in only £12.5m extra profit.

To make up for those price cuts, the group's lingerie prices were raised by £23.5m - and customers walked away rather than pay more.

Altogether more than £400m of unsold stock had to be discounted in the annual winter sale. The changes in staff costs - which show savings in the stores being more than wiped out by payroll increases at head office - are also unusual. Store chains normally try to trim central costs ahead of front-line store costs. "That is likely to be counterproductive," said the retail insider.

The retail chain's decision to accept credit cards has also adversely affected bottom line profits.

According to the internal documents seen by the Guardian, it will have cost the group £31m to accept cards this year. At the same time, the number of M&S charge cards issued to new customers has collapsed from 172,000 to 50,000.

A M&S spokesman said: "It was always going to cost us money to take credit cards, but there was a huge groundswell urging us to do so. And we have not been promoting our charge card at all."

Other parts of the financial services business - where trading profit is down from £89.9m to an anticiapted £58.7m - have also been hit. Unit trust sales have halved and and the number of new Personal Reserve accounts opened will have fallen from 34,000 to an expected 14,000 - nearly 10,000 less than M&S had forecast, internally, at the halfway stage.

fields.headline: Clinton Cards
fields.trailText: The future looks bright for Clinton Cards - as long as there are mothers and loved ones needing gestures of affection in paper card form.
fields.body:
The future looks bright for Clinton Cards - as long as there are mothers and loved ones needing gestures of affection in paper card form.

The firm, which issued a profits warning at the beginning of 2000, said yesterday that cards bought for Valentine's and Mother's Day boosted sales - which showed a like-for-like increase of 12.6% in the nine weeks to the beginning of April.

Clinton also announced full year profits of £17.8m, up from £16.3m, and the shares climbed 12.5p to 134p.

The company said it plans to expand its stores across the country from 676 to 1,000 over the next few years.

The group continues to "refine its portfolio" - including opening, expanding, closing, relocating and refitting stores - to push growth and strengthen performance.

Although this has led to a reduction in the number of stores in the short term, it is a move in the right direction - expanding those doing well and closing others.

The group also hopes to cash in on the regional taste differences evident in Britain, and is launching a cash till-based software system in 450 stores designed to monitor the comparative popularity of cards in different areas.

"We know there are differences - for instance, in some areas of the country your grandma is called granny or gran; there are so many regional variations like this," said Barry Hartog, Clinton's financial director.

It all sounds very promising, but the group is operating in a mature market. Clinton might have 17% of the market share, and prides itself on having a card for almost every occasion. But will demand be maintained?

The expansion of concessions in Debenhams stores - the company will operate 40 during 2001 - has not been as rapid as some analysts had hoped, and there are slightly higher levels of stock in the stores than expected.

The company is nevertheless strongly placed, and still appears undervalued.

fields.headline: Spirent spirals lower
fields.trailText: Holders of Spirent shares were nursing a loss yesterday after a profits warning from one of its closest competitors set the alarm bells ringing.
fields.body:
Holders of Spirent shares were nursing a loss yesterday after a profits warning from one of its closest competitors set the alarm bells ringing.

The telecoms-testing specialist ended 25p lower at 335p after US rival Agilent Technologies warned that revenue for the second quarter would be less than the $2.9bn it had forecast in February. Agilent, a Hewlett-Packard spin-off, blamed its problems on faltering sales to big communications firms in the past month.

It did not take City traders very long to work out the implications of the news for Spirent. Both companies generate the majority of their revenue in America - in Spirent's case 70% - and share a similar customer base. With Agilent implementing a 10% temporary pay cut to cope with the downturn, traders are concerned that Spirent's business might also be also suffering.

In the wider market, it was another volatile day for equity traders as the FTSE 100 swung around violently in reaction to weak economic data and disturbing corporate news.

After rising 60 points at the start of play, the blue chip index was nursing an 80 point deficit after the publication of weaker-than-expected US jobs data at 1.30pm. The data rekindled fears that the world's biggest economy might be headed for recession.

But a partial recovery on Wall Street combined with a strange 20-point spike in the closing auction and a strong showing from index heavyweight Vodafone, up 7.5p to 203.25p, helped the FTSE 100 recover to close just 20.3 points lower at 5,601.5. Over the week the blue chip index fell 32.2 points.

The FTSE Techmark 100 did not fare so well. Undermined by a shocking profits warning from intelligent software company, Autonomy, it fell 56.86 points to 1,780.11.

Autonomy shares finished the session 245p, or 43%, lower at 325p after revealing that declining sales in Europe would force quarter-on-quar ter revenues down by 40%.

News that the slowdown in IT spending had reached Europe sent a shudder through the rest of the sector. Misys fell 42p to 415p, CMG lost 42.5p to 430.5p, Logica surrendered 78p to 802p, and Sage shed 15.5p to 234.5p.

Against such a backdrop it was hardly surprising that speculation of a profits warning from chip designer ARM Holdings surfaced late in the session. ARM, which reports first quarter figures next Wednesday, fell 34p to 256p - the worst blue chip performer.

Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, was also under attack, rattled by a profits warning from US internet equipment firm Sycamore Networks. Marconi shares eased 20p to 325p.

Lower down the market, software services group Cedar slipped 31.5p to 131p on whispers (surprise, surprise) that a profits warning is on the way. According the gossips, Cedar failed to close a number of deals in time for its fiscal year-end last Wednesday and is having problems with the enterprise solutions group it acquired from US company, Renaissance Worldwide.

However, sources close to the company played down the speculation, saying Cedar's weak performance had more to do with the malaise affecting the sector after the warning from Autonomy.

Sytner, the owner of upmarket car dealerships, was heading the other way, advancing 11.5p to 166.5p, on the back of chatter that founder and former racing driver, Frank Sytner, is eyeing retirement and wants to sell his 26% stake. Dealers fingered Ixion, a rival motor group, as a likely buyer of the stake.

fields.headline: Morrison milestone
fields.trailText: The no-frills grocer Wm Morrison has won promotion to the FTSE 100.
fields.body:
The no-frills grocer Wm Morrison has won promotion to the FTSE 100.

Late yesterday, the FTSE confirmed that Schlumberger's takeover of current constituent Sema had gone unconditional, and that Morrison, as the highest-ranking stock on the reserve list, would take its place in the blue chip index.

The news will be particularly sweet for chairman Ken Morrison. It was his father, William Morrison, who started the Morrison empire in 1899 from a butter-and-egg stall in Bradford. Morrison became a public company in 1967. Shareholders will also be pleased. The shares rose 10p to 210p in anticipation of the decision yesterday, and traders are predicting further gains.

Morrison will not take its place in the FTSE 100 until Tuesday morning, which means funds that track the index will be forced to buy Morrison shares on Monday.

fields.headline: M&S slips deeper into crisis
fields.standfirst: Sales on the slide despite price cuts, says leaked report
fields.trailText: Sales on the slide despite price cuts, says leaked report.
fields.body:
The crisis at Marks & Spencer, which has seen the company plunge from premier retailer to the sick man of the high street, is far more severe than the company has admitted.

Confidential documents seen by the Guardian show the company haemorrhaging sales despite cutting prices. At the same time costs are spiralling and its new ventures are running up big losses. It is also understood that sales of womenswear have plunged by a quarter in the last three weeks.

Senior management staff, who have been told that they will not receive bonuses this year, are outraged that the chairman, Luc Vandevelde, is still in line for a £650,000 bonus he negotiated when he joined the company last year.

The internal files also raise questions about M&S's decision last week to close down its international business. The documents show that the European stores, which are closing down with the loss of more than 3,000 jobs, are trading better than the UK business.

There were demonstrations in five French cities as employees protested against the closures yesterday, and the French and Belgian governments are threatening the company with legal action because the moves were announced without consultation.

The confidential memo will provide them with ammunition should they decide to take M&S to court. Three-quarters of the way through the store chain's financial year, European sales were down only £5m, to £417m. In the US, where M&S is to sell off its businesses, sales were up by £66m. In total the international operations had generated £21m in operating profit by the end of last year - up from £4m in 1999.

In the UK operating profit fell from £203m to £166m. The annual winter sale cost the company £109m, up from £87m last year, as it was forced to put £400m of unsold stock on the sale rails.

The leaked documents, which will be a severe embarrassment to the company, come only a week after Mr Vandevelde outlined a new recovery plan. As well as pulling out of Europe and the US, he closed down the mail order business and promised a return to M&S's traditional roots, focusing on "classically stylish" fashion to appeal to over-35s. He described the plan as "probably the most important in the history of Marks & Spencer".

The entire board of directors at the company has been changed in two years as M&S tries to rediscover its winning formula. Although almost all M&S's rivals have produced good figures this year, there is no sign of a recovery at Marks.

The secret document forecasts that the M&S group will make a £430m profit in the financial year that ended last week - but its dismal trading performance in the last eight weeks means the final figure could now be less than that. In 1998 the group made more than £1.1bn.

The figures show the company is making some improvements by buying stock in at better prices, but all the benefits are being eaten up by unsold goods that have to be discounted and by extra costs of £80m. The group has cut the cost of its store staff by £9m, but staff costs at its headquarters rose by £12m at the same time.

M&S is secretive about the sales performances of its individual departments, but the company was forecasting a 9% slump in menswear sales last year and a 5% downturn in women's fashion sales, even though prices were slashed in both departments. The company cut menswear prices by £32m and still managed to lose £17.5m of sales. Lingerie sales are also down 5%, as customers spurn the ranges.

A spokeswoman for M&S said: "We cannot deny the figures are accurate. But they are a mixture of estimates and facts. Things are not going well, but we are not hiding that fact."

fields.headline: Haughty Crillon scorns porn publicity
fields.trailText: The comings and goings filmed at Paris's poshest hotel, Le Crillon, had nothing to do with the protocol surrounding visits by world leaders and top stars.
fields.body:
The comings and goings filmed at Paris's poshest hotel, Le Crillon, had nothing to do with the protocol surrounding visits by world leaders and top stars.

Nor, despite the title Une Americaine à Paris, did the hottest video in town pretend to be a female homage to the Gene Kelly classic.

"I'm afraid, Monsieur, it contained the sort of scenes that would be more appropriate to a vulgar hotel de passe ," a member of the staff said when asked why Le Crillon had asked the courts to censor an hour's free publicity shot in its precincts on the Place de la Concorde.

"We certainly never gave permission to shoot this disgusting display - the episode was done secretly."

Pascal Malbequi, head of the legal department of the hotel's owners, the Société du Louvre', told Reuters news agency: "It is unquestionably a blow to the image and the reputation of our luxury palace.

"Our customers would not be very pleased to know that they could appear in such movies without being aware of it."

A clue to the dignified anger emanating from the staid establishment with its £500-a-night rooms was the cinematic presence of Rocco Siffredi, Italy's outstanding porno star.

His mammoth member is a celebrity in itself after featuring in a general circuit film called Romance.

No one was saying who in the Le Crillon management got hold of the video circulating almost clandestinely in the city's sex shops.

But whoever it was had no trouble recognising the hotel.

Much of the film is devoted to the Italian stallion checking in before the inevitable X-otic bedding of an American woman in a suite usually leased to millionaires and ministers.

The most exclusive salons served as free sets throughout and, if porno freaks had any doubts about the location, the hotel's insignia could be read on a porter's uniform and cap.

Along with the Société du Louvre, the porter persuaded the Paris court this week to order the Hungarian production company RSP to cut out all images of himself and Le Crillon - amounting to 13 minutes - and remove its name from the jacket.

In addition the company was awarded about £3,000 damages, and the unwitting extra was awarded £10,000.

But the coupling will stand.

And the cut version will be back on the shelves next week, according to a sex-shop owner, Emmanuel Lehne.

He expects big sales, he said, "because Siffredi's equipment is better known architecture than the Crillon".

webTitle: Turks take to streets over cash crisis

fields.headline: Turks take to streets over cash crisis
fields.trailText: Demonstrators took to city streets across Turkey for the third day in succession yesterday in protest against government inaction and crippling economic hardship, raising fears of social instability and prompting calls for calm from political leaders.
fields.body:
Demonstrators took to city streets across Turkey for the third day in succession yesterday in protest against government inaction and crippling economic hardship, raising fears of social instability and prompting calls for calm from political leaders.

"You're sucking our blood," read banners at one rally in Istanbul, "You're a disgrace to the country."

So far, the protests have been small, but anger seems to be growing, with trade unions planning massive protests later this month.

Union leaders say that more than half-a-million people have lost their jobs this year - most of them since the current economic crisis began in February.

What must worry the government is that many of the protesters do not appear to be particularly politicised - they have simply reached the point where they can no longer earn a living.

Shopkeepers who say they have gone for several days without making a single sale have been joined on the streets by taxi drivers who can no longer afford the price of fuel. Right across the country there are fears of a social explosion.

The Turkish lira has lost nearly half of its value against the dollar in the last six weeks, and the price of imported goods has soared. Petrol rose a further 20% earlier this week, and there were additional price rises in alcohol, sugar and tobacco yesterday.

The government has been bitterly criticised for failing to respond to the crisis quickly enough, but the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said yesterday that he would not resign.

One small businessman, stranded with a hard currency debt that he cannot pay, threw his cash register down the stairs of Mr Ecevit's ministry just as the prime minister left the building on Wednesday.

Mr Ecevit admits that there is an urgent need to help ordinary people. The government is trying to put together a new economic strategy to replace the IMF-backed anti-inflation programme which collapsed in February.

"Once the problem of domestic resources is solved, we'll be able to focus more effectively on the problems of tradesmen and craftsmen, workers and public employees," Mr Ecevit said.

It is not just the government which is facing angry criticism, however. When the main opposition leader, Recai Kutan, visited Istanbul's Covered Bazaar yesterday he, too, was heckled and jeered by irate tradesmen. Many Turks have lost confidence in the entire political class.

Job losses have come in all sectors of the economy. Some industries such as shoe-making and textiles have been decimated, while nearly a quarter of the 14,000 journalists and technicians employed in the Turkish media have been sacked as companies cut costs.

Widespread disgust at the way politicians have reacted to the crisis has intensified as people realise just how much Turkey's institutionalised corruption has contributed to their current plight. State-run banks, controlled by whichever political party is in power, have run up losses of about £14bn, largely by handing out bad loans in return for political favours.

"We don't trust any of them any more," said one Istanbul shopkeeper, Mehmet Aktas, as he held up a placard saying, "Government Resign - Why should we?"

As the rumblings of social unrest have grown, so have constant rumours of a change of government. Last week, the National Security Council felt the need to issue a formal statement rejecting speculation that an "interim regime" of technocrats, backed by the military, might take over.

The current regime insists that there will be good economic news to report soon, as it tries to finalise a new deal with the IMF. International lenders want to be sure, though, that there is a real political will to change the system.

If far-reaching political and economic reforms are approved, economists believe a good recovery is possible within a couple of years. Many ordinary people, however, are wondering how they will make it through the next couple of weeks.

webTitle: Race plays key part in Peru's poll

fields.headline: Race plays key part in Peru's poll
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow's election could see the nation's first indigenous president
fields.trailText: Alejandro Toledo, the former shoe-shine boy who narrowly lost rigged elections in Peru a year ago, is expected to win tomorrow's presidential ballot despite widespread voter apathy.
fields.byline: Jane Diaz-Limaco  in Lima and  Alex Bellos
fields.body:
Alejandro Toledo, the former shoe-shine boy who narrowly lost rigged elections in Peru a year ago, is expected to win tomorrow's presidential ballot despite widespread voter apathy.

"Today is the start of a new era. The dark night of the dictatorship is over," Mr Toledo said in the closing speech of his campaign in a working-class district of Lima. Dressed in a sober grey suit and blue tie, he stood with his arms outstretched as tens of thousands of people chanted "Toledo president".

Mr Toledo was a symbol of resistance against the authoritarian 10-year regime of Alberto Fujimori, who is now in self-imposed exile in Japan. But after the political tumult of the past year - including street battles, political scandal and a presidential resignation - the overall mood in Peru is less than festive.

Polls show that about a quarter of the electorate have no idea who they will vote for. "I fear that the next government won't be able to finish its term," said Carlos Tapia, a veteran political analyst. "Expectations are too high, the economic restrictions are too tight and there's a lack of cohesion."

Mr Toledo has promised to revive the economy and create 500,000 jobs a year by pruning sales and employment taxes to revive demand. The US-trained economist is on course to take first place tomorrow but may not clinch the 50 per cent of votes he needs to win outright.

The real contest is for runner-up and a place in the second round, due to be fought in May or June. The centre-right congresswoman Lourdes Flores is running neck and neck with the leftwing former president Alan Garcia, who has risen phoenix-like from the ashes of his chaotic administration.

Ms Flores, who stands a chance of being Peru's first woman president, has run a campaign based on her personal integrity and administrative experience. She says that Mr Toledo's government plan is inconsistent and that only she offers "a guarantee against populism". But on the campaign trail, Ms Flores has looked uncomfortable in her frumpy trouser suits and garish spectacles. Her candidacy has also suffered from accusations that her alliance is peppered with technocrats from the Fujimori regime and rightwing members of the Catholic Opus Dei group.

The surprise of the election has been the remarkable comeback of the former president, Mr Garcia, who is returning to Peru after nearly nine years in exile. It is a testament to his political skills and, say critics, the short memory of Peruvians. His government brought hyperinflation of more than 7,000 per cent, food queues and spiralling guerrilla violence.

However, Mr Garcia is the most talented orator of the bunch and has mastered the populist touch, recording a music video of him singing a Peruvian waltz as part of his campaign. A Lima University poll put him at 23.5 per cent of valid votes and Ms Flores at 24.3.

Mr Toledo's campaign has been beset by a sex and drugs scandal. He is accused of testing positive for cocaine in late 1998 after spending the day with three unidentified women in a seedy hotel. He claims he was abducted by the intelligence service as part of a set-up to discredit him.

If elected, Mr Toledo, one of a family of 16 children of Andean-Indian descent, will become Peru's first democratically elected president with indigenous roots. Race has been a key factor in this election. Ms Flores is from Lima's white elite. A remark by her father that Mr Toledo was a "llama from Harvard" played in Mr Toledo's favour in a country where most people are of mixed race.

Mr Toledo, known as "El Cholo" (half-breed) in reference to his ethnic background, has often recalled his ancestry and his poor upbringing. As he made his closing address, supporters waved the rainbow-striped flag of the Inca empire.

He also paid homage to Pachacutec, the Inca leader known as the great builder who extended the empire. He has promised that if he wins he will hold his inauguration at Machu Picchu, the spectacular Inca site in the Andes.

He has promised that if he wins he will hold his inauguration at Machu Picchu, the spectacular Inca site in the Andes.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Croats attack peacekeepers
fields.body:
Croats attack peacekeepers

Bosnian Croat nationalists attacked international officials yesterday as they tried to take over a bank used to finance a separatist rebellion.

A spokesman for the international community's High Representative in Bosnia, Chris Bird, said the nationalists had staged riots as peacekeepers, international and local police began a joint action to put the bank under international control.

Reuters, Sarajevo

Bush's tax cuts lose support

The US Senate was due to inflict a political defeat on President George Bush last night over his $1,600bn (£1,000bn) tax cut plan.

Republican senate leaders said they no longer had the votes to stop the passage of a smaller $1,200bn plan, after two Republican senators decided to join 49 Democrats in support of the smaller tax cut package.

Martin Kettle, Washington

Girl, 9, takes gun to school

A nine-year-old girl was suspended after she brought a loaded handgun to her elementary school, authorities in Erie, Pennsylvania, said. She was not charged but prosecutors were considering charging her father.

AP, Erie.
