webTitle: France joins US attack on new Israeli settlement plan

fields.headline: France joins US attack on new Israeli settlement plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: France joined the US yesterday in condemning as provocative Israel's plan to expand Jewish settlement in the West Bank, a move that has incensed the Palestinians.
fields.body:
France joined the US yesterday in condemning as provocative Israel's plan to expand Jewish settlement in the West Bank, a move that has incensed the Palestinians.

The French rebuke to the government of the hardline rightwinger Ariel Sharon was unusually stark by diplomatic standards. It claimed Israel had lost direction since he took over last month.

As Israeli tanks and helicopter gunships hit Gaza, damaging a power station and a police post, a French foreign ministry spokesman, François Rivasseau, said: "This downward spiral leads to more violence, more destruction and more suffering. The Israeli government has taken a wrong turning."

He cited recent developments such as "the provocative announcement of the resumption of settlements in the occupied territories, the continuation of so-called extra-judicial murders, the military clashes in Gaza and attacks on the safety of negotiators."

France traditionally has been more inclined than other countries, especially Britain, to criticise Israel and take a more pro-Arab stance.

Egypt, too, expressed alarm over the prospect of Israel consolidating its hold on parts of the West Bank by auctioning land for a further 700 houses.

Palestinian leaders welcomed the US condemnation of the plan. The US state department called it provocative.

There are 200,000 Jews living in often isolated pockets dotted around the West Bank and Gaza, among more than 3m Palestinians, who view the settlement expansion as part of a gradual land grab that has been going on for more than 50 years.

The strategy of Mr Sharon, who initially pursued much the same policy as his predecessor, Ehud Barak, is becoming clearer. Whereas Mr Barak took reprisals for Palestinian attacks, Mr Sharon has opted for pre-emptive punitive strikes.

The aim appears to be to try to bomb the Palestinians back to the negotiating table.

Mr Sharon's spokesman, Raanan Gissin, said Israel will retaliate "relentlessly from now on and Palestinian security installations will be considered targets as long as security forces fail to prevent attacks on Israelis".

The Israeli internal security minister, Uzi Landau, said its forces should hit Palestinian targets "every day, hour after hour." He added: "The price we will exact from the Palestinian Authority will become intolerable."

In a hint of further assassinations by Israel, Mr Landau said Palestinian officials behind attacks on Israel are "not immune to Israeli attack" and that the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, should be declared a war criminal "as one who specialises in attacking babies and shelling villages".

An Israeli helicopter attack on Gaza overnight was followed at daybreak by Palestinian mortar attacks on the Israeli settlement of Netzarim, south of Gaza city. Israeli tanks returned fire.

There was also the by now almost ritual stone-throwing in Jerusalem by Palestinians returning from Friday prayers in the Old City. Injuries were minor.

But the tension in Jerusalem is set to rise after Mr Sharon's announcement on Thursday that he had asked his security agencies to make arrangements for Jews to visit the disputed religious site, known to Arabs as Haram-ash-Sharif and to Jews as Temple Mount.

Since the Palestinian uprising began, few other than Muslims have been allowed to visit the site.

Mr Arafat's office warned that the order would increase the cycle of violence in the region and called on Islamic officials "to prevent Israel from [taking] this destructive step and insulting the holy places".

In the West Bank, a leading Islamic militant killed in a boobytrapped phone explosion was buried in the town of Jenin. Eight men in white robes, meant to symbolise death shrouds of suicide bombers, carried the flag-draped body of Iyad Hardan through the streets, followed by some 5,000 mourners demanding revenge.

webTitle: Teamwork session that ended in murder charge

fields.headline: Teamwork session that ended in murder charge
fields.standfirst: Nine players at South African rugby club face trial for lynching black youth
fields.trailText: Nine players at South African rugby club face trial for lynching black youth.
fields.body:
Murder is the ultimate team building exercise. But for the men of the Noordelike rugby club the difficulty was not in the killing, which was over in minutes. The real test of loyalty was whether anyone would crack and reveal just what occurred on a Dendron farm two weeks ago, and the whereabouts of a corpse that had been found and lost by the police.

The Noordelike rugby club in Pietersburg has taken in a lot of new players recently. So when the squad met two Saturdays ago for a practice session it was as much about team-building as tactics.

After the practice, Riaan Botha invited a dozen of his team-mates back to the family farm to continue the bonding session. The group was made up of the sons of white farmers. Among those who took up the invitation were the established players - Johan Van Ravenstein, the club chairman; Jaco Hartslief, the match secretary; and two members of the club's executive, Ben Korff and Kobus Joubert, a lieutenant in the South African army. With them came some of the latest recruits including the youngest of the group, Francois Viljoen, who is just 19 years old. All those people named are charged with murder, along with Mike Adendorf, Corne Kloppers and William Boshoff.

The 13 men watched rugby on television and drank late into the evening. Four went home but the rest slept the night on the farm just outside Dendron, about 40 miles north of Pietersburg. The bonding continued on Sunday with a barbecue - a "braai" in South African parlance - a lot more beer and brandy. Riaan Botha produced a couple of rifles and suggested a little hunting later.

Tshepo Matloga and his cousins, Alex and Melford Motlokwane, did not know about the party just a few hundred yards away as they slipped through the fence with about 10 dogs on a hunting expedition. They were looking for hares to eat or to sell. The black teenagers were trespassing, but they were not carrying weapons and what they were poaching was of no value to the Botha family.

Alex Motlokwane still does not know what gave them away. Perhaps it was a dog barking, but it was not long before Mr Botha and friends abandoned their "braai" for the hunting rifles.

Dogs yelping

The first Motlokwane knew of the white men's presence was a shot and one of the dogs yelping. The teenager turned to run and felt a sudden heat in his arm as a bullet caught him.

"We just went there for fun, for hunting. I saw people loom across the field and then the bullets started flying. I don't know where they came from. We ran in all directions," he said. At home in gaMokgehle village, Motlokwane's sister prompts him. "Did they call you a 'kaffir'? Did they say they wanted to kill you?" she asks. "They were saying nothing. They were just shooting," he said.

Motlokwane kept running. Another bullet hit his hand and a third one caught his ribs. Motlokwane glanced around for his cousins. One had disappeared but Tshepo Matloga was trying to get through the fence. Motlokwane turned and kept running until the shots died away.

"I slept on the farm because I didn't dare move in case they were still hunting me. In the morning I met a black woman who took me to another farm. The owner phoned the police," he said.

A policeman questioned Alex Motlokwane. He was not sure what to say.

"I didn't really know what had happened. All I could say was that these boers were shooting at us. I told him I was lucky to be alive and I didn't know if the others were alive or dead," he said.

The police decided to look for themselves. Just inside Botha's farm, close to the fence, they found a body. It was 19-year-old Tshepo Matloga.

A police inspector - who the authorities decline to name - led his men in search of other evidence. They discovered a trail of dead dogs, rifle cartridges and beer cans. When they returned to re-examine the corpse, it was gone.

Riaan Botha and his team-mates were in a panic. They reasoned that they had to get rid of Matloga's body because without a corpse who could ever prove there had been a murder?

The men discussed a few options but settled on dumping Matloga in the Arabie dam 140 miles away. It was a long drive but they concluded the dam was best because it was full of crocodiles which would dispose of the evidence.

The conspirators set off for an isolated part of the dam where one knew where to lay his hands on a boat. In the middle of the water, they lashed the corpse to an iron gatepost and tipped it over the side of the boat. So far as the men were concerned, that was the last time Tshepo Matloga would ever be seen.

It left the police with a problem. They had discovered a dead body but lost the evidence, for which an inspector has been charged with negligence. They knew who the victim was because his cousins had spelled out the story but they could only speculate as to who had killed him.

Still, Riaan Botha was wrong. In South Africa you can be tried for murder even when there is no body. The police arrested and charged eight of the men who were on the farm when Tshepo was killed. A ninth was added later.

But it was going to be a difficult case to prove, particularly without at least one confession. The two survivors had been too busy saving their own skins to pay attention to Matloga's fate so they could not swear to the circumstances of his death. No one could even say how he died. The presumption was that he was shot. And the police's evident incompetence would not help them provide a convincing case before a judge.

At first, none of the nine would talk but the silence was soon broken. After a few days, one of their number, who protested to the police that he did not take part in the killing, was persuaded to cooperate as an alternative to spending decades in jail for other people's crimes.

He broke ranks and confessed what had happened on that Sunday afternoon. He also told the police where to look for Tshepo Matloga's body. The police called in divers to search the dam but after a week they still had not found the corpse.

The black community said the white police inspector in charge was not interested in finding the body. He was replaced with a black officer. But it was luck that delivered the evidence. Botha and friends had been wrong about something else too. The Arabie dam is more than 100ft deep in parts. When they dumped Matloga's body overboard tied to the gate post it sank to a level below which crocodiles swim.

Just as the police were about to abandon the search, Matloga's rotting corpse slipped free from the gate post and floated to the surface. The police were ahead of the crocodiles on that day.

On the way to the mortuary Matloga's body was lost again, this time after being diverted to the wrong town. When it was recovered, a postmortem revealed that Matloga was beaten to death. He had a fractured skull and broken ribs.

To many people, that made the crime all the worse. It was not a stray bullet or one man with a gun who killed Matloga but a brutal attack in which some of the men participated but none apparently tried to stop.

On Thursday the nine appeared in court laughing. Their relatives appeared similarly buoyant. They seemed to expect that the Afrikaner magistrate would automatically free their men on bail. The crowd outside suspected the same thing and pressed their way into court. "May you burn in hell," shouted one elderly black woman. A man held a sign: "Nine boers, nine bullets".

Matloga's death touched a raw nerve in Dendron and Pietersburg where many black people believe little has changed since apartheid ended. Among the protesters demands at the court were for searches on other farms for people who have gone missing recently.

The province has a long history of racism. The Northern Transvaal, as it then was, was the only part of South Africa to vote against political reform in the all-white referendum a decade ago.

"These boers commit a heinous crime knowing their brothers will let them off. The boers still think they have the power," said Thomas Ramaloko, a mourner at Matloga's wake in gaMokgehle. "He died a terrible death. There's no doubt this was racially motivated."

The nine appeared in court again yesterday. This time there was none of the jollity. They looked cowed and scared. Outside the crowd threatened to lynch the men if they were freed on bail. Even the defence lawyers did not object to a few more days in police custody.

webTitle: Israel: The dove patrolling on the hawk's wing

fields.headline: The dove patrolling on the hawk's wing
fields.standfirst:
Israel's peacemaking foreign minister Shimon Peres believes his warring fellow septuagenarians Sharon and Arafat share wisdom and experience

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli foreign minister and Nobel peace laureate Shimon Peres is unapologetic that, having devoted so much of his life to the pursuit of peace, he has entered into a partnership with Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
The Israeli foreign minister and Nobel peace laureate Shimon Peres is unapologetic that, having devoted so much of his life to the pursuit of peace, he has entered into a partnership with Ariel Sharon. The partnership is only a month old, and the question that will come to dominate Israeli and Palestinian politics is how long the dove and hawk can work together.

In an interview with the Guardian he justified his presence in the cabinet on the grounds that by being there he could exert a moderating influence on Mr Sharon.

"I think I can be effective," he said. "I am not there to add water to the soup. Sharon knows my views and I have not changed."

Regardless of the increasing violence, much of it being inflicted by his own government, Mr Peres is optimistic about the chance of peace.

When serious negotiations eventually began in the Middle East, he said, "You will be surprised how fast it [peace and economic growth] can be."

Throughout a blood-stained career Mr Sharon's instinct has been to resort to force, and events since he became prime minister a month ago suggest that little has changed.

Mr Peres disputed this. "I have known Sharon for 50 years. We did not agree politically, but we kept on a personal relationship. It is the first time he is becoming prime minister. I do not think he would like to wind up his term as prime minister having the country in flame and blood."

Had Mr Sharon changed?

"I think the situation has changed. I think also that age does not necessarily have a negative impact on people. Arafat, Sharon and myself are together 232 years. It is a lot of time. It must have some promise of wisdom and experience."

While Mr Sharon punishes the Palestinians with an economic blockade, rocket attacks and assassinations, it is Mr Peres's job to be the acceptable international face of the government and to open channels to the Palestinians.

Symbols of peace

If Mr Sharon allows it, it will be through Mr Peres that peace negotiations will eventually resume.

He met his Palestinian counterpart in Athens on Wednesday, the first high-level contact between the two sides since Mr Sharon took office.

"After a long interruption, the mere meeting was a departure from the monopoly of guns," he said.

Mr Peres's office in a high-rise block in Tel Aviv is filled with symbols of peace: statues of women holding doves and olive branches; a buddha; and, in the most prominent spot of all, a blow-up of him signing the Oslo peace accord in 1993 with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Mr Sharon described Oslo as appeasement. Mr Peres plays down the insult. "Politicians have a collection of so many expressions, some of them right, some of them wrong. I think this expression is a wrong expression."

Had it been vanity, at the age of 77, to seek power one more time?

He replied: "I am sure the person who said it is free of vanity." But he added: "It is not a competition of beauty, not even a competition of politicians. It is a very serious situation. If I shall be immodest - you can call it vanity - I will put whatever experience I have to use in order to reopen negotiations. I do not believe the problems can be resolved by force."

Mr Peres spoke to the third of the ageing trio, Mr Arafat, by phone a few weeks ago, and he remains in touch through intermediaries, but they have not yet met since he became foreign minister.

Mr Sharon has called Mr Arafat a terrorist, and the interior minister, Uzi Landau, called him a war criminal yesterday. But Mr Peres said: "We know each other quite well and we are very careful not to turn a disagreement into an insult."

He had no such qualms about insulting the Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad, the London-trained ophthalmologist who replaced his father as president last year and last month likened Israel in its treatment of the Palestinians to the Nazis.

Until last year Israel was hoping to negotiate a peace deal with Syria, but Mr Peres confirmed that there was little chance of pursuing that track in the near future.

"I am not saying it has no future, but there is no present," he said.

"Bashar looks like he studied ophthalmology in London, but his vision is even more short-sighted than his father's. To make a speech comparing Israel to the Nazis! For that, believe me, you should not waste your time in London."

Step by step

In his talks with the Palestinians in Athens, Mr Peres made it clear that he favoured an interim agreement, a step by step approach, rather than the all-embracing one that the previous prime minister, Ehud Barak, was seeking.

He offered to relax the economic embargo on the Palestinian territories in return for their cooperation in reducing violence. His vision is the creation of a vibrant economy in the Middle East embracing Israel and its Arab neighbours

The Palestinians pressed for international observers, from the UN or the EU, to give protection from Israeli soldiers and settlers. Mr Peres was scathing.

"We have doubts about what these observers will do. Will they be allowed to visit the clandestine headquarters of Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Hizbullah to see where the terror is being originated?"

The only other peace plan around at present, put to the White House this week, is an initiative by Egypt and Jordan. Mr Peres ruled out any progress in that direction.

It was, he said, aimed at trying to put back on the table the final offer made this year by Mr Barak and Bill Clinton, an offer Mr Arafat had rejected.

"Once rejected, they no longer exist," Mr Peres said.

Did he rule out Israel simply leaving the West Bank and Gaza, an option considered but discarded by the previous government?

"The borders are very complicated. Time didn't stand still and what once was two eggs is now omelettes, which are hard to divide and organise."

There were other problems: the future of Jerusalem, the fate of the Palestinian refugees and the issue of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.

He said he had extracted a promise from Mr Sharon that there would be no new settlements, though it was announced on Thursday that existing ones would be expanded, which, to the Palestinians, is just as bad.

France and the US condemned the plan as inflammatory. But although most Israelis accept that eventually many settlers will have to leave the West Bank, Mr Peres refused to concede the point.

"The problem is not the settlements but the people who reside there. Take Hebron: there are 170,000 Palestinians and 400 Israelis. Why can't they live in peace? It is a matter of relations, not locations."

In Israel, he said, there were 6m Israelis and 1m Arabs: the implication being that they had learned to co-exist.

He rejected the right of Palestinian refugees to return to their former homes, saying it would mean the end of Israel, and he ruled out an apology for their loss of land.

"Why should Israel apologise? There was a Jewish quarter in Hebron in 1929. Most of them were assassinated in cold blood. You cannot pave history with apologies."

He added: "I think people who are busy with the future should not think of the past: it is so full of so many errors. History is a chain of errors. We have to concentrate on the history of the future, not the history of the past."

fields.bodyText: The Israeli foreign minister and Nobel peace laureate Shimon Peres is unapologetic that, having devoted so much of his life to the pursuit of peace, he has entered into a partnership with Ariel Sharon. The partnership is only a month old, and the question that will come to dominate Israeli and Palestinian politics is how long the dove and hawk can work together. In an interview with the Guardian he justified his presence in the cabinet on the grounds that by being there he could exert a moderating influence on Mr Sharon. "I think I can be effective," he said. "I am not there to add water to the soup. Sharon knows my views and I have not changed." Regardless of the increasing violence, much of it being inflicted by his own government, Mr Peres is optimistic about the chance of peace. When serious negotiations eventually began in the Middle East, he said, "You will be surprised how fast it [peace and economic growth] can be." Throughout a blood-stained career Mr Sharon's instinct has been to resort to force, and events since he became prime minister a month ago suggest that little has changed. Mr Peres disputed this. "I have known Sharon for 50 years. We did not agree politically, but we kept on a personal relationship. It is the first time he is becoming prime minister. I do not think he would like to wind up his term as prime minister having the country in flame and blood." Had Mr Sharon changed? "I think the situation has changed. I think also that age does not necessarily have a negative impact on people. Arafat, Sharon and myself are together 232 years. It is a lot of time. It must have some promise of wisdom and experience." While Mr Sharon punishes the Palestinians with an economic blockade, rocket attacks and assassinations, it is Mr Peres's job to be the acceptable international face of the government and to open channels to the Palestinians. He met his Palestinian counterpart in Athens on Wednesday, the first high-level contact between the two sides since Mr Sharon took office. "After a long interruption, the mere meeting was a departure from the monopoly of guns," he said. I think this expression is a wrong expression." Had it been vanity, at the age of 77, to seek power one more time? He replied: "I am sure the person who said it is free of vanity." fields.headline: Hillary says: I won't run
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton has ruled out ever running for US president in spite of support among American Democrats for another Clinton in the White House.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton has ruled out ever running for US president in spite of support among American Democrats for another Clinton in the White House.

After giving a speech in New York, the state senator was asked whether she had ruled out a presidential campaign in the next two elections "and beyond". Her answer - "yes" - was the most emphatic statement she has made on the subject since becoming a US senator last November.

Mrs Clinton has previously said that she intends to focus on her existing job for its six-year term, prompting speculation that she would run for the top job in 2008. But her answer to the question posed by the New York Post suggests that she intends to remain as a senator for even longer.

During an earlier speech, she had offered a less emphatic statement when asked the same question. "There's a lot of good opportunities out there for women, but that's not something I am going to be doing," she said.

A spokeswoman for Mrs Clinton downplayed reports that her comments had surprised members of her own staff by saying: "She has always said that she is not running for president." Mrs Clinton denied her presidential ambitions during her campaign for the Senate amid suggestions that she would leave her seat early.

Mrs Clinton inspires loyalty and loathing among Americans but in at least one recent poll in Iowa, an important state for presidential selection races, she stood in second place to the former vice-president Al Gore among Democrat supporters.

Her 20-minute speech to the American Society of Newspaper Editors focused on her objections to proposals put forward by the Bush administration and her reasons for writing a memoir of her time in the White House.

She suggested that the book, with its fee of $8m, was an attempt to understand her tumultuous eight years in the White House. "I sometimes don't know how to cover my own life," she said. "I think I'm writing this book so I can just understand my own life."

Her stint in the White House included her husband's impeachment trial after lying about his affair with an intern as well as her own abortive attempt to reform America's healthcare system.

fields.headline: Skinned alive: seal cull shocks vets
fields.standfirst: Thousands of animals are suffering a long, painful death in Canada's annual hunt, a new report claims
fields.trailText: Thousands of animals are suffering a long, painful death in Canada's annual hunt, a new report claims.
fields.body:
It was once the cause célèbre of animal activists around the world. But for a decade, the annual Canadian seal hunt has managed to continue uninterrupted by claiming a new air of respectability and concern for the welfare of the animals.

Now a damning report from an international panel of wildlife vets is set to reignite demands for a crackdown by the Canadian authorities on barbaric killing methods used by the sealers.

The report, produced by the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW) and passed to the Guardian, concludes that the 2001 hunt is causing "considerable and unacceptable suffering" to the harp seal population of Canada's Atlantic coast.

The five eminent vets - two British, two American and one Canadian - who monitored last week's hunt in the Gulf of St Lawrence found that more than 40% of the seals caught were unlikely to have been unconscious, let alone dead, when they were skinned.

The Guardian has also learned that the Canadian Veterinary Medicine Association (CVMA), whose support for the hunt has been used by the Canadian government and the sealers in an attempt to persuade the public that it is humane, is considering demanding tougher welfare regulations in the light of the latest evidence of cruelty.

The organisation has already contacted Fisheries and Oceans Canada, the government department responsible for regulating the hunt, demanding that it stop citing the CVMA's support in media interviews and on its website.

Ian Robinson, one of the two British vets on the panel, said: "The Canadian government insists that this is an animal production industry like any other. They say that it might not be pretty, but basically it is just like any abattoir except on the ice. But we found obvious levels of suffering which would not be tolerated in any other animal industry in the world."

Mr Robinson, a Norfolk-based RSPCA vet with 10 years' experience treating large marine mammals, added: "We accept that the hunt is going to continue and we are not condemning the sealers out of hand. But we want to see tough regulations, enshrined in legislation and enforced, to avoid this suffering."

According to official records, more than 91,000 harp seals were killed during last year's Canadian hunt, which is the only commercial mammal hunt in the world to take place in spring, at the height of the birthing season. A further 100,000 were caught in the Greenland hunt, which is almost completely unregulated.

The killing of newborn seals - those that still have their white fur - is outlawed, but because the animals lose their white coats just 12 days after birth, up to 90% of those caught in the Canadian hunt are between two weeks and one year old.

The new evidence is unlikely to lead to the hunt being banned, but opponents hope that it will at least force the Canadian government to act to prevent suffering. Each year, animal welfare charities document instances of cruelty but prosecutions have been rare.

The vets carried out postmortem examinations on 76 seal carcasses left behind on the ice after being skinned, and their findings have shocked even the most hardened anti-hunt campaigners.

Examinations of the skulls revealed that 17% showed no signs of any cranial injury which would have caused the animal to be unconscious when its pelt was removed. A further 25% showed only minimal or moderate signs of injury which the vets conclude would also have been unlikely to cause unconsciousness.

The panel also reviewed video evidence of this year's and previous hunts. It found that in almost 80% of kills recorded, no effort was made by the hunter to check that the seals were unconscious, while in 40% of cases, the hunter left the animal on the ice before returning to club it a second time, suggesting that it was conscious and suffering in the meantime.

"Based on our observations, it is obvious that there is a tremendous lack of consistency in the treatment of each seal, and the existing regulations are neither respected nor enforced," the report says.

Humane killing

In their report, the vets say that there is only one process for ensuring the humane killing of a seal. It must be rendered unconscious with a single blow or shot, the corneal reflex should be checked by poking it in the eyes to ensure that it is unconscious, and the seal should then be bled immediately. This is standard practice in abattoirs.

"Any method for killing a seal which does not allow for the above process of stunning, checking and bleeding to be performed has an enormous potential to create suffering and is therefore unacceptable." the report says.

It continues: "As this process cannot be followed in open water, we consider that shooting seals in open water can never be humane. Any method of taking a seal which requires the seal to be recovered by gaffing or hooking before the process can be followed can never be humane."

Monitors at this year's hunt have documented dozens of examples of cruelty, from seals being hooked and dragged across the ice while still alive for skinning, to others being shot in the water and dragged by hooks on to the ice, with no attempt made to check for unconsciousness.

Rick Smith, the Canadian director of IFAW, told the Guardian: "The most valuable thing about this report is that it puts numbers to the cruelty being suffered. Even after five years monitoring the hunt, the results shocked me."

Support for the seal hunt among the Canadian public hinges on government claims that it is humane. A government survey last year showed that 54% of citizens were initially opposed to the hunt. But when they were assured that the hunting was carried out humanely, almost 70% voiced support.

Fisheries and Oceans Canada last night brushed aside the findings. Ken Jones, resource manager for the Atlantic region, said: "The findings do not match with our experience at all.

"We have had CVMA vets out on the ice and all the skulls they have found have severe fractures, suggesting a quick death."

There are clears signs, however, that the CVMA's attitude is changing. Last weekend, the organisation's animal welfare committee met in Toronto to discuss the new report.

Bob van Tongerloo, a member of the committee and executive director of the Canadian Federation of Humane Societies, said: "My understanding is that the CVMA will announce that it is no longer in a position to give its support to the hunt. That decision will be crucial to how the government handles the hunt in future."

Hunting on the up

 The official harp seal quota for 2001 is 275,000. Such a quota would leave seal numbers 20,000 short of the level needed to sustain the population, which has led opponents to accuse the Canadian government of sanctioning a cull.

 In 2000, 91,602 harp seals were reported killed in Canada; 93% were less than one year old. Ten hooded seals were killed.

 A harp seal can be legally killed as soon as it has begun to moult its white hair, around 12 days after birth. As a result, roughly 80% of the seals killed in the commercial hunt are 'young of the year' - between approximately 14 days and one year old.

 The annual Greenland catch of harp seals has been increasing in recent years and is now reported to exceed 100,000 animals.

 A recent study in the scientific journal Marine Mammal Science concluded that in 1998 the actual number of harp seals killed was somewhere between 406,258 and 548,903. This compares with the 282,070 animals reported landed by the Canadian government in the same period.

fields.headline: So easily led
fields.standfirst:
Charlie the sniffer dog
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Poor Sophie Rhys-Jones; it was a mistake any of us could have made. Arab sheikhs and Fleet Street hacks; I'm always getting those two mixed up.
fields.body:
Poor Sophie Rhys-Jones; it was a mistake any of us could have made. Arab sheikhs and Fleet Street hacks; I'm always getting those two mixed up. Perhaps when the Islamic dignitary knocked back eight pints of lager, three rum and cokes and a tequila slammer she might have suspected he was not the strictest of Muslims, but apart from that there was nothing to suggest that he was an undercover tabloid journalist.

He'd seemed so charming as well, what with that attractive microphone-shaped brooch that he'd given her. He'd insisted on pinning it on to her lapel himself, while he chatted about what a TESTING! TESTING! time she must have had recently. And after that it was just the usual small talk that you would expect to have with an unknown business acquaintance.

"So luv, tell us about Charles and Camilla, what's the dirt on them?"

"Oh well, about their secret marriage plans..."

Then the bloke holding the boom microphone over her head cut in.

"Hang on a mo', I could hear a plane overhead, can we go again?"

"Sorry Sophie luv, can we take that again - and would you mind undoing a couple of buttons on your blouse and leaning forwards towards that cleaning lady there, the one holding that camera-shaped duster!"

"Oh ya, of course!"

Poor, poor Sophie. How is she supposed to know about public relations, she's just an ordinary director of a PR company. She must learn the cautious discretion of more experienced members of the royal household like, er, the Duke of Edinburgh.

Sophie's royal career got off to a bad start when she was made the countess of a fictional place that she'd got from one her O-level English set texts. And that was only after she'd been told she couldn't call herself the Duchess of Narnia. Since then she has been cast as the poor man's Princess Diana, a minor royal look-alike who they turn to now that the original is no longer available. Just as Abba have Bjorn Again, and Hear'say have Near'say, the Princess of Wales has a tribute royalin Sophie Rhys-Jones.

She hasn't had the relentless press coverage of her predecessor - now they don't bother to build them up before they knock them down. But for a pack of newshounds desperate to use the foot-in-mouth gag for the thousandth time this story was irresistible. And what amazing gaffes they were!

She described the Queen Mother using the words "old" and "lady". I was a little taken aback at the level of outrage that this provoked. Maybe I missed something and I'm the only person in the country who hadn't heard the announcement that Britain's favourite granny was in fact a 23-year-old man.

She referred to William Hague as "deformed" - presumably because he hasn't got her husband's full head of hair and dashing good looks. And Tony Blair was far too "presidential" said Sophie, as the royal family demonstrated once again why presidents are preferable to kings, queens and countesses of Borsetshire. And all this in a week when her husband was in trouble for trying to drum up work for his failing TV company in a royal engagement with the Sultan of Brunei. In Edward's defence he didn't actually realise it was the Sultan of Brunei - he thought it was a reporter from the Sunday Sport.

Of course in any other organisation such inappropriate behaviour would result in demotion or dismissal, but somehow the royal family has managed to cling on to outmoded industrial practices. Well the time has passed when you could expect to have a job for life just because you happen to be monarch. The government should introduce performance-related pay for the Windsors; there should be an official regulatory body who could close down or promote various members according to how well they were doing in the new royal family league tables.

"We're sorry Sophie but we are demoting you from countess."

"Oh dear, so what will I be?"

"Um, well, we're not quite sure, yet; is it a baroness or is that just above a viscountess?"

"Er, dunno, isn't that the same as a female marquis?"

"Look, we'll have to get back to you, your royal er, somethingness."

The more Sophie and Edward embarrassed themselves, the more their pay would be cut, the harder they would try and use their royal connections to earn a few more quid. US internet users could subscribe to Sophie-cam, a 24-hour live web cast from inside the royal bathroom. Edward could set up salacious 0897 royal chatlines, giving premium-rate thrills on such subjects as "my brother's mistress", "older women" or "my sister's three-hour ride".

Of course, this will never be allowed to happen. To put an end to the crass commercialism that is infecting the royal family, the Queen has already decided that Edward and Sophie must be distanced from Buckingham Palace. She has taken advice on the most dignified and constitutional way in which this might be done. So, tune in tonight for Royalty Big Brother and watch Sophie and Edward get voted out. Calls cost £1 a minute.

TESTING! time she must have had recently. And after that it was just the usual small talk that you would expect to have with an unknown business acquaintance. "So luv, tell us about Charles and Camilla, what's the dirt on them?" "Oh well, about their secret marriage plans..." Then the bloke holding the boom microphone over her head cut in. "Hang on a mo', I could hear a plane overhead, can we go again?" "Sorry Sophie luv, can we take that again - and would you mind undoing a couple of buttons on your blouse and leaning forwards towards that cleaning lady there, the one holding that camera-shaped duster!" "Oh ya, of course!" Poor, poor Sophie. How is she supposed to know about public relations, she's just an ordinary director of a PR company. She must learn the cautious discretion of more experienced members of the royal household like, er, the Duke of Edinburgh. Sophie's royal career got off to a bad start when she was made the countess of a fictional place that she'd got from one her O-level English set texts. And that was only after she'd been told she couldn't call herself the Duchess of Narnia. Since then she has been cast as the poor man's Princess Diana, a minor royal look-alike who they turn to now that the original is no longer available. Just as Abba have Bjorn Again, and Hear'say have Near'say, the Princess of Wales has a tribute royalin Sophie Rhys-Jones. She hasn't had the relentless press coverage of her predecessor - now they don't bother to build them up before they knock them down. But for a pack of newshounds desperate to use the foot-in-mouth gag for the thousandth time this story was irresistible. And what amazing gaffes they were! She described the Queen Mother using the words "old" and "lady". I was a little taken aback at the level of outrage that this provoked. Maybe I missed something and I'm the only person in the country who hadn't heard the announcement that Britain's favourite granny was in fact a 23-year-old man. She referred to William Hague as "deformed" - presumably because he hasn't got her husband's full head of hair and dashing good looks. And Tony Blair was far too "presidential" said Sophie, as the royal family demonstrated once again why presidents are preferable to kings, queens and countesses of Borsetshire. And all this in a week when her husband was in trouble for trying to drum up work for his failing TV company in a royal engagement with the Sultan of Brunei. In Edward's defence he didn't actually realise it was the Sultan of Brunei - he thought it was a reporter from the Sunday Sport. Of course in any other organisation such inappropriate behaviour would result in demotion or dismissal, but somehow the royal family has managed to cling on to outmoded industrial practices. Well the time has passed when you could expect to have a job for life just because you happen to be monarch. The government should introduce performance-related pay for the Windsors; there should be an official regulatory body who could close down or promote various members according to how well they were doing in the new royal family league tables. "We're sorry Sophie but we are demoting you from countess." "Oh dear, so what will I be?" "Um, well, we're not quite sure, yet; is it a baroness or is that just above a viscountess?" "Er, dunno, isn't that the same as a female marquis?" "Look, we'll have to get back to you, your royal er, somethingness." The more Sophie and Edward embarrassed themselves, the more their pay would be cut, the harder they would try and use their royal connections to earn a few more quid. US internet users could subscribe to Sophie-cam, a 24-hour live web cast from inside the royal bathroom. Edward could set up salacious 0897 royal chatlines, giving premium-rate thrills on such subjects as "my brother's mistress", "older women" or "my sister's three-hour ride". Of course, this will never be allowed to happen. To put an end to the crass commercialism that is infecting the royal family, the Queen has already decided that Edward and Sophie must be distanced from Buckingham Palace. She has taken advice on the most dignified and constitutional way in which this might be done. So, tune in tonight for Royalty Big Brother and watch Sophie and Edward get voted out. webTitle: MoD study warns of plastic bullet risk

fields.headline: MoD study warns of plastic bullet risk
fields.standfirst:
New weapon for police and army likely to cause severe head injuries and lead to more ricochet casualties, say researchers

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A new plastic bullet to be issued to the police and army before the main marching season in Northern Ireland is likely to lead to more injuries from ricochets and more severe damage if they strike the head, according to research conducted by Ministry of Defence scientists.
fields.body:
A new plastic bullet to be issued to the police and army before the main marching season in Northern Ireland is likely to lead to more injuries from ricochets and more severe damage if they strike the head, according to research conducted by Ministry of Defence scientists.

A hitherto unnoticed report in the Commons library warns of serious injuries the bullet could inflict, including a risk of the projectile being "retained in the head".

The report on the new bullet - the L21A1, to be issued to British police, the RUC, and the army from June 1 - was drawn up by the defence scientific advisory council.

It describes the bullet as "lighter, faster, aerodynamically shaped and manufactured from a stiffer material". When soldiers or police aim below the rib cage, as they will be instructed to do, it is likely to "increase the incidence of some intra-abdominal injuries" - namely, injuries that are not life threatening.

This particular conclusion of the research was seized on by Jack Straw in a statement to MPs earlier this week.

The report also says that, despite the concern expressed about ricochets, the total number of life threatening head injuries is likely to be reduced. However, in cases where the bullets did hit the head, it says, they would cause more serious injuries than existing plastic bullets.

The report reveals that arguments between the MoD and the police led to guidelines and requirements being changed four times. And it warns: "It may be difficult to maintain the acceptable incidence of injury at the low level currently envisaged, in all operational as distinct from test and training circumstances."

Although designed to be more accurate than existing plastic bullets - or baton rounds, as they are officially called - the report admits that in practice "the probability of ricochet within normal operational range of batons will be higher with the L21A1".

The report also warns: "The severity of injuries to the brain is likely to be greater with the L21A1, due to higher pressures on the brain, and greater penetration of the projectile."

The consequences of "a deliberate or inadvertent elevation of the mean point of impact of the L21A1," the report continues, "will have more serious medical implications to the target."

Labour MP Kevin McNarama last night described the plastic bullet as an "unstable weapon of death" and potential child killer. He attacked the MoD for "defying the recommendations of Patten and pushing ahead with a secret plan to re-equip the army and police in Northern Ireland with a new generation of deadly plastic bullets."

Chris Patten's recommendations on policing stopped short of calling for plastic bullets to be banned but said officers should be better equipped with alternatives, and substantial investment put into researching safer options.

Families of those killed by plastic bullets have condemned the introduction of a new type of baton round.

Fourteen people, eight of them children, have been shot dead and hundreds injured in Northern Ireland with the current type of plastic bullet since it was first issued in 1973, as a supposedly safer alternative to the rubber bullet, which has claimed three lives.

But critics claim any plastic bullet is a lethal weapon, which should be banned, and that soldiers and police have consistently broken guidelines, firing at people's heads from close by, rather than below the waist from more than 20 metres away.

"Those who have never seen them think they are harmless, like throwing jelly," said Clara Reilly, of Belfast-based Relatives for Justice. "But they're several inches long, rock hard and they come out of a gun at 160 miles an hour.

"They kill and they do horrendous damage. People have been blinded by them, had to have steel plates inserted in their heads. They have caused brain damage, which has altered people's personalities. It's a life sentence for the whole family of those injured."

Ms Reilly also claimed they had often been used in non-riot situations to intimidate nationalists. Of the 17 people killed by plastic and rubber bullets, 16 were Catholic, one a Protestant.

"We don't want them used on anyone but it is significant they have never been fired during serious riots in England and their use against loyalists at Drumcree has not been as extensive as against nationalists," she said.

"They don't stop riots, they start them, such is the anger generated when people are hurt by them. If young nationalists join the new police service, will they be happy training to use plastic bullets, knowing the misery such weapons have caused their in their community?

"There is no accountability whatsoever. Millions have been paid in compensation to the families of those killed and injured by plastic bullets yet not one member of the security forces has ever been convicted of any offence regarding their use.

"The British government has ignored the European parliament's call to ban them. We accept there is sometimes a need for crowd control but there are alternatives, like water cannon, which was effective at Drumcree and during the European football championships."

Bernadette Devlin's 14-year-old sister, Julie Livingstone, was killed by a plastic bullet in west Belfast in May 1981.

"Twenty years on, after the Good Friday agreement, the Patten report, and all the talk about commitment to human rights, I can't believe instead of abolishing them, they're actually introducing a new kind," she said. "They might as well use live rounds."

Julie, the youngest of 13 children, was returning home with a friend when soldiers opened fire on a group of women who had gathered to say prayers and bang bin lids after the death of IRA hunger striker Francis Hughes. She was shot in the head and died the next day in hospital.

"Julie was terrified of the police and army," said another sister, Elizabeth McCurry. "She wouldn't have been anywhere near a riot. These soldiers had just driven away from an area where they had been under attack and they were all hyped up, but there was nothing threatening happening where Julie was.

"We still feel aggrieved the soldiers did not even have to attend the inquest to explain what happened. I wonder does the man who shot her ever think about the 14-year-old whose life he took?"

The secretary of state, John Reid, said research into alternatives was under way and he still wanted to eliminate plastic bullet use but it was too soon.

"The government would be delighted if the public order situation improved sufficiently to remove the need to resort to baton rounds at all," he said. "The whole community has a contribution to make to achieve that aim but sadly we are not there yet."

webTitle: Royals to get business code after Sophie fiasco

fields.headline: Royals to get business code after Sophie fiasco
fields.standfirst: Lord chamberlain to draft new rules after embarrassment at palace over attempt by countess to clinch 'deal' with undercover reporter
fields.trailText: Lord chamberlain to draft new rules after embarrassment at palace over attempt by countess to clinch 'deal' with undercover reporter
fields.body:
Guidelines regulating how members of the royal family conduct themselves in business are to be drawn up by the former Tory minister Lord Luce, the lord chamberlain of the royal household, following the Sophie Wessex affair.

Buckingham Palace insiders accept that new rules are necessary following the revelations of ill-advised personal comments about political leaders and members of the royal family by Sophie, Countess of Wessex, in pursuit of a business deal for her public relations company, and allegations that her husband Prince Edward exploited an official visit to the far east for his Ardent film production company.

With the palace anxious to draw a line under the affair, while declining to confirm the move, the message yesterday was that lessons would have to be learned. An official said: "After this unfortunate upset, it is important that there is a clear distinction drawn in future between obligations and royal duties and pursuing a wider career."

The lord chamberlain is in charge of the royal household and would be seen as the obvious candidate to set the rules. The couple have been interviewed by the Queen's private secretary Sir Robin Janvrin.

Top of the agenda for Lord Luce, the patrician former foreign officer minister - one of the team who resigned in 1982 for not foreseeing Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands - will be how far and in what circumstances members of the family can exploit their connections.

The countess attended a meeting at the Dorchester hotel with a News of the World reporter disguised as an arab sheikh to close a supposed business deal with her public relations company RJH.

She is alleged to have described Tony Blair as too presidential, his wife as "horrid, absolutely horrid, horrid, horrid", and William Hague as deformed and to have made disparaging remarks about the Queen and Queen Mother.

But there are also persistent allegations that she has boasted to clients of being able to secure the attendance of members of the royal family at functions.

The countess has been criticised by palace insiders, from within public relations circles and even by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, for her naivety. The prince and his wife ran a media gauntlet in Camberley, Surrey, yesterday when they fulfilled an engagement to tour a new centre for the disabled. They maintained resolute smiles and ignored invitations to discuss their current plight in response to shouted questions from journalists.

Confronted by a barrage of cameramen and a man claiming to be from the Sun, dressed up in arab costume, the prince noted to his wife: "There are slightly more people here than anticipated."

In the centre, the countess said to John Wilkins, a 50-year-old patient having reflexology on his feet: "It can be quite painful while it's being done to you." This turned out to be a reference to massage.

Reactions from the crowd to the couple's plight appeared to be mixed. Berni Young, a patient at the centre, said: "She's very beautiful and charming. I was very impressed with her, especially after the recent press. She's very nice and friendly." But another said: "She's made rather a big faux-pas hasn't she, poor girl?"

At the end of the worst week for the royal family since the death of Princess Diana, officials are braced for the prospect of more revelations on Sunday.

They will probably centre on comments made by Sophie's business partner Murray Harkin to the News of the World reporter Mazher Mahmood.

Mr Harkin again refused to stand down from RJH Public Relations yesterday, telling a reporter: "There is absolutely no question of me not staying on. Why should I walk away from a successful business we have spent years building up?"

fields.headline: UN asks for Ulster inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The government is under attack for not responding to the concerns of a UN human rights official who yesterday called for judicial inquiries into alleged security force collusion in the terrorist murders of two Northern Ireland solicitors.
fields.body:
The government is under attack for not responding to the concerns of a UN human rights official who yesterday called for judicial inquiries into alleged security force collusion in the terrorist murders of two Northern Ireland solicitors.

Param Cumaraswamy, special rapporteur on the independence of lawyers and judges, wants public investigations into the deaths of Pat Finucane, shot in his Belfast home in 1989, and Rosemary Nelson, blown up by a car bomb in Lurgan, Co Armagh, in 1999. Both were Catholics who had represented high-profile republicans.

Loyalist paramilitaries said they carried out the killings but no one has been convicted for either.

There have been persistent claims about cooperation between the security forces and the terrorists responsible, and the solicitors' families and supporters think independent inquiries are the only way to uncover the truth.

A team headed by Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens, who has carried out two previous investigations into similar allegations, is currently examining these claims.

The UN official also revealed that Tony Blair had not answered a letter he sent him last September, in which he said there was reason to believe the authorities knew Mr Finucane's life was in danger. He told Mr Blair in the letter that the only way to deal with the collusion allegations was by public inquiry.

fields.headline: Las Alpujarras
fields.trailText: Starting from Capileira, we followed a mule track past the cherry blossom. High above, and covered in snow, was Mulhacen, at 3482m the highest mountain in the Sierra Nevada. We descended to Rio Poqueira. A herd of goats was moving down a precipitous slope with sure-footed brilliance. Above the river we paused at an old threshing floor. The hillside above held a large flock of Samuel Palmer sheep, dappled in sun and shade, who followed their leader around - the most experienced with a bell - to a constant ring of being.
fields.body:
Starting from Capileira, we followed a mule track past the cherry blossom. High above, and covered in snow, was Mulhacen, at 3482m the highest mountain in the Sierra Nevada. We descended to Rio Poqueira. A herd of goats was moving down a precipitous slope with sure-footed brilliance. Above the river we paused at an old threshing floor. The hillside above held a large flock of Samuel Palmer sheep, dappled in sun and shade, who followed their leader around - the most experienced with a bell - to a constant ring of being.

A little puppy dog suddenly rushed up to welcome us in hope of food. We heard the bleating of lambs. Eventually the shepherd appeared, a tall, blue-eyed Spaniard. He smiled at our concern about the lambs before going into an old stone building to emerge with two black ones - twins that were born the night before.

Astonished, we asked more. Having drunk as much of the ewe's first milk as they could manage, the lambs had apparently ingested their required amount of antibodies and could be left while the mother renewed her strength with more grazing. Every night all the sheep had to be shut in because the heavy dews made the pasture too acid for safety. The sheep would blow up if they breakfasted. There were two larger dogs to help the shepherd, along with the apprentice tumbler. They stayed with the sheep all day as the terrain was so dangerous.

In the valley we moved through exuberant birdsong, red poppies, blue bergamot, yellow shiny buttercups, the scent of thyme and new growth, flowers bursting out everywhere to earn their summer siesta.

In Orgiva we found the human experience of togetherness: a fiesta. At exactly noon, fireworks deafened outside, while the inside of the church vibrated to the loudest brass and drums possible. The crucifixion was lowered from its place behind the altar to the chancel steps by men in their working clothes. The next day, at exactly 6pm, it emerged upright on a wooden platform, carried by men in black suits, followed by an image of the Virgin adorned in beauty. Ears trembled with explosions and bands. At midnight fireworks filled the skies.

fields.headline: Those aren't lakes - they're art
fields.standfirst: Artist Anselm Kiefer's estate in Provence isn't just his home, finds  Alan Riding. It's also his latest work
fields.trailText: Artist Anselm Kiefer's estate in Provence isn't just his home, finds Alan Riding. It's also his latest work.
fields.body:
The metal gate at the entrance to Anselm Kiefer's 50-acre property outside the Provençal town of Barjac bears witness to his desire for privacy. At 55, Kiefer is considered one of the most important artists of his generation, yet he does not court publicity. "I never wanted to be a star," the German artist explains. "I want to communicate through my work. I never want to have photographs of myself in the press. I am not important. All I want is to do something that goes through me and results in something."

Over the past 20 years, the artist's immense paintings and sculptural installations, many inspired by his research into German and Jewish memory and myths, have been widely exhibited in Europe and the US. To his satisfaction, a Kiefer painting is now far more recognisable than Kiefer himself.

The size of his hilltop property, with its three 19th-century stone buildings, reflects the scale of his works. For his recent acclaimed show in the chapel of the Hpital de la Salpetrière in Paris, he did six paintings more than 30ft high. These and other wall-size works fill two cavernous studios and nearby warehouses. Beside a large courtyard, there are stacks of lead sheets, metal bars, terracotta and other material used in his paintings.

"I remember that at school we had two or three days for all these 30 years. It was not enough. I had no complete idea of what had happened. Occupations was just a starting point. Then I read a lot."

His research led him deeper into Goethe, into German philosophy, into the myths that inspired Wagner's opera cycle, Der Ring des Nibelungen. He now had ample motivation for his work, but the intense paintings that followed earned him the reputation in Germany of being a gloomy and melancholic artist. Jewish collectors in the US were the first to understand and buy his work.

A more powerful connection to Judaism was established when he visited Israel in 1984. "I was born into a very Catholic family, so the Judaism in the Bible was very familiar to me," he says. "But it really started when I was in Jerusalem. I was on the Mount of Olives, standing there, looking at the city and the gates, and it struck me that Jesus went through the gates. It was so striking to be there physically, immediately." The experience led him to study Jewish mythology and to create an entirely new body of work.

Was his attraction to Jewish mysticism also a product of German guilt? "There is what you call 'German guilt'," he agrees. "But there is something else. I cannot imagine German culture without Judaism. Everything that makes German philosophy and poetry interesting to the world is a combination of Germany and Judaism. fields.headline: The king of comedy
fields.standfirst: In 1980, Peter O'Toole's Macbeth had audiences rolling in the aisles. Behind the scenes,  Timothy West looked on aghast, as he recalls in his new memoir
fields.trailText: In 1980, Peter O'Toole's Macbeth had audiences rolling in the aisles. Behind the scenes, Timothy West looked on aghast, as he recalls in his new memoir.
fields.body:
I was offered a few days on a film, Masada, in California, in which Peter O'Toole was starring as the Roman general. He told me his ideas about Macbeth - the production had been agreed before my recent appointment as temporary director of the Old Vic. Jack Gold was to direct the production. Peter was obviously full of enthusiasm for the project, and so was I. I had perfect confidence in Jack, and left California feeling quite happy about the immediate future.

On my return, I was shown the Macbeth contract, which had only just been returned by Peter's lawyers. I was astounded to see that O'Toole had been given total artistic control over the production. This arrangement is a sure recipe for dissent if not disaster. But Peter's lawyers would undoubtedly have come on strong if we tried to back out, and sue us for every penny we patently hadn't got.

The first note of doom was struck when Jack Gold came to see me, pleading to be released from his obligation as he had been offered a major film to direct. I set about looking for a replacement. Nobody jumped at the idea of directing a play over which they were effectively to have no control. Also, we had to find a designer. I immediately thought of Bob Crowley, whose work was always imaginative but could well be adapted to the simplified dictates of touring. He produced a model, and came to show it to us. Peter O'Toole had not done any Shakespeare since his Hamlet for the National in 1963, and had not taken into account the way in which Shakespearean stage design had become less descriptive and geared more towards flow and continuity of action.

"If it's a castle, where are the bloody crenellations?" he would ask. "If this is Lady Macbeth's bedroom, where is the bed?" Bob Crowley was turned down. Peter told us that his original conception of the play had involved the use of inflatable scenery. I looked blankly at Mick Wicks, our production manager, and Mick looked at the ceiling. "Inflatable scenery?" I ventured.

"Oh yes," Peter assured me. "I am a director of an Irish concern called La Botta Ltd, so named because an entire set, when deflated, can be packed into the boot of a car. I suggest I bring our designer over at my own expense, set him up in a rehearsal room for two weeks to build the set, and after that time we'll have a demonstration on stage. We have also designed a lighting rig using very small but very powerful lamps made of Campbell's soup tins, which can be operated from a transistorised panel on someone's lap, sitting in the stalls."

If he was having us on, he was keeping an admirably straight face. But the experiment wasn't going to cost us anything, and at the same time we'd quietly continue to pursue more conventional channels. So we said we would give it a try.

The Irish designer arrived, and installed himself in rehearsal room B with an enormous pack of black dustbin bags and some tins of adhesive, saying he required nothing from us except a bottle of Power's whiskey to be left outside his door every morning.

The promised demonstration was put off, but finally the genius announced that all was ready. Before the curtain rose, our ears were assailed by a noise as if of a gigantic vacuum cleaner operating at full-tilt. I leant over to Peter. "What' s that noise?" I asked.

"Air compressor," he said shortly. "We can deal with that."

The curtain rose to reveal a dimly lit collection of black plastic phalluses swaying in the wind. The general effect was of a blustery day during a refuse collection strike. Into the gloom, from behind one of these erections, emerged a young actor in a black cloak, shouting, above the noise of the compressor: "Thou Nature art my goddess . . ."

We were just beginning to be aware of the smell of burning oxtail soup, when I stood up and stopped the proceedings. I suggested to Peter that we all meet in my office, and without the bin-bag artist.

We sat down in silence; were there going to be excuses, explanation, justification? Not at all. Peter at once began shaking with merriment. "No, no, it was terrible," he gasped, and in relief that, for once, something had happened that we could agree on, we all collapsed into helpless laughter, crying with delight each time anybody remembered some fresh detail of the afternoon's disaster.

It was the last happy occasion I shared with Peter. I was not the right partner for him. What he thought he wanted was a complaisant business associate who could laugh with him, make rude jokes about subsidised theatre, join him in a barnstorming assault on an Old Vic audience that hadn't really existed since the time of Lilian Baylis, and miraculously meet all the bills out of the box office.

It would be wrong to dismiss these ideas as anachronistic and impractical. There is a lot to be said for the seasoned troupe going round the town halls, schools and local theatres, as the great Anew McMaster used to do in Ireland, delighting the populace with their vigorous accounts of the classics. If that was what Peter really wanted to do, I could have provided him, I think, with a framework in which to do it, and would have welcomed his company back into the Vic when they had finished their tour. But I had a shock when he told me the casting he proposed for such an enterprise.

"Meryl Streep is who I want for Lady Lauder [he pandered to the old theatrical superstition that it was bad luck - ho ho - to quote from this play, and always referred to it as 'Harry Lauder'], and John Gielgud as Duncan." He said that if it had been a film, those were the first people he would have approached for the parts. I pointed out that there was a world of difference between appearing in a feature film which would involve them for only a week or two for a considerable fee, and appearing night after night, not only in London but in Liverpool, Bristol, Leeds and Coventry, for a relative pittance.

"Well, they wouldn't have to do the tour," he replied.

"But they would, Peter." A cold sweat crept over me as I realised he had no idea of how the company worked. "That's what we're funded for, and the play will be in repertoire with The Merchant of Venice. Obviously I want as many people as possible to be in both plays."

"You must fight for your production, I'll fight for mine" was his reply and he stalked off.

In the end we came up with a more sensible list of possible Lady Macbeths, and he showed enthusiasm for Jane Lapotaire. I offered the part to her and she liked the idea. I told Peter the news. "Jane Lapotaire?" he retorted. "Oh, no. I want Frances Tomelty."

Frances Tomelty was duly engaged and gradually we began to assemble a cast.

Over the weeks, Peter had become convinced that myself and the rest of the organisation were out to sabotage his show. He refused to set foot in our office, referring to it as the Gas, Light and Coke Company.

We were still without a director or designer. He came up with the unusual suggestion of Bryan Forbes, the film producer and director. I didn't know when Bryan had last directed a play on the stage, but the main thing was that Peter actually got on with him; costume designers, assistant directors and stage management had one by one been sent packing as suspected agents of the Gas, Light and Coke Company and of its supremo, Miss Piggy (me).

I was forbidden the theatre during the rehearsal period, but insisted on my right to witness the first dress rehearsal.

I was shocked by what I saw. Peter looked as though he could give a perfectly good account of the part, if only he could surrender his own personality to Macbeth's. His verse speaking was quirky but intelligent and often exciting. Brian Blessed roared with laughter and radiated loyal good humour as Banquo, and Frances Tomelty gave her Thane attractive fierceness, but there was no evidence of any thought having been given to the play, and most of the other characters just stood around looking lost.

I listed a number of specific problems which it wouldn't take long to sort out. Bryan Forbes agreed with a lot of what I'd suggested, but said he would have to discuss it with Peter. I tried one last time to talk to Peter, but he wouldn't see me. Some form of self-protection was necessary for the company. There was the rest of the season to think of, and the autonomous identity of this one production had to be made clear to the funding bodies, to the touring theatre managers, and to patrons themselves. I therefore put together a brief statement, to be slipped into the theatre programme, saying that this one production was under the direct artistic control of Mr O'Toole, and that further productions in the season, by the Old Vic company, would include The Merchant of Venice. The text was circulated to our board, and to Peter's lawyer, and was approved.

The first night came and an eager public crowded into the auditorium; the great, the good, the knockers, the wellwishers, the ordinary public, God help them, the paparazzi. There was an air of real excitement: the opening of the new season, with a new and untried artistic director at the helm, and the first time Peter O'Toole had been on the London stage for 15 years.

As I stood dinner-jacketed and suicidal in the foyer, old friends passed me, smiling encouragingly. I managed a sickly return smile and watched, powerless to save the passengers as they pushed their way determinedly up the gangways of the Titanic.

The audience were at first bewildered by what they saw, then there were some giggles, and when Peter appeared after the murder drenched in blood from head to foot, there was a burst of laughter.

Peter, expert comedian that he is, waited at the top of the stairs for the laughter to subside before exclaiming, "I have done the deed," which brought the house down. From then on, right up to the final moment of the play when a nervous Dudley Sutton, as the victorious Macduff, retreated in terror before the superior swordplay of a Macbeth in modern baseball boots, not much could be taken seriously. I left before the curtain call, went round briefly to thank everyone as they came off stage - I didn't see Peter - and went home in despair.

The following morning I was woken at seven o'clock by a phone call from the London Evening Standard. Was I actually disowning the production? I said there had never been any question of my being asked to own it; that it had been understood from the outset to be Peter O'Toole's own production.

At lunchtime, out came the evening papers with the big headline, West Disowns Macbeth, on the front page. A lot of people would assume I had read the notices, panicked and tried to distance myself from the debacle. It would have been both tedious and impractical to try and explain the true circumstances, so I let it ride. I never saw Peter O'Toole's Macbeth again.


What the critics said

"A roaring-boy performance by Peter O'Toole that is about as subtle as a battering ram . . ."

"Like a British B-movie. . ."

"Three sexy Witches who, far from being wild and withered in their attire, look as if they shop at Fortnum and Mason's. . .

"Not so much downright bad as heroically ludicrous. . . "

"Like a blacksmith hammering on an anvil. . ."

"Hollywood at its most hilarious self-parody. . ."

"A cross between Bette Davis and Vincent Price. . . "


© Timothy West, 2001. This is an edited extract from his autobiography, A Moment Towards the End of the Play, published on 12 April by Nick Hern Books (£15.99). Timothy West is appearing with Prunella Scales in The External at Greenwich Theatre until 21 April and subsequently on tour.

fields.headline: Mud and guts
fields.trailText: That Aubrey Manning. He's forever scrabbling about in the dirt on the trail of some mystery. He might be attempting to find bits of the Amber Room, a bejewelled chamber given by the Prussians to Peter the Great then pinched by the Nazis, or questioning the authenticity of some supposedly prehistoric artefacts found in France. There are few things Aubrey won't do in his pursuit of knowledge.
fields.body:
That Aubrey Manning. He's forever scrabbling about in the dirt on the trail of some mystery. He might be attempting to find bits of the Amber Room, a bejewelled chamber given by the Prussians to Peter the Great then pinched by the Nazis, or questioning the authenticity of some supposedly prehistoric artefacts found in France. There are few things Aubrey won't do in his pursuit of knowledge.

He was on form in Talking Landscapes (BBC2). "What explains the trees?" he pondered in the first of a series dedicated to the exploration of the British countryside. First stop was the Weald in south-east England, and it wasn't long before he was up to his elbows in mud trying to "explain" this fascinating area. He had his own theories, of course, but most of them proved to be wrong. Every time he advanced another, an expert - usually in an anorak - came along and rained on his parade.

The Weald has had an eventful history. Cleared by Bronze Age Britons with their little axes, its woods grew back during "Dark Age confusion". They were chopped down again for the medieval iron industry and for shipbuilding under Henry VIII. The 19th century reprieved the Weald as wooden ships fell out of fashion and the iron industry slowly petered out. As Lewis Grassic Gibbon wrote, nothing endures but the land.

In his element - ie, mud - Aubrey clearly relished his role as the minging detective, bringing a genuine enthusiasm to what could be a rather dreary subject. So giddy is Aubrey - albeit in a restrained, thoughtful way - he almost makes you want to buy wellies and an anorak and go off for a jaunt in the countryside, breathe in the smell of wet leaves and feel the fresh air on your face. Almost.

(Talking of landscapes, the Weald has always sounded like something in need of a generous application of Savlon. Now I know it's derived from the Germanic word for forest, wald. You learn something every day.)

Malcolm in the Middle (BBC2) has been described as a real-life version of The Simpsons. It nearly is. The story of an eccentric lower-middle-class American family whose son Malcolm is a certifiable genius, it has shades of Roseanne, Married - With Children and The Wonder Years, only less schmaltz. After all, no one's mum in The Wonder Years ever shaved the dad's entire body.

Malcolm in the Middle is less universal than The Simpsons - it is very American, if you catch my meaning - but most enjoyable nonetheless. The cast is solid and capable and, in the title role, Frankie Muniz is extremely watchable. The show even avoids the cutesiness that afflicts so many programmes full of children. These kids play obnoxious exceptionally well; make of that what you will, though there could be a bit of Method going on here. Still, it's hard not to imagine showbiz mothers standing in the wings cheering on their offspring, who got their first break in a Burger King commercial when they were two years old. Never a nice thought.
fields.bodyText: That Aubrey Manning. He's forever scrabbling about in the dirt on the trail of some mystery. He might be attempting to find bits of the Amber Room, a bejewelled chamber given by the Prussians to Peter the Great then pinched by the Nazis, or questioning the authenticity of some supposedly prehistoric artefacts found in France. There are few things Aubrey won't do in his pursuit of knowledge. He was on form in Talking Landscapes (BBC2). "What explains the trees?" he pondered in the first of a series dedicated to the exploration of the British countryside. First stop was the Weald in south-east England, and it wasn't long before he was up to his elbows in mud trying to "explain" this fascinating area. He had his own theories, of course, but most of them proved to be wrong. Every time he advanced another, an expert - usually in an anorak - came along and rained on his parade. The Weald has had an eventful history. Cleared by Bronze Age Britons with their little axes, its woods grew back during "Dark Age confusion". They were chopped down again for the medieval iron industry and for shipbuilding under Henry VIII. The 19th century reprieved the Weald as wooden ships fell out of fashion and the iron industry slowly petered out. As Lewis Grassic Gibbon wrote, nothing endures but the land. So giddy is Aubrey - albeit in a restrained, thoughtful way - he almost makes you want to buy wellies and an anorak and go off for a jaunt in the countryside, breathe in the smell of wet leaves and feel the fresh air on your face. Almost. (Talking of landscapes, the Weald has always sounded like something in need of a generous application of Savlon. Now I know it's derived from the Germanic word for forest, wald.
