A single animal infected with E. coli 0157:H7 can contaminate 32,000lbs of that ground beef. Like the multiple sex partners that helped spread the Aids epidemic, the huge admixture of animals in most American ground beef plants has played a crucial role in spreading E. coli 0157:H7. A single fast food hamburger now contains meat from dozens or even hundreds of different cattle.

fields.headline: Raising Chicks for chicken feed
fields.trailText: The poultry industry was transformed by a wave of mergers in the 80s. Eight chicken processors now control about two-thirds of the US market. These processors have shifted almost all of their production to the rural South, where the weather tends to be mild, the workforce is poor, unions are weak, and farmers are desperate to find a way of staying on their land.
fields.body:
The poultry industry was transformed by a wave of mergers in the 80s. Eight chicken processors now control about two-thirds of the US market. These processors have shifted almost all of their production to the rural South, where the weather tends to be mild, the workforce is poor, unions are weak, and farmers are desperate to find a way of staying on their land.

Although many factors helped revolutionise the poultry industry, one innovation played an especially important role. The Chicken McNugget turned a bird that once had to be carved at a table into something that could be easily eaten behind the wheel of a car. It turned a bulk agricultural commodity into a manufactured, value-added product. And it encouraged a system of production that has turned many chicken farmers into little more than serfs.

'I have an idea,' Fred Turner, the chairman of McDonald's, told one of his suppliers in 1979. 'I want a chicken finger-food without bones, about the size of your thumb. Can you do it?' After six months' research, the laboratory of Keystone Foods developed McNuggets - small pieces of reconstituted chicken, composed mainly of white meat, that were held together by stabilisers, breaded, fried, frozen, then reheated. Initial test-marketing of McNuggets was so successful that McDonald's enlisted another company, Tyson Foods, to guarantee an adequate supply. Tyson soon developed a new breed of chicken to facilitate the production of McNuggets. Dubbed 'Mr McDonald', the new breed had unusually large breasts.

Chicken McNuggets were introduced nationwide in 1983. Within one month, the McDonald's Corporation became the second-largest purchaser of chicken in the US, surpassed only by KFC. McNuggets tasted good, and they appeared to be healthier than other items on the menu at McDonald's. But their healthy benefits were illusory. A chemical analysis of the original McNuggets at Harvard Medical School found that their 'fatty acid profile' more closely resembled beef than poultry. Now cooked in vegetable oil rather than beef tallow, Chicken McNuggets still derive much of their flavour from beef additives - and contain twice as much fat per ounce as a hamburger.

'The impact of McNuggets was so huge that it changed the industry,' the president of Conagra Poultry, another giant chicken processor, later acknowledged. Twenty years ago, most chicken was sold whole; today, about 90% of the chicken sold in the US has been cut into pieces, cutlets or nuggets. In 1992, American consumption of chicken for the first time surpassed the consumption of beef. Tyson Foods now manufactures about half of the nation's McNuggets and sells chicken to 90 of the 100 largest restaurant chains. It is a vertically integrated company that breeds, slaughters and processes chicken. It does not, however, raise the birds. It leaves the capital expenditures and the financial risks of that task to thousands of 'independent contractors'.

A Tyson chicken grower never owns the birds in his or her poultry houses. Like most of the other leading processors, Tyson supplies its growers with one-day-old chicks. Between the day they are born and the day they are killed seven weeks later, the birds spend their entire lives on the grower's property. But they belong to Tyson. The company supplies feed, veterinary services and technical support. It determines feeding schedules, demands equipment upgrades and employs 'flock supervisors' to make sure corporate directives are followed.

The chicken grower provides the land, the labour, the poultry houses and the fuel. Most growers borrow money to build the houses, which cost about $150,000 each and hold about 25,000 birds. A 1995 survey by Louisiana Tech University found that the typical grower had been raising chickens for 15 years, owned three poultry houses, remained deeply in debt and earned perhaps $12,000 a year. About half of the nation's chicken growers leave the business after just three years, either selling out or losing everything.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck begs to differ with the newpapers who declare that the Kangaroo has dealt a body blow to the Frog.
fields.body:
Goodness me, the rubbish you read in newspapers. The poor French must wonder just what sort of hyperbolic society it is that faces them across the Channel as they read (mostly in the gutter press, but also in more august dailies and Sundays, which ought to know better), that the Kangaroo has, where wines are concerned, dealt a body blow to the Frog. To read some reports, you would think the French wine industry was facing extinction.

Now, it is undoubtedly true that the Aussies have managed to achieve a market share that is nothing short of a miracle (having gone from less than 1% 20 years ago to nudging 20% today), while at the same time the French have seen their own share of the UK wine market in that time plummet from around 37% to nearer 24%. But these figures apply only to the wines sold in supermarkets and wine shops. In restaurants, however, French wine sales are still strong and ahead of everyone else, though new world wines are popular and are increasingly being offered on wine lists. I applaud all these changes - indeed this column has helped encourage them - but talk of the Aussies selling more wines than the French and sinking their wine industry is complete balderdash.

I muse on these matters because I have before me a wine that is uniquely French and that could not be bettered, penny for penny, by any new world wine. I refer to Château de Nages Costières de Nimes 1998 at Oddbins. This characterful and beautifully priced wine is fantastic value: it sports wonderful tarry, sticky tannins and very deep, rich, baked, herby fruit of complexity and presence. It's a bottle not only to quaff with great pleasure and satisfaction, but to drink with food of all style, of straightforwardness or sophistication. It rates 17 points (out of 20) and costs £4.99.

Domaine Montlobre Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (17 points, £5.99) is no less stunning. It has elegance and texture, and makes many a claret, at three times the price, blush in shame (and Bordeaux wines are a prime example of the French being so pitifully inadequate at keeping up with the times and the changing climes).

Saint Chinian Alain Grignon 1999 (15.5 points, £4.29, Oddbins) is also pretty terrific. It's a soft, hugely slurpable wine of depth and style. Dallas-Conte Rapel Valley Chardonnay 1999 (17 points, £5.99, Oddbins), from Chile, is breathtakingly stylish, with hints of apricot, pineapple, melon and lots of citric layering. Beautifully structured and immensely classy, it's a benchmark example of the sort of exceptional value-for-money wines that Chile, as well as other new world producers, can conjure from their soils. And Villa Maria Reserve Riesling 1999 (17 points, £8.99, Oddbins Fine Wine Stores), from New Zealand, is also a superb white wine that will improve over many years to become more petroleum-charged aromatically and oilier in texture. As it stands, it has mineral overtones and subtly spicy, melony fruit, and is quite gorgeous.

At Majestic, there is Chablis 1er Cru Beauroy 1996 (15.5 points, in the half bottle for £4.99). It's a first-rate Chablis, this: chardonnay in its steely mould. What does Oz have to compete? Bethany Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £7.99) has superb texture and balance of elegant elements. This is a truly exceptional chardonnay for the money. Also at Majestic, Coupe Roses Les Plots Minervois 1999 (16 points, £6.99) is an entertaining red. It fair gushes with dry, rich, red fruit that develops well on the tastebuds, revealing complexity and a firm finish. This wine is in very short supply, however, and stocks are running low.

At Sainsbury's a decade ago, there were just 16 Aussie wines on shelf. Now there are 86. This is a measure of the Aussies' progress. There were also, for example, no South African wines at JS (for obvious political reasons at that time), but now there are 49.

Two of them are here today. The store's South African non-vintage Chardonnay (15.5 points, £3.99) is a bargain with its subtle fruit and gentle acids. Kumala Chardonnay 2000 (15.5 points, £4.99) is weightier, offering big, rich, smoky musky, fruit that is just brilliant with oriental food.

 For the latest wine news, or to email Malcolm Gluck, visit superplonk.com.

fields.headline: Salad days
fields.standfirst: Green Bean, Fennel and Red Onion Salad
fields.trailText: Green Bean, Fennel and Red Onion Salad.
fields.body:
Cooked salads are among the best. In this, the main ingredients are cooked, and the onion softens in their heat.

1 big pinch dried tarragon

2 tbsp home-made vinaigrette (according to personal taste)

250g French beans

1 head smooth, unblemished fennel

1 red onion, the bigger the better

Whisk the tarragon into the dressing. Put a pot of water on to boil, top and tail the beans, and cut the fennel and onion very thin. Liberally salt the water, and tip in the fennel. When it returns to the boil, cook for around a minute, until the fennel is soft but retains a hint of bite. Remove with a slotted spoon and leave to drain. Cook the beans in the same water, testing them after two minutes; drain when cooked, and add to the fennel. When both veg are dry, put them in a bowl with the onions. Strain in the vinaigrette, toss, and serve hot or tepid.

fields.headline: Space: the final frontiers
fields.standfirst: You trip over bicycles in the hallway, your kitchen windowsill resembles a bring-and-buy stall and your alcoves are stuffed with bowing shelves. We all have our blind spots in the home. Gillian Rowe finds new ways to look at those neglected corners
fields.trailText: You trip over bicycles in the hallway, your kitchen windowsill resembles a bring-and-buy stall and your alcoves are stuffed with bowing shelves. We all have our blind spots in the home. Gillian Rowe finds new ways to look at those neglected corners.
fields.body:
I nearly ate one of the cat's steroid tablets this morning. It was an easy enough mistake to make. The small, brown bottle is hidden among my vitamin C, echinacea and other bottles, on a kitchen window ledge that could double as a bring-and-buy stall. Despite having had a handmade, state-of-the-art kitchen installed only last summer, the window ledge has fast become a dumping ground for everything from an unopened bottle of Baby Bio to a half-eaten packet of Maltesers. Not to mention the windows themselves. They remain naked after a combination of inertia and lack of funds bled away any ideas of "dressing".

The kitchen window, the hallway, the toilet under the stairs - these are some of the many areas of the house that swiftly develop into blind spots. They are spaces that have been overlooked for so long, it's hard to see how they could be put to better use. They are the areas where the imagination comes to an abrupt halt.

This is not a problem that can be quickly resolved with a visit to the dump and a can of Pledge. Oh no. Unless you invest in the professional help of an architect or interior designer, it is often impossible to make sense of those blind spots. It's as much to do with familiarity as lack of visual imagination. Once you've shoved the Hoover under the stairs for the umpteenth time, it is unlikely you will ever see that space as "going to waste". And when the sofa has been pushed flat against the wall to try and open up your narrow, knocked-through sitting room, will it ever be moved again? Not likely.

Of course, there aren't generic solutions to these problems. No house is the same, and everyone's budget is different. But just by noticing that it's a waste using 4m sq as a dumping ground, you may start to find ways to utilise your home to better effect.


Hallways

The hallway is a space that is used more regularly than any other, and offers a first impression of what your house says about you to the outside world. But most of us spend far more time agonising about what taps to put in the bathroom than what the hall looks like. The hall should set the tone for the rest of your house. Using mismatched off-cuts of carpet as a couple of runners, which I did until I tripped over them once too often (not ideal with a new baby), is not quite the tone you're looking for.

'Make it look welcoming. It's the first bit that anyone sees,' says textile designer Roger Oates. 'I think people forget it's a room, and although you don't spend a lot of time in it you do use it all the time, so give yourself some basic facilities: a bench or stool that you can sit on to take off your shoes, attractive hooks to hang things on. Make it look like a statement and as if it belongs.'

It's also the space where all the dirt comes in, so if you're laying a runner, put something on it that will take care of the dirt and is easy to clean, such as entrance matting. If there's room, put a table in the hall and landing as a repository for things waiting to go up and down stairs. Dawna Walter, an expert in clutter-free living, has 10 baskets sitting on her staircase. 'You always get to the top of the stairs and have forgotten something. We put things we need in the baskets and it's a rule of the house that we take one up when we go upstairs.'

Interiors writer Fay Sweet is more concerned with discovering hidden possibilities with the space available. 'Looking up is the thing to do with halls. Look at any area where there's a massive amount of head space and think of ways to utilise it.' Sweet suggests putting bicycles and scooters on pullies - to suspend them high up - or lining the walls with books.

For the really brutal clean-sweep, get rid of the hall altogether. 'Do away with them or bring in as much light as possible,' says Robert Sakula, of Ash Sakula Architects. 'We are obsessed with halls in this country. With the climate changing, you don't need two doors between you and the outside world to keep out drafts any more.' If he can't persuade a client to knock down the dividing hall wall, Sakula tackles the problem of light by changing the doors leading off the hallway. 'Doors tend to open away from the hall, so all the light bounces inside the room, and casts a shadow into the hallway. We swing them the other way, to let light into the hallway. If the hall is lit well it can be joyous.'

In one award-winning project by Sakula, a new house on a small, central London site, the stairwell is without walls, forming instead a delicate free-standing spiral - known as the 'tulip' - at the centre of the house. The space around the tulip has been used to the max: low cupboards beside it contain washing and drying machines, with a slate worktop. The neighbouring rooms flow from this central space, without doors or rigid walls sectioning them off.


Kitchens

Nothing gets us into quite such a lather as the thought of a fully-integrated, Smeg-ed up kitchen. But somehow we haven't quite shaken off memories of the past when mother spent all her days washing up looking wistfully out at her herbaceous borders. Tiny little pockets of cosiness still creep into the most sophisticated designer kitchen, nowhere more so than at the kitchen window.

A representative of one of the smarter kitchen companies admits that she is frequently horrified when she visits a client's kitchen once it has been installed. 'What they put at the window,' she gasps, 'it's grim; they kill the whole look.' Richard Jackson, of Mark Wilkinson kitchens, says most people still want sinks looking out of the window. To resolve the bric-a-brac window ledge dilemma, he suggests that if your ledge is the same height as the work top, to run the work top area into the window to give a much bigger working surface.

Clutter-free queen Walter has targeted her kitchen as well as her stairs. 'You have to reassess everything all the time,' she orders. 'Most people move in, unpack and never make any changes after that. You have to change the routine. Clear everything off the windowsill and then see what it looks like. Mine has seven different plants which I meticulously take care of because I see them all the time, they are in front of me.'

If you've got enough light, growing plants can be a useful option. Florist and landscape gardener Stephen Woodhams suggests individual galvanised/aluminium containers, each planted with a single herb - rosemary, thyme, sage, basil, parsley and chives. Darke says make a feature of your kitchen window: 'If the windows are completely rotten we knock them out and relocate the window to put the frame on the outside wall and cover the brickwork with a timber lining. You can make a huge deep window ledge which jutts outwards, rather than inwards.' Perfect for displaying his collection of 1950s china.

If your new, deep windowsill is low enough, make a seat out of it, throw out those, hideous mouldy old blinds and your kitchen may start to have a hint of the John Pawson about it.


Long living rooms/alcoves

In an attempt to give the 'best' room in the house more space, most Victorian terraced properties today have a knocked-through living room that may provide more square metres but often ends up feeling long, narrow and dark. Once a sofa has been added flat against one wall (generally opposite the fireplace), with bookshelves in either alcove, the waiting-room effect is complete. The resulting feeling is that the only way you can walk from one end of the room to the other is in crab-mode or by doing a bit of line dancing.

Jon Darke, of SEF Architects, suggests knocking out the hallway, 'so that you get a room that goes the full width of the property; it can transform a house.' Until recently, it's been the fashion to retain a sense of two separate rooms by keeping an arch between them, thus providing even more alcoves to fill. 'If you pay a bit more and knock out all of it, you get a free-flowing room which seems much more spacious, and you get rid of all those nooks and crannies that you don't know what to do with,' says Darke. This rather major demolition work is fine, generally, for two-storey houses, but if your house is three storeys or more it may be deemed a fire risk and Darke advises seeking planning permission for any heavy duty building work.

Andrew Weaving, who owns the modernist furniture shop Century, has gone to great lengths to make his narrow, early Victorian terrace appear wider. By putting in a supporting beam between two small living rooms, Weaving was able to knock through the dividing wall and knock through into the hallway, replacing this wall with a floor-to-ceiling sliding panel which is made of wood. 'The back room is usually more of a problem in these houses because of the staircase, so we turned the staircase round to give us more room in the hallway and also in the living room when we leave the wooden partition open.'

To add to the sense of space in his living room, Weaving has hung a huge floor-to-ceiling picture, by Bruce McClean, on one wall - the Perspex mount reflecting any light in the room - and has placed sofas at both ends to square up the space. Small pieces of furniture have been dispersed through the centre of the room to prevent the eye focusing on one area.

Alcoves are another problem area: if you fill them with bookshelves (and everyone does) your space appears even more restricted. 'It's as if people see a shelf and say, "Better line them with books",' says interiors stylist Hilary Robertson. Robertson has a particular loathing of those bookshelf units with cupboards underneath that every carpenter in town seems to specialise in. 'I call them posh cupboards that the Sloanes have. They're standard issue with every Clapham house.' To resolve the alcove issue and the equally thorny problem of what to do with the telly, Robertson has covered an alcove in silver leaf and put her telly in it on a silver table, making a feature of the whole area. Alternatively, a floor-to-ceiling mirror in an alcove can give the effect of an opening into another room.

If you do need shelving, try to avoid standard-issue horizontal lines - Ron Arad's Bookworm shelves, from Purves & Purves, can bend into spirals or long, wavy lines; or look at the new Atom circular shelving system by Stone Circle.

Use paint to give the illusion of changing the dimensions of a room. Sue Gosling, colour adviser at Dulux, suggests using a slightly darker shade of your chosen colour at either end of the room to square it up and make it appear wider. To make a high ceiling appear lower, use a darker colour or shade to create a more cosy feeling. Posh cupboards, or not, what most of us end up putting in an alcove is the telly. 'Although everybody watches it, you don't want to give the television iconic status,' says Sakula. By putting the television on the other side of the room and moving seating into each alcove, the fireplace remains as the natural focus of the room.


Under stairs cupboards, and loo

Perhaps the most ignored space in the home is the area under the stairs. There's little you can do, without getting involved with costly building work. If you are going to keep it as a general storage area (and the Hoover's got to go somewhere) put a light inside the cupboard so you don't have to feel your way through to that rusty pair of secateurs.

'We never seem to put lighting into cupboards in this country - under the stairs or in the kitchen. It's as if we've got a thing about it,' says Sweet, who reckons the best use of the area is to open it and line it with book shelves. 'Some people try to make offices out of the space, but that can be a bit dismal.'

Doug Sandle, chartered psychologist at Leeds Metropolitan University, thinks there may be deeper reasons why this area of the house is so often neglected. 'The broom cupboard, the shed, the space under the stairs, all have a mythical status for dark and unpleasant things. They feature as unpleasant places in stories and folk lore (something rotten in the woodshed, skeletons in the cupboard). As such they have a psychodynamic use as a store for the darker and disturbing things in life. Many of us will have had a creepy experience or feeling about such small spaces. Better we leave them undisturbed and not look at them in the bright light of day.'

If the area is large enough and you can afford to, put in a downstairs loo - it will prove not only useful, but will add value to your property. Because it's likely to be a small space, keep it simple. 'There are tricks you can use to make it look bigger,' says Melanie Somerville of bathroom suppliers CP Hart. 'Buy a wall-mounted basin, so you don't have a pedestal, and a wall-hung toilet, so you have the space clear underneath. It's easy to clean, and if you have young children you can mount it at a height that suits them.' Finally, put plain colours on the walls, try and avoid tiles, which will make the room look smaller, and on no account frame the wall with cartoons.

They are spaces that have been overlooked for so long, it's hard to see how they could be put to better use. They are the areas where the imagination comes to an abrupt halt. This is not a problem that can be quickly resolved with a visit to the dump and a can of Pledge. Oh no. Unless you invest in the professional help of an architect or interior designer, it is often impossible to make sense of those blind spots. It's as much to do with familiarity as lack of visual imagination. Once you've shoved the Hoover under the stairs for the umpteenth time, it is unlikely you will ever see that space as "going to waste". And when the sofa has been pushed flat against the wall to try and open up your narrow, knocked-through sitting room, will it ever be moved again? Not likely. Of course, there aren't generic solutions to these problems. No house is the same, and everyone's budget is different. But just by noticing that it's a waste using 4m sq as a dumping ground, you may start to find ways to utilise your home to better effect. Hallways The hallway is a space that is used more regularly than any other, and offers a first impression of what your house says about you to the outside world. But most of us spend far more time agonising about what taps to put in the bathroom than what the hall looks like. The hall should set the tone for the rest of your house. Using mismatched off-cuts of carpet as a couple of runners, which I did until I tripped over them once too often (not ideal with a new baby), is not quite the tone you're looking for. 'Make it look welcoming. It's the first bit that anyone sees,' says textile designer Roger Oates. 'I think people forget it's a room, and although you don't spend a lot of time in it you do use it all the time, so give yourself some basic facilities: a bench or stool that you can sit on to take off your shoes, attractive hooks to hang things on. Make it look like a statement and as if it belongs.' It's also the space where all the dirt comes in, so if you're laying a runner, put something on it that will take care of the dirt and is easy to clean, such as entrance matting. If there's room, put a table in the hall and landing as a repository for things waiting to go up and down stairs. Dawna Walter, an expert in clutter-free living, has 10 baskets sitting on her staircase. 'You always get to the top of the stairs and have forgotten something. We put things we need in the baskets and it's a rule of the house that we take one up when we go upstairs.' Interiors writer Fay Sweet is more concerned with discovering hidden possibilities with the space available. 'Looking up is the thing to do with halls. Look at any area where there's a massive amount of head space and think of ways to utilise it.' Sweet suggests putting bicycles and scooters on pullies - to suspend them high up - or lining the walls with books. For the really brutal clean-sweep, get rid of the hall altogether. 'Do away with them or bring in as much light as possible,' says Robert Sakula, of Ash Sakula Architects. 'We are obsessed with halls in this country. With the climate changing, you don't need two doors between you and the outside world to keep out drafts any more.' If he can't persuade a client to knock down the dividing hall wall, Sakula tackles the problem of light by changing the doors leading off the hallway. 'Doors tend to open away from the hall, so all the light bounces inside the room, and casts a shadow into the hallway. We swing them the other way, to let light into the hallway. If the hall is lit well it can be joyous.' In one award-winning project by Sakula, a new house on a small, central London site, the stairwell is without walls, forming instead a delicate free-standing spiral - known as the 'tulip' - at the centre of the house. The space around the tulip has been used to the max: low cupboards beside it contain washing and drying machines, with a slate worktop. The neighbouring rooms flow from this central space, without doors or rigid walls sectioning them off. Kitchens Nothing gets us into quite such a lather as the thought of a fully-integrated, Smeg-ed up kitchen. But somehow we haven't quite shaken off memories of the past when mother spent all her days washing up looking wistfully out at her herbaceous borders. Tiny little pockets of cosiness still creep into the most sophisticated designer kitchen, nowhere more so than at the kitchen window. A representative of one of the smarter kitchen companies admits that she is frequently horrified when she visits a client's kitchen once it has been installed. 'What they put at the window,' she gasps, 'it's grim; they kill the whole look.' Richard Jackson, of Mark Wilkinson kitchens, says most people still want sinks looking out of the window. To resolve the bric-a-brac window ledge dilemma, he suggests that if your ledge is the same height as the work top, to run the work top area into the window to give a much bigger working surface. Clutter-free queen Walter has targeted her kitchen as well as her stairs. 'You have to reassess everything all the time,' she orders. 'Most people move in, unpack and never make any changes after that. You have to change the routine. Clear everything off the windowsill and then see what it looks like. Mine has seven different plants which I meticulously take care of because I see them all the time, they are in front of me.' If you've got enough light, growing plants can be a useful option. Florist and landscape gardener Stephen Woodhams suggests individual galvanised/aluminium containers, each planted with a single herb - rosemary, thyme, sage, basil, parsley and chives. Darke says make a feature of your kitchen window: 'If the windows are completely rotten we knock them out and relocate the window to put the frame on the outside wall and cover the brickwork with a timber lining. You can make a huge deep window ledge which jutts outwards, rather than inwards.' Perfect for displaying his collection of 1950s china. If your new, deep windowsill is low enough, make a seat out of it, throw out those, hideous mouldy old blinds and your kitchen may start to have a hint of the John Pawson about it. Long living rooms/alcoves In an attempt to give the 'best' room in the house more space, most Victorian terraced properties today have a knocked-through living room that may provide more square metres but often ends up feeling long, narrow and dark. Once a sofa has been added flat against one wall (generally opposite the fireplace), with bookshelves in either alcove, the waiting-room effect is complete. The resulting feeling is that the only way you can walk from one end of the room to the other is in crab-mode or by doing a bit of line dancing. Jon Darke, of SEF Architects, suggests knocking out the hallway, 'so that you get a room that goes the full width of the property; it can transform a house.' Until recently, it's been the fashion to retain a sense of two separate rooms by keeping an arch between them, thus providing even more alcoves to fill. 'If you pay a bit more and knock out all of it, you get a free-flowing room which seems much more spacious, and you get rid of all those nooks and crannies that you don't know what to do with,' says Darke. This rather major demolition work is fine, generally, for two-storey houses, but if your house is three storeys or more it may be deemed a fire risk and Darke advises seeking planning permission for any heavy duty building work. Andrew Weaving, who owns the modernist furniture shop Century, has gone to great lengths to make his narrow, early Victorian terrace appear wider. By putting in a supporting beam between two small living rooms, Weaving was able to knock through the dividing wall and knock through into the hallway, replacing this wall with a floor-to-ceiling sliding panel which is made of wood. 'The back room is usually more of a problem in these houses because of the staircase, so we turned the staircase round to give us more room in the hallway and also in the living room when we leave the wooden partition open.' To add to the sense of space in his living room, Weaving has hung a huge floor-to-ceiling picture, by Bruce McClean, on one wall - the Perspex mount reflecting any light in the room - and has placed sofas at both ends to square up the space. Small pieces of furniture have been dispersed through the centre of the room to prevent the eye focusing on one area. Alcoves are another problem area: if you fill them with bookshelves (and everyone does) your space appears even more restricted. 'It's as if people see a shelf and say, "Better line them with books",' says interiors stylist Hilary Robertson. Robertson has a particular loathing of those bookshelf units with cupboards underneath that every carpenter in town seems to specialise in. 'I call them posh cupboards that the Sloanes have. They're standard issue with every Clapham house.' To resolve the alcove issue and the equally thorny problem of what to do with the telly, Robertson has covered an alcove in silver leaf and put her telly in it on a silver table, making a feature of the whole area. Alternatively, a floor-to-ceiling mirror in an alcove can give the effect of an opening into another room. If you do need shelving, try to avoid standard-issue horizontal lines - Ron Arad's Bookworm shelves, from Purves & Purves, can bend into spirals or long, wavy lines; or look at the new Atom circular shelving system by Stone Circle. Use paint to give the illusion of changing the dimensions of a room. Sue Gosling, colour adviser at Dulux, suggests using a slightly darker shade of your chosen colour at either end of the room to square it up and make it appear wider. To make a high ceiling appear lower, use a darker colour or shade to create a more cosy feeling. Posh cupboards, or not, what most of us end up putting in an alcove is the telly. 'Although everybody watches it, you don't want to give the television iconic status,' says Sakula. By putting the television on the other side of the room and moving seating into each alcove, the fireplace remains as the natural focus of the room. Under stairs cupboards, and loo Perhaps the most ignored space in the home is the area under the stairs. There's little you can do, without getting involved with costly building work. If you are going to keep it as a general storage area (and the Hoover's got to go somewhere) put a light inside the cupboard so you don't have to feel your way through to that rusty pair of secateurs. 'We never seem to put lighting into cupboards in this country - under the stairs or in the kitchen. It's as if we've got a thing about it,' says Sweet, who reckons the best use of the area is to open it and line it with book shelves. 'Some people try to make offices out of the space, but that can be a bit dismal.' Doug Sandle, chartered psychologist at Leeds Metropolitan University, thinks there may be deeper reasons why this area of the house is so often neglected. 'The broom cupboard, the shed, the space under the stairs, all have a mythical status for dark and unpleasant things. They feature as unpleasant places in stories and folk lore (something rotten in the woodshed, skeletons in the cupboard). As such they have a psychodynamic use as a store for the darker and disturbing things in life. Many of us will have had a creepy experience or feeling about such small spaces. Better we leave them undisturbed and not look at them in the bright light of day.' If the area is large enough and you can afford to, put in a downstairs loo - it will prove not only useful, but will add value to your property. Because it's likely to be a small space, keep it simple. 'There are tricks you can use to make it look bigger,' says Melanie Somerville of bathroom suppliers CP Hart. 'Buy a wall-mounted basin, so you don't have a pedestal, and a wall-hung toilet, so you have the space clear underneath. It's easy to clean, and if you have young children you can mount it at a height that suits them.' Finally, put plain colours on the walls, try and avoid tiles, which will make the room look smaller, and on no account frame the wall with cartoons.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Lucienne Day
fields.trailText: Lucienne Day.
fields.body:
Lucienne Day is 84. She met her husband, Robin, at the Royal College of Art, London, and they married in 1942. Robin became a furniture designer, Lucienne a textile designer. Her revolutionary fabric design, Calyx, won a gold medal at the 1951 Milan Triennale. Working independently in a wide range of media, the couple dominated design throughout the 50s and 60s. An exhibition, Robin and Lucienne Day: Pioneers of Contemporary Design, is at the Barbican Gallery, London, until April 16. The couple live in Sussex.

What is your greatest fear?
Going blind.

Which living person do you most admire?
Sir David Attenborough for his amazing wildlife programmes, and for alerting us all to the perils we face if we don't mend our ways.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Not being able to think quickly enough.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Procrastination.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Taking taxis everywhere in London.

What makes you depressed?
Not being able to stop certain flagrant cruelties.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
When, as head of school, I forgot my welcoming speech, in French, to a visiting dignitary.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My ageing face.

What is your favourite smell?
Lilies in my garden.

What is your favourite word?
Juniper, because it sounds beautiful.

What is your favourite journey?
Plant-hunting in the Mediterranean, or in the mountains of Italy or Spain.

How did you vote in the last election?
New Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?
New Labour.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
No - a president would be worse.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
No, that's murder which I deplore.

Do you believe in monogamy?
On the whole, yes.

When and where were you happiest?
The day my daughter was born.

Do you believe in life after death?
I don't think so, but perhaps I'll be proved wrong.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a first-rate designer.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
To be honest.

fields.headline: Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow...
fields.standfirst: 'My lord and master? He's tempted to transgress. Elaine has reeled him in'
fields.trailText: Dulcie Domum: 'My lord and master? He's tempted to transgress. Elaine has reeled him in'.
fields.body:
ÔMum! Will you help me with English? I wanna read Lady Macbeth and you can be Macbeth, okay?" Lady Macbeth is Harriet's role model - a better one than me.

"In a minute, love. I've just got to settle Aunt Elspeth down, first." I'd never have murdered the old Scottish king. I'd have tucked him in, brought him his cocoa, given the grooms tea every two hours and never complained if they had Radio 1 on all the time.

But what of my lord and master? He's tempted to transgress, you can tell. Elaine has reeled him in. I'm not quite sure what blandishments are, but you can almost smell Elaine's. "Dulcie! You'll never guess! I'm so lucky!" A firm of developers was so turned on by her sexy old rectory with its pert little outhouses, that they're going to buy it even without planning permission. Upstream at Old Pofford, workmen have already started to demolish the bridge. Then they can improve the flood defences, and Elaine's saturated plain will become a scenic meadow. I can just see the tasteful executive homes. "The Meadows", perhaps. And my cantankerous old sod of an erstwhile husband will become Thane of Elaine again, mark my words.

"Dulcie, dearrr," the aged aunt, early abed, clutches my hand. "I will trrry not to lose my marrrbles, dearrr, but if I do, you must bung me in a home immediately. Tomorrrrrrow, I want you to take out powerrr of attorrrney - just in case, you know. Sometimes, I can't rrrememberrr what day it is, and just now I had terrrrrrible trrrouble conjurrring up Ullapool."

"Dear Elspeth!" I squeeze her hand and kiss her freckly old brow. "I never know what day it is."

"But Dulcie, dearrr, I can't bearrr the thought that I might get a wee bit... incontinent!" whispers the aunt. "I noticed a strrrrange stain on the seat of my chairrr, dearrr - I'll pay to have the upholsterrry cleanerrrs in!" Assure aunt there is no need, and that I pee in my pants often, especially when old episodes of Bottom are on the telly.

However, back in the sitting room, I examine the seat of the aunt's chair and, indeed, there is a strange greasy mark. "Oh sorry, Mum," says Harriet, hovering nearby with her Macbeth cocked ready. "I dropped a bag of chips on that chair yesterday. Can we read Macbeth now?"

Her father rises from behind his newspaper, and switches off the TV sport with an ominous air. "Just a word, if I may?"

"Harriet, go and do a bit more revision. We'll read Macbeth tomorrow."

"And tomorrow, and tomorrow!" Harriet glares and departs, leaving us unusually alone. Elaine has taken little Sandy off for a weekend with her parents, to reveal her latest triumph.

Gordon takes a deep breath. "As you've probably deduced, I think it makes sense for me to move out with Elaine," he says briskly. "It'll get me out of your hair." I believe he said exactly the same thing when he walked out on me the first time, but this time it also gets the aunt off his hands. "Elaine's thinking of buying a house in town. Quite near." Far enough away not to be bothered by deafening punk rock, though. "And, after all, I ought to do my bit for the kid." Her kid, you note - not mine.

Is this a bugger that I see before me? "Well, congratulations," I sneer. "I hope you'll be very happy." He cringes nicely.

"As for Aunt Elspeth," he murmurs, "for God's sake don't do anything heroic. If she goes downhill, we'll find a residential..."

"You leave Elspeth to me," I say firmly. "I'll gladly look after her. She's shown more love and loyalty to me than you ever have." He flinches - beautifully. "But don't worry," I continue crisply. "I shall continue to be a bloody good sport. For Elspeth's sake and Harriet's, whom you haven't bothered to mention."

"Oh God, Harriet will be more than welcome! She can visit every weekend, if you like." That's Elaine's babysitter sorted, then. "And if she's any trouble, you only have to ring." He sighs. His bridges are demolished. His boats are burnt, and he's left me. Again. But why worry about burnt boats when there's a bloody great luxury liner waiting for you out in the bay?

fields.headline: How to diet
fields.trailText: The purpose of dieting is to lose weight, so that you will become more attractive to the opposite sex, who will then invite you out to expensive restaurants.
fields.body:
The purpose of dieting is to lose weight, so that you will become more attractive to the opposite sex, who will then invite you out to expensive restaurants where you can eat like a hog. Lots of people overeat because, in our abundant society, food is never more than a 30-second walk away. A good way to reduce your calorie consumption is, therefore, to locate yourself in a wilderness where there is no food. A train, for example.

There are as many different diets as there are excuses to eat biscuits. There's the F-Plan, C-Plan, etc. The most effective is the X-plan diet; you can eat anything you like as long as it has an X in it. One useful tip is to keep a list of everything you eat. This is especially good for big eaters because compiling the list can cut down the time you spend eating.

Finally, when you've finished the list, eat it. That's your meal for the day. Crash diets are where you can lose a stone in a week. This is otherwise known as amputation.

For the really serious you can have your jaws wired together, which means you have to exist on energy drinks and high carbohydrate suppositories. But remember that having your jaws wired together might also have a detrimental impact on your career in telesales.

You'll eat less if you learn to chew slowly and savour your food. If you chew each mouthful 380 times, you will cut down your food intake dramatically, as it will take you a week to get through a cheese sandwich. Avoid using this technique during important business lunches.

A great idea to make you think twice about eating is to consider where you're going to store the food you eat when your stomach is already full. For example, imagine that huge slice of chocolate cake being stored on your thighs. Go easy with this visualisation technique because you might start to associate your thigh with chocolate cake and wake up to find yourself munching away at your leg.

You can also try a treats and rewards system where you punish yourself with a stick of celery for lunch and reward yourself with a Mars bar for afters. Really fat people who eat nothing but junk food are using the same system: they reward themselves with tasty junk food their whole life and punish themselves by an early death.

Finally, if you are binge eating, the real question you should be asking yourself is not what you're eating, but what's eating you. If you look down and you're in fact being eaten by a coypu, there's your answer.

fields.headline: Archaeologists uncover 'fabulous' chariot
fields.trailText: The reputation of prehistoric Britons was notched up another peg yesterday, with the discovery of the oldest iron age chariot to be unearthed by archaeologists.
fields.body:
The reputation of prehistoric Britons was notched up another peg yesterday, with the discovery of the oldest iron age chariot to be unearthed by archaeologists.

Apart from the slight hitch that its owner was probably French, the mass of intricate bronze-work, inlaid coral and skilled joinery was described as "fabulous" proof of ancient native expertise by English Heritage and the British Museum.

Both organisations sent emergency teams to the dig at Wetwang, east Yorkshire, when the scale of the discovery emerged from a routine dig of a mediaeval barn.

"The finds are stunning," said Jeremy Hill, curator for the iron age at the museum. "They show just how skillful and unprimitive the prehistoric Britons really were."

The village on the Yorkshire Wolds, much teased since it appointed TV personality Richard Whiteley as its honourary mayor 10 years ago, was an emerging European cultural capital for the period around 350BC. Archaeologists have already unearthed six chariot burials in the village and a further 10 within 20 miles. All of the burials, including the latest, which was described yesterday as "the best yet", are thought to contain the remains of aristocrats from the French-Celtic Parisi tribe.

Responsible for giving Paris its name, the warriors are thought to have expanded from the Champagne region of France in 400BC, a theory which the Wetwang chariot may help to prove.

Apart from well-preserved metal bindings, decorative work and iron "tyres", the trove includes sections of wooden wheels, horse harnesses and an exceptionally detailed "ghost" of the long since rotted yoke.

"A mould has been taken to reconstruct the form of this, the first time this has been done," said David Miles, chief archaeologist for English Heritage, which is also working with the Museum on the grave's intact skeleton, pottery and animal bones found nearby.

"The person in the grave was clearly very important and was buried with a rite clearly linked to the continent," he said.

The museum and English Heritage praised local developer Hogg the Builders, who plan to construct five houses on the site, for model practice over the dig. Apart from financing the initial excavation, the firm was given credit for what Mr Miles called "one of the most significant and exciting middle iron age burials ever found".

Adrian Havercroft, chief excavator at Wetwang, said: "These fabulous things were only discovered because Hogg's decided on a final check after we had found a ditch surrounding a barrow. One of our trenches and had missed the grave pit by a whisker."

webTitle: RSC fires off warning shot to patrons

fields.headline: RSC fires off warning shot to patrons
fields.trailText: The Royal Shakespeare Company has sent patrons a health warning for a play whose author promises "more gunshots and squibs going off on stage than any production you've ever seen".
fields.body:
The Royal Shakespeare Company has sent patrons a health warning for a play whose author promises "more gunshots and squibs going off on stage than any production you've ever seen".

Martin McDonagh's The Lieutenant of Inishmore, previewing at The Other Place in Stratford-upon-Avon next week, is billed as a wild farce about Padraic, a psychopathic, cat-loving terrorist.

In a letter to all ticket holders, Kate Horton, the RSC's director of marketing, makes it clear "no cats or people are hurt in reality", but says the show is unsuitable for children under 15 because of its violence. She also warns of a large number of gunshots.

"The sound generated is within the legal limit for noise exposure. However, if you or anyone in your party is very young, elderly, pregnant or visually or hearing impaired, you should be aware of the significant noise."

The theatre's systems to assist people with hearing problems will be adjusted to keep sound at "acceptable levels".

The RSC has never issued warnings about its core repertoire - plays such as King Lear (eye gouging), Titus Andronicus (unwitting cannibalism), The Revenger's Tragedy (kissing a poisoned skeleton) and Edward II (red hot poker up bottom).

A company spokeswoman said normally it would have a sign outside advising of a gunshot, but there were sustained gunshots in this play.

"We sell tickets before rehearsal, and things change and develop along the way. We feel we have to tell people.

"As far as I know, no one has cancelled."

webTitle: Medical misuse of sedatives 'kills 200 a year'

fields.headline: Medical misuse of sedatives 'kills 200 a year'
fields.trailText: Doctors believe that at least 200 people a year die as a result of accidents linked to sedatives administered by hospital doctors before they carry out diagnosis or treatment.
fields.body:
Doctors believe that at least 200 people a year die as a result of accidents linked to sedatives administered by hospital doctors before they carry out diagnosis or treatment.

More than 1m patients each year are given medication to ease anxiety and help erase unpleasant memories of discomfiting procedures while remaining conscious.

But few doctors are trained to administer such drugs, and there is mounting concern that overdoses tip patients towards losing consciousness. Guidance on use of sedatives, along with other drugs such as painkillers, is not being followed.

A working party from dentistry, accident and emergency services, radiology and gastroenterology, will soon demand compulsory training in giving sedatives to accompany the procedures. These include endoscopy (using tubes to investigate internal organs) and some x-ray examinations; these should not need anaesthetists, who are in short supply.

Six years ago, an audit of procedures using endoscopes through the upper body and sedation suggested one in 2,000 patients died within 30 days, an alarming figure even allowing for numbers of high-risk and comparatively elderly patients involved.

As a consequence professional bodies issued guidance, but members of the working party believe these are often not followed. Another forthcoming endoscopy study by the British Society for Gastroenterology is expected to reinforce concern.

Rory McCloy, a member of the working party commissioned by the United Kingdom Academy of Medical Royal Colleges, said: "There are undoubtedly people dying because of the inappropriate use of sedation."

The figure nationally across all procedures was probably between one in 3,000 and one in 5,000, far higher than the one in nearly 200,000 associated with being given anaesthetics. "Doctors could go many years and never see a death, so they don't think there is a problem. It is like seatbelts: everyone drove round without them, thinking nothing would happen to them; the only way to change people's habits was to make it illegal not to wear seatbelts."

Dentists were now given good grounding in administering sedation but Mr McCloy, a consultant at Manchester royal infirmary, revealed that courses offered by the Royal College of Surgeons in the mid-1990s had to be can celled because so few volunteered. "There should have been thousands, from junior doctors up to consultants."

Many doctors did not know the side-effects of drugs or how long they remained in the body. Manufacturers gave guidelines, but doctors were multiplying doses so as to almost put patients to sleep. "If you put them to sleep, you have given them an anaesthetic. And if you are not an anaesthetist, you are in trouble."

News of the concern emerged yesterday as the husband of a patient who died in 1998 while undergoing a procedure involving an endoscope and sedatives began legal proceedings. Peter Wiles, a postal worker from Blackpool, Lancashire, who has children aged 15 and 13, alleges negligence by the Blackpool Victoria hospital in treating his wife, Deborah, 32.

Mr Wiles's solicitor, Diane Rostron, hoped that the case, launched at Preston county court, would focus attention on such procedures and lead to a public inquiry. An inquest into Wiles's death in 1998 returned a verdict of death by misadventure.

A spokeswoman for the hospital trust said it was investigating the claim and is cooperating with the family's solicitors."

webTitle: Stars over Salford New hotel caps city's regeneration

fields.headline: Stars over Salford New hotel caps city's regeneration
fields.trailText: A new hotel named after the north's favourite artist proudly proclaims that it is Manchester's only five-star hotel. The Lowry, which flung wide its doors in a typical north-western downpour this week, is certainly five-star. But the elegant, curving building, with 164 air-conditioned bedrooms (five of which were occupied on the opening night by the boy band Westlife), is actually in Salford, a city which has not been known as a gathering point for the super rich for some time.

webTitle: BA hides cameras in hold to deter baggage theft

fields.headline: BA hides cameras in hold to deter baggage theft
fields.trailText: British Airways is to install surveillance cameras throughout its 340 strong fleet to deal with the growing problem of theft by baggage carriers, it said yesterday.
fields.body:
British Airways is to install surveillance cameras throughout its 340 strong fleet to deal with the growing problem of theft by baggage carriers, it said yesterday.

Thousands of pieces of luggage have gone missing over the past few years and BA has been involved in a covert operation to track down offenders.

Ten baggage handlers at Paris's Charles de Gaulle airport have been arrested on suspicion of stealing from passengers' bags. They were filmed in the hold by hidden cameras. A further seven have been identified on videotape, and suspended.

It is the second security operation launched by BA in the past few weeks. A similar operation was carried out in Frankfurt, where the airline was in danger of losing an important mail contract because of bag tampering.

The Paris authorities and the local workforce were informed that BA was using cameras in the hold, as required by French law. None of the handlers employed by BA's ground handling agent in Paris will be rostered on BA aircraft.

Victoria Beckham has been BA's highest profile customer to fall foul of luggage theft. She demanded free first class flights for life after her luggage was stolen. It emerged that the luggage had been stolen during an internal transfer from Heathrow to her final destination, Manchester.

John Stewardson, BA's senior manager in charge of investigations, said: "The great majority of our people who do our ground handling work around the world are excellent and law abiding."

But action would be taken against handlers suspected of illegal activity. He stressed that baggage theft was not confined to BA, and was evident across the aviation industry.

He added: "As we put our cameras in the holds, the message to anybody thinking about stealing from our aircraft is that if you do, there is a better than even chance of getting caught."

BA said its entire fleet, including Go and Deutsche BA, would be fitted soon.

Charles de Gaulle and Johannesburg airports between them between them account for 50% of all theft claims. Four other BA stations, three in the United States, are under close scrutiny.

webTitle: Setback for football clubs over replica kit

fields.headline: Setback for football clubs over replica kit
fields.trailText: The lucrative market in football club merchandise was threatened yesterday when Arsenal failed in a high court attempt to stop a market trader using its name on replica shirts.
fields.body:
The lucrative market in football club merchandise was threatened yesterday when Arsenal failed in a high court attempt to stop a market trader using its name on replica shirts.

The North London club was seeking court orders to protect the rights to its name, the nickname Gunners and the club crest and cannon emblem.

Trader and Arsenal fan Matthew Reed had used the name and logos on scarves, hats and shirts which he sold from stalls near the club's Highbury ground.

Yesterday Mr Justice Laddie upheld the trader's defence that he was using the marks as "badges of allegiance" so that fans could declare their support.

The club complained that Mr Reed, of Stanford le Hope, Essex, was guilty of "passing off" his goods as the real thing.

But Mr Reed's lawyers said there was an established trade in unofficial football club merchandise and that fans knew the difference.

However, the judge ruled that the trader's use of the trademarks as badges of allegiance could still be an infringement of the club's rights.

This question, he said, could only be decided by the European court of justice. The hearing resumes on May 1 when the court will decide whether the case should be referred straight to Europe or go to the court of appeal.

In the meantime Mr Reed can carry on trading. The trader has been an Arsenal fan since the early 1960s and began his business as the proprietor of a wholesale and retail football merchandise company more than 30 years ago. The football club has been in dispute with him for 10 years.

The ruling means football clubs could now be exposed to competition from bootleg traders without being able to retaliate in the courts.

Oliver Butler, editor of Soccer Investor magazine, said: "This will make clubs think twice about taking court action, if this precedent has been set."

But the sale of merchandise is not the cash cow it once was. "We're seeing merchandising sales stagnate or decrease. It isn't such a great source of revenue as TV or gate receipts."

Arsenal has used both criminal and civil law against traders selling goods without its licence.

Some had been prosecuted by trading standards officers, resulting in fines, community service orders, probation orders and the destruction of stock.

Match programmes have contained articles about the steps taken by the club to stop the sale of "counterfeit or illegal" goods.

webTitle: Paper puts on a brave face as senior journalists take express route out

fields.headline: Paper puts on a brave face as senior journalists take express route out
fields.trailText: The Express newspaper last night launched a promotional push headed by the TV presenter Davina McCall, at the end of a week in which about 100 staff said they wanted to leave the paper.
fields.body:
The Express newspaper last night launched a promotional push headed by the TV presenter Davina McCall, at the end of a week in which about 100 staff said they wanted to leave the paper.

Among those about to leave are the paper's assistant editor Robert Jobson, who joins the growing queue of staff who have decided they no longer want to work under the new owner, Richard Desmond.

This week the three most senior executives on the newsdesk quit, leaving the paper without a management team in the newsroom. The news operations of the Express, Sunday Express and the Daily Star are to be merged.

Morale is said to be at rock bottom. One source said: "Soon there will be no men standing. Journalistic integrity here is under immense pressure and many have decided that they are better off going even if the jobs market is flooded."

However, despite the departures, executives are said to be bullish. The arrival of the top celebrity photographer Jason Fraser has boosted the number of star pictures appearing in the paper. There have been strong promotional efforts with the paper's new magazine stablemate, OK!

Commentators have acknowledged that Chris Williams, who took over as editor when Rosie Boycott left last year, has done a commendable job in making the newspaper appear confident.

Nevertheless, the staff departures have not helped morale. The late Anthony Bevins, the political editor, became the first to quit after the takeover last year by Mr Desmond, who owns a string of pornographic magazines. Columnists Mary Kenny and Stephen Pollard left soon after. Peter Oborne became the latest to quit yesterday.

The head of news, Sean Rayment, news editor Alan Qualtrough and number three Phillip Derbyshire, have all resigned. Staff from the financial pages are also considering leaving. The showbusiness and media department is running at half strength. The exodus has been prompted by the announcement that Mr Desmond plans to make 145 staff redundant. All staff are being offered a severance package; around 100 have accepted.

Mr Jobson becomes the most senior departure since Ms Boycott left with her deputy, Chris Blackhurst, last year. He had ambitions to edit the paper and was considered a possible candidate following Mr Desmond's takeover of the paper last February. The job went to Mr Williams.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Nice to meet you, Mr Bond
fields.body:
Nice to meet you, Mr Bond

Sir Sean Connery and his wife, Micheline, were visiting the White House as tourists when Laura Bush came over and took them to meet George W Bush - "a wonderful surprise". The actor told the story while in Washington for an award from the Scottish-American community; he went on to urge Americans not to be dissuaded by foot and mouth from visiting Scotland and the UK.

Mother jailed for killing son

Lesley Wessel, 43, of Findon, West Sussex, was jailed for 4 years at Lewes crown court after admitting manslaughter in tranquillising and strangling her son Alex, 14. She afterward had tried suicide, depressed at losing her home and her third husband leaving.

Man cleared of manslaughter

An Old Bailey jury cleared Raymond Phillips, 29, from Harlesden, north London, of the manslaughter of Mohammed Chaudhry, 51, last June. Mr Phillips said he acted in self defence in a row after taking Mr Chaudhry's parking space at his computer college.

Permission for Easter march

The Derry Apprentice Boys have permission to march on Easter Monday along the lower Ormeau Road in Belfast for the first time since l999, though they must not play music.

£100m riding on Grand National

Bookies say this weekend will be their biggest ever, with £100m riding on today's Grand National, two FA Cup semi-finals, two Six Nations rugby matches, the US Masters, and the IBO world featherweight fight.

fields.headline: Ziggy and the Zeitgeist
fields.trailText: The "knock-on effect of The Dice Man [and] Warhol's culture flattening ..." as pervasive influences I have no trouble buying into (We reinvented culture the way we wanted it - with great big shoes: David Bowie remembers glam, G2, April 2). But when he moves on to co-opt Jacques Derrida and Michel Foucault into his pin-ups selection, I'm less convinced.
fields.body:
The "knock-on effect of The Dice Man [and] Warhol's culture flattening ..." as pervasive influences I have no trouble buying into (We reinvented culture the way we wanted it - with great big shoes: David Bowie remembers glam, G2, April 2). But when he moves on to co-opt Jacques Derrida and Michel Foucault into his pin-ups selection, I'm less convinced. "By 1970 [...] the break dances of Derrida and Foucault had substantially changed the notion of 'the absolute', of reality."

Well, yes. But here's a thing: Derrida's first three major works weren't translated until 1973, 1976, and 1978 respectively; and the first two major Foucault translations came in 1971 (The Order of Things) and 1972 (The Archaelogy of Knowledge). And then even professional philosophers had a devil of a time assimilating the conjoined epistemological "break" of these epochal texts. It would be at least half a decade or more - post 1970 - before those groovy "de.con" FX began to be felt outside the grooves of academe.

Bowie's pretensiousness is not at question here; but is he asking us to accept that - in between birthing and binning Ziggy, overhauling every other pop media extant and leading a tres eventful recreational life - he had the available longeurs to parse these fiendishly difficult texts ... in the original French?

Blimey. Consider my mind well and truly blown, Dave.
Ian Penman
London ian.pen@which.net

 Where, Tony Wright asks (Bad Language, April 6), is public philosophy? "Its absence," he says "is today's trahison des clercs." Quite right. As an academic philosopher, I struggle hard to write clearly. I have something to say which is I think of importance for our public life. What I experience is an unrelenting struggle to get anything into print anywhere, but especially in the public arena (my 1984 book, From Knowledge to Wisdom, is out of print). The media play their part in blocking lucid discussion of what our problems are and what we might do about them.
Nicholas Maxwell
Emeritus reader in philosophy of science, London University

 It's no coincidence that some of the new political class have easily exchanged the "verbless vacuities" of the left's esoteric argot for the equally obscure and vacuous jargon of the New Managerialism. I blame New Left Review for infecting an entire generation with orotundities of public discourse that ... Er, see what I mean?

London
M.Allen@cranfield.ac.uk
fields.bodyText: The "knock-on effect of The Dice Man [and] Warhol's culture flattening ..." as pervasive influences I have no trouble buying into (We reinvented culture the way we wanted it - with great big shoes: David Bowie remembers glam, G2, April 2). But when he moves on to co-opt Jacques Derrida and Michel Foucault into his pin-ups selection, I'm less convinced. "By 1970 [...] the break dances of Derrida and Foucault had substantially changed the notion of 'the absolute', of reality." Well, yes. But here's a thing: Derrida's first three major works weren't translated until 1973, 1976, and 1978 respectively; and the first two major Foucault translations came in 1971 (The Order of Things) and 1972 (The Archaelogy of Knowledge). And then even professional philosophers had a devil of a time assimilating the conjoined epistemological "break" of these epochal texts. It would be at least half a decade or more - post 1970 - before those groovy "de.con" FX began to be felt outside the grooves of academe. Bowie's pretensiousness is not at question here; but is he asking us to accept that - in between birthing and binning Ziggy, overhauling every other pop media extant and leading a tres eventful recreational life - he had the available longeurs to parse these fiendishly difficult texts ... in the original French? Blimey. Consider my mind well and truly blown, Dave. Ian Penman London ian.pen@which.net  Where, Tony Wright asks (Bad Language, April 6), is public philosophy? "Its absence," he says "is today's trahison des clercs." Quite right. As an academic philosopher, I struggle hard to write clearly. I have something to say which is I think of importance for our public life. What I experience is an unrelenting struggle to get anything into print anywhere, but especially in the public arena (my 1984 book, From Knowledge to Wisdom, is out of print). The media play their part in blocking lucid discussion of what our problems are and what we might do about them. webTitle: Letters: We're now back on track

fields.headline: We're now back on track
fields.trailText: Peter Hetherington's report of his train trip from Peterborough was highly selective (Travellers' patience frays as fares rise and delays get longer, April 5).
fields.body:
Peter Hetherington's report of his train trip from Peterborough was highly selective (Travellers' patience frays as fares rise and delays get longer, April 5). Rail passengers, particularly commuters, have undoubtedly had a dreadful time due to the speed restrictions, flooding and much longer journeys. That's why we provided 46 days full refund to season ticket holders as compensation.

Things are rapidly returning to normal. Over the past few weeks more than eight out of 10 trains have arrived on time. Next Monday, a new GNER timetable starts with more and faster journeys. On Monday we launched our £5 single (£10 return) promotion for travel anywhere on our route from London to Inverness. We recruited an extra 100 telesales staff and are keeping the lines open 14 hours a day. To date, over 70,000 tickets have been sold. In January we were applauded for freezing our proposed inflationary fare increase. It would have been wholly inappropriate because our services were far from normal. They will return to normal with the summer timetable from 21 May, when the inflationary increase will be applied.

GNER has felt many emotions over the past six months, but "rattled" is not one of the them. Sadness, shock, disappointment, certainly. But, our overriding emotion is one of determination - both to restore services to normal as soon as possible, to develop our award-winning service and to build a bigger and better railway. After two tragic accidents, the speed restrictions and pre-Christmas flooding, our 3,000 superb staff have been to hell and back. They have responded magnificently to the most difficult of circumstances, winning plaudits from many of our passengers. I am very proud of them.
Christopher Garnett
Chief executive, GNER

 You assume (In the grip of 'rail cancer', April 6) that the recent £1.5bn accelerated payment by the government (through the strategic rail authority) is "to help pay for re construction costs following the Hatfield tragedy". As Keith Harper pointed out (Analysis, April 5), the payment reflects the fact that the regulator allowed for us to spend about £15bn on maintenance and renewals in the next five years, but he only forwarded revenues of £13.5bn, with the balance to come at a later date, post 2006.

All parties agreed it was right that this deferred income should be paid as we spent it on the network. It in no way reflects any of the consequences of Hatfield, the full effects of which have been £600m in the year ended March 31 and which we have said our shareholders will pay for.
Donal McCabe
Railtrack

 The 10% increase in Virgin's rail fares is a drop in the ocean compared to First Great Western's 100+% increase thanks to a price rise and a change in the small print last summer. My return fare between Chippenham and Paddington has increased from £29 to £63. As a freelance consultant working in London two to three days per week, this increase is crippling my business. Instead of enticing infrequent users back on to the trains with £10 and £15 pound offers, rail operators should focus on their core asset - their commuters.
Caroline Wilson
Corsham, Wilts

 Balfour Beatty's head of rail operations, hence in charge of maintenance at Hatfield, is paid an £86,000 bonus. For what? Only one major crash during his first year?
Dr Dominic Elliott
University of Sheffield

fields.headline: Online Bell
fields.trailText: In a letter you published earlier this year (January 13), Oliver Kamm said "Martin Bell MP... has no website, never will have a website".
fields.body:
In a letter you published earlier this year (January 13), Oliver Kamm said "Martin Bell MP... has no website, never will have a website".

Oh yeah? Then what is www.bellforbrentwood.com? In the leaflet posted through my door, Bell's supporters state that he stands for true democracy. So far this media darling MP has dominated airtime and press inches to the exclusion of the other candidates in Brentwood & Ongar (except the sitting MP) - notably the only female candidate, Diana Johnson. Her website is www.labourlink.com/brentwood for those who like a more balanced view when selecting their candidate.
Martin Coule
Brentwood, Essex martin.coule@virgin.net

webTitle: Letters: A class act, but leave it out

fields.headline: A class act, but leave it out
fields.trailText: In Libby Brooks's interview with Steve McFadden, he rolled out all the usual rubbish about the working class and the theatre (Who shot me?, G2, April 4).
fields.body:
In Libby Brooks's interview with Steve McFadden, he rolled out all the usual rubbish about the working class and the theatre (Who shot me?, G2, April 4).

My father was a manual worker, my mother a typist, we lived in a pre-fab, then in a council house in a tough area where the neighbours practised with guns in the back yard to keep their aim in, and my brother used to have regular punch-ups to keep them out of our garden.

My mother was quite a soap fan - more Coronation Street than EastEnders - but that didn't stop her from going to the theatre as often as she could, from going to classical concerts, from reading and writing (or at least trying to write) poetry. My father couldn't stand football and spent what free time he had reading, or bashing out tunes on the piano in the pub.

"Soap snobbery" or any kind of snobbery, is not a purely middle-class phenomenon. It is also an ingrained attribute of people like Mr McFadden, who seem to believe that the interests of working-class people should be restricted to what is "good and proper" for them, as defined by a narrow set of prejudices. ("They're perfectly happy sitting at home watching EastEnders," he alleges.)

Who is Mr McFadden to say what working-class people or any class of people should be interested in? Their interests might include soaps, but why should they end there? Why not the theatre as well? So it's all right for Steve McFadden to go off and be an actor, apparently - an occupation which, round where we lived, would have had him down as highly suspect - but any other working-class person with interests outside of the usual is a pretentious prat?

Leave it out, Steve.
Alex Shearer
Backwell, Somerset

fields.trailText: If the rest of us can grasp the concept that someone who actively wants to join the royal family might not necessarily be the most sparkling firework in the box, why does it surprise The Firm (Press row envelops Queen, April 6)?
fields.body:
If the rest of us can grasp the concept that someone who actively wants to join the royal family might not necessarily be the most sparkling firework in the box, why does it surprise The Firm (Press row envelops Queen, April 6)?
Chris Coates
London

 Most of your writers have portraits at the head of their columns. May we please have one for Matthew Norman? Full head please, not one of your letter-box clips. Then we alopecian/slappy baldies - possibly including David Yelland (Diary, April 6) - can gawp in envy and reverence at the luxuriantly fecund follicles of which he is so proud.
Tim Gossling
Cambridge

 What about those thousands of us suffering from post-Thatcher stress disorder (Ex-service personnel to sue over trauma, April 3)? We would be happy made another example of "the growing compensation culture".
Bob Davenport
London

 Your list of soap shootings (It was Lisa who shot Eastender Phil, April 6) omitted the greatest shooting of them all: the Simpsons' wonderful spoof, "Who Shot Mr Burns?"
Paul Brazier
London

 So the emergency fuel distribution system (Wartime RAF pipeline may be used to beat future fuel protesters, April 6) is surveyed daily for damage. Disgraceful! It should be privatised at once, so that inspections can be reduced to twice a year and the money saved used to provide bonuses to directors.
Neil Muir
Shrewsbury

 Re the outraged expat letters (April 6): we've had Connex, now the French no longer have Marks & Sparks. Revenge, like a chicken tikka sandwich, is best eaten cold.
Gavin Greenwood
Brighton

webTitle: Leader: New pension scheme too frail

fields.headline: An uncertain stake
fields.standfirst:
The new pension scheme is too frail

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The need could not be more obvious. In no age group is the inequality of income as wide as among the retired. The future looks equally bleak. More than half the population still does not contribute to a pension.
fields.body:
The need could not be more obvious. In no age group is the inequality of income as wide as among the retired. The future looks equally bleak. More than half the population still does not contribute to a pension.

One motive behind the launch yesterday of the stakeholder pension is admirable: drawing in the previously excluded. Low-income people do need more help in retirement. All employers with more than five employees without an occupational scheme will be required to make a stakeholder scheme available.

Even the employers have had to concede the red tape has been cut to a minimum. The big pension companies are ready to do the paper work. Although employers will not be required to contribute, the government is committed to topping up every £78 contributed by employees with a further £22.

Moreover, pensioners are no longer to be restricted to wage earners. A divorced wife with a large lump sum will be able to invest in the scheme. Ditto unemployed workers with large redundancy pay outs. And ditto carers with capital wanting to attract extra government funds.

There are other benefits which the new scheme has generated. It has transformed the industry with its notorious hidden charges into a new 1% world. Unlike current schemes which can levy up to 7% in initial charges plus annual charges of 2% and policy charges of £2 a month, stakeholder providers are limited to a 1% charge. Several big names have brought in charges even below this level.

And yet the future of the scheme looks frail. Where once it was billed as a replacement for the state earnings related pensions scheme (serps), it now has an uncertain role as a gap plugger for people unable to afford a personal pension scheme. The reason low-income people do not contribute to a pension is that they cannot afford to. Average family savings have fallen from 12% of income in 1992 to 3% today.

Poor people have even lower savings. Moreover, for many people, an Isa, a tax-free individual savings account, is a better deal. Should their roof fall in, they would be able to take out their savings. A further problem has been created by the government's minimum income guarantee for the poorest pensioners.

This was vitally needed, but reduces the incentive to set aside contributions for a pension. The government's new pension credit reduces the disincentive but not entirely. Stand by for more restructuring after the election.
