fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with us here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help
fields.trailText: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with us here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help
fields.body:
Should I sell bonds for a better return?

I invested £5,000 in premium bonds in 1997. I won prizes worth 5% in the first two years, just 2% in the third year, and nothing over the past six months. Should I cut my losses and sell the bonds?
PH, Surrey

The premium bond prize fund returns 4% of the total in bonds tax-free - it has been reduced this month from 4.25%. The bigger your holding, the more likely you are to attain this average return. Anyone with a £5,000 holding is statistically likely to have a run of months with no prizes. But you could soon be lucky enough to win one of the 300 or so major prizes a month of between £5,000 and £1m. If you like the idea of a low risk punt, stick with the bonds -Ernie is a better deal than the national lottery. But if you want an income, sell - you can do better elsewhere.

Sickness cover and the artist

I'm a self-employed artist aged 53 living hand to mouth: so I'm good at surviving. But I do have occasional worries about the future. Although I can hardly afford to, should I take out sickness cover in case I can't work? I'm a single parent, claiming working families tax credit. I have very little savings.
AB, Powys

Don't waste your money on insurance. At your age, sickness cover will be very expensive. And there is the additional problem of claiming - you would have to be very ill or extremely disabled for insurance companies to admit you could not work any longer as an artist, not an occupational group they have any experience of, or sympathy with. Even the most basic cover - £100,000 if you die or suffer a serious illness such as cancer or heart attack - will cost you around £100 a month. As your savings are low and you already qualify for working families tax credit, you would be better off claiming income support if you are ill enough to stop work.

Smaller car, but refused a rebate

The Budget said cars up to 1,500cc will qualify for a £55 a year reduction in the tax disc, backdated to November 2000. I have a 1,300cc car, but the DVLA in Swansea has refused me a rebate. What's going on?
GO, Middlesex

Your car will qualify - but you must wait until July 1 before you can apply for a rebate back to November 1. This is to stop claims for cars that are scrapped between now and July 1.

I'm charged for foreign cheques

I am an academic receiving small royalty cheques from publishers. In January I was sent a US cheque for $175 - worth around £119 at current rates. But my bank, the Woolwich, told me they were unable to clear foreign cheques. We would have to use American Express for a £7.50 fee. But it did not end there. American Express hit me with a further £52.75 charge. I received £58.49 - I had lost half my money.

We switched our current account from Barclays to Woolwich last September to take advantage of the Open Plan mortgage deal. Barclays, which now owns the Woolwich, had charged for foreign cheques, but nothing like this. Is this a quirk of the Woolwich cheque clearing system or a feature common to the newly converted banks?
LB, south-west London

The Woolwich admits that it does not offer all the facilities of traditional high street banks. It says the Amex charge was out of its control. But it concedes that the Woolwich branch should have either advised you to go elsewhere or warned of the charges. The branch did neither, which Woolwich, to its credit, accepts was unfair. It is refunding the £60.25 fee. One solution is to keep an old account open for these occasional transaction.

Interest paid on storecard goods

We have a Selfridges storecard which we usually pay off in full every month. However, in February, we forgot to pay £34.95 which was then carried over on to our March bill. They then imposed a service charge (2% per month) of £7.70 on the £385 bill. Since the March bill was not then due, can they charge me interest on purchases ahead of the payment date?
LC, London

Yes. Rules on cards vary, but most only allow an interest-free period on purchases if your debt was cleared on the previous bill. Card issuers argue that you have borrowed money so you should pay.

Take the tax-free sum and get out

Participants in Equitable Life personal pension schemes without a guaranteed annuity rate are likely to see low growth rates in future.

It, therefore, appears a good but undiscussed strategy for people between 60 and 65 to make a penalty-free exit from the Equitable now by taking the maximum tax-free cash sum and converting the remainder to an annuity from elsewhere, even if they intend to continue working for a few more years.

Are there any legal impediments or hidden financial disadvantages to collecting benefits from one pension plan while still earning and contributing 40% of salary to a new pension plan?
DG, Essex

Given the present uncertainty, there is no point in throwing more money at Equitable Life - especially if you do not have a guaranteed annuity rate. The new stakeholder pension regime means that most providers can now rival Equitable's low cost flexibility - the basic reason for that company's success given its less than inspiring investment record.

There is no legal reason why you should not cash in on one personal pension while continuing to contribute to another but you should check the figures add up for your personal needs.

As you are over 60, you could contribute up to 40% of your income from earnings - not investments or annuities - into a personal pension plan. This could be tax-efficient.

If you are a 40% taxpayer, you could pay in £1,000, receive £400 back in tax relief, encash your pension still worth £1,000 and take £250 (25%) as a tax-free lump sum. The remaining £750 (assuming no investment growth or shrinkage) has cost you £350 so your actual annuity rate is really more than double the stated level given the low cash amount you have paid. For basic rate taxpayers, there are still some advantages by taking this course although they are less pronounced.

You could continue to invest and encash plans until you reach 75, providing you have sufficient earnings.

GO, Middlesex Your car will qualify - but you must wait until July 1 before you can apply for a rebate back to November 1. This is to stop claims for cars that are scrapped between now and July 1. I'm charged for foreign cheques I am an academic receiving small royalty cheques from publishers. In January I was sent a US cheque for $175 - worth around £119 at current rates. But my bank, the Woolwich, told me they were unable to clear foreign cheques. We would have to use American Express for a £7.50 fee. But it did not end there. American Express hit me with a further £52.75 charge. I received £58.49 - I had lost half my money. We switched our current account from Barclays to Woolwich last September to take advantage of the Open Plan mortgage deal. Barclays, which now owns the Woolwich, had charged for foreign cheques, but nothing like this. Is this a quirk of the Woolwich cheque clearing system or a feature common to the newly converted banks? LB, south-west London The Woolwich admits that it does not offer all the facilities of traditional high street banks. It says the Amex charge was out of its control. But it concedes that the Woolwich branch should have either advised you to go elsewhere or warned of the charges. The branch did neither, which Woolwich, to its credit, accepts was unfair. It is refunding the £60.25 fee. One solution is to keep an old account open for these occasional transaction. Interest paid on storecard goods We have a Selfridges storecard which we usually pay off in full every month. However, in February, we forgot to pay £34.95 which was then carried over on to our March bill. They then imposed a service charge (2% per month) of £7.70 on the £385 bill. Since the March bill was not then due, can they charge me interest on purchases ahead of the payment date? LC, London Yes. Rules on cards vary, but most only allow an interest-free period on purchases if your debt was cleared on the previous bill. Card issuers argue that you have borrowed money so you should pay. Take the tax-free sum and get out Participants in Equitable Life personal pension schemes without a guaranteed annuity rate are likely to see low growth rates in future. It, therefore, appears a good but undiscussed strategy for people between 60 and 65 to make a penalty-free exit from the Equitable now by taking the maximum tax-free cash sum and converting the remainder to an annuity from elsewhere, even if they intend to continue working for a few more years. Are there any legal impediments or hidden financial disadvantages to collecting benefits from one pension plan while still earning and contributing 40% of salary to a new pension plan? DG, Essex Given the present uncertainty, there is no point in throwing more money at Equitable Life - especially if you do not have a guaranteed annuity rate. The new stakeholder pension regime means that most providers can now rival Equitable's low cost flexibility - the basic reason for that company's success given its less than inspiring investment record. There is no legal reason why you should not cash in on one personal pension while continuing to contribute to another but you should check the figures add up for your personal needs. As you are over 60, you could contribute up to 40% of your income from earnings - not investments or annuities - into a personal pension plan. This could be tax-efficient. If you are a 40% taxpayer, you could pay in £1,000, receive £400 back in tax relief, encash your pension still worth £1,000 and take £250 (25%) as a tax-free lump sum. The remaining £750 (assuming no investment growth or shrinkage) has cost you £350 so your actual annuity rate is really more than double the stated level given the low cash amount you have paid. For basic rate taxpayers, there are still some advantages by taking this course although they are less pronounced. You could continue to invest and encash plans until you reach 75, providing you have sufficient earnings.

fields.headline: Rail commuter's ticket ordeal
fields.standfirst: Connex staff breached rules by refusing to sell child tickets to a parent - highlighting the approach of train companies, reports Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: Connex staff breached rules by refusing to sell child tickets to a parent - highlighting the approach of train companies, reports Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
The piece I wrote last week on the dubious legality of Connex's willingness to delay passengers during its vigorous ticket inspections struck a chord with a reader from West Sussex who wants to be known as just Martin.

In a story that exemplifies the way rail companies now treat customers, he and his two daughters had been held up at Victoria the previous Sunday for nearly 30 minutes, with no fewer than four Connex employees refusing at some point to sell them tickets.

Three Bridges station near Crawley, where they joined the train, had no staff on duty and, Martin claims, three broken machines. The guard, who was doubling rather inexpertly as a ticket inspector, announced that passengers who hadn't purchased a ticket should come to his van to buy one. After Martin and his daughters had been queuing for about 10 minutes, during which just two tickets were sold, the guard lost interest and told remaining passengers that they should buy theirs at Victoria.

Diligently, Martin and the girls joined the ticket office queue at Victoria. When they finally reached its head, the clerk said she would not sell him child tickets without proof of his daughters' age.

Connex, when subsequently questioned by Jobs & Money about this, admitted there was no possible basis for such a refusal.

Even if the clerk had doubts about whether the girls were under 16, that is a matter for a ticket inspector when they try to use the tickets.

An adult is, in any case, entitled to buy child tickets, even if the child isn't present.

Martin wrote to Connex the same day saying of that clerk: "To call this woman rude and unhelpful would be a serious understatement."

Despite the company's supposed commitment to customer service, a fortnight later the letter had not been acknowledged, let alone action taken, or a request made for further information that might have enabled her to be identified.

A spokesman this week merely claimed: "An investigation is now under way."

After the clerk's refusal, an inspector was called over. He too refused to sell Martin any tickets, saying they could only be bought from the main ticket office.

Less scrupulous passengers would probably have felt that Connex had had its chance to collect its money by now and simply left the station.

However, Martin did go over to the main office. There another unhelpful clerk initially declined to sell him tickets, saying he should find another inspector. Martin finally procured tickets by, for the first time, refusing to co-operate with Connex's nonsense and saying he wasn't leaving until they were provided.

These facts do not give Martin the potential claim for damages for false imprisonment that I discussed last week, although they would have done had anyone attempted to physically stop him leaving the station.

Requiring proof of a child's age, except on the Tube, where 13-year-olds to 15-year-olds have to carry a photocard as a condition of half-price travel, is a breach of the rail company's obligations to carry passengers. It is improbable that junior staff would adopt these obstructive policies if they knew management would come down on them like a ton of bricks.

Of course, all large organisations are going to employ a few surly, unhelpful or glaringly incompetent persons who come into contact with customers.

However, although one may have a lot of disdain for how, say, banks and supermarkets operate, neither as a rule has such lax standards that four such people could be encountered in the course of the most routine transaction. Nor is it likely they would ignore a letter such as the one Martin wrote.

Part of the problem with Connex may derive from the fact that it has already lost its South Central franchise. Those running the railway may now have little interest in its long-term future.

All they can hope to do is maximise revenue, and hence profits, over the short period they remain in charge.

The argument advanced by Connex to defend its aggressive fare enforcement policies - that honest customers lose out because of fare dodgers - does not hold water. The fare- capping system means it will inevitably charge as much as the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority will allow. "Fare dodging", deplorable though it is, merely erodes profits.

The priority Connex repeatedly gives to this issue, at the expense of more serious problems in its service, is, in the opinion of many, why it should be required to hand over the business before the franchise formally expires in 2003.

Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: My big break
fields.standfirst: What Katie flew next
fields.trailText: What Katie flew next
fields.body:
Katie Board is not just Britain's only female airship pilot, she is the only one in the world - although there is an Austrian woman rising through the training ranks at the moment. She is also the pivotal member of an otherwise all-male crew. Frequently she will be summoned to fly with just an hour's notice. Often she will spend 10 hours alone in the four-seater cockpit with no autopilot and no toilet. And she is just 24 years old.

"I've always been a bit of a loner. But I do sing to myself," she says. It is a job that demands a rock solid nerve and self-belief, as well as strong communication skills for the occasions when she is carrying passengers. Ms Board says she has never been afraid while in the air. "It's only once you are back on the ground that I sometimes realise what could have happened," she says.

An airship is a strange beast. It is at the meeting point of old and new technology. The steering system is similar to a boat's, with left and right peddles and a wheel that edges the nose up or down, but some of its filming and surveillance equipment is state of the art.

The Ministry of Defence is trailing the use of airships in mine detection in Kosovo and Ms Board would jump at the chance to go. Airships are ideal for this kind of work as, unlike helicopters, they do not cause dangerous vibrations on the ground.

The blimp is also a mode of transport that, in a techno-saturated world, still inspires awe and excitement in those who spot it sneaking silently over their heads. She tells the story of a night flight over the M4 when the balloon was lit from inside. "I was contacted by an air traffic control tower who had been called by the police. Apparently I was causing chaos on the motorway as people were convinced they'd spotted a UFO."

Her passion sprang from a flying lesson in a Cessna given to her as a present for her 19th birthday. She was instantly hooked, but her parents would not pay for more lessons. "There are three ways of getting your flying paid for. You can join the forces, but I decided that this would not be honest as I have absolutely no intention of killing anyone, you can get sponsored by a commercial airline and then be bonded to them, or you can fork out £40,000 and pay for it yourself."

She decided instead to work for a flying club for her gap year, making contacts and taking every opportunity possible to gain airtime and flying hours. She took up a place at Kingston University to study aeronautical engineering, but soon realised she could not afford to stay at college, so she filled a bag and moved to Gatwick, determined to find a job.

"I knocked on every door, but most places just told me I was overqualified and that I would soon leave. I ended up working as a waitress for six weeks, but then I got a job in the accounts department of Air 2000 working on their scheduled services.

"I still had plenty of friends in the flying world and so I still took every opportunity I could to get airborne. I would always offer to fly friends' planes back from places. It gave me some fantastic experiences and I got to fly some rare planes and helicopters."

Her next job was with Virgin's balloon flights operation, but was still office based. A couple of months later came her big break. "They told us they were relocating to Telford and offered everyone either redundancy, a relocation package or the opportunity to work for another Virgin company. Which do you think I went for?"

After two months of interviews, she was accepted on to the airship training programme, starting as a member of the ground crew.

"I think it's really important to have done some crewing. It means that I really understand just what is going on on the ground. I also remember the difference between how I felt on my first airship flight and how I felt on the first flight after I'd crewed.

"The crews are fantastic, they really work together. If ever we meet another crew, we'll always share information, even if we're supposed to be commercial rivals."

It is a situation that cannot occur with great frequency, however - there are just 23 airships in the world and 17 of them are owned by Virgin.

So what ambitions does she have left? "I'd love to do the Atlantic crossing. Watch this space: although you'll find that airship pilots are always talking about it. But if it was being done, I'd like to be the pilot."

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Marketing is increasingly about creating consumer preferences where there are no real differences among competing products.
fields.body:
Marketing is increasingly about creating consumer preferences where there are no real differences among competing products. Blind product tests invariably show consumers cannot tell the difference between one beer or cigarette and another. Most personal computers and cars are functionally identical.

Yet, even though they cannot recognise product differences, consumers do have strong preferences and are often willing to pay a big price premium for their favourite. These preferences are based on the emotional values marketers have associated with a brand's name. Sometimes these associations are about prestige or status. BMW, Rolex and Martini are examples of status brands.

More common today are brands that promise shared values with which consumers want to be associated. Examples of these lifestyles brands are Ben & Jerry's, Coca-Cola and Virgin.

Such associations are typically built on the creativity and investment the company makes in advertising and packaging. When done well these investments build intangible assets that create tremendous value for shareholders. For example, the Coca-Cola brand name is valued at £50bn.

Absolut Vodka is entering marketing folklore as an example of creative branding. Twenty years ago, Sweden's state-run liquor monopoly decided to export vodka to the US to help the country's export drive.

That vodka was seen as Russian, the US market was extremely competitive and Sweden had no history of producing vodka, did not bother the advertising agency charged with developing the strategy. The marketers appreciated that all vodka looked, smelled and tasted the same. The key was to come up with a unique image that consumers could identify with.

They first created an unusual bottle that could signify the brand's uniqueness. They then decided on the name Absolut and on positioning the brand as being purer than the competitors - even though, as yet, they had no product.

Next they decided the brand needed heritage, so they claimed it had been produced for 400 years. As the agency cheerfully pointed out, "fraud had always been part of the advertising business". They then developed one of the most successful advertising campaigns in history, all built around a two-word play on the product name. Starting with Absolut Perfection and Absolut Elegance artists and celebrities, like Andy Warhol and Salman Rushdie, competed to extend the brand's creative expression.

Finally, they built a plant in Stockholm to make the product. Today it has become a $3bn brand, by far the most successful export vodka and an icon in the industry.

This reminds us that, in today's biggest markets, success is rarely about product superiority. Companies like Coca-Cola, IBM and Microsoft increasingly see manufacturing as a non-core activity that can be contracted out.

The competitiveness of top brands is generally based on how their brand images have been created and developed.

It is curious how the government has not understood this. In seeking to close Britain's productivity gap, Mr Brown focuses on giving incentives for investment in plant and equipment and R&D. In the competitiveness reports it publishes marketing never gets mentioned. But today, intangibles like brands are far more important than tangible assets like factories and machinery.

Britain's competitiveness and productivity will be enhanced far faster by creating more appealing brands rather than by building more efficient factories.

Peter Doyle is professor of marketing at Warwick Business School. His latest book is Value-Based Marketing. P.Doyle@warwick.ac.uk

webTitle: When customer service is a lifeline

fields.headline: When customer service is a lifeline
fields.standfirst: It looks as though the economy is in for a bumpy ride so companies would do well to study past recessions for survival tips, writes Jonathan Dee
fields.trailText: It looks as though the economy is in for a bumpy ride so companies would do well to study past recessions for survival tips, writes Jonathan Dee.
fields.body:
Do not let recent stock market tremors distract you from the economic achievements of the past decade, which has seen almost unprecedented growth. The British economy, for example, has enjoyed continual growth since 1993, unemployment has declined, inflation has fallen and standards of living are rising.

That said, of course, it has not all been rosy; and now there is talk of an economic downturn, though many stop short of whispering the 'R' word. This dip in economic fortunes, however transitional or shallow, is still there.

Whether we have a soft landing, or miss the runway entirely, the outlook could look potentially very bleak, if the early 90s are anything to go by. Then, the recession meant high job losses and organisation-wide budget slashing. This resulted in only the fittest and fastest companies emerging relatively unscathed on the other side of the gloom, surviving in conditions where others submerged in a sea of profit-warnings, balance sheet misery and internal collapse.

What kept the survivors buoyant then was (and is) their ability to cope with uncertainty and respond positively to changing circumstances. They kept their focus on the external customer, recognising that it was essential to keep customer loyalty high when marketing and advertising budgets were cut to a bare minimum. They knew that when customers leave, they leave in droves - ask M&S.

A recent BBC study shows that customers dissatisfied with services or goods are likely to tell at least eight others about their bad experience, so any mistake by an organisation is multiplied across the marketplace.

Many businesses are beginning to recognise that when the economy is in for a bumpy ride, there should be increased marketing activity and an unrelenting pursuit of customer loyalty.

This is reinforced by the Harvard Business Review, which analysed the links of the employer-customer-profit chain at Sears. It found that a 5% increase in staff satisfaction correlated with a 1.3% increase in customer satisfaction, which delivered a 0.5% increase in sales.

The logic for this is devastatingly simple and just as powerful. However tempting it is for an organisation to cut the softer-edged budgets like internal communications, marketing and human resources, when the economy heads south, the truth is, this very act could lead to the failure that every company wants to avoid.

A good example of avoiding this scenario is Tesco, which has toppled Sainsbury's from its perch as our top supermarket chain.

Tesco's "Every little helps" initiative is more than a glib marketing slogan. It promises to meet customer expectations of quality, service and value.

As Tim Mason, Tesco marketing director, explains: "What we're saying with our every little helps campaign is that whatever it is you're looking for, whether it is organic vegetables, healthy eating or advice on lactose intolerance, whatever it is that you need we try really hard to have thought of that and to provide it as part of your routine shopping trip.

"One of the great liberating things that we ever did was to say to our staff, treat your customers the way you'd like to be treated, and allowed them to go wrong providing they were genuinely trying to help the customer."

Organisations that have truly connected with their customers, such as Tesco, Orange and First Direct, have also built empathy with their workforces. Such companies understand that to produce a competitive shield, it is crucial to galvanise their employees to back the corporate strategy and give them the freedom as individuals to chase their ideas with passion tinged with commercial awareness.

If a sharp economic slowdown does occur, only those firms which have earned the backing of their employees and the loyalty of their customers through high levels of service will be able to cope.

Jonathan Dee is a business communication consultant. Email: jonathan.dee@bannermcbride.com

"One of the great liberating things that we ever did was to say to our staff, treat your customers the way you'd like to be treated, and allowed them to go wrong providing they were genuinely trying to help the customer." Organisations that have truly connected with their customers, such as Tesco, Orange and First Direct, have also built empathy with their workforces. Such companies understand that to produce a competitive shield, it is crucial to galvanise their employees to back the corporate strategy and give them the freedom as individuals to chase their ideas with passion tinged with commercial awareness. If a sharp economic slowdown does occur, only those firms which have earned the backing of their employees and the loyalty of their customers through high levels of service will be able to cope. Jonathan Dee is a business communication consultant. Email: jonathan.dee@bannermcbride.com

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Sandy Leitch, Chief executive Zurich Financial
fields.trailText: Sandy Leitch, Chief executive Zurich Financial
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To excel in computer systems design back in 1965 and to prove that I had made the right decision by forsaking my place at university.

What has been your best moment in management?

Becoming chairman of Allied Dunbar - 25 years to the day after I joined the firm as a systems designer.

And your greatest mistake?

In my early career, not "daring to fail" enough.

How would you describe your management style?

Demanding, but caring.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

I can't tolerate dishonesty - that really upsets me.

Does your organisation have a "glass ceiling"?

No.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

It gets easier the higher you go.

What is the biggest challenge facing your industry?

Consumer awareness of the need to save and protect. The average life insurance per UK family is £15,000. That is truly terrible.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Enthusiasm will overcome most obstacles.

Who is your management hero?

I don't have one but I do respect great, inspiring leaders from Nelson Mandela, to Jack Welch to Tony Blair.

Who is your favourite politician?

The politician whom I admired most was the late leader of the Labour party, John Smith.

If you could change an aspect of British business, what would it be?

Alter our national trait of underselling ourselves.

Do you have a view on British membership of the EMU?

It will come eventually.

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Giving - I believe this is probably a higher form of happiness than achieving. I once heard a Franciscan monk say: "Poverty can be dignified if you choose it, wealth is only ever worthwhile if you share it."

What annoys you most?

Thoughtlessness in others, and the enormous gap between the haves and have nots - we must all do everything we can to close this gap.

How do you relax?

Listening to music, enjoying the antiques and art that I impulsively collect and the company of friends.

What was your last cultural experience?

Eric Clapton concert at the Royal Albert Hall.

What is your favourite city?

I have two: Bath, where I spent much of my working life, and Edinburgh.

Do you have a favourite website?

www.dunfermline-athletic.com - Scotland's greatest football team.

What is your greatest regret?

Not knowing my father, who died when I was two.

What is your biggest fear?

I still don't like rats or heights!

What would you really like to have been?

A successful 18th-century explorer.

fields.headline: Dusting off the V&A
fields.trailText: You report the perception of families with young children is that the V&A is "dry" and "dusty". They are spot on (V&A offers glimpse of 'glamorous' galleries, April 5).
fields.body:
 The notion that I have given the V&A a six-month deadline "to justify its existence" (April 3) is entirely fanciful. There is certainly a need for all of us to think hard about how this great museum can present itself better to the public. But an ultimatum from me to the new director would hardly improve the chances of this happening. I have confidence that visitors will continue to increase, and that the museum will scrap admission charges later this year, following the VAT changes announced in the Budget.

The new director Mark Jones has a big job. Stories about non-existent deadlines will not make it any easier.
Chris Smith MP
Secretary of state for Culture, Media and Sport

webTitle: Minding someone else's business for a change

fields.headline: Minding someone else's business for a change
fields.standfirst: Jump the queue with a course in consulting
fields.trailText: Jump the queue with a course in consulting
fields.body:
A glance at any league table of graduates' preferred career options suggests that management consultancy remains an attractive option for many. The Universum survey of graduates' ideal employers published in last week's Rise ranked Accenture, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Arthur Andersen all within the top ten.

This means that there is always an over-supply of candidates aspiring to enter the arena but a growing number of MA and MSc courses in research and consulting are helping to place postgraduates at the front of the queue.

Postgraduate qualifications are by no means a pre-requisite for career entry. A strong academic background to degree level and evidence of strong interpersonal skills is enough for some of the largest practices who are happy to recruit at graduate level. The strategy houses, for example, will take a few of the highest flyers of their year - typically candidates who have achieved a 2:1 or first-class degree from one of the most prestigious universities - and usually with a strong numerical basis to their academic background. These 'bright young things' will be recruited into the most junior consultancy grade, generally described as 'analyst' and, as the title suggests, carrying a remit that concentrates on the research and analysis of technical information to support more senior consultants in the provision of their services.

An alternative route of early entry is via a chartered accountancy traineeship with one of the big firms of accountants. Some of these practices will offer the best applicants the chance for entry to their consultancy arm after qualifying via the tax or audit division.

For the majority of consultants entry into the profession comes later, typically between the ages of 28 and 35, having armed themselves with a broad-based background of commercial experience.

However relevant postgraduate qualifications can provide a shortcut for graduates eager to begin their consulting career.

MBAs are an obvious springboard into consultancy and many firms will view the decision to undertake an MBA as a good indication of a candidate's commitment to investing in their career. But MBAs can be costly and are often available only to graduates with several years of management experience.

The number universities offering less expensive MAs or MScs in consulting, however is on the increase.

Lancaster Universty's School of Independent Studies, which has been allowing postgrads to tailor their own courses for the last 30 years, has launched an MA in Applied Research and Consultancy. Open to graduates in any discipline, the course allows students to focus on a sector or area of their choosing.

But what makes the Lancaster MA unique is the opportunity it gives students to spend much of their year acting as a consultant to one of the university's public or private sector partners which include BBC Radio Lancashire, the Royal Exchange Theatre, publisher Blackwells, Lancaster city council and The Guardian. Once the university has matched a student with a relevant organisation, the student is set a problem or challenge and a deadline for drawing up recommendations.

Recent projects have included evaluating European marketing strategy, producing a company video of broadcast quality and drawing up a business plan for a literature festival.

Director of independent studies John Wakeford says the course offers something very different from work placements. "Our clients treat our students as consultants, not as someone they can give routine tasks," he says. "It's a real selling point for our students when they start applying for jobs."

The school has even unleashed some of its students to examine the challenges facing the university. Psychology graduate Sianne Gordon is currently working with the arts and humanities faculty to examine ways of generating new income streams. "Because the course is project-based, I'm developing a whole set of skills which I can transfer to the workplace," she says.

The MA can be taken as a full-time course over 12 months or on a part-time basis over 24 months. Fees are £2,805 for full-time and £1,405 for part-time students, but six bursaries ranging from £600 to full fees will be available for the 2001/02 academic year.

Other postgraduate consulting courses include the MA in Business Consultancy at Leeds Metropolitan and MScs in Management Consultancy at the University of Salford and at Nottingham Business School.

Several courses are accredited by the Institute of Management Consultancy (www.imc.co.uk).

webTitle: Heard the one about the comedy workshop?

fields.headline: Heard the one about the comedy workshop?
fields.standfirst: Use humour in a job interview or presentation and you'll be laughing
fields.trailText: Use humour in a job interview or presentation and you'll be laughing.
fields.body:
"What did the big cigarette say to the little cigarette?"

While the response (you're too young to smoke) is unlikely to get you many laughs, jokes are a great way to break the ice in many situations. However, you not only have to pick your moment but also the joke.

Infantile humour may work well in a social situation, but how can you tell what jokes or humour would be appropriate at a job interview, meeting or presentation?

Jongleurs Comedy Club, the launch pad for the careers of many stand-up comedians runs one-day workshops on presentation skills where participants have to write and perform a five-minute comedy sketch.

The workshops are the brainchild of Maria Kempinska, founder and owner of Jongleurs. "My background is in teaching and drama and the idea came about because I wanted to develop a presentations skills course which was a bit different," explains Maria.

The workshop, which is run by a trained performer, teaches participants about the importance of connecting with their audience when presenting. In particular, it shows them how to project their voices and use the microphone effectively.

However, the aim of the workshop is not just to improve participants' presentation skills but also to give them the confidence to incorporate humour into their presentations where appropriate.

This is where tact and diplomacy come in according to Maria. "Jokes which were appropriate 20 years ago may now be deemed offensive to some people. If you're beginning a presentation and want to make a joke, self-deprecating humour works well - perhaps a joke or anecdote about your journey, something along the lines of "On my way here..."

This not only gets a reaction from the audience - hopefully laughs - but puts you on their level."

Humour can be used to advantage in other situations such as meetings or even interviews. The key again is knowing when and how to use humour.

"In difficult meetings when the tension is rising and suddenly difficult issues start to become personal, a joke about the situation can lighten the mood, but it's important not to make jokes about or at the expense of other people," suggests Maria.

Most people get nervous at interviews, so using humour at a time when you are nervous and keen to impress may sound counter-intuitive. Nevertheless, humour used at the right time and about an appropriate subject can be to your benefit.

Subtle humour works best at interviews - perhaps a joke about the industry in which the company operates or about its competitors. The idea here is to use humour to show your knowledge about the company.

However, cautions Maria, it's important to know when to stop. Telling too many jokes at an interview might give the impression that you're not serious. And remember that the purpose of the interview is to get a job. "Similarly, telling a string of jokes in a presentation is not appropriate - it's better to casually drop humour into the presentation at key moments rather than treat it as a comedy stand-up routine," she adds.

We could all do with some humour in our lives but who benefits from attending such a workshop? "People from all walks of life have done the workshops - IT executives, insurance salesmen and PR professionals. We have had excellent feedback from all those who have attended," says Maria.

The workshop gets the thumbs-up from Jeremy Eaton, managing director of Vital PR, who took part in the workshop with members of his staff and some of his clients.

"Most people have had some form of presentation training but in my opinion the courses are all very similar and sometimes people forget about the communication aspect and are just going through the motions. The Jongleurs workshop looked at presentation skills from a very different angle," says Jeremy.

For Vital PR, the fact that clients and staff did the workshop together worked well. "It didn't matter what position you had in the office, everyone was at the same level and had to write and perform a five minute comedy sketch with no props and no PowerPoint slides to rely on."

Not that Jeremy has anything against using technology in presentations but "sometimes people hide behind technology when presenting. PowerPoint slides are an aid to a presentation - they should not be the main focus".

And what benefits did Vital PR's staff gain from the workshop? According to Jeremy, it has given them a massive confidence boost. "We have a couple of younger staff who are just out of university - the course not only gave them the confidence to present but also showed them how to inject a bit of humour into their presentations.

"In particular, one account manager lacked confidence but is very knowledgeable and competent. She would often start a presentation by apologising, but the course made clients and other staff look at her in a different way, appreciate her knowledge and expertise and it gave her more belief in herself."

Jongleurs: www.jongleurs.com

webTitle: How to ... work for men and women bosses

fields.headline: How to ... work for men and women bosses
fields.standfirst: Are female managers really less dictatorial and authoritarian?
fields.trailText: Are female managers really less dictatorial and authoritarian?
fields.body:
Despite longstanding equal opportunity legislation and a climate of political correctness, women bosses are still seen as 'different' from their male counterparts. Not necessarily better, or worse. But different all the same. Gender is commonly supposed to influence how they deal with their peers and subordinates.

But are there really any significant differences between working for a man and working for a woman? Moreover, if there are, how should you make the best of the situation?

If we are to believe Dr John Gray, male and female bosses are worlds apart. The author of the best selling self-help book Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus , writes at length about the differences. He concludes that men are interested in objects and things, whereas women are interested in people and feelings.

Many dismiss this theory as inaccurate, sexist nonsense. Angela Ishmael, head of the Dignity at Work Community Initiative at the Industrial Society, says that what makes one boss different from another has much less to do with gender than management style.

And management style, she argues, is based on your boss's business sense and is independent of biology.

Most of the convincing academic research in this field suggests that, if anything, male and female managers are more alike than dissimilar; this finding was most recently confirmed in the 2000 edition of Women in Management - Current Research .

The few differences that do appear to exist can be simplified. Dr Sandi Mann, author of Psychology Goes To Work and senior lecturer at Lancaster University, says that women tend to be more co-operative, team-orientated and people-orientated. They are concerned about individuals and keen for everyone to participate. Men, she says, on the whole, are less consultative and more authoritarian. However, points out Dr Mann, these are sweeping generalisations and are by no means true of all men or all women.

Richard Branson has a reputation - real or spun - for a caring, sharing, collaborative relationship with his staff. The same could hardly be said for Margaret Thatcher.

So, for you the question is not how do you deal with a boss that is either male or female, but how do you deal with a boss that's either democratic or, at the other extreme, dictatorial.

Professor Marilyn Davidson, of the Manchester School of Management at UMIST, is considered something of an expert when it comes to these sorts of questions. She offers the following advice for those who have a "lets-do-this-together" boss:

 Don't try to get away with doing the minimum, letting those around you do your work for you.

 Don't shrug off responsibility for yourself.

 Do take the initiative.

 Do get involved.

 Do ask for guidance if it is not forthcoming.

Meanwhile, for those who toil under a "do-as-I-say" boss:

 Don't be arrogant.

 Don't be bolshie

 Do open up the lines of communication.

 Do seek out opportunities for more work freedom.

 Do try to empower yourself in the office as best as possible.

Remember, that regardless of your particular boss, just because you don't like them doesn't mean you have to lump them. "You have choices," says Professor Davidson. "You can always walk away and go elsewhere."

fields.headline: 'We'd rather work for a bloke'
fields.trailText: While academics may not always be able to agree if there is a difference between male and female bosses, those working directly with them certainly can.
fields.body:
While academics may not always be able to agree if there is a difference between male and female bosses, those working directly with them certainly can.

In a recent poll the recruitment company Office Angels found that 64% of its respondents would prefer to work for a man. Around 30% had no preference. That left just 6 % who would opt for a woman.

Sonia Liff, senior lecturer at Warwick Business School, found that as many as 25% of men interviewed said they would "find it difficult to work with a woman".

This is despite research in the US which showed that both peers and subordinates rated senior female executives higher than their male counterparts.

'Men blow their own trumpets'

Never mind male and female bosses - what about male and female colleagues? Is there a difference between the ways these two halves of the species deal with office life?

One lifestyle magazine recently argued that "men and women do things differently in the office"; it also suggested some lessons the sexes can learn from each other.

For example, women can teach men to talk things through, to have a good laugh, to listen to people's feelings and to look out for more than number one.

Men, on the other hand, can teach women to blow their own trumpet, to get to the point, to keep their cool and to stop being nice all the time.

webTitle: An ABC guide to scoring well in psychometric tests

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to scoring well in psychometric tests
fields.trailText: A. Made to measure
fields.body:
A. Made to measure

If you've got it, someone will want to measure it. Attributes such as problem solving, spatial ability and even your personality won't be taken on trust. Employers want to see how you compare and they have the tools to do the job. Psychometric means measuring the mind, a tricky undertaking but one that keeps many occupational psychologists busy as they strive to apply scientific rigour to it. The theory is that reputable tests are fair, reliable, can't be fixed and do what they're meant to.

B. Compare and contrast

Because the mind is as much of a mystery to its owner as to outsiders, the outcome of such tests can provide enlightenment for both. Whatever the result in employment terms you should ask for feedback. Raw scores might not mean much on their own - it's considered good practice to provide a detailed interpretation of them as well. As you're always being compared with others, it's essential to know who they are, what's being looked for and how you performed.

C. Time trials

Whatever your attributes, you can always adjust them a little. Many are timed so the ability to work quickly and accurately can make a difference. All reputable testers send out some preparatory material and hints on how to prepare, but there's

more you can get from careers offices and websites like www.shldirect.com - if you know what to expect and brush up on associated techniques, you'll be better able to measure up.

fields.standfirst: News
fields.trailText: • Class action: The number of graduates applying to do teacher training jumped by almost a quarter last month compared with March 2000. There was a 24% rise in both primary and secondary applications while the number wanting to work in comprehensives was up by 27%, according to the Graduate Teacher Training Registry.
fields.body:
 Class action: The number of graduates applying to do teacher training jumped by almost a quarter last month compared with March 2000. There was a 24% rise in both primary and secondary applications while the number wanting to work in comprehensives was up by 27%, according to the Graduate Teacher Training Registry.

 Aussie rules: The secret of career success could lie solely in self- confidence. Researchers at Teeside University studied 70 rugby league players and found that players who learned to play in Australia, and play mostly in Australia, also have the highest levels of self-confidence. The Australian rugby league team has won every World Cup since 1975.

 Rabitting on: Rise is taking a much-needed week off and will return on April 21. In the meantime, why not sign up for the Guardian Graduate Email - a weekly digest of advice and jobs which delivers more goodies than the Easter bunny. Sign up at www.theguardian.com/graduates. Rise is edited by Ian Wylie

 Don't mention the fussball:

If you've been laid off by a bankrupt dot.com, adjust your attitude before attending your next job interview advises career consultancy The Five O'Clock Club. For a start, don't consider yourself superior to others just because you worked in the internet business. Don't talk about the jeans atmosphere. Or the music in the background or that people brought dogs to work. Most likely, they want someone serious. Many dot.comers had so much fun that's all they talk about. Instead, play it down: "Yes, I learned a lot, but I'd love to tell you about some of the other things I've accomplished."

webTitle: Help: I have a problem past!

fields.headline: Help: I have a problem past!
fields.standfirst: I left my first job to go travelling after eight months because I loathed my boss. I'm back now and getting interviews but not jobs. I'm sure it's because I find my reasons for such a short stay hard to explain.  AE, account executive, Liverpool
fields.trailText: I left my first job to go travelling after eight months because I loathed my boss. I'm back now and getting interviews but not jobs. I'm sure it's because I find my reasons for such a short stay hard to explain. AE, account executive, Liverpool.
fields.body:
Your applications are good enough for potential employers to want to know more about you so they're not worried about the short stay. Something's happening when you talk to them that makes them uneasy. You need to exorcise the strong dislike you have for your ex-boss.

If that's coming across in interviews it's likely to make them wary. There's an invisible bond of support among managers - they identify with each other. Belittle one and you hurt them all. The golden rule of describing your past is to be nothing less than positive about a previous employer, however bad they were.

Grievances never come out in a way that does you any credit. By highlighting personality conflicts you're asking a recruiter to take sides: a bad idea because they feel greater loyalty and kinship towards your previous employer than to you.

Recruitment is an expensive business. Employers need reassurance you won't be a force of discontent or give into travel urges. They will however react positively to the concept of learning from mistakes. Appear to take the blame for all that went wrong and they'll treat that with the same scepticism as any boss-from-hell tale. Go for the line "I wasn't ready to handle the situation, but taking time out has made me aware of what I want and you are part of that". Self-awareness, humility and flattery: a combination few employers can resist.

Irene Krechowiecka (ijk@excite.com)

fields.headline: Baking the oven-ready graduate
fields.standfirst: Careers services in line for a shake-up
fields.trailText: Is your careers service doing enough for you? Not according to Developing Modern Higher Education Careers Services - aka The Harris Report. Although not be a burning topic of conversation amongst students, its recommendations should ensure that the help you get with finding work after university is as good as it can be.
fields.body:
Is your careers service doing enough for you? Not according to Developing Modern Higher Education Careers Services - aka The Harris Report. Although not be a burning topic of conversation amongst students, its recommendations should ensure that the help you get with finding work after university is as good as it can be.

At the moment your awareness of options, readiness to cope with the rigours of recruitment and the confidence with which you can communicate your potential has as much to do with which university you're at as with your abilities.

It's this lottery which the recommendations from the report aim to eliminate. According to its author, Sir Martin Harris, students now see themselves as a university's paying customers and expect value for money. They need reassurance that their investment in education will pay off, that greater lifetime earnings will truly be theirs - and soon.

Terry Dray, from the University of Manchester and UMIST Careers Service, is confident that its portfolio of services, events and courses lives up to the expectations of both employers and students. "Companies increasingly look for 'oven ready' graduates - individuals who can slot into an organisation and start contributing from day one. Providing that readiness is what we're about."

Activities that make this a reality include insight courses, mentoring schemes, credit-rated career management modules, application workshops, fairs, vacancy bulletins, job shops and a plentiful supply of work experience. If all that sounds a bit alien, perhaps you haven't discovered the service at your university.

Or, perhaps you have and found it rather lacking. When setting up the review last year, Baronness Blackstone described university careers services as "often a Cinderella service, out on the remote edges of higher education, with little or no presence or influence in the lives of students".

This was certainly the experience of Marie, a postgraduate student at the LSE. "I used the career services only once, thinking they could help me with a general understanding of the work scene. They basically had a library, but you couldn't take most things away. My meeting with the career adviser was of little help. I came away with a leaflet on how to do a CV."

Marie, who now works as a web producer, did her first degree at Ohio State University and was accustomed to more structured support and guidance. "I was immensely frustrated, but not knowing the system here, thought that was the way things were."

It's not the way things have been for Henry Burridge, an engineering student at Bristol. "The hardest part was making the effort to go along and see what they had to offer. With all the things they organise it's made really easy for you. What I've appreciated most is the chance to meet lots of different employers informally. It's helped me decide to go into finance rather than engineering and I've got a job fixed up for when I leave."

If all the recommendations made in the Harris Report are put into place, Henry's experience will be the norm. The timetable is optimistic. Improvements are promised by the start of the academic year 2002/2003 at the latest, by which time all students should have access to a 'common core' of services.

Which is good news for those who are currently missing out. Students on franchised courses have too often accepted the inevitability of not getting the same support as those at the parent institution. Peter Rankin, head of the University of Central Lancashire's careers service, welcomes the emphasis on equal entitlement for all.

"As a university that franchises many courses throughout Lancashire, Merseyside and Cumbria we've long been aware that distance creates problems for students at partner institutions. Although they can use all our facilities at Preston, it's not generally practical for them to do so. We started implementing solutions long before the Harris Report, but there's still some way to go before we could confidently say all our students receive the same level of careers guidance."

Measures they've taken include training advisers in partner colleges and offering guidance by email. Rankin sees web-based resources as one means of providing equal services. "Students at our main campus have had the option of taking credit-rated career management courses for several years but we've not been able to offer those to other students. Now we're working towards an online version which will, in time, be available to everyone associated with us."

Jeff Goodman, a vice president of the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services (AGCAS) and director of the Careers Advisory Service at Bristol believes all university careers services do the best they can to help students move into rewarding work but acknowledges that some are better resourced than others.

"The term Cinderella service was not really accurate for my own university. We feel very much part of the institution, are well used and get positive feedback from students. But for institutions with fewer staff and resources providing what students need can be a real challenge."

Looking at the websites of other services is one way of seeing whether you're getting your fair share of support. Manchester (www.netwise.ac.uk) and Bristol (www.cas.bris.ac.uk) provide open access to most of their information. Terry Dray says Netwise gets a surprising amount of use by students from other universities both in the UK and further afield.

"We're happy to see the site used by anyone who can benefit from it. We do have some extras such as mentoring and work experience schemes because we've bid for additional funds.

"However, the events we organise and the information we provide are the common core that students everywhere should have access to. Students who aren't happy with what their careers service is providing should learn to push a bit harder."

Helping advisers to help you

Check what your service offers. The basics should include help with researching employers and career options, making applications, information on postgraduate study, recruitment fairs for vacation work as well as graduate jobs and vacancy notification services. Many offer much more. Make contact early - most services have events and resources that can help you right from your first year.

fields.headline: Bottom rung
fields.standfirst:
Craig Pinder
Aged 26
Contracts manager, The Woodland Trust
fields.trailText:
Craig Pinder
Aged 26
Contracts manager, The Woodland Trust
fields.body:
Currently upgrading his HND from the National School of Forestry into a BSc, Craig Pinder started his career working as part of a tree surgery team. "The physical work seemed to suit me and my passion for the industry has grown from there."

After his HND he applied to several forestry companies and was recruited by the Woodland Trust.

"I worked for the first nine months as a woodland surveyor, mapping a number of the Trust's woodlands across central and southern England. I applied for a contract manager's post in Leicestershire and the National Forest which I have now been in for almost two years, managing over 30 woodlands, preparing contracts, applying for and monitoring woodland grant schemes."

He also deals with inquiries from the public and works with the Forestry Commission and other environmental organisations and volunteer groups. "The job is very much hands-on with new challenges every day." He is currently writing a management plan to restore ancient woodland.

His ambition? "To progress as far as I can within the Woodland Trust and then gain wider experience working for other forestry companies in the UK and overseas."

For more details visit the website www.woodland-trust.org.uk

fields.headline: Top rung
fields.standfirst:
Mike Townsend
Aged 43
Chief executive, The Woodland Trust
fields.trailText:
Mike Townsend
Aged 43
Chief executive, The Woodland Trust
fields.body:
After leaving school at 16 Mike Townsend worked at a tree nursery and farms then, aged 22, went to Kenya with VSO for three years on a forestry and horticultural project. This was followed by a degree in forestry at the University College of North Wales - he got a first.

He worked in the private sector and for himself before joining the Woodland Trust six years ago as head of woodland management. He became operations director and was made chief executive three years ago.

"I have never really thought of it as a career. I have always been motivated by environmental issues and taken the opportunities as they present themselves."

His day-to-day role involves developing long term plans, monitoring performance, developing policy and representing the Trust externally with government, civil servants and sponsoring organisations.

What's the buzz? "The enthusiasm and boundless optimism of the people I work with, saving woods through our campaigning and planting new woods for the future."

He looks for common sense, flexibility and open mindedness in graduates. "Relevant practical experience helps too."

fields.headline: Country heir
fields.trailText: Name: Annabel Armstrong
fields.body:
Name: Annabel Armstrong

Status: Chartered rural surveyor with Strutt and Parker

Past: Degree in rural land management at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester. Joined Strutt and Parker as a trainee chartered surveyor in its Lewes office. Six months after obtaining professional qualification, moved to offices in rural Leicestershire where she became an associate of the firm.

Present: "I work for a variety of clients on farms and rural estates in the midlands and the south east. One day I can be talking to a farmer, the next a duke or duchess. My work includes negotiating and administering agricultural and business tenancies."

Future: "I'm committed to this profession and I hope to become a partner with Strutt and Parker."

Strengths: "Being a woman in a male-dominated profession is a bonus. People tell me things they wouldn't tell a man."

Weaknesses: "Time management: it's hard to prioritise my work load."

Wisdom: "Be a well rounded character by striking a balance between work and your outside interests."

References:www.struttandparker.com, www.rics.org

webTitle: Mike Rapaport: He's no Vanilla Ice

fields.headline: Here's the Rap
fields.standfirst:
Mike Rapaport plays a white television executive
obsessed with black culture in Spike Lee's
Bamboozled, but in real life he's no Vanilla Ice
fields.trailText: Mike Rapaport plays a white television executive obsessed with black culture in Spike Lee's Bamboozled, but in real life he's no Vanilla Ice
fields.body:
He calls himself Mike Rap. But Michael Rapaport is one white boy who's earned the right to represent like that. At 30, the New York actor has proven himself a persuasive portrayer of many kinds of everymen, from hoods to honkies to the sweet, stupid lunks, but Rapaport has made an extra effort to appear in films that address America's ever-evolving racial conflicts in all of their snarled complexity. Spike Lee's Bamboozled is the latest example. Rapaport plays Dunwitty, the head of a struggling television network who thinks that he's blacker than his token African-American writer. When Dunwitty browbeats the Ivy League-educated creative, played by Damon Wayans, into dreaming up a saleable urban comedy, the angry writer comes back with a 21st-century minstrel show that he hopes will be so intolerable it will get him kicked out of his contract - but which, due to Dunwitty's densely enthusiastic backing, becomes a huge hit.

Some think that Spike doesn't like white people. Apparently, you beg to differ.

He whipped me a couple of times, beat me. No, he's cool. I don't know where that impression came from. Maybe the people who say that get offended by things they see in his films.

Worried that black people who see this are not going to like you for playing such an insensitive wannabe?

No. I loved the fact that the character was so uncensored, and that he thought he had his finger on the pulse of black culture. I never was concerned with offending the other actors or the crew. When I did Higher Learning about five years ago, it was the same thing; I kept asking John Singleton if it was too offensive. But Spike wrote this part and he knew what he wanted me to do it.

We just saw you in another movie about racism, Men Of Honor. Why are you attracted to this subject?

It has a lot to do with the way I grew up and the friends that I had. I have a lot of views and experience with different kinds of people. I'm very comfortable talking about it, and I'm really proud of the fact that I've done racially charged movies.

Tell us more about your upbringing.

When I grew up, mostly, all of my friends were black, so it's not unfamiliar territory. I'm from Manhattan, I went to school in Brooklyn and was the only white kid in my high school and I didn't think twice about it, it was never uncomfortable at all. My father ran a radio station that was actually the first station in the country to play disco.

I hope Dunwitty wasn't based on him.

No. He's based on a record executive I've met a few times, and a couple of film directors that I know.

Who might they be?

I can't say. [laughs] But you've interviewed them, for sure. They're like, "I've got a black girlfriend, I've got a picture of Muhammad Ali on my wall and I know wassup."

Is that just affectation or an indication that pop culture colour-lines are increasingly blurring?

I think, because of the integration of hip-hop music into white culture so much these days, there are people walking around using the language and behaving like that. And it's good, in one sense, that kids are all listening to the same kind of music. But it's bad in the sense that everybody, black and white, is taking on some of the negative, stereotypical ways from that stuff.
